HEADLINE: Two Towns Use Different Tactics to Fight Beach Erosion

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEA BRIGHT, N.J., Oct. 8

 BODY:
As two of the metropolitan area's most eroded oceanfront communities, this splinter of a coastal town and the town of Westhampton Beach, L.I., have much in common. But they could hardly be further apart when it comes to staving off the sea.
Sea Bright, at the northern tip of the Jersey Shore, is an eager partner in an Army Corps of Engineers' project to build a 200-foot-wide protective beach -- roughly equivalent to 18 million truckloads of sand -- as part of the most expensive beach restoration in the nation's history. 
 But at Westhampton Beach, a far more modest restoration plan has been bogged down for years by bickering between New York State and the engineer corps as well as a homeowners' lawsuit blaming government for the loss of homes to the sea.
The difference reflects the persistent debates in all coastal areas about the cost of staving off shorefront erosion, the wisdom of using public money for a project that largely benefits private homeowners, and the ecological soundness of trying to fight back the ocean.
In both places, there are critics who say the new beaches are a waste of Federal and state tax money.
"This is shoreline pork," said D. W. Bennett, executive director of the American Littoral Society, a conservation group based on Sandy Hook, N.J., just north of Sea Bright. "You pump sand and then it goes away and then you pump it again." Maybe, he said, it's time to "let the ocean go where it may."
Proponents of the beaches argue that the work will save property and attract recreation and tourist dollars.
Bernard Moore, head of the engineering division in New Jersey's Bureau of Coastal Engineering and Flood Control, defends the plans to rebuild the beach and replenish it over 50 years at a cost of $440 million.
"There's plenty of people saying we're throwing our money away" and ought to stop development on beachfront areas, he said. "But I say everything you have has to be maintained."
New Jersey has tried to control erosion and preserve its beaches at a cost of $82 million in beachfront preservation bonds and taxpayer dollars since 1977. Most of the money has gone into the southern half of New Jersey's 127-mile shoreline, where tourists spend most of their money.
 
Two-Thirds Federal Money
 The Federal Government is required to pay 65 percent of the $200 million cost of the new beach and the $240 million projected for replenishment over 50 years. Silvio Calisi, the Corps' project manager for the beach, says that higher interest rates and inflation could drive those costs up to as much as $776 million over the half century.
New Jersey and the coastal towns getting the beach are to split the remaining costs on a 75-25 basis. The state has only $5 million available now to pay its $47 million share of construction costs and $63.2 million share of replenishment costs over 50 years.
Supporters of the project hope to finance the new beach by using $15 million a year from tax revenues on real estate sales. The Senate has approved a bill creating such a fund; action in the Assembly is pending.
The project's benefit-to-cost ratio -- the measure of dollars gained to dollars spent -- is $1.80 to $1, said Mr. Calisi, the Corps' project manager.
The Sea Bright project is expected to bring in $36.3 million in benefits in return for $20 million in expenses, Mr. Calisi said. The benefits he cited include $17.2 million in reduced storm damage, $8 million in improved land values, $9 million in increased tourist spending and $1.7 million in beach-maintenance savings in adjacent Sandy Hook.
The beaches at Sandy Hook, in the Gateway National Recreation Area, will be broadened by sands that erode from Sea Bright and drift north.
After facing the threat of being swamped for years, Sea Bright officials and most of the town's 1,700 residents are eager for the new beach, whatever the cost in state and Federal tax dollars.
Before the Federal Government agrees to the work, however, beachfront owners have to grant easements for the public to use the new beach.
All but one of the scores of property owners in Sea Bright and the neighboring towns have signed or agreed to sign the necessary easements, officials said. The holdout is Eugene A. Mulheren, the owner of the Chapel Beach Club, founded in 1864. He said the public would be welcome, as it has always been, between the water and the average high water mark on the club's beachfront, but no closer.
Mr. Mulheren's resistance is delaying the opening of bids for the Sea Bright project.
"I don't care to have new sand," Mr. Mulheren said. "We have exactly the same beach as 100 years ago because the Army Corps has never touched the property. Everything the Army Corps has down on the shore has not worked."
In Westhampton Beach, a controversy over public access is just one issue in a tangled situation.
The homeowners there do not have unanimous support. Some critics, like Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, have argued futilely for a public buyout of residents on the island's severely eroded western end.
A decade ago, Westhampton Beach owners sued the engineer corps, New York State and Suffolk County in Federal court, arguing that improper construction of a field of groins, fingers of stone built into the ocean, in the late 1960's produced erosion that led to the destruction of scores of homes and threatens others.
Until 1990, the Corps wanted to spend $160 million over 50 years to build and replenish a new five-mile beach. New York's Department of State criticized that plan as too expensive and of little public benefit. After three years of bickering, the state and the Corps agreed to construct a $45 million, 1.5-mile beach, shorten the two westernmost groins and build new ones.
William R. Brown, a spokesman for the State Department, said, however, that the plan could not go ahead until the lawsuit, including the issue of public access to the new beach, was resolved.
Gary Vegliante, president of the Barrier Beach Preservation Association, a homeowners group that brought the suit, said the homeowners were willing to let people use the 130-foot width of beach closest to the ocean, but not to come further inland. He said the state and the Army Corps were blocking a solution.
"We're willing to give away our property for free," he said. "But they," meaning government officials, "don't want that because of a perceived thought this is a rich man's project and we should be allowed to fall into the ocean."

HEADLINE: Trade Pact With Mexico Expected to Have Mixed Impact on Employers

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In his 60 years as a garment maker in the New York region, Ralph Shomer has seen his share of competition from companies that have fled in search of cheaper labor.
First came the flight of garment manufacturers to the South, and then to Asia. Now, Mr. Shomer said angrily, comes the last straw: the proposed North American Free Trade Agreement, which he and many others say provides new incentives for manufacturers to move to Mexico. 
 "I may be dumb, but I don't understand how people making coats in Mexico are going to help me," said Mr. Shomer, whose Young American Clothing Company employs 52 people in Newark. "This treaty with Mexico will be the end," he said, adding that the company will close by year's end if the agreement is approved.
But James D. Robinson 3d, the president of American Express, sees the agreement differently, as do most on Wall Street. "It's pro-growth," he said.
How business people feel about the pact between the United States, Canada and Mexico depends, not surprisingly, on what business they are in. There is enthusiasm, for example, among financial service companies and the large manufacturers that have developed export markets.
But executives and economists agree that its overall impact on the New York region would be to accelerate a long established, perhaps irreversible, loss of manufacturers, particularly smaller ones.
 
Concern Over Job Losses
 A New York State Senate commission warned in a report that the state's garment industry, with 88,000 production jobs, could be "virtually wiped out" if the pact is enacted.
"If you look at this state's entire economy, the results will be a wash or better," said Vincent Tese, president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation and chief economic adviser to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. "But there will be a loss of manufacturing jobs."
There is little doubt that the biggest advantages will flow to the financial services industries. And since New York City has the largest concentration of these industries, it stands to gain more than the rest of the region.
"The treaty is an unambiguous plus for the city," said Mitchell Moss, an urban planning and economic analyst at New York University. "For the region as a whole, things are not as clear."
Analysts on Wall Street said that American Express, Eastman Kodak and other major corporations based in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut would benefit from the agreement for a host of reasons: financial service companies would no longer be barred from owning Mexican subsidiaries; the biggest manufacturing companies could begin joint ventures with their Mexican counterparts, and a large part of the banking commissions and other financial charges that result from business development in Mexico can be expected to flow to Wall Street.
Enactment of the trade agreement awaits action by Congress and the legislatures of Mexico and Canada. Last week, President Bush traveled to San Antonio for the ceremonial signing of the pact, which he called a breakthrough in international cooperation. Bill Clinton, his Democratic opponent, has given the proposed agreement lukewarm endorsement.
Whatever the economic fallout of the agreement, it may have less impact in the New York region than in Texas, California and other states that are closer to Mexico.
But in some ways, the New York region has already emerged as a laboratory for liberalized trade barriers because of the 1988 United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement, which eliminated many of the same restrictions across the Canadian border that would be carved away in the new agreement.
The impact has been clearest, and most beneficial, for New York State. The Buffalo area alone has attracted more than 80 Canadian companies, many of them small manufacturers drawn by American wage rates that are more than 10 percent lower than those in Canada.
As in the proposed pact with Mexico, the Canadian agreement reduced or eliminated tariffs that discouraged exporters from shipping goods to Canada. Analysts said the agreement was the chief reason for a 75 percent jump in exports from New York State to Canada between 1989 and last year.
"We need new markets to make new sales to support new jobs," said Kay R. Whitmore, the chairman of Eastman Kodak, based in Rochester. "If we get the business, we'll create the jobs."
 
Hope for New Jobs
 In a statement issued by Mr. Whitmore and Mr. Robinson under the aegis of the Business Roundtable, an organization of chief executives, they estimated that the group's 200 member companies "alone could account for tens of thousands of new jobs, stimulated by the North American Free Trade Agreement."
In Fairfield County, Conn., home to the headquarters of 19 Fortune 500 companies, analysts say that the GTE Corporation, the Olin Corporation and others should benefit.
"We make it a policy not to comment on these things before they are enacted, but it is safe to say we believe in free trade," said Thomas Abbott, a spokesman for the Xerox Corporation, based in Stamford, which has 500 employees in its Connecticut headquarters and 14,000 workers in and around Rochester.
In New Jersey, where Johnson & Johnson, Merck and Company, Bristol-Myers Squibb and other major pharmaceutical companies maintain large laboratories and plants, analysts say the treaty is being welcomed not only because it might lead to increased Mexican sales, but because of its provisions that would strengthen the protection of United States patents and "intellectual property."
"A strong majority of business people in New Jersey are in favor," said Alex Elwood, an analyst for the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, a business group based in Trenton. "High-tech and bio-tech companies have a lot to gain."
 
A Loss of Manufacturers
 But the commission appointed by the New York State Senate to study the agreement concluded in a report to Congress in August that it is "highly unlikely" that companies will benefit from the accord to the same extent that many benefited from the Canadian agreement. By including Mexico in a vastly enlarged inter-American trading zone, the commission warned that low wage rates in Mexico would take too many jobs away from both its northern neighbors.
Even without the Free Trade Agreement, the New York region has lost a succession of manufacturers to Mexico. Most of the losses have come from the same area that has benefited most from the 1989 Canadian agreement -- Buffalo and other western New York cities.
The list of lost manufacturers includes Trico Products, which left Buffalo, eliminating 1,700 jobs, Sherwood Medical Instruments, which eliminated 420 jobs in Sherburne, and Smith Corona, based in Cortland, which has announced it will move 885 jobs to Mexico. In all, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. estimates that New York has lost 813,000 jobs to Mexico since 1970.
 
Pinning Hopes on the Pact
 The attraction of low-wage rates is clear: plants in a free-trade district established by the Mexican government in 1965 along the border of Texas pay their workers an average of less than 59 cents an hour, according to the state Senate commission's report.
Still, not all manufacturers in the region -- even in western New York -- are opposed to the trade agreement. Among its supporters are Corning Inc., based in Corning, a diversified maker of glassware, fiber optics and the glass screens for television picture tubes.
"We consider it a plus, but how big a plus remains to be seen," said Tim Regan, a Corning vice president. He said the company's employment in the Corning area, where it has 6,000 workers, "will increase."
Provisions of the Free Trade Agreement would apply far differently to manufacturers and service companies. American manufacturers setting up shop in Mexico would benefit from an immediate reduction, and eventual elimination, of tariffs and export quotas on the products they ship to the United States or Canada.
The benefits for service companies would be broader. Many, including insurance companies, banks and brokerage firms, are now barred from establishing wholly owned subsidiaries in Mexico and limited in their investments to owning small minority holdings in Mexican companies.
 
Praise for the Agreement
 The proposed agreement would fall far short of making Mexico a free-trade zone for the financial services industry, in most cases imposing sharp limits on the share of the Mexican market American companies can ultimately claim. But it would allow wholly owned subsidiaries of United States companies to operate in Mexico, for the first time allowing banks, brokerages and insurance companies to open branches and other outlets.
"We congratulate our negotiators," said M. R. Greenberg, chairman of the American International Group, a major insurance company based in Manhattan that has for more than 20 years owned a minority interest in Seguros Interamericana, S.A., an insurer based in Mexico City.
Although the company has not disclosed whether it plans to acquire more of Seguros Interamericana, it said it was ready to pursue new investments in Mexico aggressively if the trade pact is enacted.
Still, it is clear that the Free Trade Agreement will take a toll on workers in the New York region and among companies that may already be on a road to extinction.
 
For Workers, Many Worries
 Mr. Shomer's garment company in Newark is an extreme example, but it is not alone. Many economists say that highly specialized factories close to the design centers of Manhattan will always prosper. But others say that the entire garment industry in the region is in jeopardy, and Mr. Shomer agrees.
His company's 52 workers are all Portuguese-speaking immigrants who live in Newark's Ironbound district. They earn an average of $8 an hour sewing topcoats for Manhattan designers who require unusually quick delivery. Its business has only supported a six-month work schedule during each of the last three years.
Now, he says, the threat of any of his business being shifted to competitors in Mexico is all but certain to spell the company's demise.
"My biggest worry is what these people will do," Mr. Shomer said the other day as he walked down his garment sewing assembly line.
Maria Lopez, the plant supervisor, said virtually all of her fellow workers had come from small towns and farms of Portugal, and had few skills to offer in the American job market besides sewing.
"If this plant closes, there is nothing for us," Ms. Lopez said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Amdahl Will Lay Off 9% of Its Work Force

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The Amdahl Corporation, the troubled mainframe computer maker, said today that it would lay off 900 workers, or about 9 percent of its work force, next month.
Company officials said that they had recently seen a significant drop in capital spending by major customers such as airlines and banks and that a strong backlog for its top-of-the-line machines had now disappeared. 
 Last month Amdahl's president and chief executive officer, Joseph Zemke, said the company was likely to register a loss when it reports its earnings for the third quarter on Oct. 30.
 
 
'Largely the Economy'
 Of the 900 workers that Amdahl will lay off, 600 will be from the company's Northern California operations. The computer maker has headquarters in Sunnyvale, Calif., and approximately 5,700 of its 9,700 employees work there.
"It's largely the economy," Bill Stewart, a spokesman for Amdahl, said. "I don't think we're being hurt by the downsizing trend. Obviously there are applications that should be moved off the mainframe, but frequently that just creates more demand for large computers."
Analysts said that Amdahl was suffering in part from the significant head start that I.B.M. got in the market for the newest generation of mainframe computers. Amdahl is also at a disadvantage because of a shift in the way mainframes are being marketed, Robert Djurdjevic, an industry analyst who is president of Annex Research, a Phoenix consulting firm, said. Increasingly the big machines are sold as packages of hardware, software, peripherals and service, and the International Business Machines Corporation has a significant advantage in offering attractive packages.
Mr. Djurdjevic said that Amdahl was having particular trouble selling in the United States market. "In I.B.M.'s case the mainframe business is doing well, particularly in U.S., where Amdahl is having trouble," he said.
 
Severance Benefits
 The company said its laid-off workers' severance package would include at least 12 weeks of pay and benefits, as well as assistance in finding new jobs.
The company, which said last month that it expected its quarterly loss to be between $11 million and $22 million, said today that it would take an additional one-time charge of $15 million to $20 million against third-quarter earnings. The computer maker had sales of $1.7 billion last year.
In November 1989 the company laid off 5 percent of its work force, or about 400 workers.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 37.83 in Light Holiday Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rebounded yesterday in trading that was light because of the Columbus Day holiday. The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 64 points last week, rose 37.83 points to close at 3,174.41.
Stocks rose briskly at the opening and held their gains for most of the session. Analysts said stocks were due for a rebound because the Dow average has fallen 146 points since Sept. 21. 
 Larry Wachtel, market analyst for Prudential Securities, said the early buying began in the Chicago futures markets, where investors picked up bargains after Friday's 39-point fall in the Dow. That buying spilled over onto Wall Street.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by nearly 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume totaled 126.7 million shares, down from 178.9 million Friday.
Some analysts said the market rebounded on the hope of lower interest rates. The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, told reporters on Saturday that the central bank would not be swayed by election-year politics on cutting interest rates to spur the economy. But he nevertheless seemed to hold out hope for lower rates.
Tom Gallagher, head trader at Oppenheimer & Company, said, "There is some feeling that there might be a unified rate cut this week" by several countries.
Officials of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, are scheduled to meet later in the week, and Mr. Greenspan is scheduled to visit Japan this week as well.
The market's reaction to Sunday night's debate among President Bush, Bill Clinton and Ross Perot was difficult to assess.
"I really can't link it to the debate," Mr. Wachtel said of the market's gain. Some dealers had been concerned that if Mr. Bush performed poorly, it would hurt stocks.
Jack Solomon, market strategist for Bear, Stearns & Company, said: however, "The debate was a success. Why? Because nobody lost."
General Motors gained 1 5/8, to 30 3/4, in active trading. The auto maker reached agreement with the United Automobile Workers union late Friday to avert a strike at a plant in Indiana.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index gained 2.17, to 224.28, and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.13, to 365.98.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Europe Fail To Settle Trade Issues

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Trade negotiators from the United States and the European Community were unable to reach an agreement today after two days of talks aimed at settling festering disputes that have blocked progress on a broader worldwide trade pact.
The two sides said that they had made progress, however, and held out some hope that a deal was still possible. They said that meetings between their technical staffs would continue, and that Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, would meet again on Saturday in Toronto with Frans Andriessen, the European Community's External Affairs Commissioner. 
 But for the session here to break off without a deal was a clear setback to both sides' hopes of avoiding a trade war and of breaking the logjam that has blocked a liberalized global trade pact under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
 
French Pressure
 Neither the United States nor the European Community divulged any details of the talks, which centered on agricultural subsidies. But Mr. Andriessen and Ray MacSharry, the European Community's Agriculture Commissioner, were under intense pressure from France not to make any concessions that would result in a reduction of subsidies to French farmers, who are a potent political force.
The lack of an agreement also set back the hopes of the Bush Administration that it would be able to bring home before the election a free-trade deal that could eventually stimulate the economy.
The United States and Europe have been arguing for several years about the allowable level of subsidized farm exports, as well as about other issues -- including access to each other's telecommunications markets. The United States has threatened to impose $1 billion in punitive tariffs on certain European exports to the United States if Europe does not agree either to reduce government payments to growers of oilseeds or to compensate the United States for sales lost because of the subsidies.
 
 
Spur for Trade
 If the two sides cannot settle their dispute, or if the United States imposes the threatened tariffs, there would be almost no chance of completing a new and more liberal GATT agreement, which economists said could spur an additional $200 billion of world trade each year.
The failure to forge an agreement in the talks here will increase tensions at the European Community's one-day summit meeting Friday. Germany and Britain had been leading the push to reach a deal with the United States, saying that flagging European economies need the economic stimulus a trade agreement would bring. But France's Socialist Party Government, which faces an election next year and cannot afford to alienate farmers, has been adamantly opposed and has made clear that it would block any deal.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Up Overseas

BYLINE: By the Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday in overseas trading. The United States market was closed for Columbus Day.
The quoted price in London of the Treasury's main 30-year bond gained 2/32 percentage point, or 63 cents per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield was 7.51 percent, down from 7.52 percent late Friday. 
 Government securities are traded on foreign financial markets, but there is little interest when United States market participants are away.
Long-term bond prices gained on light volume after a dismal week that saw the 30-year bond fall more than $20 because of dimmer prospects for lower interest rates.
The Federal Reserve did not lower rates last week to stimulate the economy -- which would have pushed up bond prices -- despite further weak economic data, particularly an Oct. 2 report showing poor employment.
Later this week, the market is expected to receive data on September inflation and retail sales.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities in London, short-term maturities were unchanged to up 3/32 point and intermediate maturities rose between 3/32 point and 5/32 point, according to the Telerate Inc. financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
Prices of short-term Treasury bills were not quoted because of the holiday.

HEADLINE: Frank Mercurio, 80, an Enforcer Of Labor Laws for Four Decades

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Frank B. Mercurio, a longtime enforcer of labor laws, died on Saturday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old.
The cause of his death was not immediately available. 
 Mr. Mercurio, a foe of the sweatshops in New York and New Jersey, was a native of Utica, N.Y. He moved to Florida after his retirement about 10 years ago.
Mr. Mercurio attended Northwestern University, majoring in political science and administration, and graduated from the chemical-warfare school at Amherst University. During World War II, he worked in the National Mobilization Strike Force of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
After the war, Mr. Mercurio was for 10 years an assistant Industrial Commissioner in the New York State Department of Labor. There he administered the enforcement of laws dealing with minimum wages, unemployment insurance, child labor and health and safety standards.
In 1955 he began a nearly 30-year career with the United States Department of Labor when he was named a deputy director of its Region II in Manhattan, covering New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Three years later, he became the director of the region's Wage and Hour and Public Contracts Divisions. His jurisdiction included more than five million working people in more than 200,000 companies.
His Chinatown Strike Force fought rampant abuse of workers in the garment industry. "The problem of the undocumented alien is one of the greatest magnitude," he said in 1979 as the regional administrator of Employee Standards. "There exist in the Greater New York area thousands of illegal aliens who are being exploited by unscrupulous employers, especially in the service industries."
Mr. Mercurio was a Special Assistant in the Office of the Secretary of Labor and a consultant to private industry on white-collar crime when he retired a few years later.
Mr. Mercurio is survived by his wife of 57 years, the former Mabel Gillespie, and several nieces and nephews.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
U.S. Aid Package for Russia Lifts Pork and Wheat Prices

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 12

 BODY:
A new United States agricultural aid package for Russia helped lift wheat and pork prices today, although trading volume on United States commodity markets was slowed by the Columbus Day holiday.
Traders said the Russians were expected to act quickly to buy United States food products in response to the Bush Administration's long-awaited offer of $775 million in credit guarantees and food assistance, which was announced on Friday. 
 Wheat futures responded by opening strongly and then moving steadily higher at the Chicago Board of Trade. December wheat soared 10.5 cents, to $3.52 a bushel.
The bullishness was also enhanced by the trade agreement the United States reached with China over the weekend. The pact gave a sense of relief to traders worried that China would go elsewhere to buy wheat.
 
Corn and Beans Up
 Corn and soybean prices rose modestly, as farmers remained busy harvesting bumper crops and were not selling their grain. December corn gained 1.5 cents, to $2.09 3/4 a bushel, and November soybeans added 4 cents, to $5.36 3/4 a bushel. December oats gained 2.75 cents, to $1.36 1/4.
 February pork belly futures at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange rose the daily limit of 2 cents a pound, to 41.3 cents a pound, reacting to the $50 million pork allocation in the Russian aid package. Although analysts had predicted for several months that meat would be included in the aid package, the actual announcement gave the market a psychological boost.
October hog futures added 1 cent, rising to 43.575 cents a pound.
 Higher cash cattle prices and the strong pork futures market lifted cattle prices as well. December live cattle rose 0.8 cent, to 74.475 cents a pound, and November feeder cattle gained 0.7 cent, to 83.3 cents a pound.
 
Oil Prices Decline
 Oil prices, which rose last week, fell slightly with news of higher OPEC production last month and Iraq's release over the weekend of a captured American munitions expert.
The Middle East Economic Survey estimated that OPEC pumped nearly 25 million barrels of oil a day in September, about a half-million barrels more than in the previous month.
November crude oil fell 7 cents to $22.30 a barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange. November unleaded gasoline dropped 0.53 cent to 60.43 cents a gallon, and November heating oil declined 0.41 cent to 65.48 cents a gallon.
November natural gas tumbled 6.3 cents, to $2.23 for a million British thermal units.

HEADLINE: Gaining From Turmoil in Currencies

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The recent turmoil in the world's currency markets produced its share of casualties: central bankers who spent billions in a futile effort to prop up Europe's weaker currencies, government leaders who have seen the drive to European unification stalled and small American investors in global money-market funds who got burned when currencies like the pound fell sharply.
Yet the last few weeks have been made to order for trading profits at the big commercial banks. Their trading floors are the hub of the $1 trillion-a-day currency market, and the banks thrive on the volatility that central bankers and government leaders fear. 
 "From a business point of view, I'm delighted by it," said James Borden, a senior vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank, who heads the bank's foreign exchange operations in New York. "It's great for people like me."
The currency market combines elements of economics and gambling, and in their role as middlemen the banks benefit from both. "If you're the bookie, you like a lot of action," said Lowell Bryan, a banking expert at McKinsey & Company.
The banks' currency trading revenues for the third quarter have not yet been reported, and trading profits are notoriously tricky to predict. But banking analysts and consultants estimate that the recent gyrations in the market may increase pretax income from foreign exchange by 50 percent to 100 percent in the third quarter above the quarterly average last year for the six big American banks that deal in the currency market: Citicorp, Chemical, Bankers Trust, BankAmerica, J. P. Morgan and Chase Manhattan. That adds up to an extra $250 million to $500 million for the six banks combined.
"I think you'll find that all the big dealer banks did well during this period," said Donald Layton, a senior executive vice president of Chemical Bank.
The foreign exchange market has grown by 50 percent in the last three years, with an estimated $1 trillion worth of all manner of currencies traded every day. The business has mushroomed thanks to the liberalization of financial markets, the growing links among national economies and modern computer and telecommunications technology. Corporations, pension funds, mutual funds and speculators have all become larger and more sophisticated players in the currency market.
In recent years, income from foreign exchange has become increasingly important to the major banks. Citicorp, the largest, had foreign exchange income of $709 million last year, up from $453 million in 1987. Yet like the currency markets themselves, foreign exchange income can rise and fall unpredictably.
"It's a very good business for the banks, but it makes their income statements more volatile," said James McDermott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a banking analysis firm.
Banks do make money by making speculative bets with their own funds on whether the dollar, say, will rise or fall against the German mark. Such bets can be made for minutes or days, depending on the trader's strategy. But banks typically generate the bulk of their income as market-making dealers, profiting from the difference between the price at which they buy and the higher price at which they sell a given currency.
The difference, expressed in hundredths of a percent, is known as the "spread." At times last month, for example, the spread on the British pound as it fell rapidly under furious selling pressure from investors and speculators was 10 times wider than normal, or 50 points instead of the usual 5 points.
The widening of the spreads occurs partly because of the greater risk to the dealer when prices are gyrating, but also because buying or selling immediately is more important to customers than hunting around for the best prices. The wider spreads and the surge in trading volume explain the extraordinary opportunity the banks have enjoyed.
 
How Stability Can Evaporate
 The last few weeks have been a striking example of how quickly stability can evaporate in today's currency markets. Politicians and commentators have placed much of the blame for turmoil on speculators, portrayed as latter-day marauders roving from country to country, despoiling currencies. These speculators would include bank dealers trading for their own account and professional speculators.
The biggest speculators tend to be a secretive breed, disclosing little about their activities. But they were among the highest-paid individuals on Wall Street last year, Financial World magazine reported, with George Soros of Soros Fund Management leading the list at $117 million, Paul Tudor Jones 2d of Tudor Investment at $60 million, Bruce Kovner of the Caxton Corporation also at $60 million, John Henry of John W. Henry & Company at $50 million and Lewis M. Bacon of Moore Capital Management at $20 million.
Most of their funds trade not only in currencies, but also in stocks and commodities.
The growth of speculative currency funds has been considerable. For example, a group of 29 such funds tracked by Ferrell Capital Management, a Greenwich, Conn., investment manager, have increased their assets to more than $5 billion, from $1.4 billion in 1990.
But funds are not big daily traders, said Mark Fitzsimmons, a senior vice president at Millburn Ridgefield Corporation, a good-sized currency fund with about $650 million invested by wealthy individuals, private companies and Wall Street firms. "Volatility doesn't really help us," he said. "We look for a trend."
 
Tracking Trends by Computer
 Millburn uses sophisticated computer models to divine trends of a few weeks or longer, tracking things like trading patterns and country-to-country lags between interest rate shifts and currency movements. From April to September, betting against the dollar, Millburn gained 28 percent. But after Finland let the markka float on Sept. 8, effectively devaluing it, and the European currency markets began roiling, Millburn closed out its positions. Suddenly, its computer models showed confusion rather than a discernible trend. In September, Mr. Fitzsimmons said, Millburn did not turn a profit.
While professional speculators sold embattled currencies, bank traders say the real pressure came from a more respectable class of players -- mutual funds, corporations and pension funds. "It all started with the fund managers," said David Puth, a managing director and chief of currency trading for Chemical Bank in New York. "It's the capital movements led by international investors that really move currencies today."
The growth in short-term global income funds exemplifies the shift abroad in the mutual fund industry. The short-term global funds claim assets of more than $20 billion, up from less than $500 million in 1989, with offerings from Alliance, Fidelity, Merrill Lynch and dozens of others. The appeal of these funds to investors has been higher yields than money-market funds in the United States.
Fund managers attained those higher yields thanks to the European exchange rate mechanism, which allowed Europe's currencies to fluctuate only within narrow ranges. For example, the currency risk of holding a high-yielding British bond was limited, in theory, because the value of the pound could not drop lower than its floor in the European monetary system.
 
Safety Net Disappeared
 But when the mechanism cracked last month, "the theory of a government-guaranteed safety net was shot to hell," said John Rekenthaler, an analyst at Morningstar Inc., a mutual-fund research group.
As Germany refused to lower its interest rates appreciably and Britain, in the grip of a deep recession, decided it could not raise its rates any further to defend the pound, the funds sold pounds and other weak European currencies.
"These huge pools of money got spooked, and they trampled the European monetary system," said Francoise Soares-Kemp, a senior manager at Credit Suisse Bank.
As investors pulled their money out, the assets of the short-term global income funds declined to $21 billion by Sept. 30, from more than $23 billion at the start of September, said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif.
The wave of sell orders streamed into bank trading rooms. Recognizing the direction of the market, bank traders bet some of their own money, adding still more pressure on the embattled currencies. Europe's central banks spent heavily to try to prop up the 11-nation monetary system, but it gave way with Britain and Italy dropping out.
The major central banks are estimated to have lost as much as $6 billion in recent weeks, spending their reserves to buy weaker currencies, which then fell further in value.
On Chase Manhattan's 35th-floor trading room, near Wall Street, a team of 50 salespeople and traders ply the currency markets. Though a bank may make a profit on perhaps only 35 percent of its transactions, its floor is there to deal. "As major market makers, we want to be a part of as much of the flow as possible," explained Mr. Borden, the head of the operation, at 52 years old a graying veteran of the currency markets. "That's what gives us a sense and smell of the market."
 
Big Rewards for Dealers
 Four months ago, for example, Chase dedicated two salespeople to handle trade-related currency deals for regional banks, which now generate turnover of nearly $2 billion a month and give Chase another perspective on the market.
The dealers are young, mostly in their 20's and 30's, often have advanced degrees in mathematics, business or computer science and represent a multitude of nations including Japan, Sweden, Spain, Pakistan and Korea. With salaries and bonuses, bank traders can make from $100,000 to $500,000, but stars who take big positions and win have made a few million dollars a year.
Chase has a reputation for taking smaller risks than high rollers like Bankers Trust, but also gaining a steadier pattern of income from foreign exchange. Mr. Borden explains that his traders are given monthly income targets, ranging from $50,000 to $500,000, depending on their experience and the currencies they trade. "What you want is consistency from the team," he said.
But in the volatile markets of late, big gains were easier to come by. "If you have the right people in the right place at the right time, you can hit home runs time after time," Mr. Borden said. "That was what happened recently."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The trading rooms of big commercial banks are the hub of a $1 trillion-a-day currency market. At Chase Manhattan Bank, James Borden, a senior vice president, stands by Arnold Niemanis, a currency trader. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times) (pg. D18)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading; Gold Posts a Steep Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against other leading currencies in thin trading amid renewed speculation that interest rates still might ease.
Gold prices fell sharply. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fell $5.20 an ounce to settle at $345.20. The Republic National Bank of New York reported a late bid price for gold of $345.85, off $4.45. 
 John Lipsky of Salomon Brothers said the only news of interest to the currency market was that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had said during the weekend that the Fed would not let political considerations stop it from cutting interest rates again if needed to stimulate the sluggish economy.
A lower interest rate makes the dollar less attractive to foreign investors.
But given the "small magnitude of the move, it would be heroic to read too much into" yesterday's dollar trading, Mr. Lipsky said.
Lucille Palermo, vice president of Van Eck Associates, said the drop in gold prices seemed to be based on a large amount of gold entering the market from one source. She said there were unconfirmed reports that the source was Middle Eastern.
The dollar fell to 120.85 Japanese yen in New York trading, compared with 121.80 late Friday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 121.02 yen from 121.55 at Friday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 121.05 yen.
In New York trading, the British pound rose to $1.7080, from $1.6945 late Friday. In London, the pound rose to $1.7045, from $1.6855 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4685 German marks, down from 1.4865; 1.3080 Swiss francs, down from 1.3155; 4.9875 French francs, down from 5.0460; 1,291 Italian lire, down from 1,304, and 1.2445 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2487.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Dealing in Myths On Malpractice

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
BOTH President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton want to change the system under which patients can bring medical malpractice lawsuits against doctors and hospitals. But the Congressional Budget Office and other experts who have studied the numbers say such proposals are based on sketchy and often misleading beliefs about the costs involved.
Mr. Bush brought up the issue again in the debate Sunday night. He challenged Mr. Clinton to take on "the medical malpractice people," who Mr. Bush said are responsible for "these frivolous trial-lawyer lawsuits that are running the cost of medical care up by $25 to $50 billion." 
 There was no further discussion of malpractice lawsuits at the debate. But last month, Mr. Clinton said in an article in The New England Journal of Medicine that there should be changes to "take disputes out of the court system and effectively and fairly address the concerns of patients and physicians." Administrative agencies decide malpractice awards in a number of states now.
Mr. Bush favors an American Medical Association proposal for a $250,000 limit on pain-and-suffering awards; Mr. Clinton has not endorsed a ceiling. California has a $250,000 cap, which expires at year-end unless the Legislature renews it.
The American Medical Association estimates that $5.6 billion a year is spent on insurance premiums to protect doctors from lawsuits and that another $15 billion of annual health costs can be attributed to the defensive tactics that doctors use, like ordering redundant tests.
Kirk B. Johnson, the American Medical Association general counsel, said a cap on pain-and-suffering awards would remove "the windfall" for lawyers who represent injured patients. And the California Medical Association said the limit there had saved doctors and hospitals more than $1.3 billion a year in insurance premiums.
But the Congressional Budget Office said, in a new report to the House Ways and Means Committee, that the evidence is "that the larger estimates are too high and that restructuring malpractice liability alone would not generate large savings in U.S. health-care costs."
Malpractice premiums account for less than 1 percent of the estimated $817 billion in national health spending this year, the budget office said. It added that "much of the care that is commonly dubbed 'defensive medicine' would probably still be provided" if the lawsuits were eliminated.
"Physicians have always sought to provide patients with the best possible medical care at the lowest risks and would continue to do so even without the threat of lawsuits," the report said.
Michael J. Saks, a University of Iowa law professor and social psychologist, said, "Much of what we think we know about the behavior of the tort litigation system is untrue, unknown or unknowable." Tort is a legal term for a wrongful act that can be the basis of a civil lawsuit.
"This is a system that is there to serve society" by compensating innocent victims for injury and deterring wrongful behavior, Professor Saks said.
A. Russell Localio, a researcher at Pennsylvania State University's medical school at Hersey, said capping awards could make it difficult for people who are severely injured to find lawyers to handle expensive malpractice lawsuits.
He also said that one large study, by Harvard University researchers in New York State, concluded that only "a very small percentage of people who are injured as a result of negligence go on to file a malpractice claim."
Several studies have concluded that sympathetic juries often overcompensate people who have relatively minor medically induced injuries, while people with the most serious problems often do not get enough. Huge awards are often reduced by higher courts, and a plaintiff typically gets one-third of the reduced amount, after expenses.
Randall R. Bovbjerg, a senior research associate with the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research center in Washington, said, "The system works better than the doctors think." And, he added: "Health care is a lot better than the lawyers think. The typical lawyer only sees terrible cases."
"The biggest problem is that most cases aren't in the system," Mr. Bovbjerg said. "It is inherently slow, costly and, in any given case, uncertain." He favors setting benchmarks for juries to consult -- calibrating awards for pain and suffering to the severity of injury and the victim's age. Economic damages, covering future loss of income, could be standardized by providing an annuity or trust guaranteed for life, he said.
As for insurers, Barry Johnson, a spokesman for the St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company, said his company had recently raised malpractice premiums an average of 10 percent following a slight rise in claims. That came after claims had dropped sharply from 17.9 per 100 physicians in 1985 to a low of 12.5 in 1989;, they have since risen somewhat, reaching 13.9 last year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Campbell Seeks the Rest Of Australian Cookie Maker

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Campbell Soup Company made a $590 million bid yesterday for the two-thirds of a large Australian cookie maker that it does not already own.
The bid for Arnotts Ltd., described as "the Nabisco of Australia," is the latest in a series of offers for medium-sized food companies overseas made by American manufacturers, facing slow growth at home. 
 David Johnson, chief executive of Campbell's, said Arnotts would serve as a key foothold for expanding into Asia. "Asia is a key growth area for Campbell," he said. The company plans to start selling its familiar red and white cans of soup in China next week.
Campbell's has owned 33 percent of the shares in Arnotts since 1985 and is the company's biggest shareholder. The Arnotts board will meet to consider the offer on Wednesday. The board has hired an investment banking firm to study the fairness of the offer, which requires approval from a majority of shareholders. Analysts said it was possible that Campbell would be forced to sweeten its bid or that a competing offer could emerge. "I would not be surprised if Campbell has to increase its bid, said David J. Adelman, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. The current bid represents a 10 percent premium over the Arnotts closing stock price on Friday. "That is a full and fair price," said a Campbell spokesman, Kevin G. Lowery. He said another bidder was unlikely, in light of Campbell's large existing stake. Campbell's stock closed down 75 cents yesterday at $41.125 in trading on New York Stock Exchange.
Last week, H. J. Heinz announced that it had acquired Wattie's Ltd., a New Zealand food company, for $300 million. "Everybody is seeing Australia as the springboard to get into Asia," said John M. McMillin, an analyst with Prudential Securities.
Last month, the Philip Morris Companies said it planned to buy the Norwegian candy maker Freia Marabou A.S. for $1.5 billion.
"Companies are looking overseas," Mr. Adelman said. "That is where the growth is. They are going where you have an increase in population and an increase in per capita consumption."
 
Contrast to Lackluster Increases
 In sharp contrast to the lackluster increases that United States food companies are posting on their home turf, Campbell's said that sales of its Swanson broths were growing by 30 percent a year in Hong Kong.
In acquiring Wattie's, a maker of baked beans, dog food and frozen foods, Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, chairman of Heinz, said New Zealand would be an important manufacturing base for Asia, a market that Mr. O'Reilly said had "substantial growth potential."
"The United States food industry is going through a very challenging period," said Frank Blod, a consultant with New England Consulting in Westport, Conn. The purchase of food, "for the first time in many years, is being influenced by macro-economic factors, such as unemployment."
As a result, stiff consumer resistance to price increases is hurting profits. Yesterday, the Department of Agriculture said that food prices would rise by only 1 percent this year, the smallest increase in 25 years.
Also, Mr. McMillin said that food companies had been slower to expand overseas than concerns like Coca-Cola and the Procter & Gamble Company, in part because food products were less universal than soup or soft drinks. "Synergies are more of a challenge in foods than other industries because of strong regional tastes," Mr. Blod said.
Consumers in other countries eat far less prepared foods than they do in the United States. People bake cakes from scratch and do not use frozen food, for now at least. This creates huge opportunites for American companies to export the more "high tech" food developed in the United States.
Like other recent bidders for overseas concerns, Campbell would be acquiring a company with similar businesses.
If the bid is accepted, Campbell, owner of Pepperidge Farms, will take control of the world's seventh-largest cookie company. 'It makes strategic sense," Mr. McMillin said. "Too often, people buy what they don't know."
Mr. McMillin added "Campbell is trying to change from a conservative North American soup company to a global soup and biscuit company." Campbell was invited by management to invest in Arnotts in 1985, to help fend off a takeover offer from the investor Alan Bond. One of the country's more recognizable brands, Arnotts is the largest cookie and cracker company in Australia, with about 60 percent of the market. The company had sales of $511 million in its most recent fiscal year. Mr. Johnson of Campbell said Arnotts products would be expanded throughout Asia, using Campbell's sales force.
The deal requires the approval of the Australian Government.

Kraft's Bid Backed
 OSLO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Majority owners of Freia Marabou, Scandinavia's largest chocolate company, said today that they would accept a bid for their shares by Kraft General Foods, a unit of Philip Morris.
Kraft said it had received shareholder approval that would give it 57.2 percent of the total share capital. The buyout, which has stirred protests by Norwegians, must be approved by the Government.
In a separate statement, Norsk Hydro, a Norwegian energy, chemicals and metals company, said that it and its pension fund had agreed to Kraft's offer of $77 a share for 44.1 percent of the Freia Marabou stock.
Kraft said Sweden's food and drug group Procordia A.B. had agreed to sell 6.9 percent and Pauling Services Ltd. had accepted the offer for its 3.9 percent. Other minority shareholders that accepted the offer were not named.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Main Topics for Marketers: Economy and the Election

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va.

 BODY:
THE dual concerns of the sputtering economy and the looming election dominated the discussions yesterday here at the 83d Annual Meeting and Business Conference of the Association of National Advertisers.
At one point, the twin topics converged for America's largest marketers when L. Ross Love, the association's 1991-92 chairman, read greetings from President Bush. 
 "While unfavorable economic conditions have made this a difficult time for industries such as yours," President Bush wrote, "I believe that we have many reasons to be optimistic about the future." There was no response from the audience.
One speaker, Stanley C. Gault, chairman and chief executive of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, used a tale about J. Walter Thompson, the agency founder, to comment on the nation's economic woes.
Mr. Thompson, riding the subway, was approached by "a rather seedy- looking man," Mr. Gault said, who was wearing sandwich-board advertising signs. Asked his profession, Thompson replied, "advertising."
"Me, too," the man responded, Mr. Gault said. "And ain't it hell when the wind blows your boards?"
"The economic winds have been howling for several years," Mr. Gault when on, "and they've been taking a heavy toll."
"It is hell when the wind blows," he added, "but it does force us to concentrate on the tried and true sales and marketing principles that will once again contribute significantly to the success of American business in the 90's."
Mr. Gault, who demonstrated extensive sales and marketing skills at General Electric and Rubbermaid before tackling Goodyear's woes, said that detractors "suggested I was a prime candidate for the next commercial for the Maalox moment" when he decided to join the tire company last year.
He described an intensive new advertising program he has been introducing at Goodyear that includes innovative television commercials for the Aquatred tire by J. Walter Thompson Inc. It also includes a subtle strategy of furnishing videotapes to high school driver education classes that contend that "the more advanced the wet-traction design," the better the tires -- which is Aquatred's selling point.
The results are that Goodyear expects to sell nearly one million Aquatred tires by the end of the year, generating almost $100 million in revenues, Mr. Gault said.
The economy even intruded on a panel discussion about ethics in advertising, a subject that the panel reassured the audience several times was not a contradiction in terms. Burt Neuborne, a professor at the New York University School of Law who was the panel moderator, asked, "Can ethics survive bad economic times?"
David E. Collins, president of Schering-Plough Healthcare Products, said: "That's an incomplete view of advertising.
"I view advertising as a long-term investment in the brand, in the company reputation. Any short-term gain one is targeting at the expense of the long term is a misuse of advertising."
There does seem to be more optimism about the economy here than was evident at last year's conference in Phoenix. Yet what impact that might have on advertising spending, which fell 1.5 percent in 1991, is unclear. Many marketing executives have long since stopped listening to the bright forecasts made at pleasant, genteel and remote resorts like the Homestead, the setting for this conference, which are immediately recanted once everyone returns to the reality of their workplaces.
Discussion of Sunday's Presidential debate continued throughout yesterday. More than once, heated words were exchanged between a large number of stalwart Republicans supporting President Bush and a vocal minority favoring Ross Perot. As for Gov. Bill Clinton, one attendee said the only way he would be reconciled to the Democrat's victory would be by the simultaneous election of a Republican Congress.
At a reception Sunday evening, the usual schmoozing almost came to a halt as attendees stopped to watch the debate on three television sets provided by the reception's sponsors: the ABC, CBS and NBC networks.
While providing the sets seemed self-defeating for the networks, it was far more successful than the reception they sponsored last year, during the World Series. With no television sets in the room then, attendees put in perfunctory appearances and wandered off to watch the game in bars or in their rooms.
Turning to the association's own elections, the board, as expected, elected Harry E. Davis as 1992-93 chairman, succeeding Mr. Love. Mr. Davis is director of communications in the external affairs department at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in Wilmington, Del. Richard A. Garvey, vice president of marketing at Lego Systems Inc., was, as expected, elected to succeed Mr. Davis as vice chairman.

HEADLINE: CPC's Profits Increase 55.5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., Oct. 12

 BODY:
CPC International Inc. today reported a 55.5 percent increase in net income for the third quarter, citing gains in North America, Latin America and Asia.
The gains offset an 18 percent increase in financing costs and weaker performances in the European operations of CPC, the nation's third-largest food company and a leading refiner of corn. 
 CPC's products include Hellman's and Best Foods mayonnaise, Mazola corn oil and margarine and Skippy peanut butter.
CPC's net income rose to $117.4 million, from $75.5 million in the similar 1991 period. Earnings per share increased from 48 cents to 76 cents. The results of the 1991 quarter included a loss of $31.5 million from discontinued operations.
Sales in the latest quarterwere $1.6 billion, up 6.7 percent from $1.49 billion a year ago.
Shares of CPC gained 37.5 cents today, closing at $45.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
C. R. Shoemate, CPC's chairman and chief executive, said the company was pleased with continued gains in North America, Latin America and Asia. He said an economic downturn was hurting business in several European countries.
Earnings rose 13 percent for CPC's consumer foods business. Profits increased 5.4 percent in the corn refinery operations, where corn is converted into edible and nonedible products.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Narrows Plan for Improving Taxi Service

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Retreating from a plan to fundamentally reorganize New York City's taxi industry, Mayor David N. Dinkins has prepared a more modest proposal to improve cab service outside the Manhattan business districts.
The Mayor is scheduled to announce today that he will seek approval for the creation of new hack stands in northern Manhattan and the boroughs outside Manhattan, along with a new class of "community cabs," livery taxis that would be allowed to wait for riders at the hack stands, an adviser to the Mayor said yesterday. 
 Mr. Dinkins proposed a much more ambitious effort last January to improve service outside Wall Street and mid-Manhattan. That plan would have permitted radio cabs in northern Manhattan and the boroughs outside Manhattan to cruise for riders and to pick them up on the streets. Only the city's medallion, or yellow, taxis are now allowed to pick up street hails.
 
Politically Powerful
 But Mr. Dinkins's proposal -- like more than a half-dozen plans devised during the 1980's by his predecessor, Edward I. Koch -- was blocked by several of the politically powerful interests in the city's fragmented, complex taxi industry. The industry, particularly the owners of yellow taxi medallions, have long wielded considerable clout in the City Council, whose approval is needed for changes in the system. Many segments of the industry thought the Mayor's initial plan would have been too expensive because it also called for new medallions for livery cabs and the elimination of the free market in yellow medallions.
Mr. Koch used to say that two words summed up why his proposals were blocked in the City Council: "Stanley Friedman," who was then the Bronx Democratic leader.
Mr. Dinkins's latest proposal is supported in principle by representatives of the industry's various sectors, including yellow medallion cabs and livery or radio-car services, who sat on a committee he created to sift through his initial plan, the mayoral adviser said.
Industry leaders could not be reached yesterday for comment on the Mayor's latest plan. Telephone calls to more than a half-dozen taxi industry representatives went unanswered on the Columbus Day holiday.
Several elements of the new plan would require approval by the City Council, which historically has resisted changes in the current system.
Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, said the Council's leaders were also concerned about better service in the boroughs outside Manhattan and would schedule hearings to consider the latest proposal.
Discussions with the Mayor's advisory committee led to the latest plan. Industry leaders on the committee acknowledged that yellow cabs work primarily in Manhattan and the airports, and cruise infrequently in other parts of New York, the adviser said. The owners of yellow medallions, which have been frozen at 11,787 medallions since 1937, fear that if the city were to permit radio cars and other livery services to pick up street hails outside Manhattan, drivers of those cars would be emboldened to pick up people hailing cabs below 96th Street in Manhattan -- infringing on the yellow cabs' business.
Taxi industry leaders also agreed that New Yorkers outside lower and central Manhattan, who generally must telephone a radio-car service for a taxi, could be better served, the adviser said. From that came the idea for new hack stands, which would be set up by the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission at subway stops, shopping districts, hospitals and busy intersections scattered throughout all five boroughs.
It could not be learned yesterday exactly how many hack stands would be created, or even whether the number and placement of the stands has yet been determined.
 
'Community Cabs'
 The broad outlines of the revised proposal were clear, however. A new class of livery cars, called "community cabs," would be created. They would be permitted to pick up riders at the new hack stands, and they would continue to be allowed to accept passengers through radio calls.
The new community cabs would have roof lights, similar in concept to those that yellow cabs have but sufficiently distinct in design so that the two kinds of taxis could be differentiated. The new cabs would carry the livery company's name on the outside, along with fare schedules. The cab could use meters or could charge on a zone basis.
The city would also put a limit on the number of radio-car bases -- the storefronts from which livery taxis and the proposed community cabs would work. The cap, whose number has not yet been decided, could be changed by the City Council if lawmakers thought it necessary.
The number of radio cabs and community cabs that each base operated would not be regulated by the city and would be decided by the base owners, based on economic need.
The mayoral adviser argued that the new proposal would accomplish the same goal as Mr. Dinkins's original plan: improving service to the neighborhoods outside central and lower Manhattan where much of the Mayor's core political constituency resides.
Even if the livery taxis had been granted the right to pick up street hails, the adviser contended, many would not have cruised because it would not have been economically feasible in the less densely populated parts of Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island.
 
A Major Complaint
 The Mayor's latest plan also tries to address the major complaint from the taxi industry, which has long argued that the city does not do enough to keep unlicensed, or gypsy, cabs from stealing their business.
Owners of yellow cabs contend that both the gypsy cabs and the licensed livery cars often defy the law by picking up street hails in Manhattan and elsewhere. Owners of radio-car services outside central Manhattan often complain that gypsy drivers operate with impunity around subway stations, hospitals and busy intersections in boroughs outside Manhattan, essentially stealing passengers from licensed livery operators.
Mr. Dinkins's latest proposal calls for a threefold increase in enforcement by the Taxi and Limousine Commission. An unspecified number of new inspectors would be hired, with the cost to be covered by raising fees the city charges taxi owners.
The plan also calls for the city to create as many as 413 additional yellow medallions, to be sold at market rates, currently about $140,000 per medallion. The revenues raised by the sale of the new medallions would be used solely to help finance the stepped up enforcement against illegal operators.
Adding to the number of yellow medallions may require an environmental review, the adviser to the Mayor said. It would also require approval from the Council, which has previously shown great reluctance to expand the size of the yellow-cab segment of the industry.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "TRANSPORTATION: Comparing Cab Proposals"
 
DINKINS'S ORIGINAL PROPOSAL
Allow licensed livery cabs to pick up people on streets in northern Manhattan and the boroughs outside Manhattan and wait for passengers at designated hack stands.
In return, the city would sharply step up enforcement against illegal gypsies who steal business from the licensed car services outside central Manhattan and against the gypsy- and livery-cab drivers who pick up street hails in Manhattan.
To help yellow-cab owners who fear a drop in the value of their medallions, the city would eliminate the private, free market in yellow-cab medallions and redeem them at a price close to current market value.
To finance the redemptions and license livery cabs for street pickups, the city would issue two new classes of medallions to livery cabs and to the so-called "black cars," the fancier radio cabs that operate primarily in Manhattan.
 
NEW PROPOSAL
Livery cabs would not be allowed to pick up passengers on the street. But a new class of taxis called "community cabs," would be allowed to wait for riders at designated hack stands. It is not clear how many stands would be created.
The city would put a cap on the number of radio-car bases -- the storefronts from which livery taxis and the proposed community cabs would work. The number of radio cabs and community cabs would not be regulated.
The city would triple the amount of enforcement against illegal operators. An unspecified number of new inspectors would be hired, to be financed by raising the fees that the city charges taxi owners.
The city would create as many as 413 new yellow medallions, to be sold at market rates. The revenues would help finance the stepped-up enforcement against illegal operators. (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. SHOE TO SHUT OHIO PLANT AND CUT JOBS ELSEWHERE

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The United States Shoe Corporation said yesterday that it would close its Ripley, Ohio, plant and reduce employment at a related Harrison, Ohio, site, putting about 300 people out of work. The moves will actually affect about 400 jobs, but managers said they hoped to place about 100 of those people elsewhere in the company. 
 The moves are part of United States Shoe's plan to cut costs and get rid of excess manufacturing capacity, Robert Burton, a company spokesman, said. The Cincinnati-based company is a specialty retailer of women's apparel, footwear, eyeglasses and contact lenses. Its operations include Lens Crafters and Casual Corner stores.

HEADLINE: Slaking California's Thirst

 BODY:
Congress approved new water policies last week to help California defeat drought and start restoring rivers and marshes severely damaged after having been pumped nearly dry for decades, to keep irrigation ditches full.
The package was written by a rare coalition of Eastern and Western members of Congress, led by two Democrats, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Representative George Miller of California. It prevailed despite objections from California's Governor, Pete Wilson, who called it the opening shot in "a second century of California water wars." 
 Governor Wilson and others, including Vice President Quayle, are trying to promote a Presidential veto. President Bush would be wise to ignore them and sign the bill. California desperately needs its provisions; it is edging into what could be a seventh year of drought and the third year of its worst economic slump since the Depression.
There are two important features in the bill that benefit California. One says that water developed with Federal funds is a commodity no different from food and fuel that can be bought and sold within reasonable limits to the highest bidder. Federal water now cannot be resold and, with few exceptions, can be used only for irrigation.
The other provision guarantees that enough water will be left in streams and wildlife habitat to allow restoration of fisheries and other natural areas that have deteriorated alarmingly.
The bill has formidable support in California among businessmen, fishermen, managers of urban water agencies and nearly all environmentalists and economists. It is opposed only by farmers, who use 80 percent of the state's water to produce at best 10 percent of its wealth.
The strongest argument for Mr. Bush's signature is that this is a win-win bill. It makes sense environmentally and economically. Much California land is polluted or used for crops that make money only because of Federal subsidies. The water used on such land alone would meet the needs of cities for 50 years -- time enough to discover new ways to avoid waste and stretch supplies.

HEADLINE: Unfair Shots at a Fair Tax

 BODY:
There was one point in Sunday night's debate when Ross Perot, otherwise sailing along smoothly, was buffeted by both President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton. Mr. Perot was asked about his proposal to raise gasoline taxes 50 cents a gallon over five years. He defended it, then took a double broadside.
Governor Clinton said the tax would stifle an already stagnant economy. Mr. Bush complained that it would unfairly hit certain families harder than others. These two criticisms seemed to confirm Mr. Perot's earlier fear that a responsible deficit-reduction plan would be subjected to unreasonable pot shots -- a fear that helped drive him from the Presidential race in July. 
 But his idea merits serious debate. Neither of his opponents' objections counts for much. Higher gas taxes need not threaten the economy. He proposes to delay their passage, and could, if required, phase them in slowly.
Nor are they necessarily unfair if the Perot plan is examined in its totality. Gas taxes do hit middle- and low-income families. But Mr. Perot also proposes tax hikes on the well-to-do: targeted higher income and payroll taxes and caps on deductions for mortgage interest and health-insurance premiums. Besides, research shows that the gas tax hits families up and down the income scale pretty much the same.
The debate sidestepped other essential facts. Gasoline taxes not only raise money for deficit reduction and infrastructure but also help the environment by cutting demand for fossil fuels. Families and regions that rely heavily on automobiles absorb a shock, but some discomfort is unavoidable if the United States is ever to get a grip on energy use.
Moreover, the regional impact can be mitigated. Mr. Perot suggests using some of the revenues to create jobs in heavily affected regions.
The proposal is far from perfect. Many economists wouldn't increase the gasoline tax as much or would tax oil instead. And Mr. Perot's overall program to achieve a zero deficit within five years -- of which the gasoline tax is a part -- is too much, too soon.
But those errors are remediable. Lost in the back and forth is that Mr. Perot is the only candidate to admit that Americans will have to pay steeply higher taxes if there is to be enough money in the public till to preserve essential services and investments. And he backs this honest prescription with forthright, if not ideal, options.
Presidential debates provide not only a forum for judging candidates but for illuminating important and complex issues. On the gas tax question, that opportunity was squandered .

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Mr. Bush Steps Aside

BYLINE: BY A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Months ago, even before the embarrassing Republican Convention, a number of important Republican politicians, thinkers and money-raisers began saying that President Bush should step aside and let some other Republican get a crack at the White House -- somebody who could win.
Usually they said it privately. But occasionally the idea was allowed to surface -- as when William Bennett wondered out loud whether Mr. Bush really wanted the job. You can't get much more blunt with a first-term President of your own party without handing him his hat on TV. 
 On Sunday night the President did step aside -- not from the race, but from the full responsibility of the Presidency. He said that if he won the election he would turn to another man, James Baker, and say here, you handle the economy for me and the country.
That statement, during the first debate, was the most startling political judgment made by a President about himself since Lyndon Johnson announced that he would not run for another term.
Politically, the Vietnam War and the way Johnson handled it had knocked him out and he knew it. Politically, the economy and the way Mr. Bush has handled it has just about knocked him out. He knows it.
But having missed his chance to step aside with dignity, he is grabbing at one last gimmick -- to turn the economy over to Mr. Baker as "coordinator" of the whole mess.
Perhaps if he had done it with candor he might have gained more respect -- if not votes. Instead of saying look, I did the best I could but I need help to get this thing off my back, he tried to be casual about it.
Asked specifically how he would get more people into good jobs immediately, he said he had already announced a plan about that, news that should send the unemployed singing into the streets.
Then, oh-by-the-way, he sashayed into his great idea: to make Mr. Baker the "coordinator of all the domestic side of the house." That means "all the economic side, all the training side, and bring this program together."
That's our house the man is talking about -- America. And here all along, the silly old American people were thinking that the biggest job they were paying a President to do was to deal with our house.
Mr. Baker never was elected to a blessed thing before Mr. Bush offered to share the Presidency with him. The plain import for voters is if you don't trust me, how about Jim and me?
Even that crafty Perot is back asking for election as President, not anointment.
If Mr. Baker is such a genius at economy handling, we did not catch much of a glimpse of it all those years he was Secretary of the Treasury and White House chief of staff.
In those jobs, did he know anything at all that might have led him to smell the savings and loan scandal that was about to befoul the country? Not one thing? Did he ever alert Presidents Reagan or Bush? Or anybody?
"Coordinate"? Mr. Baker would be the boss of the Secretary of the Treasury, the budget director, the White House economists. Mr. Bush cleared the way by informing the eminences holding those jobs that they are gone.
Joint President Baker would decide on their successors. But he could be expected to consult Mr. Bush, who would continue to be known simply as President.
And all dealing with Congress, all cabinet budgets, all decisions on military or foreign expenditure, would have to be approved by Acting President Baker. Without those powers, coordination is clerical work. Mr. Baker is nobody's clerk.
Here too Co-President Baker would likely consult Mr. Bush. Constitutionally, Mr. Bush could override the Partner President. Of course, if he did that he would be admitting that the idea of Economic President Baker is an act of desperation by a man who wants to hold onto a job he cannot handle.
All this must be quite a blow to the current official Vice President. How come Mr. Quayle was not handed this plainly intended boost to the 1996 Presidential nomination?
Bit of an insult, that. And one thing we can be sure of, Deputy President Baker would do his best to coordinate the hell out of Mr. Quayle.
So now we know. If we pull down the Republican lever, we will be voting not for Bush-Quayle but Bush-Baker, to be polite.
Now there's an October surprise for you.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
