HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Be Quantitative but Creative, Ad Experts Tell Marketers

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va.

 BODY:
FOR decades, marketers have ruefully joked that they know half their advertising spending is wasted, but they don't know which half.
As the 83d annual meeting and business conference of the Association of National Advertisers ended here, the nation's biggest marketers were warned yesterday that the figure in the aphorism ought to be doubled unless they redouble efforts to improve the effectiveness and creativity of their sales messages. 
 "I've been embarrassed by the lack of standards by which advertisers measure their agencies," said Solomon Dutka, chief executive of Audits and Surveys Inc. in New York, a market research company. "This amazes me," he added. "I come from the physical sciences, yet you have no marketing laboratories where you can test things."
As for the additional costs of such research, he continued, "Cheap is expensive to you people."
Mr. Dutka advocated "a common and clear understanding by clients and their agencies of advertising goals," such as increasing awareness among consumers of a coffee brand's special blend of beans or improving attitudes about a car's trade-in value. Those goals would be identified and agreed upon, he said, with the aim of achieving them over a specific period.
Theodore Levitt, a professor at the Harvard Business School, asserted that "for most people, advertising is just Muzak, background music." Ads are received grudgingly and skeptically, thereby creating "a big, receptive market for advertising bashing," he said.
"Its own success," he added, "begets agitation for more restrictive and punitive legislation -- and legislators."
Yet Dr. Levitt, who eschewed discussing his noted theories about global advertising to address the issue of advertising's efficacy, told a sparsely attended morning session that the process was often impeded by its very nature.
"Advertising overpromises by design," he said. "Only in the want ads, where amateurs operate, does it not." And, he added, advertising is purposely intrusive and, "like art, is representational, not the real thing."
Since it is widely acknowledged that "advertising is a price we pay for choice" in the American economic system, he continued, "it's not a requirement of our profession that we be fond of everything we do."
"Only an auctioneer," he said, "can be enthusiastic about all forms of art."
Carrying the banner for creativity was Philip B. Dusenberry, chairman and chief executive of BBDO New York and vice chairman of BBDO Worldwide. He urged marketers to quit being "members of Advertising Anonymous" and demand from their agencies what he called "famous advertising."
"If your advertising is not famous," Mr. Dusenberry said, "you're just not getting your money's worth." Such creativity can make advertising "so recognizable, so noticeable, so different from anybody else's," Mr. Dusenberry said, "it gives you exactly the edge you've been longing for."
Since no discussion of advertising creativity would be complete without show and tell, Mr. Dusenberry played a videotape of commercials that, he said, "stick to the roof of your mind." Many of them were even produced by other agencies like Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis (Lee jeans), Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York (Little Caesars pizza) and Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. (Nike athletic shoes).
BBDO, of course, had its fair share, including Pizza Hut's celebration of a Little Leaguer who manages to make the game-winning catch in right field and Du Pont's paean to a man who plays basketball with artificial legs.
Mr. Dusenberry acknowledged that "the potential of fame always brings you the possibility of failure."
"Remember Joe Isuzu?" he asked, referring to the campaign that was more successful at creating a career for the actor who played the lying salesman than in moving metal for Isuzu.
Nevertheless, Mr. Dusenberry said: "Advertising that's famous gives a product a greater chance of success. If the ads make the audience snooze, you lose."
Even so, can the pursuit of creativity be reconciled with the need for discipline to achieve predetermined goals? Mr. Dutka quoted Sir Joshua Reynolds's disdain for the "false and vulgar opinion that rules are the fetters of genius." And though this Reynolds is unrelated to R. J. Reynolds, the audience seemed to have appreciated the point.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Software Helps Patients Make Crucial Choices

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Told by his doctor that he had an enlarged prostate gland, Richard A. Dronen, a 59-year-old retailing executive in Minneapolis, thought he should have surgery. His doctor, however, disagreed and sent Mr. Dronen to try a high-tech method of learning more about his prospects.
Mr. Dronen educated himself about the noncancerous condition by using an interactive videodisk system that let him enter his own personal health data. Using the disk, he could weigh the risks of unpleasant complications after surgery versus trying drug therapy versus simply practicing "watchful waiting" with the condition, which hampers urination and can cause dangerous infections. 
 The video software also included on-screen appearances by two retired Dartmouth medical professors -- one who had opted for the surgery, one who had not -- describing the pluses and minuses of the options.
Like most prostate patients who have viewed the videodisks, Mr. Dronen saw the benefits of watchful waiting. The program "helped me understand the whole system better," he said.
As doctors and hospitals plunge into the computer age, a growing number of patients like Mr. Dronen are viewing videodisks and using touch-activated screens to learn more about their illnesses.
Interactive video, in which the viewer uses a computer mouse or touches the screen to answer questions and choose specific information, is already widely employed in teaching programs for doctors and nurses. Now the technology is beginning to be used to enhance the physician-patient relationship.
 
An Expanding Field
 Seeking to create a market in what had been an experimental field, an American unit of the Sony Corporation is about to start selling the prostate program and patient-information packages on breast cancer, hypertension and low-back pain. Two other companies have similar but less ambitious projects under way.
Researchers say such software programs, promoting shared decision making, hold the promise of improving quality of care and reducing costs. Many patients with prostate problems have postponed surgery after considering the alternatives, some finding that the condition remains manageable or even seems to disappear on its own. Users of other programs said they gained a better appreciation of the health consequences of disobeying expert advice about diet and exercise.
 
Could Reduce Lawsuits
 For doctors and insurers, there is a side benefit: Patients who choose surgery will be on record as having considered the risks of complications, thus reducing the likelihood of medical malpractice lawsuits.
What is more, published research has indicated that some patients who participate in this type of choice have better health results than those who get the same drugs and treatments but do not participate. "Involvement itself is good for your health," said Jonathan Brown, a researcher at the Kaiser Foundation Hospitals' Center for Health Research in Portland, Ore. "The placebo factor is really there."
Five videodisk programs, which have been under development at universities and health maintenance organizations, will be marketed across the country later this month by Sony Medical Systems, a Sony Corporation unit in Montvale, N.J.
H.M.O's and large group-medical practices can buy or lease the equipment and subscribe to one or more software programs, including periodic updates on the latest drugs and treatments. Sony said it would initially turn over 80 percent of the software fees to the nonprofit Foundation for Informed Medical Decision Making in Hanover, N.H., which produced the programs. The foundation plans to develop several dozen more programs and keep them current.
Dr. Richard Foster, medical director of a 40,000-member H.M.O. operated by South Carolina Blue Cross and Blue Shield, is buying the equipment. Patients and doctors who tried it in Columbia and Florence, S.C., found that it "enhanced the physician-patient relationship," he said.
South Carolina Blue Cross is one of nine Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations that are at various stages of studying or installing the programs. They are also being tested by Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston; Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H., and the Veterans Administration, as well as several regional Kaiser Permanente H.M.O.'s, the Minnesota Group Care Consortium in Minneapolis and the Group Health Cooperative of Puget Sound in Seattle.
Sony Medical executives said they hoped to sell 500 systems in the first six months and eventually generate up to $20 million a year for the foundation. Developing a program costs $250,000 to $500,000, plus about $100,000 for an update, foundation officials said. The research is done at universities including Dartmouth, Duke and the University of Washington.
 
Variety of Equipment
 The hardware sells for about $8,000. It includes a Sony laser-disk player and touch-screen terminal; a Dell personal computer with a Sony video board; a keyboard for entering the patient's history and a Hewlett-Packard printer. The software is priced at $975 a year for the first program, including updates, with discounts for additional programs.
Other similar products are heading for the market. Computer scientists at Louisiana State University in Shreveport, for example, are developing an "informed consent" video for patients facing gastrointestinal surgery. It will be marketed by the Health Sciences Consortium in Chapel Hill, N.C., early next year.
United States Pharmacopaea, a privately held company based in Rockville, Md., which publishes standards for drug compounds, is working on an interactive video program, using a Philips CD-ROM compact disk system, to explain drugs and diets to diabetes patients. It will cost about $3,000 with the disk.
Dr. Erol Uke, head of urology at the Park Nicollet Medical Center in Minneapolis, was the doctor who advised Mr. Dronen, the retailing executive, to consult the videodisk. Park Nicollet, which recently joined with the Mayo Clinic and Group Health Inc. of Minneapolis to form a managed-care consortium, has always been reluctant to recommend surgery for patients with Mr. Dronen's condition, known as benign prostate hyperplasia.
Dr. Uke says he shows the video only to "people whom we have to convince that they do not need surgery."
"The patient comes away with a sense of participation," he said. "They want to take more control of their disease."
Helping the patient is the main concern, Dr. Uke said, not the cost savings, which may take years -- if ever -- to become evident. For one thing, he said, electing to postpone surgery may in some cases mean the patient will have the operation when he is older and more likely to experience complications.
The new programs will help physicians collect and compare the results of surgery and other procedures. It is all part of a growing effort to enhance cost effectiveness through research on "medical outcomes."
Among those active in outcomes research is Dr. John Wennberg, a founder and vice chairman of the decision-making foundation in Hanover. He also heads the Center for Evaluative Science at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center.
"I'm trying to create a market," he said, "by making it possible for patients to know the options in an economy that traditionally has been imbalanced in terms of the availability of information."

HEADLINE: Profit Reported by Meredith

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Meredith Corporation, a publishing concern, today reported a profit of $3.4 million, or 22 cents a share, in its first fiscal quarter compared with a $4.5 million loss a year earlier that reflected a one-time charge for an accounting change.
Without last year's $7.3 million charge for adopting a new accounting principle for retirement benefits, profit rose about 25 percent. 
 Revenue in the first quarter rose 4.4 percent, to $177.4 million from $170 million, in part reflecting advertising-page increases at all of Meredith's magazines except Metropolitan Home and Successful Farming.
Jack Rehm, Meredith's chairman, said the other Meredith magazines, especially Better Homes and Gardens, made gains in advertising despite a listless national economy.
Results would have been better except for huge start-up costs of a cable television partnership that is expected to be a drag on earnings in the next two to three fiscal years, he said. Meredith has invested $100 million in the cable partnership, which so far has bought systems in the Minneapolis area and in North Dakota.
Meredith shares lost 50 cents each today, closing at $22 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Outlook Cut For Growth

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has cut its forecast for economic growth for its 24 industrial member countries to 2.1 percent in 1993 from the 3 percent growth rate it forecast in June.
That compares with its forecast for 1992 economic growth in the O.E.C.D. area, as measured by the gross domestic product, of 1.5 percent and last year's eight-tenths of a percent growth. 
 The O.E.C.D. is an economic research agency and advisory body grouping 24 developed industrial nations including the United States, Canada, the European Community countries, Japan and Australia.
The figures, announced by Kumiharu Shigehara, head of the O.E.C.D.'s economics department, at a news conference in Tokyo today, were made available here by the organization's officials.
Mr. Shigehara said the O.E.C.D. also cut its forecast for Japanese economic growth to 2.6 percent next year from the 3.1 percent it forecast in June.
Growth in the United States is now forecast at 1.8 percent this year, rising to 2.4 percent next year, Mr. Shigehara said. That compares with the June forecast of 2.1 percent growth in 1992 and 3.6 percent in 1993.

HEADLINE: Mapping Out Ethnic Foods, Freeway By Freeway

BYLINE: MOLLY O'NEILL

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
LIKE most Angelenos, Linda Burum was used to getting on the freeway and driving past every neighborhood except her own. But seven years ago, she gave up the fast track for smaller streets with meandering turns and traffic lights, streets that frequently lack signs. Her detours resulted in "A Guide to Ethnic Food in Los Angeles," which will be published this week by HarperPerennial.
Ms. Burum, who appears to be as obsessed with arcane foods as she is easily confused by unfamiliar streets, was determined to map her hometown's ethnic frontiers and render its exotic tastes accessible. But would Lewis and Clark have risked so much for a meal? 
 "Move it, lady!" screamed the driver of the tractor-trailer rig behind Ms. Burum's blue Subaru, which was paused, as usual, in the middle of an intersection. But Ms. Burum, 47 years old, who taught home economics before she turned to ethnic cartography, was impervious to the honking horns. She's learned to deal with unsympathetic traffic, desolate neighborhoods and directions issued in unfamiliar dialects.
"Hmmmm," she said. "Oh, dear." She reached to the back seat, where she carries a library of atlases and maps and guide books. "Hmmmm," she said again.
"I thought the Japanese pastry shop was in this mini-mall, but, hmmmm. Maybe not. Well, hmmmm. On the other hand, you really should taste some more soba" -- a reference to the thin buckwheat noodles that she predicts will become as popular as pasta with pesto.
Ms. Burum had proposed a three-day eating binge, concentrating on Japanese, Mexican, Thai and Persian food. She promised that the sampling would deliver "the most authentic ethnic food in the United States." Finding a handful of the city's thousands of obscure food shops and ethnic restaurants is a little like finding some of the dots that, when connected, create a picture of a complicated port of entry -- and a vibrant culinary melting pot.
Los Angeles has its discrete Chinatown, its Koreatown and Japantown. But the 4,070-square-mile sprawl of Los Angeles County, whose central nervous system is its freeways, has bred diaspora after diaspora. For instance, tourists shop and dine in Japantown along San Pedro Street in downtown Los Angeles. But the Japanese and dedicated aficionados of Japanese culture know to head to west Los Angeles, a hub of Japanese life since before World War I, or to Torrance and Gardena, where Japanese settled later. Often well heeled, these later immigrants had the money to buy real estate and to develop giant Japanese malls and superstores.
Likewise, since the late 1950's, it has been a rare mile in Los Angeles that hasn't offered a nacho-and-combo-platter Mexican restaurant. The affordable, Americanized food simultaneously appealed to non-Mexicans and gave the Mexican families who own the restaurants a financial base that allowed them to dine out. After several generations, there are enough affluent Mexicans to support Mexican-owned mini-malls in Huntington Park that are devoted to Mexican products.
In the same fashion, after the Vietnam War, some of the immigrants from Southeast Asia built upscale Thai restaurants in Hollywood featuring dishes that became familiar to Americans, like sate and pad thai. For the patronage of their fellow immigrants, they opened tiny spots in the San Fernando Valley and Lakewood sections, with obscure regional fare, like the Isaan-style cuisine from northeast Thailand. The Los Angeles Thai Chamber of Commerce estimates that there are 350 Thai restaurants in the greater Los Angeles area, more than in any place in the world except Bangkok, Thailand.
More recently, the last decade of political unrest in the Middle East has brought so many Iranian expatriates to Los Angeles that they call the place not Little Teheran, but Teherangeles, said Jeff Beckerman, the city's demographer.
Ms. Burum notes that the food of the ancient Persian court was once the haute cuisine of the medieval Islamic world, but newly arrived Iranians, like the Japanese, Thais and Mexicans who preceded them, did not open grand restaurants. They served simple kebabs, which -- like teriyaki for the Japanese, nachos for the Mexicans and sate for the Thais -- have given them cultural currency and the beginnings of an economic base.
"The kinds of stores and restaurants an ethnic group opens is a thumbnail sketch of where that population is in the assimilation process," Ms. Burum said. "The little patches that sprout up here and there show the numbers of individuals who've immigrated, where they are financially and how long they've been here." When one is greeted by a host with uninflected English and served with European-style cutlery and linens, for instance, it is generally safe to assume that the restaurant is owned by second- or third-generation Americans.
The discrete neighborhoods are an adventurous food lover's dream: because of their isolation, they serve up un-Americanized ethnic cooking. But these far-flung enclaves are also a food lover's nightmare: who can find them?
"That's one of the differences between tenements and track housing," said Ms. Burum, who is fond of calling Los Angeles "Ellis Island, west."
At the same time, the isolation born of dispersion seems to create a more ubiquitous sense of ethnicity in the city. "I've eaten more ethnic food in Los Angeles than I have in any other city," said Eberhard Muller, the former chef of Le Bernardin in New York, who moved to Santa Monica last year and opened the Opus restaurant there. "It's not that there are more ethnic restaurants here. It's just that they are more apparent and more talked about."
This phenomenon may account for the fluid lines between Los Angeles's citadels of chic and their ethnic underpinnings. At Spago, where Thai spring rolls and Cambodian soups are routinely served along with pizzas and risotto, Wolfgang Puck, the owner and chef, credits the city's vivid pluralism with both his inspiration and his appreciative clientele.
"It's a pain when it comes to shopping," he said, "because lemon grass is one place; the best Hawaiian shrimp is a 40-minute drive in the other direction.". But the dispersion means that Angelenos have a panoply of disparate ethnic restaurants in close range of their homes.
Experience has taught Ms. Burum that the emerging ethnic dishes of today are foolproof harbingers of the flavors of haute cuisine to come. She began her odyssey seven years ago, by collaborating on "Cook's Marketplace Los Angeles," a shopping guide published by 101 Productions in 1986. Her new book has more than 500 entries, and she continues to study ethnic newspapers to find what she calls "little patches of ethnicity that sprout up like wild mushrooms after the rain."
In midintersection, she continued to weigh a yakitori-and-noodle shop against a pub with Japanese-style hors d'oeuvres. The honking behind Ms. Burum's car was escalating.
"Oh, dear," she said. "I guess soba is really the thing. Those noodles are going to jump into the mainstream." She headed toward Sanuki No Sato (18206 South Western Avenue, Gardena), a tidy little noodle restaurant nestled in a mini-mall.
A gaggle of Japanese businessmen were delicately plucking long buckwheat noodles from the zaro, the bamboo-latticed serving container, and nimbly flicking them into the dipping sauce. "It's gauche to saturate the noodles," Ms. Burum said in a clear stage whisper. As well as a tireless chronicler, she is an indefatigable teacher.
"It's disrespectful to the chef," she said. "He rolls this pasta by hand." Under a mountain of steamed vegetables, the chilled noodles are deliciously chewy, yet delicate. "Definite crossover dish," Ms. Burum added.
She next suggested dropping into Yoro No Taki, (15462 South Western Avenue, Gardena) a Japanese pub in a nearby mini-mall that offers seven sakes, a variety of yakitori and fried appetizers, and a glimpse of Everyman's Japan in Los Angeles today. "The population is growing, not so much in numbers, but in affluence," she said.
As proof, she drove by the Yaohan Market (21515 Western Avenue, Torrance), several acres of an antiseptically clean Japanese supermarket with everything from prepared foods and Asian produce to more than a dozen types of soy sauce. "Better food shopping here than Tokyo," said Ms. Burum, who when not scouting neighborhoods in Los Angeles is traveling in Asia and Latin America. "But you need a pair of roller skates to get through the place."
Nearly as large, but with a humbler ambiance, was El Gallo Giro (7136 Pacific, Huntington Park), a tile-floored Mexican deli that serves up dozens of Mexican prepared foods -- fresh tortillas, torta rolls with roast pork and chilies, tacquito, empanada, stews, roasts and fresh-squeezed tropical juices. The crowd was made up of families clad in embroidered peasant shirts, long cotton skirts and sandals, as opposed to the dress-for-success singles in Japanese spots.
"See the difference?" whispered Ms. Burum. "Both populations have been in Los Angeles forever, but the Japanese community has money from Japan, while many of the Mexicans keep greeting relatives who come here practically destitute."
She bent into her bowl of tinga, pork braised with chipotle and poblano peppers, priced at $1.50. Across town at the trendy Border Grill, a similar dish was offered as a luncheon special for $12.50. That's the kind of cultural exchange that Ms. Burum loves to hear about.
She was excited, for instance, to show the difference between the food at El Gallo Giro and that at Sierra's (6819 Canoga Avenue, Canoga Park). As if to reassure patrons, the sign on the heavy colonial door of Sierra's reads "Restaurant policy: service, cleanliness, quality of food." For generations, Ms. Burum said, "Angelenos have eaten the Americanized Mexican food here."
She was equally excited by the difference between the trendy sate bar at Talesai, a soaring, whitewashed dining room at 9043 Sunset Boulevard, and that of Renu Nakorn (13041 East Rosecrans Avenue, Norwalk), a hole-in-the-wall that's situated between a barber shop and a gun-and-tackle store in a mini mall.
The first restaurant, where the food lives up to the menu's promise, "the art of Thai cooking," featured inventive sates, a delicious pad Thai and soups with depth and finesse. The hole-in-the-wall featured pungent deep-fried dried beef called neua dad deal with a peppery dipping sauce; stuffed and deep-fried chicken wings; pickled Thai sausage, and minced beef, quickly sauteed and topped with a mound of mint and cilantro.
It is too soon, Ms. Burum said, to see the same contrast in Persian restaurants. Steering through clogged intersections, she passed Shahrezad Flame, at 1442 Westwood Boulevard in West Los Angeles, where tanur lavash (oven-fired flat bread) is baked in a clay oven. She finessed several one-way streets to find Golestan (1398 Westwood Boulevard, West Los Angeles), where the walls are covered with mirrors and mosaics and the pungent stews are served from an all-you-can-eat steam table.
After several wrong turns and the ritual midintersection pause, Ms. Burum screeched into an illegal parking space near Shekarchi (1712 Westwood Boulevard, West Los Angeles). Passers-by stared and oncoming traffic braked, but the premier chronicler and cartographer of Los Angeles's ethnic plenty was unfazed. Her mind was on Shekarchi, where, behind a plate-glass window, a chef prepared magnificent kebabs over a wood-burning fire. The kebabs were served with basmati rice with saffron butter, tart cherries, sweet orange peel and almonds.
"More authentic than Iran," Ms. Burum said in a whisper as she entered the restaurant. "Definitely crossover cuisine. Just wait."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The National Pastime as Big Business

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
Baseball and Billions
A Probing Look Inside the Big Business of Our National Pastime
By Andrew Zimbalist
270 pages. Basic Books. $20.
At Shea Stadium this season, an unrepentant Ebbets Field fan and his young companions helped to increase the gross national profit by making a large investment in inflationary hot dogs, fries, soft drinks and peanuts, not to mention a few dollars for the usher who tickled the dust off the seats. Surprisingly, there was no extra charge for the mustard. Now along comes Andrew Zimbalist, professor of economics at Smith College, with the cheerful international news that treats at the ballpark in Queens are a comparative bargain because, at the Skydome in Toronto, a special hot dog goes for $6. 
 On the eve of the World Series, Mr. Zimbalist's "Baseball and Billions" fuels the debate about the economics of major- and minor-league baseball by following the money and moneymakers -- the owners, players, agents, broadcasters -- and the various sidelines of the game. As a cool designated hitter for the curious reader, he scores with historical lore and unassailable statistics that ought to keep the hot-stove league glowing all winter.
In general, the study tilts against management: "baseball's barons." Mr. Zimbalist quotes Bill Veeck, former owner of the Cleveland Indians, Chicago White Sox and St. Louis Browns, on baseball's loopholes: "Look, we play the 'Star-Spangled Banner' before every game. You want us to pay income taxes too?"
None of the facts and charts in this informative and often amusing book ought to stop a fan from rooting for the home team's player-millionaires. But the author does leave the impression that when it comes to franchise trading, tax breaks, contract negotiations and antitrust exemptions, the national pastime might more accurately be shifted from the sports to the business pages. His point about the bottom-line synergy of baseball and broadcasting seemed to be documented on Sunday when CBS stayed with the extra innings of a playoff game instead of broadcasting the first Presidential debate.
"Ten years ago baseball was looked upon merely as a pastime. Individuals of means and leisure organized clubs for pleasure, and were perfectly satisfied if at the close of the season the nine had won a fair majority of the games and receipts balanced expenditures. . . . Three institutions -- the National League, the reserve rule and the national agreement -- have changed entirely the nature of the game. What was formerly a pastime has now become a business, capital is invested from business motives, and the officers and stockholders of the different clubs include men of social standing and established business capacity."
When was that written?
Guess again. It appeared in Lippincott's Magazine, written by John Montgomery Ward, leader of the new Brotherhood of Professional Baseball Players, in 1886. Ward, both a star pitcher and shortstop for the New York Giants, presented a long list of demands for the brotherhood, including an end to the reserve clause, breaking the annual salary cap of $2,500 for most players, stopping player sales between owners for which the player received nothing, and abolishing such extra duties as collecting tickets and sweeping up the ballpark after the game.
"Baseball and Billions" looks behind the value of franchises, the financial threats against municipalities to keep teams from moving, and the profits that are concealed by accounting legerdemain. It's the player salaries that dominate the headlines, not the turnstile or the media or even the hot-dog profits. The best answer to accusations of player greed was given by Babe Ruth in 1930, when his pay reached $80,000 after he had helped to make millions for the Yankees. When he was told that his annual pay was $5,000 more than President Herbert Hoover's, Ruth replied: "What the hell has Hoover got to do with it? Besides, I had a better year than he did."
Marvin Miller, the former director of the Players' Association who played a major role in driving up player salaries, said in 1965 that players were the most exploited people he knew -- "worse than Cesar Chavez's grape pickers at the time." (On the other hand, grape pickers don't fly first class by contract from job to job.) Balancing pro-player comment, the author cites a remark in 1990 by Charles Bronfman, outgoing owner of the Montreal Expos, that major-league salaries "have lost not only all sense of proportion, but sense of reason."
Mr. Zimbalist doesn't think so, not that he cries for them; he notes that players now have additional negotiated perquisites, everything from employee benefits to licensing income to extra money from baseball cards. But he adds that baseball stars are not in the same league as stars in the entertainment industry. Where Bill Cosby, Sylvester Stallone, Madonna and Michael Jackson make tens of millions of dollars a year, the top baseball players earn far less.
"One learns in introductory microeconomics classes," he writes, "that in each of the above cases, the individual is paid according to the value of what he or she produces, the so-called marginal revenue product." Of course, neither microeconomics nor macroeconomics can explain why when faltering Mets players are traded to other teams, they suddenly come alive.
"Baseball and Billions" advocates greater government regulation of what has become interstate and international commerce: "Congress could legislate rules piecemeal that could be enforced by the watchful eye of a bureau in the Department of Commerce. One such rule might be that the All-Star Game, the playoffs, and the World Series must be available on free television, and that a certain number be played in the afternoon."
Mr. Zimbalist won't be offered the job of baseball commissioner or the presidency of a network for such challenging ideas, but his book is more than fun to read.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:
A Big Splash
Here's how long it took the tribute to Bob Dylan at Madison Square Garden that's scheduled for Friday night, featuring everybody from George Harrison, Eric Clapton and the rock poet himself to members of the group Pearl Jam, to sell out: 70 minutes. That's for 18,200 seats, and each person was allowed to buy only one pair of tickets at a time. The tickets started at $80 for the public and at $150 for industry types. What recession?
"We were pleasantly surprised about the response," said Kevin Wall, the chairman of Radiovision, the company producing the show. "The demographic is the same as has been buying back-catalogue records for years and saving the music industry. It's getting people out of the suburbs into cars to go to a concert in New York, which is hard to do. The demand is much greater than the tickets we had, and I think we could have done five nights. To have George and Dylan and Eric, it's magical. I think when value is put out here in the market place, people will buy, even if we're deep in a recession." 
 Still, $80? Mr. Wall said the concert was costing more than $5 million to produce. There are unions to pay, long rehearsals, the cost of the Garden itself and the cost of housing so many people.
The show is to be taped with both high-definition and regular television cameras. It can be seen on pay-per-view cable service at 8:30 for $19.95; it will also be seen around the world, some places live, some with a delay. The press release says half a billion people will watch it, which seems a bit much.
"We think we've got a magical moment, like 'The Last Waltz' or 'The Concert for Bangladesh,' so we thought we'd do the absolute best," Mr. Wall said. "We're going to shoot this on high definition, which is very expensive. If you can put four high-definition cameras together you're doing great, and we have eight. That right there doubled the production costs for the TV side."
The show was the idea of Mr. Dylan's representatives and Columbia Records. Mr. Dylan is a seminal figure in popular culture, even if he now sings like a wounded dog and is long past his prime. He is, inescapably, still a huge draw and has influenced everyone from the Beatles to a whole host of younger performers. Other acts on the bill include Neil Young, Mary-Chapin Carpenter, Johnny Cash, John Mellencamp, Willie Nelson, Sinead O'Connor, Tom Petty, Rosanne Cash, Lou Reed and Shawn Colvin.
Roger McGuinn, the leader of the Byrds, will also appear, and he owes a good deal of his success to Mr. Dylan. The Byrds' first single, before they signed with Columbia, was Mr. Dylan's "Mr. Tambourine Man."
"It's incalculable, his influence has been so great," Mr. McGuinn said. "If he hadn't existed, there might not have been thinking-man's music. In the mid-60's the music might just have stayed bubble gum, all those concepts of his might have been lost. The Beatles were doing straight pop, and Dylan had a talk with Lennon and after that the Beatles changed, got motivated to do something more interesting, more intellectual. Life without him in music would be the same as life without William Shakespeare."
 
8 Little Splashes
 They Might Be Giants just ended a 100-performance tour of Europe and North America, and instead of playing Madison Square Garden and charging big money, it has taken over the Variety Theater, an ex-porno palace at 110 Third Avenue, between 13th and 14th Streets in the East Village. The group, which has been touring with a band instead of its usual boom-box accompaniment, is performing for eight nights starting at 6:30 tonight, and it has a different opening act each night. The openers include David Thomas, Boss Hog and Eugene Chadbourne.
"We didn't want to do a big place," said John Flansburgh, who, with John Linnell, makes up the group. "Doing smaller shows, where people can sit down and check out the music more intensely, where a show is not so much like controlling a riot, would give us a chance instead to do real musical moments. We have a history of doing long stands in New York, and it lets us mix up the show more, so we can stretch things out a bit. And it's a good excuse to get to our homes -- we're on the extra crispy leg of a yearlong world tour, so it gives us a good excuse to get back to Brooklyn."
The group has produced the whole engagement, an unusual move that has given it the freedom to select the opening acts, shape the look of the show and determine everything else about it.
"It's better this way than if everything were picked by a promoter," Mr. Flansburgh said. "We lose the money if the money is lost, but it's worth it. And the Variety Theater has got the best marquee below 30th street, and it's been completely renovated, so people shouldn't stick to the floor.
"It's a nice place to see a show and it's not just for people who want to slam dance in the mosh pit. It's also for people who don't know what a mosh pit is. I hate big stagey productions, so I don't want our fans to think we've gone U2 on them. In the continuum between N.R.B.Q.'s production and the Rolling Stones, we're way over on N.R.B.Q.'s side."
The group will perform with a saxophonist, a bassist and a drummer as a band, which Mr. Flansburgh said is "a lot more challenging than a boom box."
"I've been doing this for 10 years, and with the band we're going through this really big transitional moment now which is good for us on a musical level. We're doing shows that are incredibly exciting, and people notice it. And the last show we do here will be a reprise of our first album. It'll be introduced by the talk show host Joe Franklin, which seems appropriate for New York."

HEADLINE: Review/Film: The Public Eye;
A Photographer Sees A City's Dark Side, But Not His Own

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
In "The Public Eye," set in 1942, Joe Pesci appears as a nervy, rude freelance photographer, Leon Bernstein, who's called Bernzy or the Great Bernzini by the editors and the cops with whom he deals. Bernzy has a way of arriving at the scene of a crime even before the police.
Armed with a Speed Graphic, the pockets of his trench coat bulging with flashbulbs and film, Bernzy roams nighttime Manhattan in search of the right subject. His specialties: mob rub-outs, tenement fires, celebrities caught off guard, servicemen and their girlfriends necking in doorways, automobile accidents, suicides and the anonymous faces of the sidewalk lookers-on. In his photographs these people speak. 
 Bernzy has an eye for detail. If the gunned-down body hasn't fallen to the pavement in a way that tells the story, he rearranges the pose, sometimes pushing the guy's hat into the frame. "People like to see the hat," he says.
His gift is to be able to freeze moments of hysteria, despair and loneliness into black-and-white images of arresting immediacy. Bernzy's tabloid pictures are vulgar, sensational and occasionally unforgettable.
Howard Franklin, who wrote and directed "The Public Eye," hasn't quite figured out how to dramatize the essence of a man as peculiarly gifted and obsessed as Bernzy, but at least he has created a rich character, whom Mr. Pesci plays with a furious, sweaty kind of authenticity.
Mr. Franklin seems to have been inspired by the life and work of the great Weegee, Arthur Fellig, whose photographs of New York in the 1940's defined the city for natives as well as those who had never seen it. Weegee's nickname, a corruption of Ouija, as in Ouija board, was apparently a reference to his uncanny way of turning up where the action was. Bernzy's dream in "The Public Eye" is to shoot a mob massacre not seconds after the victims have been turned into corpses, but as it happens.
Yet that's just part of the story of "The Public Eye," which tries to be both a 1940's film noir and a story about an artist's search for recognition. Bernzy wants a one-man show at the Museum of Modern Art. He thinks it's time his photographs were collected and published between hard covers. He's also carrying on like a private eye, uncovering a scandal that involves both mob and Government figures in the black-market sale of gasoline ration stamps.
Bernzy is drawn into this mess by the beautiful, mysterious Kay Levitz (Barbara Hershey), who has inherited a Manhattan establishment like the Stork Club from her much older, recently deceased husband. When a man who is clearly a racketeer shows up one night to declare himself her partner, Kay seeks out Bernzy, sometimes known as photographer to the mob, to find out what's going on.
"The Public Eye" never quite takes off, either as romantic melodrama or as a consideration of one very eccentric man's means of self-expression. The facts are there, but they never add up to much. The psychology is rudimentary. Mr. Pesci's Bernzy is presented as a fellow who can see the world only in terms of the black-and-white pictures he takes. He protects his feelings behind the camera lens. That is, until he meets Kay.
This most tentative love story is not helped by the lack of sparks between the two people who play the lovers. For whatever reason, Mr. Pesci and Ms. Hershey were never made for each other. It doesn't help that Kay seems to make contact with Bernzy only when the script calls for her to admire his work as an artist. The movie strains too hard for too little effect and concludes with a sequence whose only sense is vaguely poetic.
Several members of the supporting cast stand out: Jared Harris, as the menacing, ambiguously motivated doorman at Kay's swank club; Stanley Tucci, as a mob stoolie, and Jerry Adler, who plays the only person Bernzy can trust.
"The Public Eye" was shot on location in Cincinnati, Chicago and Los Angeles, although it looks as authentic as the Chrysler Building, which goes to show (the Mayor's Office on Film, Theater and Broadcasting might note) that New York is not indispensable to movie makers.
Mr. Franklin shows the audience a lot of examples of work by Weegee and his contemporaries, including Weegee's classic shot made at the opening of the Metropolitan Opera in 1948: the arrival of Mrs. George Washington Kavanaugh and Lady Peel, two smiling grandes dames cloaked in ermine. Weegee studies them, front view and in full figure, as they in turn are studied by a skeptical bag lady, standing at the side and seen in profile.
Weegee's work is full of such double whammies. The movie's only double whammy is Mr. Pesci's demonstration of his own talent and the driven character he creates.
"The Public Eye," which has been rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), has explicit violence and vulgar language.
 
The Public Eye
Written and directed by Howard Franklin; director of photography, Peter Suschitzky; edited by Evan Lottman; music by Mark Isham; production designer, Marcia Hinds-Johnson; produced by Sue Baden-Powell; released by Universal Pictures. Running time: 99 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Pittsburgh Still Seeks The Big Fish

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
THERE is no time anymore to talk of dynasties. The unequal economics of baseball will see to that. But there is one last chance for the Pittsburgh Pirates to win a pennant before Barry Bonds moves on.
The Pirates gave themselves that chance by crushing the Braves, 13-4, last night, throttling all those war whoops. The Braves imported their retired knuckleballing icon, Phil Niekro, to pitch batting practice, but Tim Wakefield baffled them anyway, setting up a seventh game tonight, the game that will decide if the Pirates lived up to their potential. 
 Potential is a burden. Just ask the Toronto Blue Jays, who need to win today or tomorrow to avoid failing again. Just ask the Montreal Expos of a decade ago or the Mets, who won exactly one pennant before they were torn apart.
Management does not need to tear apart a team that does not quite get it done. Time and free agency take care of that for them.
"This other team is a tragedy," Stan Kasten, the president of the Braves, said before last night's game with quite apparent empathy. "It's a synopsis of what's wrong. They do everything right: scouting, signing, development. The Pirates are a beautiful team."
People admire the Pirates and their gritty manager, Jim Leyland, who has revived a player moping his way out the door. Before Sunday night's game in Pittsburgh, Leyland told Bonds to don't worry, be happy, and Bonds has now started that game and last night's game with two straight hits. Now he and the Pirates have a chance to reach their potential.
Reaching the World Series is success. It is a sign that a team reached the highest level, that intelligence and planning have paid off. A team can be blown out in the World Series, but it still got there.
I'll bet that deep down in his heart, Dave Winfield smarts more over batting 1 for 22 and hearing George Steinbrenner's taunts about "Mr. May" than about losing the 1981 World Series. At least those Yankees saw the red-white-and-blue bunting.
A team can lose the seventh game of the World Series and rightfully refuse to leave the field, the way the Braves did last year. The Minnesota Twins were celebrating under their synthetic roof, but the Braves were also out there doffing their caps, and fair-minded Upper Midwest folk even cheered the Braves. (Strictly as an aside, doffing is the 837th reason baseball is the best team sport. Where else can players doff their caps?)
Reaching the World Series and losing can get old, as the Brooklyn Dodgers discovered after losing five of them to the Yankees in the Octobers of 1941, 1947, 1949, 1952 and 1953 before Next Year arrived in 1955. In those days there were only two eight-team leagues, but in 1969, baseball went to division play, creating a nether world of league championships, where the Blue Jays and these Pirates have been trapped, like the Flying Dutchman, like the Man Without a Country, like the Man Who Never Returned.
The Pirates have been coming on since Syd Thrift put the pieces together in the middle 80's, but Bonds is talking to real-estate agents in this town and other big markets with huge television money for free agents. Bobby Bonilla left after the second straight loss in the championships; Doug Drabek could also leave this year.
"I can't tell 'em to stay here because the Allegheny and the Monongahela form the Ohio," Leyland said inside Three Rivers Stadium the other night. Before the Pirates break up, Leyland wants to doff his cap deep into October.
"You want the satisfaction," Leyland said. "I don't think less of myself if we don't win. But let's face it, there's only one team that's going to have a great year. Some others are going to have a good year. I don't have any ego problems, any hangups. I'm proud of what we've done."
One of Leyland's players found out the hard way there is still a big difference between winning the pennant and winning the World Series.
"In some ways you feel the World Series is a bonus, after being the best in your league," said Andy Van Slyke, who batted .091 for pennant-winning St. Louis Cardinals in 1985. "Some teams don't get three cracks in a couple of decades. I hope this team can crack it. But then you get up, 3-1, like we did in 1985, and you lose to Kansas City, and it's disappointing.
"It's like fishing all day and catching a couple of 2-pounders, and all of a sudden you have a 14-pounder on your line. You pull it close to the boat and you put your net in the water, and you suddenly discover your 8-year-old son cut a hole in the net a week ago. It can be very disappointing."
The Pirates want to net that fish. Now they have one last chance to get into the big pond known as the World Series.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
BILLY FRANK JR., who was arrested more than 40 times for his efforts in behalf of American Indian fishing rights in the Pacific Northwest, was awarded the Albert Schweitzer Prize for Humanitarianism yesterday at Johns Hopkins University.
Named the recipient of the Albert Schweitzer Gold Medal was MARY W. LASKER, president of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation, for her support of medical research and her lobbying for increased government financing. Mrs. Lasker, 92 years old, was unable to attend the ceremonies. 
 Both prizes are given by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation.
Mr. Frank, 61, a Nisqually Indian, spent years fighting the state of Washington's refusal to recognize salmon fishing rights accorded to American Indians in treaties with the Federal Government. The Supreme Court upheld those rights in 1979. Since then, Mr. Frank has worked to heal the ruptures between Indians and non-Indians in his state.
In remarks at the ceremonies, DANIEL EVANS, the state's former Governor and Senator, said: "It was Billy Frank who after being arrested scores of times, being roughed up and beaten by agents of the state, said, 'There simply has to be a better way.' He had an enormous amount of forgiveness."
Mr. Frank had some comments of his own on the environment. "We've got to make people understand," he said, "that the economy can balance with the resources, that we don't have to take the last tree or the last drop of water."

HEADLINE: Inside Isolated Iraq, Merchants Go in Dread

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am writing to tell the world about the situation inside Iraq. The only way to enter the country is through Jordan. I took a 14-hour bus trip through the desert, three hours of which were the normal searching time for both borders, loading and unloading suitcases.
Life is miserable there, prices change by the hour, everything is expensive. The mounting tension between Iraq and the United States during the week of July 20 resulted in a panic in Baghdad's markets. Prices shot up by 20 percent. There were long lines for gas and gasoline for the three days before July 26. 
 On July 25 some small merchants were tied to columns with signs hung on their chests reading "Covetous greedy merchant." They were spat on and pelted with vegetables by security service men pretending to be ordinary shoppers. The daily newspapers confirmed the incident.
According to Babil (edited by Saddam Hussein's son Uday), "Most of our people were happy, rushing to the markets to see the covetous greedy merchants. Small signs were hung on their necks telling of their greed. . . . this action taken by the Government resulted in lowering prices and striking individual suspected merchants." Yet most people knew rising prices were not the fault of the merchants.
On July 26, the economic security police started a roundup of merchants. Up to 200 were detained in the economic security headquartes or in Abu Greab prison. Some were picked up from home. By an order from Saddam Hussein, 40 of them were executed (most probably shot) in the economic security headquarters, and their bodies were sent to Abu Greab prison to prepare their death certificates. Their eyes were donated to the human parts bank. All properties of the executed were confiscated.
The next day their families received the bodies with instructions not to perform the normal burial rituals, which include taking the dead to a large mosque and praying for their souls just before burial. Also, no funerals were allowed.
In addition, some 400 merchants were called to attend a "special urgent meeting" by the Ministry of Commerce. They were told by the Ministers of Commerce and the Interior that from now on for every infraction of the law the punishment would be execution. No fines or imprisonments as before, only executions. They were told, "If you don't like what you hear, then go to your homes and don't open your stores."
On the evening of July 26, Saddam Hussein was on television handing out medals to military personnel, commemorating their bravery in "the mother of all battles." He said that they had solved the problem of the "covetous greedy merchants" with "some necks." He added that he had been given a second list of profiteers, but he "had enough" for now. He was laughing during that ceremony after the executions -- a type of laughter last seen on television before the Kuwaiti invasion. People say he is always happy after killing his enemies.
I saw 40 percent of the food stores closed for the next two days after the executions. Then they were open after a rumor spread that the ruling Baath party members of each district would force open the stores and sell everything inside.
I saw a wholesale market area called Jamila surrounded by special forces with machine guns. The best description for the main market areas would be that the merchants were living dead, and the shoppers were ghosts. The market was abnormally quiet, none of the shouting, action or bargaining that is common in Middle Eastern markets. Merchants sat quietly in their stores, as if at a funeral, and small kids did the selling. People were trying to buy what was left in the markets since everything was disappearing, and prices were unchanged or increased in some cases. By July 31, there was hardly any rice, oil, flour or sugar.
One of the executed merchants, Haji Latif Basil al-Ubaidi, was a man who helped needy families. He was a respected figure of his community. He was executed with his son (around 20 years old). On the day the corpses of Haji Latif and his son were brought to their family, people from their district (Ahdamia) gathered to see what was going on. They wanted to take the bodies to the mosque of Imam al-Adam to pray for their souls. Rumor has it that they were chanting, "There is only one God, Haji Latif is God's martyr."
Special forces were there and started to shoot into the air and on some people to disperse the crowds. Some were injured. Haji Latif became the merchants' symbol of virtue.
This was the largest massacre in Baghdad after the Adnan al-Hamdani killings of 1979. I am surprised how little attention is given to this brutal slaughter. It seems Saddam Hussein has really succeeded in isolating Iraq from the rest of the world.
After finishing with the food merchants, Saddam Hussein moved to attack cloth merchants. On July 27, the merchants in the main cloth market were attacked with sticks by the economic security police. They asked about the prices of clothes and spraypainted high-priced displayed clothes with the prices they considered reasonable. All merchants in that area closed their stores and fled.
I don't know how to end this letter, except by saying the world must do something.
 
NAME WITHHELD
St.-Lambert, Quebec, Sept. 26, 1992

SECTION: Section D; Page 15; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 258 words

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Polaroid Corporation today reported higher third-quarter sales but substantially lower profits compared with the 1991 third quarter, when it received a huge payment from Eastman Kodak to settle a longstanding lawsuit.
Polaroid said it earned $27.7 million, or 59 cents a share, far below last year's quarterly profit of $582 million, or $10.47 a share. The 1991 period's results, however, were skewed by by the $873.1 million Polaroid received from Kodak to settle a patent-infringement suit involving instant cameras. 
 Without that payment, Polaroid would have reported a loss last year, meaning the latest report is an improvement.
Polaroid said its sales of $514.1 million in the third quarter represented 8 percent growth from $474.6 million a year earlier. United States sales slipped 1 percent, to $274.9 million from $278.1 million.
Operating profits -- which exclude taxes, interest payments and the Kodak settlement -- were up 25 percent, Polaroid said.
"In the third quarter, in the U.S., consumer purchases of Polaroid film and cameras increased," the company's president, MacAllister Booth, said in a statement. "Total U.S. sales revenue, however, remained flat as dealers continued to manage inventory levels in response to a sluggish economy."
The company also noted that it introduced a new auto-focus, single-lens instant reflex camera in the third quarter and would begin shipping the product this month.
Polaroid stock slipped 37.5 cents, closing at $31.625 a share today on the New York Stock Exchange.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 19, 1992, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A brief article by Reuters in Business Day on Wednesday about the third-quarter earnings of the Polaroid Corporation misstated the effect of a patent-infringement settlement on Polaroid's results in the corresponding period of 1991. Excluding the settlement with the Eastman Kodak Company, Polaroid would still have had a profit in the 1991 quarter.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: James Stockdale;
Reluctant Politician Tempers Professional Edge

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

 BODY:
His hands shook with nerves. He stammered. He paused in the middle of his opening statement to put on his reading glasses. His snow-white forelock kept falling in his eye. He missed one question because his hearing aid was off.
"Who am I?" James B. Stockdale asked at the beginning of last night's debate. "Why am I here? I'm not a politician." 
 In the political spotlight for the first time, Ross Perot's running mate, a retired Admiral who won a Medal of Honor for heroism as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam, was no match for the glib professional politicians he was competing with.
But there was some charm in this 68-year-old who uttered simplicities amid the bombast, sometimes addled but occasionally pointed. He changed the familiar cadence of the political debate. Without practiced skills and polished positions, he made the evening more awkward, less solemn.
Stationed between Vice President Dan Quayle and Senator Al Gore, Mr. Stockdale spent most of the evening swiveling his head -- "like an observer at a Ping Pong game," he said -- as the Republican and Democratic candidates went after each other.
 
Of Water Lilies and Incentives

 
 When Hal Bruno of ABC News, the moderator, called a cease-fire between Mr. Quayle and Mr. Gore so Mr. Stockdale could get a word in on the economy, he could only say, "I'm out of ammunition on this one."
But minutes later, he got in his best line of the night. As his opponents shook their fingers and lobbed statistics, Mr. Stockdale interjected: "I think America is seeing right now the reason this nation is in gridlock. The trickle-downs and the tax-and-spends, or whatever you want to call them, are at swords' points. We can't get the economy going."
In answer to a question about the environment, he said, "You can overdo environmental cleaning," he said. "If you purify the pond, water lilies die.
"I love this planet," he went on. "I don't want to see it the property of fanatics."
On education, he said simply, "In schools, bureaucracy is bad and economy is good."
On the question of health care, Mr. Gore huffed that if a criminal had a right to a lawyer, every family had a right to a doctor. Mr. Quayle puffed that legislation restricting medical malpractice was the key.
Mr. Stockdale referred to the problem was "a web of wrong-way incentives that has to be changed." Few experts would disagree. But, Mr. Stockdale seemed not to have a clue as to what the necessary changes might be.
Mr. Stockdale expressed impatience with what he called the pointless "chitchat back and forth on the issues," saying the candidates' character was more important.
His own character, he said, was shaped by his seven and a half years as a prisoner, the highest ranking officer incarcerated. He ran a "civilization" with its own laws and constitution, he said, adding, "I was the sovereign."
"The best thing I had going for me," he remarked, "was I had no contact with Washington all those years."
Mr. Stockdale seemed to have tried to memorize Mr. Perot's economic plan, but in his nervousness, he often had trouble recalling it and more trouble finding it in his notes.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore went on and on about the economy. Here, by contrast, is Mr. Stockdale's entire answer to a question about what should be done to get people back to work:
"The lifeblood of our economy is investment. And right now when we pay 350 -- we borrow $350 billion a year -- it saps the money markets, and the private investors are not getting their share. What we do is work on that budget by an aggressive program, not a painful program, so that we can start borrowing less money and getting more investment money on the street through entrepreneurs who can build factories, who will hire people, and maybe we'll start manufacturing goods here in this country again. That's my answer."
He used a question about the military budget to warn against unnamed people "who are really kicking the props out from under our grand military establishment."
On the abortion question, he had a clear answer. "I believe a woman owns her body and what she does with it is her own business. Period."
Mr. Quayle and Mr. Gore debated that issue for more than five minutes.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. WILL REQUIRE FULLER DISCLOSURE OF EXECUTIVE PAY

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Under pressure from lawmakers and shareholders who have criticized large executive salaries, the Securities and Exchange Commission will approve rules Thursday that will require publicly traded companies to disclose in full how much top executives earn and will make it easier for shareholders to challenge incumbent directors.
The regulations fall short of more ambitious corporate-democracy proposals made by stockholders, lawmakers and others over the years. Chief among these were plans to give stockholders a greater say in setting pay scales. 
 Nonetheless, the new rules were widely regarded by both corporate and shareholder groups and by regulators in Washington as a significant step toward opening board rooms to greater involvement by small as well as large shareholders.
 
Issue's Increasing Attention
 The issue of corporate-executive compensation has received increasing attention as the number of multimillion-dollar executive compensation packages has grown, even at a time of general economic recession, job layoffs and painfully slow recovery.
The issue came to the fore during President Bush's trip to Japan in January with senior auto company executives when the President complained that Japan imported so few American cars while America imported so many Japanese autos. The Japanese replied that the problem was the high cost of American products, which they said was caused by, among other things, high American executive salaries.
The average annual salary among senior executives at the top 30 Japanese companies was $525,000 at the time; among the top 30 Americans, it was $3.2 million. The highest salary and compensation packages reported by American companies last year went to Anthony F. O'Reilly, chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company, who received $75.1 million in salary, bonus and stock options.
 
More Latitude Now
 Existing regulations give companies some latitude in describing the pay of senior executives, prompting many annual statements that are so confusing on the question of actual salaries and benefits that even business school professors and accountants have a hard time understanding them.
Senior officials at the agency said that under the new rules, which will be effective next year, companies will have to explain to stockholders how they determine pay and bonuses for senior executives and publish charts in their annual reports that compare the pay rates with the performance of stock prices.
Comparisons will also have to be made of the stock prices of either similar-sized companies, companies in the same industry or the price of various widely followed stock indexes.
And the companies will have to assign values to the stock options that the executives receive, either by using one of several formulas used by compensation experts or by providing a range of values pegged to possible changes in the company's stock price over future years. The options permit the executives to purchase stock at a set price over a certain number of years.
Conspiciously absent from the new rules are two proposals that would have had the greatest impact on excessive compensation of all those before the commission. One would let stockholders limit executive salaries. The other would require companies to reflect the executive stock options on company financial statements, by charging the options against earnings when the options are exercised. These options would end up costing the companies millions of dollars.
On the first point, the Democratic candidate for President, Gov. Bill Clinton, said earlier this month in response to questions by a shareholder group, that he supported letting shareholders "determine the compensation of top executives."
That idea was not seriously considered by the S.E.C., which is dominated by Republicans who are against adopting rules that would pre-empt the state corporation laws. The laws in all states now give the directors the ultimate say over pay issues.
Governor Clinton also supported legislation that would limit corporate tax deductions for salaries that are "excessive." Under the present law, corporations can deduct executive salaries as a business expense. Governor Clinton did not specify how the deductions would be limited.
Democrats in Congress introduced legislation this year to limit such deductions for executive pay over $1 million.
Officials in the Bush Administration are in general agreement with the commission's new proposals, although they disagree with some of its finer points. Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson, himself a former chief executive of G. D. Searle & Company, has said for instance, that he does not think it is wise for companies to put values on the options granted to senior executives.
The new proxy regulations will make it easier for shareholders to communicate without the prior approval of regulators and reduce the costs and effort of obtaining mailing lists of other shareholders in certain circumstances.
Under the new regulations, large institutional shareholders will be able to tell others how they are voting without first obtaining permission from the commission, and shareholders holding less than $5 million of stock will also be able to wage written campaigns without the approval of agency officials.
All of the changes follow many months of study and intensive lobbying by both shareholder groups and many large corporations. The companies have tried to influence the agency's decision by pleading their cases to senior officials at the White House and Treasury Department.
Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C., said in an interview today that the adoption of the regulations would mark "a watershed for corporate governance" and that the regulations were intended "to empower shareholders."
"The proposals would give the shareholders more information and then make it reasonably possible for them to do something about that information," he said in an interview. "The philosophy that underlies the proposals is that the people in the best position, if a company is deteriorating or stagnating, to do something about it are the people who own it.
"For too long, the Wall Street rule has been that if you don't like what's going on, sell out. That has made it difficult and expensive for shareholders."
The commission's lone Democrat, Richard Y. Roberts, said that the changes "will enable shareholders to be more active" and would probably head off legislation.
In February, the commission ruled that shareholders could seek votes on their views about pay packages. While the ballots are nonbinding, officials and corporate experts said the possibility of an embarrassing defeat provided a powerful incentive for directors to reassess the compensation of senior management.
The changes in the proxy rules were first proposed in June 1991 after years of study, and then withdrawn by the agency a few months later. They had run into heavy criticism by large corporations.
The opponents of the new rules -- most notably the Business Roundtable -- had insisted they would significantly alter the corporate landscape by giving large institutional shareholders more power.
 
A 'Big Victory'
 Shareholder supporters are generally pleased with what happened. "This gives us about 90 percent of what we expected to get in 1990 when we filed our petition for rule making," said Ralph V. Whitworth, president of the United Shareholders Association, a group based in Washington and founded by the oil executive T. Boone Pickens. "It's a big victory for us."
Dick Anthony, a spokesman for the Business Roundtable, said the organization would have no comment until the commission's final action Thursday.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Military Feels Economic Pinch, U.S. Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
North Korea's military has significantly cut pilot training and ground exercises because of the nation's deteriorating economic condition, the commander of American forces in South Korea said today.
The commander, Gen. Robert RisCassi, said there appeared to be a "lessening of resources" available to the military under the hard-line Communist Government of President Kim Il Sung. 
 North Korea has a "marginal" ability to feed its people and depends on its weapons sales abroad "for the basic necessities of food and fuel," General RisCassi said. The nation's economic crisis began in 1989, when the Soviet Union demanded that all goods, in particular fuel, be paid for in hard currency.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits With Americans;
Brew and a Juke Box Make Debate Easier to Swallow at One Cleveland Bar

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARMA, Ohio, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The backroad comforts of the Mama Mia lounge in this Cleveland suburb included draft beer to go with the live debate. There was a young couple spooning obliviously under the TV screen, and a man at the bar talking about "the illusion of the first time."
He was speaking of the art of debating, not spooning, and he talked back to the TV debaters, demonstrating how they might better mask all their nervous civics preparation and make memorization sound natural. "The boy stood on the burning deck, eating apples by the peck," intoned Richard N. Meadows, a speech and theater professor from across the road at Cuyahoga Community College. He made the classroom sound bite evoke Ronald Reagan speaking from his baritoned heart, right to the hideaway voters at Mama Mia's. 
 But the TV screen was definitely resisting the illusion of the first time. The Vice-Presidential boys were standing toe to toe on their own burning deck, and the Mama Mia clientele were in various stages of paying attention or not, staring into their beer, or maybe into the nation's future.
 
An Overriding Theme
 Debate night in America can be an exercise in diffusion, a free-fall through the hustings void of sound scraps and sadly drifting agendas. There was some consensus at Mama Mia's (Dan Quayle has used nearly four years of incumbency to upgrade his nervous giggle into a self-confident laugh). And there was an overriding theme to the cacaphonous night ("Dave, when you have a chance?" was shouted steadily, thirstily at the bartender, David Reinosa).
But most of all there was a fractured spectrum of voter involvement and disinterest that might have made Alexis de Tocqueville fear for the latest version of the Republic, yet fascinate him anew at how decisions come of all this.
"Marge, I'm sorry," a young man with his back to the event fairly sobbed at a waitress who passed him by, pert and silent. "I forgot all about Sunday and I'm sorry, Marge," the young man pleaded over the TV melange of pointed fingers and raised voices. Marge continued on, carrying libation and some sort of secret as Dan Quayle kept demanding that Al Gore explain why Bill Clinton was worth trusting.
Staring at the screen, two men at a nearby table were engrossed and wondering about the election's implications for their local home-building business. The telephone beeper of one of them, Timothy Shear, suddenly cut across the buzz of candidates' talk. When he returned from the phone Mr. Shear laughed in quoting the quick query of a friend watching the debate elsewhere. "Who is this guy?" the caller had asked of the awkward performance of the evening's third candidate, James B. Stockdale.
 
An Uneasy Question
 Mr. Shear and his partner, Frank Spinelli, agreed that Ross Perot, a supersalesman if nothing else, would have to explain at his next debate the precise attraction of Mr. Stockdale.
"Are you afraid of someone who's a great salesman?" Mr. Shear asked, getting at what he thinks may be the heart of this year's disturbing campaign, the strange pleasure and curiosity Mr. Perot is engendering once more in the land.
"You hear comments like that in selling in our business: 'You make so much sense it scares me.' Well, could the fact that Perot is a great salesman have to do with the fact that he is listening very carefully and giving the people what they want?" Mr. Shear asked, sounding uneasy at not being sure.
Some dissenter down the bar suddenly put money in the juke box and turned the music up loud.
"Should pull the plug on that guy," said Mickey Florentino, an executive in a temporary-help agency who is doing well in the hurting economy. "How does a guy sitting here know who's telling the truth?" he asked, staring at the debaters. "That guy in the middle doesn't know what to do," he added rather sympathetically of Mr. Stockdale. "And people earning 200-thou a year are going to find a way around all the talk of taxes, right?"
 
Some Optimistic Talk
 His friend, Phil Bova, directed an aside to the bartender, "David, when you have chance?" Then he talked optimistically above the music about the debate winking from the screen. "Listen, the future is right here," Mr. Bova insisted from his bar stool. "These guys are going to be calling the shots, leading America, and it's good this is coming right into the front room."
"You know, a lot of wonderful guys died in wars so we could have this," he added, his beer glass glistening with reflections from the debate.
Down the bar, Mr. Meadows, the speech teacher, was savoring the headlong technique of Mr. Quayle's performance. "This is a chance for him to redeem himself," the professor said. "How many of us get a second chance?"
Another helping of music rose up again over the debate, and a thin, bearded man at the juke box beamed in malicious satisfaction.
"I see spooky guys like that, playing rap music," Mr. Shear commented. "They don't understand the ramifications, can't see the changes happening in the world. The Berlin wall has come down, the cold war has ended, and anything can happen. Hey, Ross Perot could be elected President."
Whatever, David the bartender kept to his rounds, and the rap music barely allowed the final words in edgewise as the debate wound down at Mama Mia's.

HEADLINE: Bush Camp Using Tax Office To Attack Clinton Proposals

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Over the years, the Treasury Department's Office of Tax Analysis has operated like the Census Bureau and the Bureau of Labor Statistics, sources of reliable data with no overtones of partisan politics.
But this year, the Bush Administration has used the tax office's staff and computers to generate questionable assessments of Gov. Bill Clinton's tax proposals. 
 Desiree Tucker-Sorini, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Public Affairs, defended the new procedures today. "It is our job to analyze economic proposals and their implications on tax policy," regardless of where the proposals come from, she said.
But John E. Chapoton, who headed the tax office in the first Reagan Administration, said he had never before heard of the office becoming involved in a political campaign. "It disturbs me," Mr. Chapoton said. "It's not wise to do anything that compromises the trust people have in the office as completely objective."
Last month, the head of the tax office, Fred T. Goldberg Jr., Assistant Treasury Secretary for Tax Policy, called reporters to his office and said the Treasury Department's calculations showed that the Clinton policies could increase the taxes of Americans with incomes as low as $20,000 a year.
Mr. Clinton maintains that he would raise the taxes only of couples with incomes of more than $200,000 and individuals with incomes above about $150,000. The Treasury's computer calculations were based on unprovable assumptions provided by President Bush's election campaign.
Mr. Goldberg was joined by two other Assistant Treasury Secretaries, Ms. Tucker-Sorini and Hollis S. McLoughlin, who serves as chief of staff for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. They spoke then only on the condition that their names not be used. Two days later, the three went to the Bush-Quayle campaign headquarters and made the same sweeping assertions under the same condition.
Reporters who did not attend the sessions are not bound by the attribution condition.
