HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Pulse -- Florida;
In Formerly Safe Florida, It's Nip and Tuck for Bush

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 14

 BODY:
It has come to this for George Bush with less than three weeks left until Election Day: He could quite conceivably lose Florida, the nation's fourth largest state, which he carried by almost a million votes four years ago and which has been the safest of all the megastates for the Republicans in recent Presidential elections.
The President trails Bill Clinton by a substantial margin in places where they were supposed to be slugging it out at this stage, like Pennsylvania and Illinois and New Jersey. But the race for this state's 25 electoral votes remains very close, if private polls for the two major parties are to be believed, so Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton keep returning to Florida. In mid-October 1988, Michael S. Dukakis pulled his campaign staff from the state, conceding it to Mr. Bush, who did not visit these parts at all after Labor Day. 
 Mr. Bush may yet carry the state. Inured to defeat, local Democrats "don't dare get all that excited about winning," said Lieut. Gov. Buddy MacKay, a Democrat, "but it could just happen."
If it does, it will happen largely because Florida's seemingly inexhaustible boom has proved to have limits, even in Orlando, which has been transformed in less than 40 years from a sleepy orange-grove town of 50,000 into the world's leading tourist destination, with 76,000 hotel rooms, the most of any city in the nation.
 
Recession Changes Politics
 In wealthy Naples on the southern Gulf Coast, unemployment has reached 13 percent. In the high-tech plants spawned by the Kennedy Space Center, workers "know they only have a year or 18 months left before the defense cutbacks get them," a union official said. Retirees in St. Petersburg and elsewhere fret because the monthly payments from their certificates of deposit and money market funds have withered. And all over the state, the banks are in the doldrums and the real estate goose has stopped laying golden eggs.
"The recession has changed the politics of Florida," commented Geoffrey Garin, a Washington poll taker who works for local Democrats.
"Unhappily for us, there's a smoke screen that covers Clinton, and it's called the economy," said Stan Smith, a Tampa-area consultant for Republican candidates. "While it's there, you can't get people to see Clinton's faults, let alone convince them to vote against him, and Bush hasn't been able to find a way to blow it away."
Tommy Thomas of Lakeland, a prominent Republican since his days as national committeeman in the Nixon era, has been predicting trouble for the President for months. He appealed publicly but vainly to Mr. Bush last summer to drop Vice President Dan Quayle from the ticket as a means of showing that he took the nation's problems seriously.
"I wish he had done it," Mr. Thomas said, "and I'm afraid that he's going to wish he had done it, too. The problem is that no matter what he talks about, people want to know why it took him so long to wake up. It's a crying shame, but we're no better than 50-50, and he could surely lose this state. It chills my bones to think of four years of 'Slick Willie,' but that's coming, I guess."
Jeb Bush, a Miami businessman and the President's son, is his campaign chairman in Florida. He said in an interview this week that he thought his father would take Florida, but he readily conceded that there was still a good deal of work for the President to do.
"Voters here need to be given the assurance that the energy and talent that were brought to bear on world problems in the last four years are going to be focused on our country's long-term economic problems in the years ahead," he said. "I really believe that there is a large reservoir of goodwill toward Dad. But if we are going to win, we have to increase the level of confidence in him.
"We need some kind of breakthrough, and we need it soon."
Breaking through is harder when there are constant setbacks. Radio and television stations in the state routinely describe Mr. Bush as the loser in the first Presidential debate, which does nothing to dispel the suggestion, strong even here, that Mr. Clinton may be heading for a landslide victory.
There is no suggestion that Ross Perot, despite his strong showing in the first face-off, has much of a chance to win here.
Jack Gargan, the founder of a grass-roots voter organization based in Tampa, said he was still bothered by Mr. Perot's surprise decision to pull out of the race in July and his equally sudden decision this month to rejoin it. He added, "That was fatal unless he can come clean convincingly."
Van Poole, the Republican state chairman, said the debates would have little impact until all of them had been completed, and for that reason, he theorized, "the decision process is going to be completed very late, as late as the last weekend."
"A lot of people say they're for Clinton, but they can't really tell you why they're for him," Mr. Poole said, in a comment typical of Republican professionals around the country this fall, seeking to keep hopes high. "I think they're agonizing over how to go. They want change, but they're afraid that Clinton's change will end up meaning higher taxes."
 
Democrats Are More Organized
 The Republicans have been training for 18 months for a huge grass-roots effort in the final weeks, involving phone banks and get-out-the-vote campaigns. Since 1988, they have cut still further into the traditional Democratic edge in voter registration, increasing their own numbers by 200,000 while the Democratic total has fallen by 50,000. In a state with a large number of military families, they have put together a sophisticated absentee-ballot operation, like the one that snatched victory from Mr. MacKay in the 1988 Senate race and handed it to Connie Mack 3d, a Republican, by only 35,000 votes.
But Richard Sher, a political science professor at the University of Florida, says the Democrats are much less disorganized this year than is usually the case in this diverse state, which has five or six major population concentrations and intense regional rivalries in the state.
"We haven't seen anything like this in a long, long time," Mr. Sher said. "In the 1988 primary, Gore was completely out-organized in Florida, but he has built close ties since then. I must say that Clinton has also shown a real talent for political spadework, and for the first time in years you see local candidates clustering around the two of them when they visit the state."
Mr. Clinton has not yet put a significant amount of money into television advertising, although radio commercials are running in several cities. Mr. MacKay said that if Mr. Bush's television campaign, which is only now beginning, proved to be substantial, the Democrats had money available "to do what we need to do, which is unusual."
 
Regional Disparities
 The President's strongest regions are the Panhandle, the deeply conservative east-west strip of Florida that abuts Georgia and Alabama and shares their political culture; Dade County, centered on Miami, which is now slightly more than 50 percent Hispanic, and the Gulf Coast towns from Clearwater south, which are heavily populated by retirees from the Midwest.
Mr. Clinton is stronger in other parts of the state, and appears to be scoring among women and younger voters. Jay Hakes, a longtime Democratic strategist, said that Mr. Bush's assaults on the Arkansas Governor's antiwar activities "may have given him some lift among older voters, but it has infuriated the baby boomers."
The so-called I-4 Corridor, which runs from Tampa Bay to the Atlantic Coast, passing near Orlando, Ocala and Gainesville, may prove decisive. Most people settled in that area to take up jobs, not to retire. They are younger than the state average. Many are Reagan Democrats whose views have been affected by the state's economic woes.
Mr. Clinton's and Mr. Gore's big campaign event in Florida was a bus tour early this month with an itinerary that covered the I-4 corridor. They drew huge crowds, even in Republican strongholds like Ocala, where perhaps 10,000 people filled a rodeo arena, and the mood was exuberant. The President's crowds have been much more subdued.
"People have been waiting and waiting for the President to give them a reason to vote for him," said Bob Joffee of Mason-Dixon Political Research, which is based here. "As we get closer and he doesn't do it, a lot of people are starting to give up."

Florida's fragmented politics reflects its racial, ethnic and linguistic mix. The state gained four Congressional seats and has new districts with black and Hispanic majorities. Carrie Meek, a Democrat, is assured of becoming Florida's first black assured of becoming Florida's first black in Congress since Reconstruction. Senator Bob Graham, who was on Bill Clinton's list for No. 2, has been a top fund-raiser, gathering $2.2 million by August.

HEADLINE: U.S.-RUSSIA ACCORD ON ARMS HITS SNAG

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Hopes for an early signing of a far-reaching nuclear arms reduction agreement between the United States and Russia have faded because of technical reservations being raised by Moscow, Bush Administration officials said today.
On June 16 in Washington, President Bush and the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, initialled an arms control agreement that would, among other things, eliminate all of Russia's most powerful SS-18 multiple warhead missiles. A week later, then Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d testified to Congress that the accord would likely be translated into a treaty in three to five weeks, but at the latest by Sept. 1. Now, most officials say, it won't be finished until sometime after the election at the earliest. 
 At this point, officials say, there is no indication that the Russians have any intention of reneging on the deal. The Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, has repeatedly stressed that his Government wants to complete it quickly. Nevertheless, United States officials say there is a degree of uncertainty within the Administration over exactly why the Russians have suddenly raised the possibility in negotiations among technical experts whether they could retain SS-18 missile silos and some SS-19 missiles seemingly proscribed by the draft agreement.
 
Issue in Debate
 The delay has become a political issue. At Tuesday's Vice Presidential debate, the Democratic candidate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, declared that after President Bush shifted his main negotiator, James A. Baker 3d, from the State Department to White House chief of staff, "the deal unravelled, and now there is no deal at all."
Vice President Dan Quayle did not dispute Mr. Gore's assertion, but responded that Mr. Bush still has a "commitment" from Mr. Yeltsin to carry out the deal.
Russia and the United States now have about 22,500 warheads. Last year, the Soviet Union and the United States signed a strategic arms reduction treaty, known as Start, that will reduce their combined arsenals to about 15,000 warheads altogether by the year 2000. Then in June, Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin agreed in principle to far-reaching additional cuts that would reduce to their combined arsenals to about 7,000 warheads, or roughly 3,500 each, by the year 2003. It is this second accord, known as Start II, that is being delayed.
According to Administration officials and other arms control experts, the delay in the production of a formal treaty is nothing more than the usual kind of problem that arises in arms control negotiations when experts try to take the broad outlines of an agreement reached by the politicians and translate it into highly technical treaty language. The military bureaucracies on both sides tend to try to minimize the effect on them by quibbling over wording.
 
Russians Wait for Election
 Less benign interpretations about what is causing the delay relate to political developments in Moscow. One is that the Russians would simply like to see who wins the American election before they sign, maybe even hoping that they can get better terms out of a Democratic Administration.
Another interpretation is that the Russians are worried about opposition to the treaty from hard-line nationalists in their own Parliament and military. This agreement has been criticized by some Russian hard-liners ever since Mr. Yeltsin initialed it. Since the Yeltsin Government is about to submit the Start I treaty to the Russian Parliament for ratification this week, it may prefer not to ask the Parliament to approve even deeper arms cuts.
Still another interpretation is that the objections the Russians have raised really are purely to save money. But some American officials suspect that even this economic argument masks political motives by hard-liners in the military to renegotiate the deal.
Mr. Kozyrev gave Russian questions and proposed changes to the American draft of the agreement to Acting Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger at a meeting on Sept. 24. But Mr. Kozyrev also raised at least two other objections to the agreement that are potentially more serious. These objections were repeated when a team of American arms control experts visited Moscow last week.
One has to do with the SS-18 missiles, the largest intercontinental ballistic missiles in the Russian arsenal, each of which carries 10 warheads.
The Russians are now asking to retain the silos from which these SS-18's are launched. They want to modify these silos for use by others that they will be allowed to retain under the treaty, most likely the mobile SS-25.
Although American officials acknowledge that destroying or building new missile silos is an expensive process, they say they could not accept a Russian request to retain them given the possibility that these silos could still be used to launch SS-18's.
The other proposed change at which the Americans are balking has to do with Russia's six-warhead SS-19 missile. The new agreement bans all such multiple-warhead missiles and Russia wants to be able simple to take five warheads off the top of each SS-19. That way they can live up to the letter of the treaty without scrapping the SS-19's and go through the expense of building a new, single-warhead missile.
But if the SS-19 is just stripped down to one warhead, it would still have the potential to simply be reloaded with the full six missiles.

HEADLINE: In Crown Heights Murder Trial, Witness Says Hasid Started Fight

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
In an account that differed sharply from previous testimony about the moments leading up to the killing of Yankel Rosenbaum, a man from Crown Heights testified yesterday that he had seen the Hasidic student step out of a car, argue with several young men and kick them before they pummeled him.
The man, John Anderson, 24 years old, an unemployed clerk, was a surprise witness on the first day of the defense case in the murder trial of Lemrick Nelson Jr. Prosecutors contend that Mr. Nelson, who is charged with second-degree murder, emerged from a group assaulting Mr. Rosenbaum and stabbed him to death during the racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in August 1991. 
 In his testimony yesterday Mr. Anderson also said that he did not see Mr. Rosenbaum fall to the ground or see anyone stab him. Mr. Anderson said he was standing across the street from the attack and saw Mr. Rosenbaum chase several youths who had assaulted him before the police went to help him.
In cross-examination an assistant district attorney, James Leeper, focused on the inconsistencies between Mr. Anderson's testimony and that of at least nine witnesses who have testified in the last three weeks. Prosecution witnesses have said Mr. Rosenbaum was attacked as he was returning home, the random victim of a crowd of youths seeking revenge for the death hours earlier of a 7-year-old black boy who was hit by a car in the entourage of the Lubavitch Grand Rabbi.
 
At Accident and in Crowd
 Police officers have testified that crowds of youths angered by the death of the boy, Gavin Cato, ran through the streets of Crown Heights throwing bricks and bottles, firing guns and overturning cars. One group attacked Mr. Rosenbaum.
Mr. Anderson's account was sharply at odds with that testimony. He said that he had been at the scene of the car accident and that he had been part of the crowd of youths on the streets.
Mr. Anderson, who could not remember any names of the people accompanying him, said that the crowd was peaceful and that Mr. Rosenbaum had instigated the attack. "Nobody threw rocks," he said. "If a car flipped over, I didn't see it." He added that he remained at the scene of the attack and was stopped by the police and taken to be identified by Mr. Rosenbaum, who, Mr. Anderson said, was standing up, and not lying down, as the prosecution contends.
"I saw people throw punches at his back," Mr. Anderson said. "I didn't see anyone stab him. I refused to run because I didn't do nothing." Mr. Anderson added that Mr. Rosenbaum told the officers it was impossible for him to identify his attackers because "he couldn't see nobody."
The prosecution has contended that Mr. Rosenbaum identified Mr. Nelson by his red shirt. Mr. Anderson said that at least three people including him were wearing red shirts and that several youths were taken to Mr. Rosenbaum to see if he could identify any of them.
Mr. Anderson was the defense's second witness. The first was Gavin Cato's father, Carmel. His voice breaking, Mr. Cato briefly described how he had tried unsuccessfully to lift the car off his son and how Gavin had died at the hospital.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Says Economy Is Resisting Remedies

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 14

 BODY:
After three days of consultations with Japan's top economic officials, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, offered a sobering thought today: he emphasized repeatedly at a news conference that one of the most troubling aspects of these difficult times is that the tried and true methods of economic analysis and the old monetary tools just do not seem to be working.
"No models can explain the types of patterns we are having," Mr. Greenspan said, referring to the sluggish economic growth in the United States and elsewhere despite the fact that interest rates have been cut sharply in most countries. "This is really a quite extraordinarily difficult type of environment." 
 It was a surprising note of frustration from one of the world's most influential central bankers. But it was an apparent reflection of the difficulty the Fed has faced in trying to pull the American economy out of its rut. One official said Mr. Greenspan's comments were similar to those he had shared in a closed meeting with Yasushi Mieno, governor of the Bank of Japan, who is also grappling with an anemic economy and ailing banking sector.
 
Unusually Reflective
 Central bankers tend to be elliptical and vague in their public remarks, in an effort to avoid disrupting financial markets or giving notice of changes in interest rates. And Mr. Greenspan is a master of responding at length and reasonably to questions, while giving away nothing.
But he seemed unusually reflective today in his remarks, made after a routine visit to meet with Japanese officials. While there had been speculation that he might organize a concerted reduction in interest rates with the Bank of Japan, officials said the visit had been planned since April and was just an opportunity to exchange views.
Mr. Greenspan said he had agreed to keep the details of the discussions here confidential but indicated that he had talked about the world economic situation and the foreign exchange market, which has gone through weeks of turmoil, as well as the coordination of economic policies among the major industrialized nations.
The two sides also discussed, he said, the problem of what is called "asset deflation," or the sharp declines in real estate prices in the United States and Japan in recent years and the impact of these declines on banks.
 
Voicing Frustration
 But after dodging a number of questions about exchange rates and interest rates, Mr. Greenspan took some time at the news conference this afternoon to note that the policy makers' methods for analyzing the American economy, developed and proved in the postwar period, were simply failing to guide the Fed as surely as they once had.
Mr. Greenspan has commented before on the unusual challenge the Fed is facing in trying to steer the economy through this drawn-out slowdown while the banking system is weak and businesses and individuals are still burdened with too much debt. But an aide confirmed that he elaborated on the frustrations and the sense of being adrift at somewhat greater length than before.
Not everything has changed, Mr. Greenspan insisted, but "they've changed enough that reliance on the old models is inadequate."
He added, "We are being forced to look at different structures."

HEADLINE: Televising the Recession: Job Fair on L.I. Is Broadcast Live

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PLAINVIEW, L.I., Oct 14

 BODY:
It is perhaps a sign of the times that Barry Zimbler, already a few months behind on his mortgage and desperate to take almost any job, went on television tonight wearing a crisp white shirt, staring glumly at the camera and talking about his experience in a "multifaceted position" with a small Manhattan jewelry manufacturer.
"I was there approximately 13 years," he said in a monotone, as his name, his job title, director of computer operations and identification number, 103, flashed across the screen. "I was recently let go and I have been seeking employment ever since. Thank you very much."
 
One in 10 Jobs Gone
 As the recession continues to take its toll, wiping out nearly one out of 10 jobs in the New York metropolitan area, Mr. Zimbler, out of work for more than 18 months, turned to the airwaves tonight, in a rare television campaign to reach out to the casualties of the economy. 
 For two hours of live television, WLIW, a public television station here that reaches most households in the metropolitan area, set aside its regular programming for a televised hiring hall, at which private employers, government officials and social-service agencies worked together to match workers with jobs.
There on camera were the phone banks and the local celebrities, familiar from countless public-television membership drives. But this time, instead of recording membership pledges and credit-card numbers, rows of volunteers were taking down job listings that were quickly read on the air, followed by the video resumes of people like Mr. Zimbler.
There was Gordon Steele, number 104, who was laid off as chief budget officer in the Nassau County Parks Department, two weeks shy of the 20 years of service he needed for full pension benefits. He is 57 years old and has been looking for work since February.
"I am looking for a job in a management capacity," he said, "and I would like to thank you for this opportunity, and maybe you would like me to come and work for you."
Or Roberta Livingston, number 107, a marketing manager who helped build up sales at a BJ's Wholesale Club in Farmingdale until her job was "consolidated." Her husband, also in marketing, is working only occasionally, she said.
Now she is looking for a job in a "smallish to medium-size company, where I can make a difference."
"I always project a positive attitude," she said. "I can increase the demand of any product or service and I would love an opportunity to work for you."
Hundreds of job openings turned up, paying from minimum wage to $94,000 a year. Computer Associates, a software company with headquarters in Islandia, L.I., had openings for a lawyer, an accountant and computer operators. Metropolitan Life wanted manager trainees and account representatives.
 
Friendly Persuasion
 The idea of the fair was to use the friendly persuasion of television to persuade employers to call not only with jobs that appeared in classified ads, but also with jobs they had not yet advertised, or with hiring proposals that had been sitting on someone's desk for final approval.
"We hope that if an employer is considering maybe hiring a secretary or sales person that this will sort of egg them on to do so," said Dara Welles, the producer and host of the program.
Between job offers, read by a team of volunteer announcers from three New York commercial-television stations, the job fair offered advice on job hunting, resumes, financial planning and where to get help. Each offer was followed by a code number that viewers could use to get more information from the State Department of Labor.
Long Island United Way was on the air offering its guide to the recession, Help for Hard Times, and listing services that ranged from mortgage-default counseling to measures against domestic violence.
"We have an emerging population that is now in need," said John Renyhart, senior vice president for Long Island United Way. "People who enjoyed the good life on Long Island are now unemployed. People who used to give to our food pantries are now the people who are going there to ask for assistance."
 
Tried in San Diego
 A similar job fair was first tried last winter in San Diego on a commercial television station, KGTV, which devoted several hours of prime time to the effort.
"We had an annual toy drive and, for once, we found the gold was off of California," said Don Lundy, the station's program director. "So we did some research and we were told it was bad and it was going to get worse."
In a few hours, he said, 800 job offers were collected, most of them soon filled, and since then they have found 3,500 more jobs, he said. The station runs free video resumes every weekday morning.
The idea was picked up by Nassau County officials, struggling to find a way to fight the worst recession on Long Island since the postwar building boom. The County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, took it to the television station, the business community and social-service agencies.
Thirty percent of all manufacturing jobs, most related to military production, and a third of all construction jobs have disappeared since the late 1980's.
Yet Gary Huth, an economist with the State Department of Labor, said that with layoffs declining, this was a good time to hold a job fair.
"I don't think that companies are going to hire people because they look good on a telethon," he said. "But companies may be on the verge of hiring anyway. A lot of the groundwork for an improvement in the economy has been laid. This could be a psychological boost."
 
Compelling Moments
 But the most compelling moments came when unemployed New Yorkers told their stories through video resumes lasting 45 seconds or less.
There was LuAnn Vivona (number 105), a flight attendant laid off by Continental Airlines; Brian Cavanagh (number 101), who is "available to work in your credit department," and Charmaine Hemmings (number 106), seeking to conduct workshops on empowerment for women and diversity in the workplace.
But Mr. Zimbler, well groomed, calm, but with the look of a deer staring into the headlights of a car, told the most troubling story of all.
After 13 years running the computer system and other operations in a small family-owned jewelry factory, he was abruptly dismissed, by overnight letter, from his $55,000-a-year job, virtually without explanation, struggling to pay his $1,600 mortgage.
Now, in desperation, he has applied for warehouse work, only to be turned down, he says, because he is "overqualified."
"You can't sound desperate with these people," he said. "They know that if they hire you, you are going to leave when a better job opens up."
In the meantime, he and his wife, a hairdresser, are down to bare essentials, living without health insurance, spending his retirement account, borrowing the limit on credit cards, and abandoning any thought of vacations.
When his wife of three years had a miscarriage last year, they were devastated, but now Mr. Zimbler wonders whether it was for the best.
"We've lived very well," he said. "All of a sudden to have the hammer fall down and hit you on the head is unbearable."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Right Jolt: A Fiscal Menu

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
UNLESS unemployment falls very fast, very soon -- a prospect only slightly more likely than a Nobel Peace Prize for Pat Buchanan -- the next President will be under enormous pressure to give the economy a fiscal lift. But how?
That old favorite, public works spending, conjures images of gents in sharkskin suits swapping Cadillacs for contracts to build highways to nowhere. Even if these images of waste and corruption are dated, the economists' critique of creating jobs by pouring concrete still stands: "It just takes too long to turn them on," said George Perry of the Brookings Institution. 
 An across-the-board income tax cut, by contrast, could put money in people's pockets as fast as payroll deductions can be reprogrammed. But with the Federal budget hopelessly out of balance and Wall Street sniffing the wind for signs of inflation, Washington would be at pains to set a tight time limit on the largess -- say, 18 months. And the evidence suggests that a relatively small portion of any temporary windfall in take-home pay would be spent.
What is left? Plenty, in the view of economists itching to prove that an active fiscal policy still has a place in an era of $300 billion-plus budget deficits.
Grants to states and localities. No-strings Federal revenue sharing got a bad name in the 1970's because some governments used the cash for frills, or simply passed it through to residents as tax cuts. But the worm has turned. In the 1980's, Washington began demanding that localities provide expensive new services, notably health care, from their own resources. And these Federal mandates are proving particularly unwelcome in a recession that has drained local treasuries, forcing cutbacks in everything from library hours to pothole repair.
This largely explains why Robert Solow of M.I.T. and James Tobin of Yale have been pressing for across-the-board increases in aid to states and cities. Much of the money would be spent promptly, they believe -- and, most likely, on services that had earlier met the test of local taxpayer approval.
Investment tax credits. While the temporary nature of an income tax cut would no doubt undermine its efficacy as fiscal stimulus, a fixed expiration date for investment incentives would have the opposite effect.
Uncle Sam might, for example, offer a fat tax credit -- say 20 cents off next year's tax bill for every dollar invested in machinery. This would be equivalent to a 20 percent-off sale on new capital equipment, good only during the recession. And while most companies would have trouble planning and building new capacity on such short notice, many would happily accelerate plans already on the drawing board.
This is trickle-down economics -- albeit trickle-down at its best. And while the investment tax credit has loyal fans in both the Clinton and Bush camps, a tax break for which the immediate beneficiaries would be corporations would probably be resisted by some Congressional Democrats. Francis Bator, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, has a very different qualm. He believes tax subsidies that enhanced productivity are such a good idea for the slow-growth American economy that he is reluctant to offer them merely as a temporary antidote for recession.
Employment subsidies. If the main purpose of temporary tax breaks and increased spending in a recession is to create jobs, why not skip the middleman? Daniel Hamermesh, an economist at Michigan State University, wants to give tax credits to employers who hire additional workers -- say $2,000 for the first year. And the idea is reportedly receiving a good reception in Little Rock.
So modest a wage subsidy would really only make a difference for employers thinking about hiring low-wage workers. But that does not bother Mr. Hamermesh. Workers at the bottom, after all, have suffered the most during the recession.
Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, does not quarrel with this logic. But he is not convinced that the tax break would make much difference. In America's one brief experiment with temporary employment subsidies during the Carter Administration, he notes that roughly half the eligible employers did not even bother to claim the credit.
First-time home buyer's credit. Few economists get excited about this one, in part because plunging mortgage rates have already made houses more affordable, in part because they think there are higher-priority uses for deficit-busting tax benefits. But the idea of creating jobs for home builders by giving first-time buyers a leg up on the down payment is already part of the Bush Administration's recovery plan.
And with more than a little help from the housing lobby it could end up as part of the stimulus package next January, no matter who gains the lease on the White House.

HEADLINE: Japan Eases 57 Varieties Marketing

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Suntory Ltd., one of Japan's beverage giants, wants no thirst unquenched. It sells about 100 soft drinks, including a combination of celery and orange juice, another of the Caribbean acerola berry and lemon, a plum drink, a yogurt-flavored soda and a yogurt-flavored water, 11 types of canned tea including peach, and 10 different blends of canned coffee.
But that style of doing business is changing. Hurt by stagnant sales and the rising costs of capital, some Japanese companies are giving second thoughts to the longstanding notion that market share gains are the key to business success, and that product variations and rapid-fire product introductions are the best ways to get them. Variety has been a key competitive strategy for Japanese industries ranging from food products to electronics and automobiles. 
 But in an effort to cut development costs, some companies are starting to trim the variations in their product lines and slow the rate of product introductions. Some executives here say the change is part of a broader strategic shift that emphasizes profits rather than market share.
With the economy in the doldrums, consumers also seem less enamored of new products. "Consumers are focusing more on the genuine quality of the products," said Jiro Aoki, general manager of the domestic sales planning office of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.
If the trend gathers steam, it could make it easier for American companies to compete with the Japanese in industries like automobiles and electronics. In autos, for example, Japanese companies have traditionally introduced new models after four years, compared with five to ten years for American and European car makers. But now, Nissan and some smaller Japanese auto makers are beginning to lengthen the model cycle to five years or longer. Mazda is offering only one type of engine in its new RX-7 sports car instead of two and one type of wheel instead of six. For its new 929 luxury sedan, Mazda is offering 23 variations instead of the previous 96.
In electronics, Matsushita, known for its Panasonic brand, is reducing the number of models of television sets it offers by 30 to 40 percent and the variations among cooking appliances by 30 percent.
Sony, which offered televisions in 12 different sizes, has dropped its 27- and 31-inch offerings and might drop some smaller sizes as well. Mitsubishi Electric is shrinking its facsimile machine product line, which has included more than 20 models.
American companies, of course, also offer varieties of products. In personal computers, where technology is changing rapidly, American companies have generally been faster than the Japanese in introducing new models.
But in products in which technology is not changing as rapidly or at all, the Japanese seem to have elevated product proliferation to a fine art.
Take the humble pen and pencil, for instance. "We've got mechanical pencils that are so similar, I can't tell the difference, and yet it's a different name and different price point," said Ronald G. Shaw, a director of the Pilot Corporation of Japan and president of its American subsidiary.
Mr. Shaw said the Pilot Corporation of America chose to market a small subset of the pens and pencils sold by the parent company. "Our product catalogue in America has 10 to 12 pages," he said. "Theirs is a couple hundred pages. It's thick. It's a book."
Why so many products? "They claim the competition is doing it so therefore they have to do it," Mr. Shaw said.
Japanese executives say Japanese consumers love the latest products, a trait that manifested itself in the speed at which Japan modernized after being exposed to Western culture in the 1850's. In addition, they say, Japanese consumers pay attention to details in a way that Americans don't.
Japanese companies have evolved a system of competing by trying to cover every possible market niche to attain maximum market share. "The attitude of manufacturers, retailers and distributors has been to respond to all kinds of needs and requests from consumers," Mr. Aoki said.
In some cases, product introductions seem to serve as a substitute for pre-market testing. Suntory introduces 15 to 20 soft drinks a year, some completely new, some variations of existing products. About 90 percent fail and are withdrawn from the market in about a year, said Akihisa Hirabayashi, general manager of the planning department of Suntory's food and beverage division.
The economic boom in the late 1980's encouraged this trend as consumers, with money to spare, seemed easy to entice. "During the bubble era, anything new could attract consumers," Mr. Hirabayashi said.
To cope better with such demands, Japanese companies invested heavily in so-called flexible manufacturing systems, which allow more than one type of product to be manufactured on the same assembly line.
But even with these systems, the numerous product variations and rapid product introductions have put a strain on engineers and product designers and raised costs. Each different type of engine or seat in a car, for instance, requires a whole different set of crash tests for safety.
"We feel that we might have gone a little bit too far in making these varieties," said Teisuke Horio, general manager of the vehicle development management service center at Nissan, Japan's No. 2 auto maker. "Generally speaking, if you have more than 30 varieties, then 10 types cover 80 percent of the orders."
Mr. Horio is heading an effort to streamline the product line and to use more common parts in Nissan cars. Nissan has 22 car models, but 1,096 variations when the options in body type, transmission, engines and other factors are included. Some sell in very small amounts, but the company must still go through the expense of designing separate parts for them and stockpiling these parts for repairs later.
Nissan has two main categories of its Bluebird car in Japan that have almost no parts in common except the tires. In its entire product line, there are 500 different sizes, shapes, colors and textures of steering wheel, including 65 offered for just the Nissan Sunny alone.
Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry has also been encouraging the slowdown in product introductions and varieties, in part to help reduce working hours to bring Japan more in line with other advanced nations. In addition, the tendency of consumers to buy new electric appliances every few years and throw out the old ones is contributing to a tremendous garbage disposal problem in this crowded country.
 
Government Makes Survey
 How far the cutting will go is hard to quantify. In a survey of the product lines of 10 electronics companies in March, the trade ministry found that 211 models of televisions were being offered and that they remained on the market an average of 12 to 13 months. A new ministry survey projects those models will number only 192 by next March, when the model cycle will have lengthened to 14 months.
But the trimming of variation and slowdown in new model introduction is selective. Sony, for instance, still updates its 29- and 34-inch television models every year because these televisions are considered the main ones in the home and Sony wants to have as competitive a product as possible, said Tadao Kubodera, general manager of the TV group's Japan business division.
Not everyone is persuaded that cutbacks in variety are the way to go. Some auto dealers are calling on car makers to introduce some hot models to perk up the market. Indeed, with companies no longer able to rely on overall market growth, they must steal market share from others to grow. That could set off the product race all over again.

HEADLINE: U.S. Oil Production Down 5% in September

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Domestic oil production was 5 percent lower in September than in the corresponding month a year earlier, at just under seven million barrels a day, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday. This continued a string of reports that show increasing United States reliance on oil produced overseas.
The petroleum institute, the industry's main trade association, attributed part of the drop to Hurricane Andrew, which disrupted operations in the Gulf of Mexico and Louisiana, but noted that production for the first nine months was down 3.6 percent from the previous year. 
 Imports made up the difference, rising 7 percent, to 8.378 million barrels a day for the month. For the first three quarters of the year, imports were up 7.765 million barrels a day, up 1.1 percent over the period a year earlier, according to the Institute's monthly report. Taking account of inventory changes, imports are now supplying 45 to 46 percent of domestic demand, the institute said, or 7.7 million to 7.8 million barrels a day. The number of barrels imported is rising by about 6 percent annually.
Consistent with the recession, oil demand has been spotty, falling nine-tenth of 1 percent in September but rising 1.1 percent in the first three quarters of the year. The institute noted that deliveries had been increasing in recent quarters despite the recession, but for the third quarter had dropped seven-tenths of a percent, which the institute called disappointing. It said oil product deliveries for the third quarter had been under 16.9 million barrels a day.
Gasoline consumption may have been lower this summer because of the recession, the institute said, with vacations and recreational activities "curbed more than other types of travel by the sluggish economy."
Air travel boomed in the summer, but jet fuel deliveries were no higher than those of the previous year, because airlines filled seats that would otherwise have been empty rather than add flights, the report said.
Heavy fuel oil, used in electric generation, was down 21.4 percent in the third quarter, the report said, a sign of sluggish demand for electricity.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ames Sues Its Advisers on Zayre Bid

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Ames Department Stores Inc., which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in April 1990, said yesterday that it had sued its investment bankers for breach of fiduciary duty and professional malpractice in connection with the retailer's 1988 purchase of the Zayre Corporation.
Ames's acquisition of Zayre, a rival discount chain, for a total of $1.3 billion in cash and various forms of debt, is widely seen as the principal cause of its descent into bankruptcy. 
 The suit filed in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York named Wertheim Schroder & Company and its chairman, James A. Harmon. At the time of the Zayre transaction, Mr. Harmon also served as chairman of the Ames board.
 
Advice to Zayre at Issue
 In addition, Wertheim had been acting as an adviser to Zayre. The suit contends that early in 1988 Wertheim advised Zayre that the value of its discount store division was "hundreds of millions of dollars" less than the price the firm subsequently recommended that Ames's board pay.
The suit seeks to recover damages of around $400 million, including more than $20 million in investment banking fees.
Mr. Harmon resigned his membership on the Ames board of directors yesterday. Wertheim said it would vigorously contest the lawsuit.
Ames, which filed a reorganization plan in January and an amended plan on Sept. 3 to settle a total of $1.6 billion of estimated claims against the company, is still suffering as a result of the recession in the Northeast, where most of its remaining 369 discount department stores are situated. After it acquired Zayre's stores, Ames had more than 700 stores.
Ames reported a net loss in its second quarter ended July 25 of $36.2 million on revenues of $586.5 million.
 
Suit Called 'Groundless'
 In a statement, Wertheim said that Ames's latest proposed bankruptcy plan "relies in part on the unsubstantiated hope of proceeds from this groundless suit."
Whether or not Ames ultimately wins its case, the fact that Mr. Harmon was actively involved in the Zayre acquisition raised eyebrows at the time. The 57-year-old executive first took a seat on the Ames board in 1967, served as chairman from January 1988 until June 1990, and maintained a board seat until yesterday.
According to the lawsuit, Mr. Harmon and Peter Hollis, a former Zayre executive who in 1988 was Ames's chief executive, were proponents of the merger. Worried about Zayre's financial health as well as the apparent conflict of interest inherent in Mr. Harmon's involvement, Ames's co-founder, Herbert Gilman, and John Geisse, another board member, opposed the acquisition.
Mr. Gilman and Mr. Geisse have since died. Other board members did not return phone calls yesterday seeking comment.
John C. Coffee, Adolf Berle Professor of Law at Columbia Law School, said it was not a conflict for an investment banker to recommend a merger between two clients. But he said that Ames's charge that Wertheim withheld information about Zayre could be more serious. "As a director, disclosure of any material kind of information is required," he said.

HEADLINE: Digital, Scrambling Hard, Posts Loss of $260 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation said today that it had lost $260.5 million in its most recent quarter, showing the strains that the computer company is experiencing as it tries to change directions drastically in a sluggish economy.
The loss was bigger than what some analysts had expected for the nation's second-largest computer maker. Sales for the three-month period that ended on Sept. 26 totaled $3.3 billion, up slightly from $3.29 billion in the corresponding period last year. The period is Digital's first fiscal quarter. 
 John F. Smith, a Digital senior vice president, said that he did not expect revenue to increase significantly this fiscal year.
In the fiscal year that ended in June, Digital lost nearly $2.8 billion. That included a one-time charge to pay for thousands of job cuts.
Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., disclosed yesterday that it had cut 5,300 jobs in the first quarter, reducing the payroll to 108,500. Mr. Smith said he expected the company to slash even more jobs in the current quarter. The company eventually expects to shrink its payroll to fewer than 90,000 employees, according to plans confirmed by Digital's new president, Robert B. Palmer.
Digital's stock rose $1.375 a share today, to $37.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Palmer, who replaced the company's co-founder, Kenneth Olsen, this month, has also pledged to scale back Digital's computer offerings.
In its first quarter last year, Digital earned $11.6 million, or 9 cents a share, on its operations. But Digital reduced its earnings by $485 million to cover accounting changes for retirement benefits. That left a net loss for the quarter of $473.8 million.
Mr. Smith declined to predict when Digital would post profits again.
Digital also said that it had borrowed $250 million last week through debt securities. Company officials said that this would give Digital more financial flexibility. Digital, which traditionally shied away from debt, said in August that it would be willing to borrow up to $1 billion.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Join Retail Sales in 0.3% Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
In continued evidence of meager economic growth, retail sales edged three-tenths of 1 percent higher in September amid subdued inflation, the Government said today.
Still, the rise in sales in September, aided to some extent by rebuilding in Florida and Louisiana after Hurricane Andrew, combined with an upward revision in the August sales figure to dampen hopes of an imminent cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve. 
 "The economy is still moving ahead, though very slowly," commented Edward Guay, a senior economist for the Cigna Corporation, the Connecticut-based insurer.
The Producer Price Index for finished goods climbed three-tenths of 1 percent, keeping the inflation gauge for the latest 12 months at the same 1.6 percent pace it averaged in July and August. Excluding the volatile food and energy components, the index rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department calculated.
Gains in retail sales, which account for one-third of economic activity, were concentrated last month in durable goods, which climbed to $58.74 billion from $58.27 billion, the Commerce Department reported. This was a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent. Sales of nondurables inched down one-tenth of 1 percent, to $102.39 billion.
But while the aftermath of the hurricane undoubtedly pushed sales totals higher, the department could not quantify the impact.
Not only were many forces, including some negatives, at work, but today's so-called advance report was also based on a relatively small sample of 3,000 retailers. Next month's "preliminary" estimate of September sales will cover 12,000 outlets, while the final tally will cover 22,000.
This also helps explain the frequent, substantial revisions of the figures, which now show August retail sales unchanged instead of down five-tenths of 1 percent.
The biggest hurricane effect was seen in a 2.6 percent sales jump reported by merchants in building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes. This followed a 1.5 percent decline in August, a result largely unaffected by the hurricane since it occurred one week before the end of the month.
Sales of furniture, home furnishings and equipment climbed 1.9 percent in September, and there appeared to be at least minor hurricane-related sales gains in the four-tenths of 1 percent increase for automotive dealers.
Ronald Piencykoski, a Commerce Department specialist, pointed, for example, to people leasing recreational vehicles as substitutes for lost homes.
On the other hand, sales of some nondurables, including food and clothing, appeared to have been cut by the storm, partly reflecting the appearance of soup kitchens and donated items.
Sales declined 1.5 percent at the nation's food stores last month while sales at restaurants and bars eased two-tenths of 1 percent. There was no change at drug and proprietary stores, but solid gains were recorded by department and other general-merchandise stores, which enjoyed a five-tenths of 1 percent increase, and by gasoline service stations and apparel and accessory stores, both up 1.9 percent.
 
Caution on Storm
 Mr. Piencykoski cautioned against overestimating the effects of the hurricane, noting that Dade County, Fla., the area hardest hit, accounts for only seven-tenths of 1 percent of national sales.
Last month's retail spending was 4.4 percent higher than that of September 1991, but this does not make allowance for price changes. Consumer inflation has run at a 3.1 percent pace over the 12 months through August. The Consumer Price Index for September is to be published Thursday.
Though the consensus among private economists was that the economy was showing little improvement, the Bush Administration welcomed today's report. In a statement, Commerce Secretary Barbara Hackman Franklin said sales for the third quarter, which rose at an annual rate of 5.3 percent, represented a "solid increase" from the second-quarter annual pace of nine-tenths of 1 percent and was "evidence of an ongoing recovery" in the economy at large.
Today's inflation report covering prices received by producers was marked by an eight-tenths of 1 percent surge in the price of energy, mainly gasoline, and a 4.3 percent jump in the price of tobacco prices. Food rose four-tenths of 1 percent, but there were sizable declines for passenger cars, prescription drugs, periodicals and soaps and detergents.
Prices at the intermediate stage of production edged up two-tenths of 1 percent after two months of no change. Energy and feeds gained in price while construction materials rose slightly more than in August. Prices declined for both durable and nondurable materials used in manufacturing.
Goods at the crude level rose 1.6 percent following two months of negligible or no change, the report said.

HEADLINE: Gun Control Is Crucial Issue In Challenge to Congressman

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMMONTON, N.J., Oct. 13

 BODY:
Two years ago, the political hold that William J. Hughes exercised in the Second Congressional District in South Jersey was so formidable that the Republicans did not even bother to field a candidate against him.
This year, things are different. Buoyed by anti-incumbent feeling across the nation and opposition to Gov. Jim Florio that swept Republicans into control of both houses of the Legislature last year for the first time in two decades, Assemblyman Frank LoBiondo is mounting an aggressive and energetic campaign that has Mr. Hughes in his toughest fight in years. 
 It also has had its nasty elements, with fliers circulating in the sprawling, semirural hunting area that picture a saluting Adolf Hitler above the words: "Everyone in favor of gun control raise your right hand. Dump Bill Hughes."
Mr. LoBiondo has vigorously denied any connection with the fliers, whose origin remains a mystery, and has publicly denounced them.
 
Heads Panel on Crime
 Still the candidates' positions have kept the issue very much alive. Mr. Hughes, a Democrat now in his ninth term, is chairman of the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime, which has produced a series of gun-control measures.
Mr. LoBiondo was the primary sponsor of a bill to repeal the tough ban on the sale and possession of military-style semiautomatic firearms that was approved by the Legislature in 1990. Governor Florio vetoed the measure earlier this year and the Legislature has not yet tried to override the veto.
Voters in the Second District are no strangers to battles over gun issues.
Members of the National Rifle Association and its New Jersey affiliate, the Coalition of New Jersey Sports, were instrumental in causing the defeat and ultimate retirement from the Legislature of Assemblyman Edward H. Salmon in a bid for the State Senate in 1990. They also made a strong but unsuccessful attempt to help defeat State Senator William L. Gormley in the primary last year.
The Congressional race has escalated the battle. The National Rifle Association, in a mailing to its South Jersey members in May, urged them to "register and vote for Frank LoBiondo to win on June 2 in the primary and in November."
The letter urged members to "send a signal from New Jersey to the rest of the nation that 18 years of Bill Hughes is too much."
 
'A Disgrace'
 Mr. LoBiondo has refused to accept contributions from the National Rifle Association, lest he be accused of playing up to the association, and has termed the issuing of the Hitler flier, the origin of which remains a mystery, "a disgrace."
"I did not know about it until The Atlantic City Press called me about it," he said. "I decried it, I condemned it. It has no place in our campaign or anybody else's."
He accused Mr. Hughes of trying to divert the campaign from vital issues.
"I wanted a discussion of the economy, jobs, health care, the deficit, a balanced budget, Congressional reform," he said.
Mr. LoBiondo, 46 years old, of Vineland, operates the family trucking business in Deerfield and represents an Assembly district that includes Cape May County and parts of Atlantic and Cumberland Counties. He has focused his campaign on "the need to change the way Congress does business," assailing the incumbent for his votes against the balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution and in favor of the Congressional pay raise.
The 59-year-old Mr. Hughes said he opposed a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget because it would allow "an unelected judiciary to set national priorities." Instead, he has proposed legislation that would require the President to submit a balanced budget and forbid Congress to consider any budget in which spending exceeded revenues, except in times of declared war or national emergency.
He said he voted for the pay raise because the legislation also called for elimination of honorariums and other outside income.
Mr. Hughes, who retained all of his old district with some new areas added by redistricting, returns there every weekend, even when the House is in session. He is running largely on his record in Congress, including his role in drafting major crime measures in 1984 and 1986 and anti-drug legislation in 1986 and 1988.
He is the author of legislation banning "cop killer" ammunition that can pass through police body armor, and of a ban on the manufacturing of machine guns for private use and of plastic firearms that can pass through metal detectors.
Despite these actions, he said in an interview on Monday that he was not an anti-gun candidate. "I am a hunter myself, and I own guns myself," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Beer Companies Shift Their Focus to, of All Things, Taste

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
"BEER Is Back" proclaims the Coors advertising campaign for its Extra Gold.
That may be overstating things a bit, in light of the fact that beer has been with us since medieval times. But the sentiment points up a noteworthy shift among the leading brewers to focus increasingly on their products' taste, rather than on less tangible imagery. 
 Besides the Coors Extra Gold campaign, Anheuser-Busch has woven a new theme into its "Why Ask Why?" campaign for Bud Dry: "Easy like a light, and has real draft taste." For its core Budweiser brand, the brewer has developed its "Beer Talk" campaign, in which elder loyal Budweiser drinkers educate two young beer drinkers on why Budweiser is the best-tasting beer.
And the Miller Brewing Company touts its barley beer, Miller Reserve, with commercials that urge drinkers, "Taste what barley does for a beer."
To help point up the bolder taste of their beers, both Coors and Miller have brewed a darker beer. Miller Reserve is darker because barley is the only grain used, and Coors achieves this effect by roasting barley longer than usual for its Extra Gold. In the Coors "Beer Is Back" campaign, the difference in color is highlighted with frequent shots of clear mugs of Budweiser and Extra Gold side-by-side on beer trays.
Selling a beer's taste is by no means new. The major breweries' advertising has long included tales of the hallowed processes used to brew their beers. But these have been relatively minor notes sounded in the commercials favored in the last couple of decades. In the 1970's and early 1980's, campaigns for core brands like Budweiser and Miller focused most intensely on telling drinkers that their brands were the perfect reward for a hard day's work, with congratulatory taglines of "This Bud's for You" and "It's Miller Time." As light beers grew, many brewers started suggesting that their beers were key ingredients to successful parties for thin and muscled twentysomethings.
None of these themes are going away, but brewers are embracing taste for a couple of reasons. First, sales of domestic premium beers are flagging -- Budweiser declined 5.8 percent in 1991 -- as their many older drinkers quaff less and younger drinkers choose other brands. And their choices are helping fuel swift, although still minuscule, sales of heartier microbrewery beers, like the Boston Beer Company's Samuel Adams brand, and of imported beers.
The straits for the big domestic brewers were made plain in late summer by a regional advertising campaign by Anheuser-Busch's Natural Light brand that called into question the integrity of the Coors Rocky Mountain heritage. Its commercials said that Coors shipped dense beer from its Colorado brewery by tanker car to a plant in Elkton, Va., where local water was added. Now Anheuser-Busch has extended that attack by running similar spots for its Michelob Light brand that challenge Coors.
Why are beer drinkers gravitating to products with a little more heft?
Industry executives and analysts suggest that this trend is in keeping with these half-empty economic times. Simply put, consumers seem to want a basic, tangible reason for buying one product over another. "We want to get back to more rational points of difference," said August Busch 4th, Anheuser-Busch's vice president of Budweiser brands.
Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., a consulting firm, added that consumers were favoring tastier beers for the same kinds of reasons that Ross Perot gained many followers last spring. "Consumers are more pragmatic," he said. "They want products that really deliver, and they're not buying open and empty images."
Mr. Pirko said this trend was also reflected in the beverage industry over all, where fledgling brands with a bold taste, like Clearly Canadian fruit-flavored soda, are selling well. Industry executives said that in light of the collective mood of Americans, taste -- as opposed to life-style images -- would probably be an important selling point for some time to come. "People want to just enjoy beer for the pleasure of drinking beer," said Gary Skovsted, the Coors brand director for Extra Gold.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Are Down on Money Market Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds fell in the latest weekly survey of 862 funds by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
The decline was more apparent in tax-exempt funds, where yields had recently reached levels that made them competitive with taxable funds and had prompted cash inflows into the tax-exempt funds over the last few weeks. 
 Assets of tax-exempt money funds rose by $1.3 billion for the week, to a total of $96.8 billion, with the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios unchanged at 67, IBC/Donoghue's analysts said.
 
Tax-Exempt Yield: 2.53%
 The seven-day average compounded yield for the tax-exempts dropped 14 basis points, to 2.53 percent, with the simple yield down 33 basis points, to 2.31 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point. Over a 30-day period the average compounded and simple yields were both down 22 basis points, to 2.36 percent and 2.33 percent, respectively.
Not factoring in state taxes, the figures mean that the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield is 3.51 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 3.66 percent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket.
In the weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee, was the best-performing fund with a yield of 3.05 percent.
 
Taxable Yield: 2.81%
 For taxable money market funds, the yield decline was much softer, as total assets rose by $850 million, to $487.3 billion. Analysts said the tapering off of the cash inflow was a signal that the drop in yields was ending for this round at least. But they still expect one more decline in the Federal funds rate and, as a result, another drop in money fund yields.
The total cash inflow into the taxable funds was pulled down by a $350 million outflow of cash from institutional assets, to a total $169.4 billion, while retail assets grew by $1.2 billion, to $317.9 billion.
The average seven-day compounded yield for taxable money market funds was down 6 basis points, to 2.81 percent, and the simple yield was off a similar amount, to 2.77 percent. Over a 30-day period the average compounded yield fell 4 basis points, to 2.88 percent, with the simple yield off 3 basis points, to 2.4 percent.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios remained at 65.
The Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, was the top returner among general-purpose funds, with a yield of 3.85 percent -- the same yield offered by United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services in San Antonio in the usually higher government-only funds with assets under $100 million.
For comparative purposes, the average bank money market account this week yielded 2.81 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
3 Big Banks Post Sharp Income Gain

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Large banking companies are reporting sharp increases in earnings, their problems with delinquent loans having abated at the same time that low interest rates have padded their profit margins.
Three of the nation's 25 largest banking companies reported sharp third-quarter gains yesterday -- the Bank of New York Company, up 66.1 percent; the Wachovia Corporation, up 21.3 percent, and the First Fidelity Bankcorporation, up 48.8 percent -- indicating that 1992 will be a record year. These companies were not among the hardest hit by loan defaults the last few years, but like the rest of the industry, they are recovering from a sharp increase in bad loans that they suffered in 1990. 
 "The industry trend is essentially the same as for the past several quarters -- lending margins are wide, loan demand is weak and loan losses are tapering off," said Judah Kraushaar, a banking analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. He noted, however, that commercial real estate loans were still a problem for many banks, particilarly in California, where large banks have not yet reported third-quarter profits.
While the level of badly delinquent loans remains unusually high at most banks, those problems have been made easier to bear by declining interest rates. By reducing the interest rates they pay on deposits more quickly than the rates charged on loans, banks have earned the profits they needed to cover losses on bad loans made in the 1980's, and accumulate more capital so that they are in a stronger position to absorb unexpected losses in the future.
Following are the details of the banks' results:
 
Bank of New York
 At the Bank of New York, third-quarter profits of $98 million, or $1.12 a share, were up from $59 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier. Non-performing assets, consisting of badly delinquent loans and others that are not expected to be repaid in full, plus real estate acquired through foreclosure, fell $75 million, to $1.027 billion at midyear, and are well below the $1.57 billion total a year ago. At the same time the Bank of New York has increased its reserves to 125 percent of its most troubled loans, from about 89 pecent a year ago.
The company added that its profits were helped by good growth in its back-office processing for securities and mutual funds where revenues of $115 million in the third quarter were 15 pecent greater than a year ago. Service charges and other fees levied on depositors and other customers grew 20 percent in the last year to $110 million in the third quarter.
 
Wachovia
 The Wachovia Corporation, Winston-Salem, N.C., earned $108.8 million, or $1.26 a share, up from $89.7 million, or $1.04 a share, a year earlier.
"We are seeing some pockets of loan growth, mainly in the consumer area," said Robert S. McCoy, chief financial officer at Wachovia. He said growth had been "excellent" in the credit card business, where it has been offering cards with an 8.9 pecent rate to customers with a good credit rating. But business borrowers remain scarce, Mr. McCoy said, as some companies are paying off their loans as fast as others are borrowing.
Wachovia has one of the banking industry's best records for avoiding bad loans, but was still hit with an increase in problems in 1990. In the third quarter, nonperforming assets totaled $280.4 million, down $9.3 million from midyear and $40.9 million from a year ago.
 
First Fidelity
 First Fidelity Bancorporation, Newark, earned $82.3 million, or $1.01 a share, up about from $55.3 million, or 81 cents a share, a year ago. Non-performing loans and foreclosed real estate fell to $751.2 million, down $58.52 million from midyear and $220.7 million from a year ago. While loans declined to $16.67 billion from $17.21 billion at midyear, First Fidelity was able to increase earnings because of a wider interest margin. The difference between rates paid on deposits and rates earned on loans and investments grew to 4.73 percent in the latest quarter from 4.59 percent in the second quarter of this year. The company, which has been an active buyer of deposits from failed savings and loans and banks, now has consumer deposits totaling $23.2 billion, or about $6.5 billion more than it has in loans.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sales of U.S.-Built Vehicles Rise by 6.1%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose 6.1 percent in early October, although automotive demand remained weighted down by uncertainty over the economy and the Presidential election.
In results reported today, car sales dropped 5.7 percent, to 151,224, but sales of light trucks, which include mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickups, rose 29.7 percent, to 103,271, from a year ago. Over all, vehicle sales totaled 254,495, compared with 239,894 last year. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales for the period Oct. 1-10 was a sluggish 5.8 million, down from 6.8 million in late September but up from the 5.5 million rate of last year in early October.
"It's a microscopic recovery, with all the strength in the light-truck sector," said David Healy, automotive analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company in New York.
The General Motors Corporation posted an 11.4 percent decline in car sales, to 63,723, but a 24.7 percent increase in light trucks, to 39,704. G.M.'s weakness in car sales was pronounced in the Chevrolet, Oldsmobile and Cadillac divisions. Sales of the Chevy Caprice, Olds 98 and Cadillac DeVille cars were off sharply from a year ago.
 
G.M.'s Light-Truck Market
 In the light-truck market, G.M.'s full-size pickup and full-size sport utility vehicle sold strongly.
The Ford Motor Company notched an 8.2 percent increase in car sales, to 51,425, and a 35 percent increase in light-truck sales, to 35,702.
Jerry Roberts, general manager of Morris Ford-Mercury in Burnt Hills, N.Y. cited continued strong sales of the Ford Explorer sport-utility vehicle. "We stocked a lot of inventory, but as I look down the road they're going to be harder and harder to come by for 1993," he said.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated that car sales for the Chrysler Corporation rose 12.2 percent, to 15,600, in early October; the trade letter estimated that Chrysler's light-truck sales rose 25.3 percent, to 22,300, in the period. Chrysler posts sales only once a month. Chrysler dealers have reported a great deal of interest in the auto maker's new L/H midsize models.
John Johnson, an owner of Chrysler franchises in Kingfisher, Okla., said he had six L/Hs on order, and had received only two so far: "We'll take as many as we can get," he said, acknowledging, however, that "business is pretty slow."
Two large Japanese auto makers, the Honda Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Corporation, reported sharply lower sales, as a result of higher prices and competitive models from the Big Three. Honda's domestic car sales reached 7,906 for the period, down 42 percent. Toyota's domestic car sales dropped 30.1 percent, to 5,782. Toyota's light-truck sales reached 2,138 in late October; last year's domestic light-truck sales, the auto maker's first, were insignificant.
The Nissan Motor Company, which recently introduced its Altima compact sedan, sold 2,940 domestic cars, up 84 percent from last year. But Nissan's domestically built light-truck sales slipped 9.5 percent, to 2,270.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Coca-Cola Earnings Up 18.5% in Quarter

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that third-quarter profits increased 18.5 percent, despite cold weather that hurt the soft drink industry's sales and weak economies in important markets.
Earnings were $540.6 million, or 41 cents a share, compared with $456.3 million, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed 11 percent, to $3.51 billion from $3.17 billion. 
 Roberto C. Goizueta, the chairman and chief executive, said, "All this was accomplished in a quarter in which key markets had unfavorable weather and/or economic conditions." He said the economies of important world markets were either very soft or "in depression."
 
U.S. Volume Up
 In the United States, unit soft drink volume sold to retail and fountain customers grew more than 2 percent, and gallon shipments of concentrates and syrups increased 1 percent in the third quarter. The company said Coca-Cola brands in the United States grew faster than the soft drink industry as a whole in the quarter, resulting in expanded market share.
The earnings were in line with expectations, and Coke's stock climbed 62.5 cents a share, to $38.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
In the Northeast Europe and Africa group, case sales grew 10 percent, and gallon sales increased 5 percent.
In the European Community, case sales fell 1 percent. Growth of 4 percent in Germany was offset by declines of 13 percent in Britain, reflecting the dismal economy there. Case sales fell 19 percent in France, where volume was affected by a price increase as well as the weak economy. Case sales in Japan were flat.
In the third quarter, unit case volume in Latin America decreased 4 percent. Unit case volume in Argentina and Mexico grew 20 percent and 5 percent, respectively, partly offsetting a 29 percent decrease in Brazil.
At Coca-Cola Foods, which makes Minute Maid orange juice, operating income increased during the third quarter as higher margins offset slightly lower volumes. Volume for all juice and juice-drink products in the third quarter dropped 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 5.94 Amid Unease Over I.B.M.

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday, driven down by a late wave of computerized sell programs and weakness in I.B.M. shares, reversing two days of gains.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 5.94 points to close at 3,195.48. Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered gainers, 885 to 823. Volume was 175.9 million shares, compared with 186.7 million on Tuesday. 
 Richard Meyer of Ladenburg Thalmann said that when I.B.M. "started to become unglued," the rest of the market followed suit.
I.B.M. fell 3/4, to 78. Traders said the slip was apparently fueled by jitters ahead of the company's third-quarter results expected today.
"I think the market got a little ahead of itself," said Robert Walberg, an analyst at MMS International, referring to the two previous days of gains.
 
Downward Trend
 Alfred Goldman, at A. G. Edwards, said: "We worked off the oversold condition, and so it was time to go back to the primary short-term trend, which is down.
"I assume the message of the market is that earnings are going to be disappointing. The market still hasn't finished worrying about a President Clinton, the state of the economy and whether corporate earnings would be good as the market was betting they would be."
Among other issues, United States Surgical roared ahead 8 1/4, to 64 3/4. The company cited positive reactions to its new laparoscopic product and surgical staples at an analysts meeting. Dean Witter repeated a buy recommendation.
Xerox rose 1, to 78 1/8. It agreed to sell its Van Kampen Merritt money management unit for $360 million.
Springs Industries slumped 5 1/8, to 32 7/8, after reporting third-quarter results. Prudential cut estimates on the company.
Coca-Cola rose 5/8, to 38 1/2. Kidder, Peabody raised its rating to hold from sell after the company reported that third-quarter earnings rose 18.5 percent.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.07 point, to 409.37. The American Stock Exchange index fell 0.66, to 366.17.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.08, to 225.39. The Nasdaq index of over-the-counter issues fell 0.22, to 576.22.
