HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Depressed by Signs Germany Plans No Rate Cut

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower yesterday in moderate trading on world currency markets.
Gold prices were mixed overseas but declined in domestic dealings. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $342.80 an ounce, off $1.20. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $1.05 an ounce, to a late price of $342.75. 
 Traders said the dollar was depressed by word that Germany's central bank did not plan a news conference after today's regularly scheduled meeting of its policy-making council. The news dashed hopes of many dealers that the Bundesbank would announce a cut in interest rates after the meeting.
"That really prevented the dollar from going higher," said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "Interest-rate differentials have stopped narrowing, and that hurts the dollar."
High interest rates overseas make foreign fixed-income securities more attractive to investors.
 
2 Sluggish Reports
 On the domestic front, the Government released two reports that pointed to a continuing sluggish economy. The Labor Department said wholesale prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September, the biggest increase in five months. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in September.
The data were within market expectations but prevented the dollar from gaining ground nonetheless, Mr. Holzer said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 121.10 yen, down 0.50 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 121.05. In New York the dollar settled at 121.02 yen, down from 121.10 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7085, from $1.7165 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.7065 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.7160.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.4605 German marks, down from 1.4640; 1.3015 Swiss francs, down from 1.3068; 4.9620 French francs, down from 4.9760; 1,290.50 Italian lire, down from 1,297.50, and 1.2480 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2440.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.4625 German marks, down from 1.4690; 1.3035 Swiss francs, down from 1.3120.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Steel Mills Hope For Higher Prices

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
THE flood of trade litigation undertaken by the nation's largest steelmakers against foreign steel producers is certain to have a profound impact on the American companies, besides keeping their lawyers busy for months. Analysts say the complaints, when resolved, will significantly help steel companies in the United States gain price increases.
In a battery of complaints, the nation's biggest steel companies have charged that foreign companies are selling steel in the United States at unfairly low prices. The Government, analysts contend, is likely to side with the American producers and begin assessing duties on steel brought into the United States from countries that are found to be judged as dumping subsidized steel. 
 "If most of the trade cases proceed, I expect prices to go up by as much as 10 percent," said John Jacobson, president of Jacobson & Associated, a Philadelphia-based steel consulting firm. "The availability of imported products has kept prices below what they would have been otherwise. If you take that away, you're going to see upward movement in prices, and that's the objective of big steel companies.
For American steelmakers, who are selling many products at prices lower than those of two years ago, the prospect of higher steel prices is particularly cheery. Most big steel companies reported huge losses for the first half and are expected to suffer deep deficits for the entire year.
Cold-rolled steel, for example, which is used in everything from automobiles and appliances to construction, sells for about $420 a ton, compared with an average price of $540 three years ago. Structural steel, used widely in high-rise construction and bridges, costs about $180 a ton, half its price two years ago.
Steelmakers are hardly waiting for the impact of the trade litigation to take effect, since decisions on the most significant disputes might not be reached until the spring. Two large companies, USX's steel division and the LTV Corporation, said last week that they would raise prices, beginning next year.
The question is whether the price increases will take hold. Some analysts contend that only with economic improvement will those price increases remain firm. "They do have a chance with this proposed price increase," Mr. Jacobson said. "With the prospect of some economic recovery coupled with the prospect of the impact of the trade cases, they have an opportunity to see price increases."
Even if these price increases hold, there is no shortage of doubters about how long they will benefit the large companies. Many people in the industry contend that the gains by major producers might be short-lived, even if the higher prices cause the level of imported steel to recede. Indeed, there are several repercussions to the trade litigation that could add to the problems of the domestic industry. For one thing, while higher steel prices may lead to profits for the major producers, they are also likely to spur more smaller steel companies, known as mini-mills, to begin making products that compete more directly with big steel companies.
Those products, principally the sheet steel that goes into automobiles and appliances, are now the domain of the large companies, including USX, Bethlehem Steel and LTV. Mini-mill producers typically make steel from scrap and produce lower-quality products with smaller work forces that receive lower wages. But in recent years, Nucor, the largest of the mini-mills, has begun producing small amounts of sheet steel at a new plant.
Mr. Jacobson and other analysts said they expected several mini-mills to move aggressively into the flat-rolled market, which is more lucrative, adding that the prospect of higher prices would probably help them make that decision.
James Todd, chairman of the Birmingham Steel Corporation, a mini-mill steel producer based in Birmingham, Ala., said his company had been considering building mills that would produce sheet steel for automobiles and appliances but added that the prospect of high prices had not necessarily been a factor in the company's analysis.
"We are very much committed to evaluating the flat-rolled market and we will probably conclude that we will want to get into that market," Mr. Todd said. "I fully expect some modest price increase."
There is also the issue of how foreign shipments to the United States will be affected by the pending litigation. Charles A. Bradford, a steel analyst with UBS Securities, said he expected foreign steel producers to intensify their shipments to the United States in anticipation of the Government's imposing penalties at a later time. "The dumping litigation is probably harmful to the industry in the United States," Mr. Bradford said.
"The foreign steel companies expect a negotiated political settlement, like the American Government imposing some sort of quota," he added. "So, for the meantime, they want as high a level of shipments as possible in the United States. For the next few months, there will be more steel coming in than might be the case normally."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Chairman To Be Released

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Robert C. Stempel, was expected to be released on Thursday from a Washington hospital after a health problem caused by elevated blood pressure was corrected, the company said today.
G.M. said Mr. Stempel, 59 years old, planned to resume work on Friday. It said doctors at George Washington University Medical Center upgraded his condition to good from serious this afternoon after several tests. 
 Mr. Stempel was admitted after becoming ill on Tuesday while he was in a meeting at the Willard Hotel in Washington.
He took over the top job at G.M. two years ago and is running the world's biggest vehicle maker at a tough time. The weak economy has stifled sales, and competitors, particularly the Japanese, continue to win customers, cutting G.M.'s share of the North American market.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Hits New High

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 14

 BODY:
After slowly building for nearly two years, Japan's trade surplus with the United States and the rest of the world soared to an all-time high in September, in spite of numerous Japanese Government pledges to take measures to bring its trade into balance.
The surplus is having a particularly pronounced effect now because the Japanese and American economies are both weak, and the Governments are struggling to stimulate growth. The growing surplus is providing a major lift to the Japanese, while proving a drain on the American economy.
 
Worldwide Surplus Up 25 Percent
 Some business leaders and economists said that the prospects of further growth in Japan's surplus was thus setting the stage for more serious clashes between Tokyo and Washington when attention turns from the Presidential election to the nuts and bolts of America's economic problems. 
 Japan's worldwide surplus rose 25 percent in September from a year earlier to a record $12.1 billion, the Finance Ministry reported. The surplus with the United States reached $4.84 billion for the month, and $30.4 billion in the first nine months of this year, also a record.
The figures released today are measured on what is known as a customs-cleared basis. They do not include various expenses, including insurance and freight. If the surplus were measured with all the costs included, called the balance of payments basis, it would be from 20 percent to 30 percent larger. Those figures, the most commonly cited, are not expected for several weeks, but they are also likely to show yawning Japanese surpluses.
What the trade imbalance signifies for Americans is that "we are losing our competitiveness and at a fairly rapid rate, far more than most people believe," said Joseph T. Gorman, chairman of TRW Inc., a major technology company and auto parts manufacturer, and chairman of the U.S.-Japan Business Council.
Mr. Gorman said that he felt his council was making progress in cooperating with Japanese companies to increase their imports of American goods, but that he was frustrated at how little tangible progress was being made even after years of effort.
The problem is underscored by the fact that Japan's surplus is responsible for most of the country's current economic expansion, which nevertheless is meager, while helping keep America's growth at an anemic pace, economists say.
Robert Alan Feldman, economist here for Salomon Brothers Asia, said Japan's trade surplus would provide about 60 percent of the country's expected growth rate of 1.5 percent this year. "Trade almost totally accounts for their growth now," Mr. Feldman said.
In the first half of Japan's fiscal year, which began April 1, Japan's surplus with all regions of the world jumped sharply, a major feat considering that the global economy is in a slowdown. Demand is weak, but the formidable positions that Japanese manufacturers have built in markets around the world are paying off.
Japan's customs-cleared surplus with the United States in that six-month period rose 22 percent, to $21.2 billion. The surplus with Asia hit a high of $20.9 billion, a 26 percent increase from the period a year earlier, while the surplus with the European Community jumped 22 percent, to $16.3 billion, the Finance Ministry reported.
In the first nine months of the year, Japan's customs-cleared exports totaled $248.6 billion, an 11 percent increase from the first nine months of last year. Imports rose 8.4 percent during the same period to $164.8 billion.
That left the overall surplus for the period at $83.8 billion, a big increase from $71.8 billion in the first nine months of 1991.
 
Measures to Cut the Surplus
 Since 1985 Japan has agreed to a number of measures aimed at reducing the surpluses, but they seem to have had a modest impact at best.
In September 1985, James A. Baker 3d, then the Treasury Secretary, engineered a nearly 50 percent reduction in the value of the dollar against the yen, an agreement known as the Plaza Accord. One of the principal results of that was to cause Japanese acquisitions of American companies and real estate, from film studios to a partial interest in Rockefeller Center, to soar because the yen bought so many more dollars.
The two sides entered a long and occasionally bitter series of negotiations to open Japanese markets and encourage Japanese imports. Japanese companies moved billions of dollars worth of production capacity overseas, putting auto plants in Tennessee and electronics factories in Malaysia, for example.
In addition, the Japanese Government agreed to stimulate its economy, an attempt to increase imports and curtail exports by getting the Japanese to consume more at home. The results of all this have not been impressive, as evidenced by this year's rising surpluses.

HEADLINE: Designers Show Off, But Not Too Much

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
ONE is a show house on a shoestring; the other is a not-too-showy show house.
As these things go, both seem to be contradictions in terms. 
 At the Royal Oak Showhouse in Manhattan, which opens today, decorators tried to behave themselves and hold on to their checkbooks.
In Roxbury, Conn., the 1992 Litchfield County Designer Showhouse is in a spanking new 10,000-square-foot mansion designed by Rod Thorne and David Cleaves called Raven Cliffs. It's for sale. Even with 30,000 square feet of new sod outside, it is understated for its $3.9 million price tag.
"We insisted on the importance of being sensitive to economic realities," said Chris Casson Madden, one of the organizers of the Royal Oak Showhouse. "We felt it was possible for good design to live within practical budgetary constraints," she added, and smiled just a bit.
David Easton, a decorator known for his luxurious Upper East Side rooms, made a valiant effort to keep it simple and inexpensive. He even went bargain hunting. "David shopped the Lower East Side for the fabrics," said John Christensen, who worked with Mr. Easton on the multipurpose studio apartment that anchors the fifth floor.
"What's $50 a yard net in the D & D Building is $11 a yard downtown," Mr. Christensen added. He also pointed out a screen covered with $3-a-yard fabric and the beige and white striped cotton and linen fabric that was hung from the walls on grommets. "That's about $6 a yard," he said. "Budget is what's it's all about," he continued, especially proud of the floor-to-ceiling Masonite fireplace wall that was painted to look like patinated bronze.
But what about the tony brass lamps that swing out from the mantelpiece? "Not on the budget," Mr. Christensen said with a shrug. "But we just couldn't do without them."
Budgetary concessions took interesting turns. Billy W. Francis used a draped table instead of a pricey antique in the palatial second-floor dining room, and he covered the floor with a raffia-and-cotton rug instead of a fine Oriental. Never mind that the lavish floral centerpiece made up for his frugality.
Mariette Himes Gomez had bedrooms in both houses. Her stately bedroom at Raven Cliffs bordered on the stodgy. In Manhattan she chose overscale accessories and vintage photographs for an elegant and laid-back setup. "White is a color," she decreed in the third-floor room, in which the bed had an Empire double headboard, gilded.
"I'm already turning toward silver instead of gold," Ms. Gomez said. "That's paring down, isn't it?" She added in a whisper, "And if you use big things, you don't have to use so many."
Just try not to covet the lavish bed linens.
Some decorators used wit as one decorating element that's not priced by the yard. Nina Campbell added monkeys to her new fabric and placed animal topiaries atop the paneled bookcases in the baronial library.
Mark Zeff paired paintings of nude men on the walls with prints of antique shoes. "I wanted to fill the space with what I call "eccentric and funny ideas," said the New York designer in the game room he set up on the second-floor landing. "It's almost as if someone would have collected these strange things that don't work together. I just don't know what these things have to do with each other."
Let's just move on to Natasha Bergreen and Liza Spierenburg's cedar closet transformed into a rough-hewn kitchenette on the fifth floor, where a knife and fork are pulled (and pushed) into service as door handles.
Then there's the bar on the third floor that's stocked with mineral water and baby food. "I dedicated it to Murphy Brown," said Brett Nestler, its designer. "She doesn't drink and she's just had a baby, but you know that, of course," she said.
"I call it affordable collecting," said Craig Raywood of his fourth-floor music room where the walls were painted in trompe-l'oeil tortoise shell and ivory. Mr. Raywood advised hanging "a little Beatles thing on the wall instead of a Picasso."
He went further. Under an antique French train luggage rack filled with a medley of musical instruments was an enviable array of musical memorabilia -- photographs and autographs, from Satchmo to Elvis to Callas. "I sing, so this was a natural," Mr. Raywood said.
So was a fantasy realized by the English designer Helen Cooper. "This is my reinterpretation of the folly at Montacute House," she said of the foyer, a sort of baronial hall on a budget. Ms. Cooper has been obsessed with a particular Elizabethan estate for quite some time.
The walls, of her secret-recipe plaster, were painted with red and white lozenges. "Elizabethan colors are meant to last forever," she said.
Earphones, a television, popcorn, an easy chair, a floor of mound moss below and the sky above were the stuff of Paul Bott's fantasy living room on the roof. There was even an outdoor shower. "What more does anyone need?" he asked.
Nothing, absolutely nothing.
But at the Royal Oak Showhouse, virtue was not always rewarded.
Stephen Sills and James Huniford were the bad boys of the house, and proud of it. "We used just fabulous, extravagant things, the best of the best," said Mr. Sills, whose sparsely but elegantly furnished second-floor room was the epitome of current chic -- and the show stopper of the house: a luminous room to rise to the occasion in. And don't forget your attitude.
The elaborate moldings had been camouflaged with flat white paint, the fireplace filled with bizarre stone stars. The furniture had provenance, the more glamorous, the better.
Christian Dior once owned the antique wine-tasting table, and Alberto Giacometti created the cone-shaped ceramic-and-plaster lamp that once hung in Cecil Beaton's bedroom.
The mohair velvet sofa was Mr. Sills's idea, as were the striking overlapping draperies: he took Scalamandre fabric, reversed it and had what he called "a disturbing stripe" removed. "That's for a more subtle color effect," he said.
If anyone doubts that "Connecticut" might be considered a style rather than a place, then they haven't been to Raven Cliffs, in Roxbury, where the views of the fall foliage are worth the price of admission.
From Abbey Darer's totally coordinated yellow-and-blue formal dining room, to Lourdes Catao's living room for a crowd, the soigne dressed-for-breakfast look seems to be flourishing.
There are no groundbreaking decorating tips here, but Raven Cliffs has a few rooms worth walking through. Florence Karasik's idea of putting scatter rugs instead of a runner on the stairs was great, as was Frank Reijnen's serene master bathroom with its glass cylinder shower and softly painted marbleized walls.
Most appealing for its up-to-the-moment restraint was the bedroom by DeBare Saunders and Ronald Mayne, designers based in New York and Watertown, Conn. They performed an agile balancing act between understatement and austerity. That was hardly the case in Ann Fitzpatrick Brown's little boy's room, in which 13 fairy tales were depicted on the walls and and where it looked as if F. A. O. Schwarz's entire Christmas stuffed-animal order had been delivered by mistake.
One felt like making a beeline to hide in Joanna Seitz's his-and-hers closets, transformed into miniature Santa Fe-style studies. "They're spiritual escapes where the owners of the house can go to feel more cozy and private," Ms. Seitz said.
Please, please, can we come, too?
 
Seeing Them For Yourself
 THE Royal Oak Showhouse and Design Workshops, 121 East 73d Street, benefits the Royal Oak Foundation, an American group that supports the work of Britain's National Trust. The house is open daily through Nov. 8. Thursday hours are 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. All other days, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $15. A series of seminars, workshops and lectures is also being offered, for a fee, on a wide range of topics. Information from (212) 966-6565.
The Litchfield County Designer Showhouse, at Raven Cliffs in Roxbury, Conn., benefits the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury, Conn. The house is open daily through Nov. 1, from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $15. Tickets for visitors over 62 years old and those in groups are $12. Information and directions to the house are available from (203) 753-0381.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Coup: To Be Both In and Far Out

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Last night, as limousines circled the neo-Renaissance 1908 Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Lafayette Avenue, a first-night audience attended a party celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Next Wave Festival, which has become the most prominent avant-garde showcase in New York City.
The evening was also the 25th anniversary of the stewardship of the academy by its president and executive producer and tireless promoter, Harvey Lichtenstein. Not since Joseph Papp made the New York Shakespeare Festival in his own image has the identity of a performing arts institution been as closely tied to the vision of a single individual. 
 The academy, or BAM, as it is known, is still basking in the attention showered upon Mr. Lichtenstein's fall theatrical coup, the two-week importation from Paris of "Les Atrides," directed by Ariane Mnouchkine. Despite decidedly mixed reviews, the $1 million, four-play cycle of Greek dramas had the cultural elite falling all over themselves in pursuit of tickets.
All of this would seem to stand in sharp contrast to the picture at the academy a year ago, when the sometimes volcanic Mr. Lichtenstein was sounding a cry of alarm for his institution's survival. Faced with severe budget cuts from New York City and New York State -- $1 million of the academy's $13.2 million budget disappeared during a single year -- and with the recession-induced loss of $226,000 in private contributions, Mr. Lichtenstein pared back programming and cut the academy's staff of 120 by 22, moves that he hoped would put the academy on a solid footing.
Was the academy crying wolf? It might seem so, given the speed with which its mood has turned around in a year. But the academy has hardly pulled back completely from the brink. Unmentioned amid the hoopla of the sold-out run of "Les Atrides" was a $220,000 loss. And while advance ticket sales for the Next Wave Festival are significantly higher this year than last, subscriptions have dropped for the Brooklyn Philharmonic, the academy's resident orchestra.
All of this suggests that the academy's future lies in attracting events such as the ones that make up the Next Wave, though the very idea of an institution focused on the avant-garde would seem to be an oxymoron. But the academy has increasingly had to scramble to remain at the cutting edge artistically at a time when the avant-garde is being absorbed into the mainstream and is susceptible to almost instant commercial exploitation. The work of vanguard artists featured at the academy -- Peter Sellars, Peter Brook, Robert Wilson and Pina Bausch, to name a few -- is now embraced by larger establishment audiences.
Mr. Lichtenstein must also deal with the quandary of an institution that often seems to make a bigger splash around the world than it does in its own neighborhood. The academy, whose four performance venues are home to a wide range of dance, opera, theater and concert events, may be in Brooklyn, but its success has, to some critics, made it less and less relevant to the troubled downtown in which it sits.
Certainly there are many signs of vitality. At a time when other arts groups worry about their aging and declining audiences, the academy has been more successful than any other institution in New York in attracting a highly sophisticated, younger audience: the very audience other institutions say they crave. Surveys have shown that 80 percent of the Next Wave audience is under age 40.
"Harvey has created a more diverse and younger audience at BAM than at Lincoln Center," said Bernard Gersten, executive producer of the Lincoln Center Theater. "We are genuinely jealous. We all want to have people who dress funny and have people with -- well, hair. And Harvey does."
Even some of his habitual critics have praise for Mr. Lichtenstein's ability to keep the academy in the public eye. "Harvey is a brilliant promoter," said Samuel Lipman, publisher of The New Criterion, a neo-conservative monthly journal of the arts. Mr. Lipman sparred for years with Mr. Lichtenstein when both were on the National Council of the Arts. "BAM has gotten a fabulous press, because the press is bored and tired of writing every week about the Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera."
One major difference between last year and this year at the academy is the optimism over the current Next Wave Festival, which opened last night in the academy's Majestic Theater with "Frida," a musical-theater work exploring the life of the Mexican painter Frida Kahlo.
In addition to anticipated debuts like that of "The Hard Nut," Mark Morris's comic reworking of "The Nutcracker," the series will include a revival of Robert Wilson and Philip Glass's "Einstein on the Beach," the epic opera that made a splash at the academy in 1984 and helped to establish the Next Wave Festival as a national and international event on the arts scene. (The success of "Einstein" was followed by such high-impact Next Wave events as Peter Brook's nine-hour Indian epic, "The Mahabharata" in 1987, and John Adams's operas "Nixon in China" in 1987 and "The Death of Klinghoffer" in 1991.)
This year's ticket advance for the Next Wave is $520,000, a huge upsurge from the $148,000 in ticket sales at this point last year, and the academy expects many productions to be sold out.
The upturn for the Next Wave comes after a 1991 season that many critics felt was dull and cautious, and that Mr. Lichtenstein admitted reflected the impact of budget cuts. Although in its early years the festival established a position as America's Parnassus of avant-garde performance, the recession has taken its toll; funds for last year's festival dropped $600,000 from 1990, to $1.6 million. And despite the excitement over this year's festival, some academy watchers have come "to worry whether the festival has begun to play it safe," as Jack Anderson, a dance critic, wrote last year in The New York Times. Others point out that the avant-garde movement itself is aging and may not be as interesting as it was, devolving into a recycling of 60's counterculture while pretending to be breaking new ground.
"The avant-garde is weaker than it was 25 years ago, when Harvey came to BAM," said Mr. Lipman. "The historical verdict on what Harvey has done does not seem to me to be so strong."
For several years, those at the academy have shunned the very term avant-garde, preferring to use "vanguard" and other terms. "Our esthetic isn't at all that of the 60's, it's very contemporary," said Mr. Lichtenstein. "We're still trying to find new experimental work, and we're doing it in a broader network than ever. I think Next Wave is as daring as it was in 1983. We're certainly not stuck in a time warp."
 
Still in the Shadow Of a Failed Troupe
 Mr. Lichtenstein said he thought of the academy "as a presenting organization, not as a producing organization." If there is a reluctance to gamble more on production, some think it may date from Mr. Lichtenstein's brave but disastrous enthusiasm for creating a classical American repertory troupe in 1979, the BAM Theater Company. The group was underwhelming to both critics and audiences, and expired in 1981, leaving the academy $2 million in debt. "My heart is still with that company," said Mr. Lichtenstein.
Beyond the Next Wave, the academy's budget is $13.2 million for the fiscal year that ends next June, up more than $600,000 since 1990. Revenues from ticket and other sales are nearly $4.6 million, an increase of more than $450,000 since 1990. Despite budget and programming reductions, attendance has risen steadily during the last two years, from 218,000 to 232,000 last year.
Mr. Lichtenstein has worked hard to bring those people into the academy's four spaces: the 2,000-seat Opera House, the 1,000-seat Owen Carey Playhouse, the multi-purpose Lepercq Space and the 878-seat Majestic Theater on Fulton Street. Generally, given the academy's budget restrictions, this has meant scaling down the size and cost of productions rather then offering fewer productions, though the 1993 Next Wave will have 8 productions instead of 10, said Joseph V. Melillo, the academy's producing director.
When Mr. Lichtenstein took over the nearly moribund academy in 1967, the annual budget was $675,000, the Opera House had nonacademy tenants and many in Brooklyn bypassed the building on their way to Manhattan for theater, dance and music.
"It took us 12 to 15 years to get an audience to respond to the work we were doing," Mr. Lichtenstein said.
 
Staying in One Place With a Vision
 These days, after the collapse of arts festival after arts festival, the 63-year-old Mr. Lichtenstein stands apart for his quality of indomitability. "I think he has a great reputation because he's stayed in one place and had a clear vision over a long period of time and done it consistently," said Dr. Michael C. Hardy, executive director of the International Society of Performing Arts Administrators.
Those on his staff confirm that Mr. Lichtenstein, though still capable of an explosive reaction when dis pleased, has mellowed. "It's true I was very volatile in the early days," he said. "But now I'm more relaxed because I have a great staff -- and because of the erosion of the years."
But by all accounts, including his own, Mr. Lichtenstein is as vital and energetic as a presenter as he was 25 years ago. "BAM isn't tired, and neither am I," he said. "Just look at what we did with 'Les Atrides.' "
The academy's Brooklyn location and its nonmainstream stance has kept it from attracting to its board of directors the kind of deep-pocketed benefactors who are the ornaments of higher-profile, Manhattan-based institutions.
Nevertheless, this year, William I. Campbell, the president and chief executive officer of Philip Morris U.S.A., joined the academy's 38-member board (Philip Morris Companies Inc., the Next Wave's chief corporate sponsor, gave $450,000 to this year's festival.) And in March Bruce C. Ratner, an energetic 47-year-old real-estate developer with major interests in Downtown Brooklyn, became the new board president.
Last year's fiscal crisis clearly shook up, and woke up, the board, which is now looking for long-range solutions to the academy's fiscal problems. For example, to replace recession fund losses, board members put together a consortium of major corporations in Downtown Brooklyn that, early this year, committed $1.5 million to the academy over a three-year period in an initiative known as the Metrotech Downtown Fund.
 
It's in Brooklyn, Yes, Yet Is It of Brooklyn?
 Despite the academy's Brooklyn-based swagger, it is still true that at some performances Manhattanites outnumber Brooklynites, underlining longstanding questions about its identity. Is it at times something of an alien entity in the borough that gave it a name?
"BAM is not a community center," Mr. Lichtenstein responded, "but we have a tremendous commitment to Brooklyn." He points to the 15-year-old Dance Africa Festival, the largest annual festival of black dance in the United States, which the academy heavily markets to Brooklyn residents; to the academy's performing-arts programs, which he says reach 100,000 school children annually, and to events like the annual Martin Luther King Day celebration, which the academy sponsors.
In 1988 the academy established the 651/Kings Majestic Corporation, an independent presenting group affiliated with the academy that creates arts events like last year's 100 Years of Jazz and Blues festival. In addition, in 1981 the academy organized the BAM Local Development Corporation to support the revitalization and redevelopment of the 16-block area surrounding the academy in Fort Greene and Downtown Brooklyn.
In 1989 Mr. Lichtenstein began a new opera-programming initiative, offering a series of contemporary works, rarities and adventurously staged productions from the standard repertory. The academy has presented the American debut of the Welsh National Opera, the Paris Opera Comique's production of Lully's "Atys" in its American premiere, the United States debut of the Theatre Royal de la Monnaie of Brussels, and the American premiere of the "The Death of Klinghoffer," directed by Peter Sellars and choreographed by Mark Morris.
In 1990, however, several opera productions were canceled for lack of money. Matthew Epstein, the respected manager and opera consultant who was hired in 1986 to revitalize the academy's opera program, resigned in 1990 because of budgetary constraints. In addition, that year the Metropolitan Opera, citing monetary problems, withdrew from a collaboration planned for 1991.
"Our plans for opera will be as ambitious as our budget will allow," said Mr. Lichtenstein. Among the works the academy hopes to bring in next season include "Orphee," a Philip Glass chamber opera based on the 1949 Jean Cocteau movie, and a fully staged production of "Medea" from the Paris Opera Comique.
Three years ago, the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, which has been housed at the academy since the group's inception in 1953, established an affiliation agreement with the academy that made the Philharmonic the resident orchestra. The two organizations now share administrators and facilities while remaining separate, nonprofit companies.
In November 1991, Dennis Russell Davies became principal conductor of the Philharmonic, replacing Lukas Foss, and Mr. Davies has chosen to present fewer orchestral warhorses and more contemporary programs -- positioning itself, in effect, as an alternative orchestra.
The transition has been painful, and subscribership has dropped below 3,000 this year from about 3,600 last year. "Yes, subscription has dropped dramatically," said Mr. Lichtenstein, "but we had no choice. We can't compete with other traditional orchestras."
Then, speaking of the orchestra yet sounding a theme that has long animated his vision for the academy as a whole, Mr. Lichtenstein added: "We have to find a new niche and build our audience."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Trying for a Debate Worthy of the Name

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The lone moderator in tonight's meeting of Presidential candidates, Carole Simpson of ABC, is faced with the job of turning it into something resembling a debate. If she succeeds, the result should prove more rewarding to viewers than Sunday night's set of assertions and animadversions or Tuesday night's Vice-Presidential slanging match. Sunday's meeting was not the worst such show the nation has endured. But as in other years, the reporters, who outnumbered the candidates, were hemmed in by rules imposed by the political parties to keep the pressure down: a question; a two-minute answer; two one-minute rebuttals, which rarely rebutted; next question.
By this time in the long campaign, the two major candidates are like walking commercials. Their personas have been packaged and repackaged, and on the big night they showed off their labels: Experience from George Bush; Change from Bill Clinton. Even the here-today-gone-yesterday Ross Perot, who won compliments for his pithy cracks, relied on Trust Me. It was like watching humanoids spring full-blown from focus groups. 
 If tonight's meeting is to dig into substance, Ms. Simpson will have to tear away more vigorously at the protective wrappings than the amiable Hal Bruno could do on Tuesday.
The format may help. Questions from the audience are to be featured. These tend to be used by politicians as launching pads for any missiles they happen to have in stock. That's why they love to go on "Larry King Live." But perhaps Ms. Simpson will be permitted to give professional help to the amateur questioners, with follow-ups that can whip the candidate back to what is being asked.
For example, if Mr. Perot asserts, as usual, that whatever is needed, he would just do it, Ms. Simpson may inquire approximately what he would do, about, say, education, besides bringing together the wisest people in the country.
If Mr. Bush waxes optimistic yet again about America's economic condition, Ms. Simpson may ask why voters should find him more reassuring than all the optimistic White House surrogates who have been filling talk shows with good news for the last two years or more.
And she may beg Mr. Clinton to explain, so that simple folk can understand, where he will find the money he promises to pour into industrial growth, education, job retraining, police protection and other desirable causes without increasing the oppressive national debt.
As for the closer encounters of the candidates permitted by having a single moderator, the problem, made evident on Tuesday, is that cameras (and studio partisans, who can be counted on to ignore the moderator's plea for no applause) invite punchy one-liners. For all the seasonal incantations about the abiding wisdom of the American people, what candidate is about to entrust his chances to a television audience's patience or sophistication by analyzing difficult issues in public? Since any expression of an honest reservation, not to say uncertainty, lays one open to a charge of waffling, the screen rings with assurances about matters that defy assurance.
Or, as Dan Quayle demonstrated, the contender can pound away at what somebody has told him is an opponent's vulnerable spot: "Do you trust Bill Clinton to be your President?" Or, like Al Gore, he may try for a dramatic moment, demanding repeatedly that the Vice President raise his hand and take a pro-choice oath. Why shouldn't the dignified James B. Stockdale have switched off his hearing aid?
Ms. Simpson will be faced with the fact that debates have a way of descending to the level of the most shameless competitor, and it will be up to her to try to keep her men more or less on the subject. As Mr. Bruno observed somewhat wanly, "We throw out the topic and then we drift."
When desperation strikes in the final weeks of a campaign, anything goes, particularly on television. Nevertheless, there is much to be said for letting the candidates have at each other. The Quayle-Gore exchanges on matters like the environment, abortion and defense spending did bring out real differences. And besides adding a touch of excitement to prime time, man-to-man confrontations provoke reactions of a sort that prudent campaigners do their best to restrain and that may reveal something of a person's character, pardon the expression.
No moderator can compel Mr. Bush, Mr. Clinton or Mr. Perot to address the gaps in their respective proposals or keep them from resorting to mere insults. But let's hope Ms. Simpson will try harder than her predecessors to use what power she has to encourage candor and extract information. That would also make for a better show than this debate week has yet produced.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Abrams: TV Spots to Mark Remaining Days of Campaign

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
After modest use of television advertising, this 30-second ad is the first in a series of commercials the Abrams campaign intends to use in major markets throughout the state in the remaining days before the election. It began airing last night.
 
PRODUCER Struble-Totten of Washington.
 

ANNOUNCER Scandal after scandal after scandal. Al D'Amato has betrayed our trust. But even worse, D'Amato opposes national health insurance. Voted for the Bush policies that wrecked New York's economy. And supports the Mexican trade pact that will cost us thousands of jobs. He voted with the radical right to defeat the civil rights act. And ban all abortions. Al D'Amato swears he hasn't done anything wrong. But the question is, has he done anything right?
 
ON THE SCREEN The backdrop is a collage of newspaper stories reflecting issues for which Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has been criticized. As the announcer begins to cite each of Mr. D'Amato's positions, with a billboard at the bottom of the screen to highlight each one, a close-up of the senator's face is super-imposed over the collage, faintly at first, then gaining dominance over the newspapers as the commercial concludes.
 
ACCURACY The commercial frames State Attorney General Robert Abrams's position on several key issues by defining Mr. D'Amato. But the quick-hit phrases represent only broad interpretations, at best, of Mr. D'Amato's positions.
The national health care program the Senator opposes, for example, is a pending plan that Mr. Abrams endorses and many Congressmen view as too costly. The contention that Mr. D'Amato has supported the Administration's position that "wrecked" the state economy is only partially correct, in that Mr. D'Amato has often voted against the President's position. Also, it remains unclear whether Federal policies have cost the state jobs and, if so, to what degree. Further, while Mr. D'Amato favored a trade agreement with Mexico, he claims that it benefits the state by $900 million a year.
The reference to the civil rights act is based on the Senator's vote to sustain President Bush's veto of the Civil Rights Act of 1990, and his position on abortion reflects Mr. D'Amato's consistent voting record in opposing abortion rights.
 
SCORECARD Besides the verbal mesasge that suggests Mr. D'Amato is wrong in his positions and harmful to the state, ominous music plays in the background, adding a foreboding mood to the ad.
Although his opponent's positions are portrayed with minimal exactitude, the ad is one of the few in the campaign from either candidate that addresses issues, rather than personal attacks.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Looming Discord in Asia

BYLINE: By LEON V. SIGAL

 BODY:
As America draws down its armed forces in East Asia, many strategists worry that the Pacific won't remain pacific for long. They fear that the resulting power vacuum could set off a scramble for security. But that need not happen, not if America's diplomatic engagement intensifies as its military presence is reduced.
The countries of the region are a diverse, disputatious lot whose trade rivalries and territorial conflicts are now breaking out of their cold war confines. 
 South and North Korea, fearing each other and Japanese resurgence, vie for China's favor. Japan, thwarted by Russia's refusal to return four islands seized at the end of World War II, and Russia, angered at Japan's demands for their return, may each want to ally with China as well. Meanwhile, renewed Chinese assertiveness in the Spratly Islands raises fear from India to Australia. And the whole region is engaged in a frenzy of arms purchases.
To allay the insecurities and cool the conflicts, many countries in the region want Washington to remain engaged. But that need not mean maintaining the U.S. military presence at current levels. U.S. troops on the Korean Peninsula can continue to be pulled back from the 38th parallel and further reduced as talks between the North and South progress. U.S. carrier task forces are not needed to show the flag; Aegis cruisers will do. And Navy operating tempos can slow.
But high-level U.S. diplomatic attention cannot afford to recede. A multilateral forum with regular meetings might assure America's active engagement.
The U.S., Japan, China and Russia are already brokering a cease-fire in Cambodia and coaxing North Korea to give up its nuclear ambitions. And they could be guarantors of a more permanent peace. But this nascent Concert of Asia may best be left to operate informally.
It would also be premature to create an Asian analogue of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. A more promising forum for now may be the Association of Southeast Asian Nations if all four powers and other Asians can be made full participants.
Engagement has risks. Regional conflicts may require Washington to take sides. But American disengagement is far riskier. That could set off an arms competition and shifting alliances that, sooner or later, lead to war.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
No Longer for Bush

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Foreign leaders, seeing American economic troubles and sensing the passage of their comfortable second-fiddle days, are beginning to think of the U.S. and themselves in new and revolutionary ways. The trends are unmistakable in the comments of leaders and diplomats moving in and out of the U.N. and Washington in recent weeks.
Many, except mainly Arabs, are setting aside their generation-old preference for Republican realism in foreign affairs. Their top priority now is a U.S. President who can restore America's economic dynamism -- and thus help jolt their own economies. And like Americans, they are losing faith that George Bush can do the job. 
 Many world leaders also are recalibrating America's power and importance. To them, the U.S. remains pre-eminent, but not as lofty as before -- except in the military sphere. In other arenas, foreign leaders are taking initiatives without waiting for Washington's blessing.
Even as these new attitudes evolve, one upshot is already clear: The world's major industrial powers are not lifting a finger to help President Bush's re-election -- as they helped him four years ago and as they have backed his Republican predecessors since 1972, when George McGovern made Democrats look like isolationists.
Four years ago, Japan and Germany propped up the value of the dollar to make the U.S. economy look stronger and give Mr. Bush a lift over Michael Dukakis. This year, Tokyo did nothing to reduce its huge trade surplus with the U.S., and Bonn's bankers rejected White House pleas to lower interest rates. Western Europeans and most Asians have their own problems; Mr. Bush will have to fend for himself in 1992.
At the same time, most world leaders applaud Bill Clinton's enthusiasm for issues like environmentalism and population control. These are very big matters outside the U.S., and Mr. Bush has been a tremendous drag on both.
Most of all, leaders of industrialized democracies look to Mr. Clinton to do something about the beleaguered U.S. economy. They think his ideas somewhat fuzzy. But at least he has ideas -- unlike Mr. Bush.
The notable exception to this trend away from supporting Mr. Bush is Arab states. Kuwait changed plans to buy tanks from Britain and decided to buy American instead. The Saudis, though strapped for cash, went ahead with a multibillion-dollar purchase of F-15 fighter-bombers.
Chinese leaders are also staying by Mr. Bush's side. They gave in to his trade demands and did not explode over U.S. F-16 fighter sales to Taiwan.
China's present rulers cringe when they think about the intrusive passions of Democrats for human rights and democracy. So do most other world leaders.
Many leaders are putting aside these qualms about a Democratic foreign policy and their affinity for Republican pragmatism abroad in hope that Democrats can repair America. In the past they rarely worried about our economy, often demanding financial sacrifices of the U.S. as the price of its leadership. Now such sacrifices are too much to ask.
Western Europeans continue to struggle toward greater economic unity, largely without reference to Washington. The economic power of the European Community, even in disarray, equals America's. Its members can afford to settle their internal matters themselves.
Japanese leaders are planning new initiatives on the environment, trade and refugees. They will go ahead with these plans to define their own leadership role whether Mr. Bush wins or loses -- or the U.S. approves or disapproves.
Most surprisingly, Syria and the Palestinians will bring new ideas to next week's talks with Israel. They have evolved their own interests in advancing negotiations even without heavy U.S. pressure.
Where the U.S. still counts most is on the military front. There, others remain fearful of treading without U.S. muscle or leadership. European passivity on Bosnia is typical.
Much else, however, is turning topsy-turvy. For the first time since 1945, most of the world seems ready to forgo American leadership on certain issues, knowing America must focus on healing itself. Meantime, many nations will begin to accept greater responsibility for their own problems. All in all, these are healthy trends -- if the U.S. seizes the chance to fix itself up.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 2147 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Debate;
ISSUES, NOT ATTACKS, DOMINATE AS AUDIENCE GUIDES 2D DEBATE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The three Presidential candidates engaged in an earnest town-meeting exchange last night that became a forum for airing the nation's domestic woes during President Bush's Administration.
Mr. Bush defended his record and his sensitivity to the suffering of the recession. "Of course, you feel it when you're President of the United States," he said. 
 But he asserted that a Clinton Presidency would mean huge new taxes rather than a growing economy. "Governor Clinton's program wants to tax more and spend more," Mr. Bush said. "I don't believe that's the way to do it."
Governor Clinton, however, quickly dismissed the charge.
It was a night in which there were a few sweeping promises. Ross Perot, the independent candidate, promised he would serve only one term and would not take compensation for the $200,000-a-year job. Mr. Clinton promised to propose a universal health-care plan in the first 100 days of his Presidency.
 
Thrives on Format
 Mr. Clinton, who seemed to thrive on the town-meeting format that he had used throughout his primary campaign, presented himself as a man with long years of experience in dealing with the problems of ordinary people. He also asserted that the blame for these problems clearly rested with the "failed economic theory" of the Republicans.
Mr. Perot once again sharply criticized the "gridlock" in Washington, casting the two parties as mired in a cycle of blame that produced only economic drift and decline. "It's not the Republicans' fault, of course, and it's not the Democrats' fault," he said. "Somewhere out there there's an extraterrestrial that's doing this to us, I guess."
At the start of the program and in his closing statement, Mr. Bush tried to move the debate to the issue of character and trust, which he said should be a paramount consideration for voters when they choose a President, and suggested that Mr. Clinton did not pass the test. He asked the voters which President they would prefer in the event of an international crisis.
As for Mr. Clinton, at one point he looked at Mr. Bush and said: "I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the Presidency."
 
Little New Ground
 But in general, it was a night that broke little new substantive ground and offered Mr. Bush few opportunities for the dramatic strokes that his strategists think he needs to come back from a clear deficit in the public opinion polls.
Mr. Clinton, for his part, seemed clearly content to avoid confrontations and follow a no-risk strategy befitting a front-runner. He pointedly turned away from opportunities to respond to Mr. Bush's probing attacks on his character and to take on the President over his handling of Iraq.
The 90-minute debate, held on the campus of the University of Richmond, opened the candidates to questions from an audience of 209 people selected by the Gallup Organization to represent uncommitted voters. Carole Simpson, of ABC News, was the moderator. The questioners were relentlessly focused on issues, from gun control to free trade, from health care to urban woes.
The unusual format, with the candidates occasionally perched on stools and occasionally wandering the stage like talk show hosts, made for a far less confrontational debate than might have been expected, given the tenor of the campaign dialogue in recent days.
More than once, members of the audience gently chided the candidates for not sticking to the issues this year.
Still, Mr. Bush again assailed Mr. Clinton as a man who habitually straddled the issues. He also took pains to answer Mr. Clinton's attack of Sunday night's debate, in which the Democrat pointedly noted that Mr. Bush's father, Senator Prescott Bush, had been a leading critic of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. Democrats have accused the Republicans of practicing McCarthyite tactics against Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Bush's reply last night suggested that the allusion to his father had nagged him. "I remember something my Dad told me," Mr. Bush said. "I was 18 years old, going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy, and he said, 'write your mother,' which I faithfully did; he said 'serve your country,' -- my father was an honor, duty and country man -- and he said, 'tell the truth.' And I've tried to do that in public life, all through it. That says something about character."
Despite the occasional personal jab, the debate was dominated by domestic concerns. The only question on foreign policy came more than an hour into the debate, and it was a general inquiry about how the country should participate in the "new world order."
The candidates agreed that the United States should remain an international superpower. Mr. Bush tied the collapse of Communism to steady Republican stewardship, while Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot insisted that the nation had to improve economically to maintain its strength internationally.
Mr. Perot, who was widely considered the winner of the first debate, spoke mostly in generalities last night. While he consistently contended that ridding the country of its huge deficit was crucial, he did not use the forum to advance his package of austere tax increases and spending cuts.
Mr. Perot tried to distinguish himself from his rivals on trade, lambasting what he asserted was a government that failed to look after the interests of the home front when trade agreements were negotiated.
Mr. Bush countered that the nation's economic problems would be much worse without strong exports. "Free and fair trade is the answer, not protection," he said.
Mr. Clinton sounded a similar theme, arguing, "The trick is to expand our export base and to expand trade on terms that are fair to us." To do that, he said, requires making sure that markets in other countries are as open to the United States as America is to foreign products, and changing the tax code to insure that it encourages investment at home.
On the subject of the deficit, the candidates were asked to detail how much they would reduce it in four years and whether they would promise not to seek re-election if they failed.
Governor Clinton said he would not make such a promise, warning that overly drastic measures would harm the economy. Instead, he said he would work to cut the deficit in half in his first term, which he contended would still allow for measures to spur economic growth.
Mr. Bush countered, "I don't see how you can grow the deficit down by increasing taxes."
Mr. Perot, who said he did not plan to seek re-election, repeated his pledge to make cutting the deficit a priority and charged that the two major parties had proved themselves unable to deal with it.
Several questioners expressed disgust at what they said was the mudslinging tone of the campaign and asked the candidates to discuss national issues rather than dwelling on character questions.
Mr. Perot said issues were exactly what he was trying to talk about, noting that he had bought 30-minute chunks of television advertising time to describe in detail his economic proposals. "Let's talk jobs, health care and crime," he said.
But Mr. Bush said "character is part of being President," as important to qualities of leadership as detailed programs. He accused Governor Clinton of starting the negative campaigning and said, "I'm not going to sit there being a punching bag."
He renewed his attack on Governor Clinton's involvement in Vietnam War protests while he was studying at Oxford University in England in the 1960's. He said he was "deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstrations against his government in a foreign country."
 
Is It a Generation Gap?
 "Maybe that's generational," he said.
Mr. Clinton, responding briefly, said he was disheartened by "the tenor and tone of this campaign."
Mr. Bush defended his domestic accomplishments throughout the night. For example, he said he supported one questioner's call for doing more to rebuild the cities and the nation's roads, bridges and water systems. He said that this year the Government passed the "furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highway program." The President also defended his call for enterprise zones to help revive the nation's inner cities. He said he was frustrated at the difficulty in getting such a proposal through Congress, but acknowledged that he had threatened to veto the bill that provided tax breaks for investments in poor urban areas.
 
Motives for Veto
 He said he objected to other provisions of the bill added by Democrats in Congress and used the discussion to appeal anew for a line-item veto. If he had that, he said, "we could knock out the pork, knock out the tax increases and do what the people want us to do, create enterprise zones."
But Mr. Clinton quickly retorted that the real reason Mr. Bush wanted to veto the bill, which included several tax increases that Mr. Bush opposed, was because it "asks the wealthy to pay a little more." Sensitive to charges of dirty campaigning made by some in the audience, Mr. Clinton insisted that his charge was not "mudslinging but fact-slinging."
All three candidates tried to tread lightly on the politically perilous ground of gun control. Governor Clinton said that while he supported the right of people to keep arms, he supported a bill in Congress that would require people seeking to buy guns to submit to a waiting period while their backgrounds could be checked for mental illness or criminal records.
Mr. Bush said he opposed the gun-control bill, named for James Brady, the former White House press secretary who was severely wounded in the attempted assassination of President Ronald Reagan in 1981.
President Bush said, "I was not for the bill because it was not tough enough on criminals."
Mr. Perot called the Brady bill "a timid step in the right direction."
The candidates split three ways on the question whether members of Congress should be subject to term limitations.
"I strongly support term limits," said President Bush, staking out ground taken by most Republicans in the Democrat-controlled Congress. He said he believed "this would return government closer to the people."
 
Merits of Term Limits
 Mr. Clinton said term limits "may be popular, but I am against them." He said they would "pose a lot of problems for little states" and "would increase the influence of staff members -- people who were never elected."
Mr. Perot responded: "I intend to be there one term. I don't want to spend one day thinking about re-election. I will take absolutely no compensation.
"The point is we have got to reform government. If you don't reform government, term limits won't help."
On the issue of health care, Mr. Clinton reiterated his promise to produce a national health-care plan in the first 100 days of his Presidency. Mr. Bush said a leading factor driving up health costs was malpractice suits. "They're breaking the system," he said, noting they cost more than $20 billion a year. "I want to see those outrageous claims capped."
He said he wanted to make insurance available to the poor and to allow Americans to take their health-care policies with them when they leave their jobs.
The questioners sometimes seemed to unsettle the candidates. Mr. Bush took umbrage with what he saw as the premise of a woman who asked how each of the candidates had been personally affected by the national debt. He said she seemed to be suggesting that people of means were untouched by it. "I don't think it's fair to say that if you haven't had cancer, therefore you don't know what it's like," he said.
"You ought to be in the White House for a day, hear what I hear, see what I see, the mail I read," he said. "Everybody's affected by debt. Everything is more expensive. Everything comes out of your pocket and my pocket."
Mr. Perot said his decision to enter the Presidential race, disrupting his private life and business, was evidence of his deep concern with the debt.
 
Economic Woes Discussed
 Mr. Clinton used this moment to make an impassioned case for his commitment and his closeness to the nation's economic woes. He said that as Governor of Arkansas for 12 years, and as a candidate over these past two years, he had seen the troubled economy and its toll up close. "When a factory closes, I know the people who ran it," he said. "For the last 13 months, I've been meeting with people like you all over America, who have lost their livelihoods, their jobs, their health insurance."
But he told the questioner that the deficit was not the only cause of these problems, citing a lack of investment in America's people and years of what he called trickle-down economics. "We're in the grip of a failed economic theory," he said. "And this election better be about what kind of economic theory you want."

HEADLINE: New York City and Environs Land Goodwill Games for '98

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
It was a sporting upset in the fine tradition of New York. Only this time it was the city itself, and the metropolitan area, that managed the surprise.
New York City, New Jersey and Long Island were awarded the 1998 Goodwill Games last night, an intriguing but risky choice by the Games' selection committee. Six years from now, the area will be called upon to play host to thousands of international athletes and fans who have every right to expect upgraded athletic facilities and a convenient ride to the arena. 
 The final decision came late last night in Atlanta, after hours of debate by a nine-member selection committee following final presentations in the afternoon. The committee reportedly had a sharp, lengthy debate about the merits of the New York and Dallas bids, after eliminating the other two finalists, South Florida and St. Louis.
The victory was a major plum for the New York City Sports Commission and its eager young director, Matt Scheckner, who estimates the extravaganza could pump as much as $500 million into the city's economy. The New York metropolitan area has never been host to a bigger, more demanding sporting event encompassing as many competitions.
The Games are held every four years. The 1994 Games in St. Petersburg, Russia, are expected to feature 2,500 athletes from more than 50 countries in 24 sports. The 1998 Games are likely to be at least as ambitious. According to the bid proposal, New York organizers will invest more than $55 million in preparation for the 1998 event, funds they hope to raise largely through private contributions and possibly through a special state-endorsed lottery.
The Goodwill Games will require the New York organizers to construct a new velodrome and aquatic center. Most of the events, however, will utilize existing facilities. The athletes' village will be placed at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I.; opening ceremonies will be at Ellis Island; closing ceremonies will be at Lincoln Center; gymnastics and basketball at Madison Square Garden; boxing at the Paramount Theater; figure skating and ice hockey at Nassau Coliseum on Long Island; rowing at Orchard Bay in the Bronx; soccer at Fordham University, and track and field at Columbia University's Wien Stadium, at the northern end of Manhattan.
Jack Kelly, the president of the Goodwill Games and co-chairman of the Site Selection Committee, said more than 60 percent of the Olympic medalists at Barcelona had participated in the 1990 Goodwill Games in Seattle.
 
Created by Ted Turner
 The Goodwill Games were conceived in the mid-1980's by Ted Turner and featured on his Turner Broadcasting System as a cooperative competition that would match the Soviet Union's top athletes against those of the United States.
At the time, because of successive Summer Olympic boycotts, the two athletic superpowers had not faced each other in top competition for a number of years. The United States led a boycott of the 1980 Summer Games in Moscow, and the Soviet Union instigated an Eastern bloc boycott of the 1984 Games in Los Angeles.
With Turner as the catalyst, the first Goodwill Games were held in Moscow, in 1986.
With the breakup of the Soviet Union and the end of the cold war, the Goodwill Games are now a more diverse affair. The primary opponent for the United States is now Russia, but the other former Soviet republics will be represented in the competition.
Kelly had worried that New York might be too big to focus its energies on such an event. The United States National Track and Field Championships at Randalls Island in 1991 represented such a mini-disaster, as the city largely ignored the prestigious event.
But Kelly also said the city offered tremendous cultural advantages, and Scheckner pointed out that the New York area's infrastructure is accustomed to handling massive transportation problems on a regular basis.
"These Games would not be heavy lifting for New York," Scheckner said.
Gov. Mario Cuomo lobbied Wednesday in Atlanta on behalf of the New York bid, grabbing the ear of Turner, who is the chief financial sponsor of the Games. Turner had no official vote among the nine voting members of the board of directors, but his influence might have been a factor in the decision.
The Goodwill Games' organizers, including Turner, are scheduled to hold a news conference at Madison Square Garden this afternoon to make an official announcement.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis;
A No-Nonsense Sort of Talk Show

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

 BODY:
The format of the second Presidential debate last night may have resembled the sort of daytime talk shows where guests wax confessional and personal on all human idiosyncrasies. But when George Bush tried to press the character attack that his advisers see as his best hope to beat Bill Clinton, the audience swiftly cut him off.
They wanted a sober, serious discussion of issues: infrastructure, keeping jobs in the United States, crime, gun control, health care and deficit reduction. They did not ask about foreign policy in the first 65 minutes of the debate. They did not want to know about Mr. Clinton's draft record, marital problems, travel schedule in Moscow or antiwar activities in Europe. 
 Last night's debate in Richmond was the natural culmination of a campaign season that has been played out on television talk shows and other populist forums. But those who had worried that the "Oprah Winfrey" format, with the candidates perched on stools and the audience asking the questions, would lower the quality of the Presidential discourse, were proven very wrong.
It was a night in which the voters blew the whistle on mud wrestling and had a civilizing effect on the often feral 1992 campaign.
The President, cut off on character and foreign-policy issues for the most part and boxed into a situation where he was forced to confront his weakest issue, the economy, seemed uncomfortable and sometimes grew testy. By 9:50 P.M., he was checking his watch to see how much longer this infrastructure quizzing would go on.
Mr. Clinton, who suggested a format that he has made the medium for his campaign, had the empathy and confidence of a television evangelist, moving close to the questioners and urging one woman to repeat her question about whether Mr. Bush was out of touch.
Ross Perot offered his usual back-porch wisdom: "If you want to have a high-risk experience comparable to bungee-jumping, go into the Congress," he said. "Wear your safety-toe shoes when you go."
He accepted a pledge to avoid any negative campaigning and offered to forgo a salary and a second term if elected. Mr. Perot, who was positioned in the middle this time, tried to exert a physical dominance by standing most of the time before a stool that was too tall for him.
 
Jabs at Mr. Fixit
 But the audience and Carole Simpson, the ABC News correspondent who served as tart-tongued moderator, seemed less interested in colorful maxims and sweeping promises than in pinning him down on specific ideas.
Ms. Simpson was an unusually intrusive moderator: at one point she needled Mr. Perot about his know-it-all answers, and she drew a few laughs when she referred a question about schools to Mr. Bush as "the education President."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton, clearly relieved that Mr. Perot was not charming the audience as easily as he had in the first debate, both tried to capitalize on the sterner mood about economic solutions, by telling Mr. Perot, each at separate moments, a version of, "You can't just say you're going to fix it."
The President's original strategy had been to follow up on the Vice Presidential debate on Tuesday night, in which Dan Quayle aggressively pressed the issue of whether America can trust Bill Clinton.
Soon after the debate started, a woman in the audience complained that "the amount of time the candidates have spent in this campaign trashing their opponents' character and their programs is depressingly large."
At first, in an inaccurate reading of the audience mood, Mr. Bush only saw this question as an opening to push the trust issue. He accused Mr. Clinton of starting the fight and then resumed his attack on the Arkansas Governor for demonstrating against the Vietnam war while he was a Rhodes scholar at Oxford in 1969.
Then he began pressing another Republican argument that Mr. Clinton changes his positions regularly. "I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House," Mr. Bush said. He continued the assault, but was cut off by Ms. Simpson, who gave the floor to Mr. Clinton.
In reply, the Governor quoted a newspaper editorial that called Mr. Bush a political chameleon, but he seemed to quickly sense the change in temperature.
 
'The Night Belongs to You'
 "I'm not interested in his character," Mr. Clinton said. He added, turning to the questioner, "So I think you're right, and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you."
Mr. Clinton, who has been bruised by Republican attacks on his evasiveness on the draft and other issues, tried to make himself the victim. "I'm just as sick as you are by having to wake up and figure out how to defend myself every day," he said, walking toward the audience as though to identify with their concern. "I never thought I'd be involved in anything like this."
Mr. Perot, however, was the only one of the three candidates who was willing to "take the pledge," demanded by a man in the audience, that the candidates stick to the issues and stop "mud wrestling."
He also realized that the talk-show format, often used by people selling books or exercise videos, was the perfect place to plug his campaign advertisements.
 
Until Tomorrow
 "I'll see you tomorrow night. On NBC, 10:30 to 11 eastern," he told the crowd, expansively.
Mr. Bush thinks he is a good politician when he is able to be with voters one on one, as opposed to giving large set speeches. But it did not work tonight because the audience wanted to see where he planned to take the country and whether he understood their problems.
His worst moment came when a young black woman in the audience asked him pointedly and repeatedly, "How can you honestly find a cure for the economic problems of the common people if you have no experience in what's ailing them?"
Mr. Bush did not react warmly, saying, "Help me with the question, and I'll try to answer it."
Mr. Clinton immediately saw his opening to be a champion of the middle class. He moved toward the woman and said: "Tell me how it's affected you again. You know people who've lost their jobs and lost their homes?" The woman nodded and said, "Well, yeah."
He then explained that as governor of a small state, "When people lose their jobs, there's a good chance I'll know them by their names. When a factory closes, I know the people who ran it."
 
Endorsement for Barbara Bush
 Mr. Clinton even passed up an opening offered to him by Ms. Simpson to attack Mr. Bush on one of the Democrats' favorite issues, his friendly policy toward Iraq before the war in the Persian Gulf.
Struggling through the issues portion of the evening, Mr. Bush a couple of times tried to point to his best asset: Barbara Bush, who watched from the audience. At one point, sounding pessimistic about his own prospects, he said: "I think if Barbara Bush were running this year, she'd be elected, but it's too late."
In his closing statement, the President tried to return to his game plan, presenting himself as the more trustworthy of the two major party candidates.
"Who has the perseverance, the character, the integrity, the maturity to get the job done," he said. "I hope I'm that person."

HEADLINE: Troubled Oakland Tribune Is Sold Again

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 15

 BODY:
The nation's only major black-owned daily newspaper, The Oakland Tribune, was sold today to the Alameda Newspaper Group, which owns four small dailies in the East Bay area.
The sale may end years of uncertainty at the unprofitable and debt-ridden newspaper, which its publisher, Robert C. Maynard, acquired from the Gannett Company in 1983. 
 "Today's announcement assures the people of Oakland that an Oakland Tribune will continue," Mr. Maynard said. "In an age when daily newspapers are disappearing from the American landscape, we are proud that this title will remain."
 
$9.5 Million in Loans
 Terms of the sale were not disclosed, except that the Alameda Newspaper Group will reimburse the Freedom Forum for the $9.5 million in loans that the journalism foundation made or guaranteed to The Tribune.
The Alameda Newspaper Group is part of Media News Group Inc., which also owns The Houston Post, The Denver Post and other newspapers.
Oakland, with a population of about 375,000, almost became the nation's largest city without a daily newspaper last year when The Tribune seemed on the brink of extinction, as it had many times before.
The Tribune was saved after Gannett agreed to concessions on the repayment of debts from Mr. Maynard's purchase of the newspaper, and the Freedom Forum offered to pump millions of dollars into the newspaper.
 
Effects of Recession
 Despite the bailouts, The Tribune has continued to suffer the effects of the recession.
"It has become painfully obvious to the Maynards and others that the market cannot support the weight of the newspaper's operation unless production, overhead and other costs are shared with other publications," said William Dean Singleton, chief executive of Media News Group in Houston.
The asset sale includes the trademark and use of the Oakland Tribune name, its circulation list and its advertising accounts. The sale does not include the landmark Tribune Tower, which dominates the Oakland skyline, or the antiquated printing presses.
The sale is subject to the completion of negotiations with The Tribune's labor unions and antitrust approval by the Justice Department.
The Alameda Newspaper Group publishes The Daily Review in Hayward, The Fremont Argus, The Alameda Times-Star and The Pleasanton Tri-Valley Herald. The Tribune will share production, accounting and administrative operations in Hayward with those papers.
The Tribune will have its own editorial, advertising and circulation staffs based in Oakland.
The four Alameda newspapers have a combined circulation of 120,000 a day and 648 employees.
The Tribune has a weekday circulation of 121,500, down from a peak of 220,000 in the late 1960's. The paper currently employs 600 people, although its work force has been reduced by years of attrition.
But the publisher of the Alameda Newspaper Group, J. Allan Meath, said The Tribune would employ only about 250 people after Dec. 1.
Mr. Meath invited current Tribune employees to apply for new jobs at the paper and predicted that many would be retained. But he added that others in the newspaper chain or from outside the paper would also be considered for the jobs.
Martin Snapp, a columnist at The Tribune, said his friends had for years brushed off his predictions of imminent unemployment during each of the paper's crises. "They thought I was crying wolf," he said. "Well, after all these years, the wolf finally ate us."
