What I would do is to bring in the pension experts of the country, take a look at it and strengthen the pension requirements further because it's not just enough to have a guarantee. We had a guarantee on the S.& L.'s, right? We had a guarantee and what happened? You picked up a $500 billion bill because of the dumb way the Federal Government deregulated. So I think we are going to have to change and strengthen the pension requirements on private retirement plans.
 
Foreign Affairs
 Q: Thank you. I think we have a question here on international affairs, hopefully.
Q: We've come to a position where we're in the new world order. And I'd like to know what the candidates feel our position is in this new world order and what our responsibilities are as a superpower.
Q: Mr. President.
BUSH: Well, we have come to that position since I became President, 43, 44 countries have gone democratic. No longer totalitarian; no longer living under dictatorship or Communist rule. This is exciting. This is -- new world order to me means freedom and democracy. I think we will have a continuing responsibility as the only remaining superpower to stay involved. If we pull back in some isolation and say we don't have to do our share or more than our share anymore, I believe you can just ask for conflagration that we'll get involved in in the future. NATO, for example, has kept the peace for many many years and I want to see us keep fully staffed in NATO so we'll continue to guarantee the peace in Europe.
But the exciting thing is the fear of nuclear war is down and you hear all the bad stuff that's happened on my watch. I hope people will recognize that this is something pretty good for mankind. I hope they'll think it's good that democracy and freedom is on the move. And we're going to stay engaged, as long as I'm President, working to improve things. You know, it's so easy now to say Hey, cut out foreign aid, we got a problem at home. I think the United States has to still be have the Statue of Liberty as a symbol of caring for others. We're -- right this very minute we're sending supplies in to help these little starving kids in Somalia. We're trying to get -- we're -- it's the United States that's taken the lead in, in humanitarian aid into Bosnia. We're doing this all around the world. Yes, we got problems at home and I think I got a good plan to help fix those problems at home. But because of our leadership, because we didn't listen to the freeze, the nuclear freeze group, you remember? Freeze it back in about 19 -- the late 70's. Freeze. Don't touch it. We're going to lock it in now or else we'll have war.
President Reagan said, "No, peace through strength." It worked. The Soviet Union is no more and now we're working to help them become totally democratic through the freedom support act that I led on. A great Democratic Ambassador, Bob Strauss, over there. Jim Baker. All of us got this thing passed through cooperation, Ross, it worked with cooperation and you're for that I'm sure. Helping Russia become democratic. So the new world order, to me, means freedom and democracy, keep engaged. Do not pull back into isolation and we are the United States and we have a responsibility to lead and to guarantee the security. If it hadn't been for us, Saddam Hussein would be sitting on top of three-fifths of the oil supply of the world and he'd have nuclear weapons. And the -- only the United States could do that. Excuse me, Carole.
Q: Thank you. Mr. Perot?
PEROT: Well, it's cost effective to help Russia succeed in its revolution. Pennies on the dollar compared to going back to cold war. Russia's still very unstable; they could go back to square one and worse. Still, all the nuclear weapons are not dismantled. I'm particularly concerned about the intercontinental weapons; the ones that can hit us. We've got agreements but they're still there. With all this instability and breaking in the republics, and all the Middle Eastern countries going over there shopping for weapons, we've got our work cut out for us so we need to stay right on top of that and constructively help them move toward democracy and capitalism. We have to have money to do that. We have to have our people at work.
See, for 45 years we were preoccupied with the Red Army. I suggest now that our No. 1 preoccupation is red ink in our country, and we've got to put our people back to work, so that we can afford to do these things we want to do in Russia. We cannot be the policemen for the world any longer. We spent $300 billion a year defending the world. Germany and Japan spend around $30 billion apiece. It's neat. If I can get you to defend me and I can spend all my money building industry, that's a homerun for me. Coming out of World War II it made sense. Now, the other superpowers need to do their part. I close on this point. You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower. If we're not an economic superpower we used to be, then we will no longer be a force good throughout the world. And if nothing else gets you excited about rebuilding our industrial base, maybe that will because it's job I; is to put our people back to work.
Q: Governor Clinton, the President mentioned Saddam Hussein. Your Vice President and you have had some words about the President and Saddam Hussein. Would you care to comment?
CLINTON: I'd rather answer a question first, then I'll be glad to. Cause the question you ask is important. The end of the cold war brings an incredible opportunity for change. Winds of freedom blowing around the world. Russia demilitarizing. And it also requires us to maintain some continuity; some bipartisan American commitment to certain principles. And I would just say there are three things that I would like to say.
No. 1, we do have to maintain the world's strongest defense. We may differ about what the elements of that are. I think the defense needs to be with fewer people and permanent armed services, but with greater mobility on the land, in the air, and on the sea. With a real dedication to continuing the development of high technology weaponry, and well-trained people. I think we're going to have to work to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Got to keep going until all the nuclear weapons in Russia are gone, and the other republics.
No. 2, if you don't rebuild the economic strength of this country at home we won't be a superpower. We can't have any more instances like what happened when Mr. Bush went to Japan and the Japanese Prime Minister said he felt sympathy for our country. We have to be the strongest economic power in the world. That's what got me into this race. So we could rebuild the American economy.
And No. 3, we need to be a force for freedom and democracy and we need to use our unique position to support freedom whether it's in Haiti, or in China, or in any other place; wherever the seeds of freedom are sprouting. We can't impose it but we need to nourish it. And that's the kind of thing that I would do as President. Follow those three commitments into the future.
Q: O.K., we have a question up there.
 
Education and Jobs
 Q: Yes, you've talked a lot tonight about creating jobs, but we have an awful lot of high school graduates who don't know how to read a ruler, who cannot fill out an application for a job. How can we create high-paying jobs with the education system we have, and what would you do to change it?
Q: Who would like to begin? The education President?
PEROT: Go ahead, yeah, go ahead.
BUSH: I'd be delighted to. Because you can't do it the old way. You can't do it with the school bureaucracy controlling everything. And that's why we have a new program that I hope people have heard about. It's being worked now in 1,700 communities -- bypassed Congress on this one, Ross -- 1,700 communities across the country. It's called America 2000. And it literally says to the communities: Reinvent the schools. Not just the bricks and mortar, but the curriculum and everything else. Think anew. We have a concept called the New American School Corporation where we're doing exactly that.
And so I don't -- I believe that we've got to get the power in the hands of the teacher, not the teachers' union. I -- what's happening up there.
And so our America 2000 program also says this. It says let's give parents the choice of a public, private or public school -- public, private or religious school. And it works. It works in Milwaukee. Democratic woman up there taken the lead in this -- the Mayor up there -- on the program. And the schools that are not chosen are improved; competition does that.
So we've got to innovate through school choice; we've got to innovate through this America 2000 program. But she is absolutely right -- the programs that we've been trying where you control everything and mandate it from Washington don't work.
The governors -- and I believe Governor Clinton was in on this, but maybe -- I don't want to invoke him here. But they come to me and they say, "Please get the Congress to stop passing so many mandates telling us how to control things. We know better how to do it in California" or Texas or wherever it is.
So this is what our program is all about, and I believe you're right on to something. If we don't change the education we're not going to be able to compete. Federal funding for education is up substantially, Pell Grants are up, but it isn't going to get the job done if we don't change K through 12.
Q: Governor Clinton?
CLINTON: First of all, let me say that I've spent more of my time and life on this in the last 12 years than any other issue. Seventy percent of my state's money goes to the public schools, and I was really honored when Time magazine said that our schools had shown more improvement than any other state in the country, except one other -- they named two states showing real strides forward in the 80's. So I care a lot about this and I've spent countless hours in schools. But let me start with what you said. I agree with some of what Mr. Bush said but it's nowhere near enough. We live in a world where what you earn depends on what you can learn, where the average 18-year-old will change jobs eight times in a lifetime, and where none of us can promise any of you that what you now do for a living is absolutely safe from now on.
Nobody running can promise that, there's too much change in the world. So what should we do? Let me reel some things off real quick because you said you wanted specifics.
No. 1, under my program we would provide matching funds to states to teach everybody with a job to read in the next five years and give everybody with a job a chance to get a high school diploma; in big places, on the job.
No. 2, we would provide two-year apprenticeship programs to high school graduates who don't go to college, in community colleges or on the job.
No. 3, we'd open the doors to college education to high school graduates without regard to income; they could borrow the money and pay it back as a percentage of their income over the couple of years of service to our nation here at home.
No. 4, we would fully fund the Head Start program to get little kids off to a good start.
And 5, I would have an aggressive program of school reform, more choices. I favor public schools or these new charter schools; we can talk about that if you want. I don't think we should spend tax money on private schools but I favor public school choice, and I favor radical decentralization and giving more power to better-trained principals and teachers with parent councils to control their schools.
Those things would revolutionize American education and take us to the top economically.
Q: Thank you, Governor Clinton. What the question is, what is it going to cost? What is it going to cost?
CLINTON: In six years the -- I budget all this in my budget -- in six years, the college program would cost $8 billion, over and above what -- the President's student loan program costs four. You pay $3 billion for busted loans because we don't have an automatic recovery system and a billion dollars in bank fees. So the net cost would be 8 billion six years from now in a trillion-plus budget, not very much.
The other stuff, all the other stuff I mentioned, costs much less than that. The Head Start Program full funding would cost about $5 billion more. And it's all covered in my budget from the plans that I've laid out from raising taxes on families with incomes above $200,000 and asking foreign corporations to pay the same tax that American corporations do on the same income. From $140 billion budget cuts including what I think are very prudent cuts in the defense budget. It's all covered in the plan.
Q: Thank you. Mr. Perot, you on education, please.
PEROT: Yes. I've got scars to show from being around education reform. And the first words you need to say in every city and state and just draw a line in the sand, is public schools exist for the benefit of the children. You're going to see a lot of people fall over. Because anytime you're spending $199 billion a year, somebody's getting it. And the children get lost in the process. So that's Step 1.
Keep in mind in 1960 when our schools were the envy of the world we were spending $16 billion on them. Now we spend more than any other nation in the world, $199 billion a year and ranked at the bottom of the industrialized world in terms of education achievement. One more time, you bought a front row box seat and got a third-rate performance, because the Government is not serving you.
By and large it should be local. The more local the better. An interesting phenomenon. Small towns have good schools, big cities have terrible schools. The best people in a small town will serve on the school board. You get into big cities, it's political patronage, stepping stones. You get the job, you gave your relatives the janitors jobs at $57,000 a year, more than the teachers make and with luck they clean the cafeteria once a week. Now, you're paying for that. Those schools belong to you. And we put up with that. Now as long as you put up with that that's what you're going to get. And these folks are just dividing up 199 billion bucks the children get lost. If I could wish for one thing for great public school's it'd be a strong family unit in every home. Nothing will ever replace that.
You say, well, gee, what are you going to do about that. Well, the White House is a bully pulpit and I think we ought to be pounding on the table every day. There's nothing -- the most efficient unit of government the world will ever know is a strong loving family unit.
Next thing, you need small schools not big schools. In a little school everybody's somebody. Individualism is very important. These big factories, everybody told me they were cost effective. I did a study on it. They're cost ineffective. Five thousand students, why is a high school that big? One reason. Sooner or later you'll get 11 more boys that can run like the devil that weigh 250 pounds and they might win district. Now that has nothing to do with learning.
Secondly, across Texas typically half the school day, was non-academic pursuits. In one place it was 35 percent. In Texas you can have unlimited absences to go to livestock shows. I found a boy -- excuse me but this gives the flavor -- a boy in Houston kept a chicken in the bathtub in downtown Houston. He mixed 65 days going to livestock shows. Finally had to come back to school. The chicken lost his feathers. That's the only way we got him back. Now, that's your tax money being wasted.
Now, neighborhood schools, it is terrible to bus tiny little children across town. And it is particularly terrible to take poor tiny little children and wait until the first grade and bus them across town to Mars where the children know their numbers, know their letters, have had every advantage. The end of the first day that little child wants out. I close on this.
You've got to have world-class teachers, world-class books. If you ever got close to how these books were selected, you wouldn't want to go back the second day. I don't have time to tell the stories.
Q: No, you don't.
PEROT: If we don't fix this, you're right, we can't have the industries of tomorrow unless we have the best educated work force. And here you've got for the disadvantaged children, you've got to have early childhood development; cheapest money you'll ever spend. First contact should be with the mother when she's pregnant. That little child needs to be loved and hugged and nurtured and made feel special. Like your children were. They learn to think well or poorly of themselves ----
Q: Thank you.
PEROT: ----In the first two years they learn how to learn or don't know how to learn how to learn and if they don't, they wind up in prison ----
Q: Thank you, Mr. Perot
PEROT: ---- than it does to send them to Harvard. I rest my case.
Q: Thank you. President Bush, you wanted to ----
BUSH: I just have a word of clarification because of something Governor Clinton said. My school choice program, G.I. Bill for kids, does not take public money and give it to private schools. It does what the G.I. Bill itself did, when I came out of World War II. It takes public money and gives it to families or individuals to choose the school they want. And where it's been done; those schools like in Rochester, those schools that weren't chosen, find that they then compete and do better.
So I think it's worth a shot. We've got a pilot program. It ought to be tried. School choice; public, private, or religious. Not to the schools, but -- you know, 46 percent of the teachers in Chicago; public school teachers; send their kids to private school. Now, I think we ought to try to help families and see if it will do what I think make all schools better.
CLINTON: I just want to mention, if I could, just ----
Q: Very briefly.
CLINTON: Very briefly. Involving the parents in the pre-school education of their kids, even if they're poor and uneducated, could make a huge difference. We have a big program in my state that teaches mothers or fathers to teach their kids to get ready for school. It's the most successful thing we've ever done.
Just a fact clarification, real quickly. We do not spend a higher percentage of our income on public education than every other country. There are nine countries that spend more than we do on public education. We spend more on education because we spend so much more on colleges. But if you look at public education alone, and you take it into account the fact that we have more racial diversity and more poverty, it makes a big difference. There are great public schools where there's public school choice, accountability and brilliant principles. I'll just mention one. The Beasley Academic Center in Chicago. I commend it to anybody; it's as good as any private school in the country.
Q: We have very little time left and it occurs to me that we have talked all this time and there has not been one question about some of the racial tensions and ethnic tensions in America. Is there anyone in this audience that would like to pose a question to the candidates on this? Yes.
 
Race and Politics
 Q: What I'd like to know -- and this is to any of the three of you -- is aside from the recent accomplishments of your party, aside from those accomplishments in racial representation, and without citing any of your current appointments or successful elections, when do you estimate your party will both nominate and elect an Afro-American and female ticket to the Presidency of the United States?
Q: Governor Clinton, why don't you answer that first.
CLINTON: Well I don't have any idea, but I hope it will happen sometime in my lifetime.
BUSH: I do too.
CLINTON: I believe that this country is electing more and more African-Americans and Latinos and Asian-Americans who are representing districts that are themselves not necessarily of a majority of their race. The American people are beginning to bolt across racial lines and I hope it will happen more and more.
More and more women are being elected. Look at all these women Senate candidates we have here. And, you know, according to my mother and my wife and my daughter this world would be a lot better place if women were running it most of the time. I do think there are special experiences and judgments and backgrounds and understandings that women bring to this process, by the way. This lady said here, how have you been affected by the economy. I mean, women know what it's like to be paid an unequal amount for equal work. They know what it's like not to have flexible working hours. They know what it's like not to have family leave or child care. So I think it would be a good thing for America if it happened, and I think it will happen in my lifetime.
Q: We have just a little time left. Let's try to get responses from each of them. President Bush or Mr. Perot.
BUSH: If Barbara Bush were running this year, she'd be elected. But she -- it's too late. You don't want us to mention appointees, but when you see the quality of people in our Administration, see how Colin Powell performed -- I say Administration; he's in the -- --
[Unintelligible interjection]
BUSH: You weren't impressed with the fact that he ----
Q: Excuse me, I'm extremely impressed with that.
BUSH: Yeah, but wouldn't that suggest to the American people, then, here's a quality person, if he decided he could automatically get the nomination of either party or ----
[Unintelligible interjection]
BUSH: Huh?
Q: I'm totally impressed with that. I just want to know when's your guess when?
BUSH: You mean time?
Q: Yeah.
BUSH: I don't know. Starting after four years. No, I think you'll -- I think you'll see more -- --
Q: Mr. Perot.
BUSH: I think you'll see more minority candidates and women candidates coming forward.
Q: Thank you.
BUSH: This is supposed to be the women's -- the Year of the Women in the Senate; let's see how they do. I hope a lot of them lose.
Q: Mr. Perot, I don't want to cut you off any more, but we only have a minute left.
PEROT: I have a fearless forecast. Unless he just won't do it, Colin Powell will be on somebody's ticket four years from now, right? Right?
[Unintelligible]
PEROT: You, you, you wanted -- that's it: four years.
Q: How about a woman?
PEROT: Now if he won't be, General Waller would be a -- you say, why do you keep picking, picking military people. These, these are people that I just happen to know and have a high regard for. I'm sure there are hundred of others.
BUSH: How about Dr. Lou Sullivan?
PEROT: Absolutely.
BUSH: Yeah, a good man.
Q: What about a woman?
PEROT: Oh, oh.
BUSH: My candidate's back there.
PEROT: O.K. I can think of many.
Q: Many?
PEROT: Absolutely.
Q: When?
PEROT: How about Sandra Day O'Connor, as an example. Dr. Bernadine Healy
Q: Good.
PEROT: National Institute of Health. I'll yield the floor. Name some more.
Q: Thank you. I, I, I want to apologize to our audience, because there were 209 people here and there were 209 questions. We only got to a fraction of them, and I'm sorry to those of you that didn't get to ask your questions, but we must move to the conclusion of the program.
It is time now for the two-minute closing statements and, by prior agreement, President Bush will go first.
BUSH: May I ask for an exception because I think we owe Carole Simpson a -- anybody can stand in between these three characters here and get the job done, we owe her a round of applause.
Just don't take it out of my time.
I feel strongly about it but I don't want it to come out of my time.
 
Closing Statements
 Q: Give that man more time.
BUSH: No, but let me just say to the American people in, in two and a half weeks we're going to choose who should sit in this Oval Office. Who to lead the economic recovery, who to be the leader of the free world, who to get the deficit down.
Three ways to do that: One is to raise taxes; one is to reduce spending, controlling that mandatory spending; another one is to invest and save and to stimulate growth.
I do not want to raise taxes. I differ with the two here on that. I'm just not going to do that. I do believe that we need to control mandatory spending. I think we need to invest and save more. I believe that we need to educate better and retrain better. I believe that we need to export more so I'll keep working for export agreements where we can sell more abroad. And I believe that we must strengthen the family. We've got to strengthen the family.
Now let me pose this question to America: If in the next five minutes, a television announcer came on and said there is a major international crisis -- there is a major threat to the world or in this country -- a major threat. My question is: Who, if you were appointed to name one of the three of us, who would you choose? Who has the perseverance, the character, the integrity, the maturity to get the job done? I hope I'm that person. Thank you very, very much.
Q: Thank you Mr. President. And now a closing statement from Mr. Perot.
PEROT: If the American people want to do it and not talk about it, then, they ought -- you know, I'm not person they ought to consider. If they just want to keep slow-dancing and talk about it, and not do it, I'm not your man. I am results-oriented, I am action-oriented. I've built my businesses. Getting things done in three months what my competitors took 18 months to do. Everybody says you can't do that in Congress; sure you can do that with Congress. Congress is -- they're all good people. They're all patriots. But you've got to link arms and work with them. Sure, you'll have arguments; sure, you'll have fights. We have them all day, every day. But we get the job done.
I have to come back in my close to one thing, because I am passionate about education. I was talking about early childhood education for disadvantaged low-income children. And let me tell you one specific pilot program, where children who don't have a chance go to this program when they're 3, and now we're going back to when the mother's pregnant. They'll start right after they're born. But going -- starting when they're 3 and going to this school until they're 9, and then going into the public schools, in the fourth grade? Ninety percent are on the honor roll. Now, that will change America. Those children will all go to college. They will live the American dream.
And I beg the American people, any time they think about reforming education, to take this piece of society that doesn't have a chance and take these little pieces of clay that can be shaped and molded and give them the same love and nurture and affection and support you give your children, and teach them that they are unique and that they're precious and there's only one person in the world like them and you will see this nation bloom. And we will have so many people who are qualified for the top job that it will be terrific and finally, if you can't pay the bill, you're dead in the water. And we have got to put our nation back to work. If you don't want to really do that, I'm not your man. I'd go crazy sitting up there slow-dancing that one; in other words unless we're going to do it, then pick somebody who likes to talk about it. Now just remember, when you think about me, I didn't create this mess, I've been paying taxes like you. And Lord knows, I've paid my share. Over a billion dollars in taxes. For a guy that started out with everything he owns in --
Q: I'm sorry.
PEROT: It's in your hands. I wish you well. I'll see you tomorrow night. On NBC 10:30, 11 Eastern.
Q: And finally, last but not least, Governor Clinton.
CLINTON: Thank you, Carole. Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. Since I suggested this forum and I hope it's been good for all of you, I've really tried to be faithful to your request that we answer the questions specifically and pointedly. I thought I owed that to you and I respect you for being here and for the impact you've had on making this as more positive experience.
These problems are not easy and not going to be solved overnight. But I want you to think about just two or three things. First of all the people of my state have let me be the Governor for 12 years because I made commitments to two things. More jobs and better schools. Our schools are now better; our children get off to a better start from preschool programs and smaller classes in the early grades, and we have one of the most aggressive adult education programs in the country. We talked about that. This year my state ranks first in the country in job growth, fourth in manufacturing job growth, fourth in income growth, fourth in the decline of poverty. I'm proud of that. It happened because I could work with people, Republicans and Democrats. That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals, hundreds of business people, many of them Republican, support this campaign.
You have to decide whether you want to change or not. We do not need four more years of an economic theory that doesn't work. We've had 12 years of trickle down economics. It's time to put the American people first, to invest and grow this economy. I'm the only person here who's ever balanced the government budget and I've presented 12 of them and cut spending repeatedly, but you cannot just get there by balancing the budget. We've got to grow the economy by putting people first. Real people like you. I've got into this race because I did not want my child to grow up to be part of the first generation of Americans to do worse than their parents. We're better than that. We can do better than that. I want to make America as great as it can be and I ask for your help in doing it. Thank you very much.

HEADLINE: Administration Engulfed in Disarray As Bush Concentrates on Campaign

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
While President Bush tries to revive his re-election bid on the campaign trail, his team in Washington is engulfed in another kind of crisis as key parts of the Administration seem to be unraveling.
In the latest twist, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, under threat of criminal investigation by the Justice Department, canceled testimony he was to give today about whether he had misused agency funds. Meanwhile, his wife was quoted in a Texas newspaper as saying that her husband had been in a "stupor," brought on in part by the political feuding between him and Bush appointees in other agencies.[Page A18.] 
 The troubles of the Director, William S. Sessions, are part of a highly unusual three-cornered battle involving the Central Intelligence Agency, the F.B.I. and its parent agency, the Justice Department. In the last two weeks this struggle has escalated into virtual civil war, with F.B.I. and Justice Department officials accusing one another today of engineering damaging newspaper leaks.
The C.I.A. and the Justice Department are also in a running contest to shift blame over the concealing of information about a multibillion-dollar bank fraud involving Iraq.
 Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, was recently forced to admit that his legal department had sent Federal prosecutors a misleading letter related to the case -- and then made the embarrassing assertion that he had been "out of the loop" on an action by his own subordinates.
 
Avoiding Distractions
 The White House has let these squabbles swirl while Mr. Bush and his chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, have concentrated on the President's re-election campaign. In a recent directive the State Department, to avoid distracting Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker from the election, instructed its staff officers not to forward any issue to the White House unless it was of the most pressing nature.
As Washington took on the distinct tone of a city full of politicians who believe a new order may be coming and are trying to salvage their fortunes, the President emerged from the White House this afternoon to fly to Richmond for the second campaign debate.
He gathered his appointees on the South Lawn so they could wave goodbye to his helicopter as he flew off without commenting on the week's developments.
But the House Judiciary Committee and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, were heavily engaged. They pressed for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate what the House panel called "possible criminal activities by high-ranking" officials of the C.I.A. and the Justice Department in connection with the scandal over $4 billion in loans from the Atlanta branch of the Banco Nazionale de Lavoro to Iraq.
 
Checking Clinton Records
 The State Department, in bureaucratic limbo with the former Secretary of State, Mr. Baker, running the campaign, was caught in an embarrassing admission that a political appointee had violated the department's own rules by expediting a request from news organizations for information from Gov. Bill Clinton's passport records from the 1960's. The search turned up nothing.
Although Defense Secretaries, notably Caspar Weinberger in the Reagan years, have often been in the vortex of such battles, the current Secretary, Dick Cheney, has so far sat out these Potomac wars. "We've been blissfully happy just to soldier on over here," said a senior Pentagon official.
Representative Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican who is retiring and is therefore willing to express publicly what Republicans at every level were talking about today, said, "I don't have any previous experience with anything like this."
Much of the new bout of unease in Republican Washington is clearly driven by Mr. Bush's electoral problems. The Bush team even got a blow today from the Postmaster General, Marvin T. Runyon, who suggested that his agency might consider delivering mail only four days a week to save money.
 
Sounding a Warning Note
 Martin Anderson, a White House adviser in President Ronald Reagan's first term, sounded a warning note. "Some people have come to the conclusion that their President will probably lose, people on the inside, and they all want to be the first rat off the sinking ship," he said. "They had better have made the right choice, because if things turn around and Bush does win, these guys are in real trouble."
Mr. Weber, like many Washington Republicans, said that he was hoping for the best but that he was increasingly nervous about Election Day. In California today, the Congressman said he was not there on behalf of the President. "I'm campaigning for candidates who can win," he said with a resigned laugh, adding hastily, "Make that, who can win in California."
Many Republicans here said Mr. Bush worsened the atmosphere last week by noisily and unceremoniously dumping his entire economic team as a gesture to conservatives. Now he is facing mutinies among top advisers who seem more intent on saving their own reputations than on helping the re-election effort.
 
Blaming Bush's Advisers
 A recent series of articles in The Washington Post about the Administration's fractured economic policy appeared in part to be an attempt by the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, to defend his record and blame Mr. Bush's political advisers.
"I think Darman explained that it was all Jim Pinkerton's fault," Mr. Weber said sardonically. Mr. Pinkerton was a relatively junior White House domestic policy aide who now works for the campaign.
It is particularly vexing to Mr. Bush's advisers that the most byzantine and potentially damaging fight of all, among the C.I.A., the F.B.I. and the Justice Department, is connected to what was supposed to have been the President's greatest triumph and electoral plus: the Persian Gulf war with Iraq. The agencies are embroiled in a struggle over American policy toward Iraq before the war, an issue that the Democrats have used assiduously to undermine Mr. Bush.
The Justice Department is conducting an investigation into whether Mr. Sessions tried to evade income taxes and billed the Government for personal long-distance telephone calls, an inquiry that seems straightforward enough.
But Senator David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who heads the Senate Intelligence Committee, suggested on Wednesday that the investigation may be partly intended to discourage the bureau from closely examining the department's own conduct in the prosecution of the bank fraud case involving the loans to Iraq.
The C.I.A. and the Justice Department have been pointing fingers at each other after a Federal judge accused both of withholding information from him and from prosecutors in Atlanta who were handling the case.
The Democrats have been quick to pounce on the deepening divisions within the Administration. "There seems to be some amount of chaos," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader. "You've got Baker going to go back to State one week, and the next week it's on to the economic front and the whole team being fired. I don't quite know why, but everything seems to be unraveling."
With all of this playing out in public, Mr. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, and Attorney General William P. Barr have made no evident move to end the feud. Indeed, Mr. Barr's public appearances have been largely confined to remarks assailing what he calls an erosion of traditional family values.

HEADLINE: Social Security Benefits to Increase 3% in January

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Social Security recipients will get a 3 percent increase in their monthly checks starting in January, the Government announced today. That is the smallest cost-of-living adjustment in six years.
The increase, made automatically to keep pace with consumer prices, will benefit 40 million Americans on Social Security, as well as four million who receive welfare payments under the Supplemental Security Income program for the aged, blind and disabled. 
 The increase is worth $19 a month for the average retired worker, whose monthly benefit will rise to $653, from the current $634.
At the same time, the Government announced that the monthly Medicare premium would increase to $36.60, from $31.80. The premium buys health insurance to cover doctors' services under Part B of Medicare. Part B is voluntary, but more than 33 million people are enrolled. The premiums are typically deducted from Social Security checks.
 
Rapid Rise in Health Costs
 Congress set the amount of premiums for 1991 to 1995 in a 1990 law. The premiums are supposed to cover 25 percent of the cost of Part B of Medicare for the elderly. General tax revenues cover the remainder.
Health costs are rising about twice as fast as consumer prices, which rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Government reported today. So economists say the new increase in Social Security benefits will not keep up with the rise in medical costs.
Horace B. Deets, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons, said: "The low inflation rate is good news. But it is overshadowed by the fear of many older Americans who live on fixed incomes and are plagued by higher health-care costs and lower interest income from savings and investments."
Five million people in other Federal programs will get the same 3 percent increase in benefits given to Social Security recipients.
Among those getting the cost-of-living adjustment are 2.2 million people who receive Civil Service retirement pay, 1.7 million who get military retirement pay and more than a million veterans who receive pensions based on financial need.
 
Examples Are Given
 The Social Security Administration gave these examples of how the 3 percent increase will affect average monthly benefits. For an elderly couple, both getting benefits, the monthly check will be increased $32, to $1,106.
For a widow with two children, the average benefit will increase $38, to $1,288 a month. For an elderly widow or widower living alone, the average monthly payment will rise $18, to $608. For a disabled worker with a spouse and children, the average monthly benefit will rise $31, to 1,076.
For a worker retiring at the age of 65, the maximum Social Security benefit, $1,088 a month this year, will be $1,128 next year. The maximum Federal payment under Supplemental Security Income, now $633 for a couple, will be $652 next year.
The maximum earnings subject to Social Security and Medicare payroll taxes will also increase. The employer and employee each pay a Social Security tax equal to 6.2 percent of the first $55,500 of earnings this year. The Medicare tax is 1.45 percent of the first $130,200 of earnings.
Next year the maximum amount subject to the Social Security tax will be $57,600, while the wage base for Medicare will be $135,000.
The cost-of-living adjustment for next year is the smallest since 1987, when benefits were increased 1.3 percent. Benefits rose 3.7 percent this year and 5.4 percent in 1991.
Of the 40 million Social Security recipients, 32 million are 60 years old or over. The others are children, disabled workers and nonelderly survivors of workers who have died.
The annual cost-of-living adjustment reflects the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index from the third quarter of one year to the corresponding period of the next year.
Social Security was created in 1935 and did not have an automatic cost-of-living adjustment until Congress established that mechanism in 1972. Before then, Congress periodically legislated increases in benefits.
Although now seen as a factor driving up the cost of Social Security, the cost-of-living adjustment was originally adopted to help control the growth of the program. The first automatic increases took effect in 1975.

HEADLINE: Europeans Seek to Restore Unity

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, England, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The one-day summit meeting of European Community leaders here on Friday, called to salvage some semblance of political unity among the 12 nations, will also highlight the deep economic divisions plaguing them.
The community will face considerable difficulty reaching accord on the two main economic issues facing its members: their approach to negotiations with the United States over agricultural trade and their efforts to put the European monetary system, which fractured during last month's currency crisis, back together. 
 On trade, France, wary of any deal that would cut subsidies to its politically influential farmers, has pledged to block any further concessions to the United States. France has given no sign that it will be willing to change its stand, even though President Francois Mitterrand will almost certainly face intense pressure from Britain and Germany, which are eager to reach a trade deal to give a boost to their weakening economies.
 
Bush Applies Added Pressure
 Additional pressure was applied today as President Bush sent a letter to European Community ministers asserting that the United States had done all it could to break the deadlock in world trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, and that it was the Europeans' turn to compromise.
"We have stretched as far as possible to meet the E.C.'s concerns," the President said in the letter. "The negotiators have done all they can. Now we need the political will."
Mr. Bush said an accord was "within reach," but he added that if the two sides fail to reach an agreement, "we face the specter of an escalating trade conflict."
In Brussels today, Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community's commission, said the United States had not made sufficient concessions in the trade negotiations, and he said the entire community must be prepared to say no to a deal. "I have considered the relationship between the adolescent community and its big brother the United States," he said. "I have always thought the community should say no to its big brother if it had the right argument."
European and American officials say France is the main country blocking an agreement. Britain and Germany have indicated that they are more or less satisfied with the American offer, and British officials say they will press France at the Birmingham summit meeting to be more flexible in the trade talks.
Because France's unpopular Government is facing a no-confidence vote in Parliament next month, few analysts expect France to embrace a compromise in the next few weeks.
"I reject the analysis that GATT is only a French problem," said Mr. Delors, who is French.
 
Discussions With the U.S.
 Asked whether Britain, which holds the community's rotating presidency, would use the meeting to press France to make concessions, a senior British official said, "We are working very hard to make sure all roadblocks to an agreement disappear."
But the official declined to be specific about what proposals might be made on trade, saying the discussions within the community and between Europe and the United States were at a very sensitive stage.
The official said Frans Andriessen, the European Community's external affairs commissioner and point man on the trade talks, would brief the leaders on the negotiations and would receive instructions from them before flying to Canada for talks on Saturday with Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative.
The biggest stumbling block is the level of subsidies provided by the community, particularly France, to producers of seeds grown for their oil. The dispute between Europe and the United States has held up progress on a worldwide trade agreement being negotiated under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
On the monetary system, British officials said Prime Minister John Major would stick to his position that the European exchange rate mechanism was flawed and must be reformed before Britain could consider rejoining. Italy also withdrew from the system last month after waves of speculative selling drove down the values of the weaker currencies.
Until Britain and Italy are back in the system of semi-fixed exchange rates, Europe is unlikely to be able to make any progress toward its goal of a single currency.
But Germany and France, among other nations, are resisting any changes to the system, and Mr. Major has made clear that Britain, battered by its own economic problems and in no position to defend the value of the pound any further, is in no rush to rejoin anyway. Britain has been suffering from waves of layoffs, including the announcement this week that 31,000 jobs would be eliminated in the coal mining industry, and Mr. Major is under intense pressure to cut interest rates to stimulate the economy, even if the pound drops further.
While the European leaders have put the monetary system on the agenda for the day, Mr. Major said the discussions would be general and would not yield specific agreements on any changes. The European finance ministers will not be present.
The review of the monetary situation "will not be a detailed operational discussion, but I hope we can come to some procedural conclusions," Mr. Major said in a letter this week to the heads of the other nations.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Lose Early Gains, and More

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market got a shot of adrenalin yesterday morning from some sour economic news out of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. But the booster shot was not enough to keep a rally going. And the market gave up all of its gains and then some some in an afternoon of tumbling prices.
Traders said there was no specific economic news in the afternoon to touch off the slide and suggested that the market was just caught in a trading range ahead of the Presidential election. 
 Pushing the market higher are the continued data showing both slow economic growth and low inflation. But concerns about the possible inflationary and deficit-enlarging consequences of an economic stimulus program after the election is putting a lid on any rally.
 
'Trading-Range Mentality'
 "The trading-range mentality is taking hold again," said James S. Fralick, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "The market is being pulled back and forth by the slow growth and low inflation fundamentals and the fears of a Clinton economic stimulus program."
This means that many traders will quickly take profits after any good rally because they think that longer- term permanent gains will have to wait until after the election and until the Federal Reserve decides if it needs to cut short-term interest rates again.
The economic data yesterday supported both the low inflation and slow-growth picture. The Consumer Price Index rose just two-tenths of a percent in September. And the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadephia's manufacturing index showed a sharp drop in September.
Late in the day, a Federal Reserve Board governor, Robert Parry, raised the possibility of further short-term interest rates cuts to stimulate the economy in a speech in San Francisco. It seems lately that Fed officials have been trying to keep the hope of a rate cut alive while not actually making one.
 
Similar Greenspan Comments
 The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, made similar comments over the weekend in an effort to dispel published reports that the Fed had decided at last week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting not to cut interest rates before the election.
But uncertainity about the election and what kind of stimulus package Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas might propose seemed to keep a lot of regular customers out of the market, traders said, and made taking profits look good to others.
In fact, a news service report saying that a Clinton Administration would allow the budget deficit to grow immediately to pay for a stimulus program helped stoke this fear, traders said, and contributed to the fall in bond and note prices.
In addition, while an interest rate cut is still likely, many traders do not expect one before the election.
"When you get the good news that came out and the market reacts like this, it doesn't make you feel too positive," said Joel Kazis, managing director for government trading at UBS Securities in New York.
In late trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered at 9630/32 , down 7/32 to yield 7.50 percent, compared with 7.49 percent Wednesday. The price of the bond had been up about 3/8 point with its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, falling close to 7.45 percent.
 
Results of Auction
 The reversal of early gains was also true for Treasury notes. The 6.375 percent 10-year note, for example, was up about one half a point but finished the day down 10/32 to yield 6.52 percent, compared with 6.47 percent Wednesday.
Another sign of the trouble the market is having resulted from the Treasury auction of $14.25 billion in one-year bills. The average discount rate was 3.12 percent, which was the highest rate since the Aug. 20 auction. But 81 percent of the bills were awarded at the low price, high discount rate of 3.13 percent.
Traders said that this meant that a lot of dealers got more of the bills than they wanted because the bid of 3.13 percent was not meant to be aggressive. By the end of the day, the discount rate had risen to around 3.16 in the pre-auction or when-issued market, meaning that many bidders for the bills had losses on the day.
 
Municipal Bonds
 Municipal bonds closed unchanged in light trading after losing gains made early in the day, traders said. The market was pulled down in part by the afternoon fall in the Treasury market.
In addition, traders said that the sale of $1.3 billion in California general obligation bonds Wednesday had not gone as well as hoped for the dealers who bought them. The apparently aggressive pricing that saved the state money left the yields too low to be attractive to many potential buyers. Some traders said the bonds were selling in the secondary market at cost or at a loss and that a small portion of the bonds was left unsold.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Latest Economic Figures Help Drive the Dollar Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against most leading currencies as the latest economic data kept traders pessimistic about the economy.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $341 an ounce, off $1.80 from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $1.75 an ounce, to $341. 
 Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said economic indicators released yesterday were not extremely positive. Economists said there was little evidence that the economy was poised to begin growing enough to make significant inroads into the unemployment rate.
 
 
'Pretty Weak'
 "Probably the weight of evidence showed the economy remained pretty weak" and dollar trading was affected by that, Mr. Steinberg said.
"Therefore the Fed was more likely to ease as not," he added, speaking about the Federal Reserve Board's inclination to lower interest rates. Speculation has gone back and forth on that possibility for weeks.
"The Fed has left people scratching their heads about what is going on," he said.
In New York the dollar settled at 120.25 yen, down from 121.02 yen on Wednesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 120.55 yen, down 0.55 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 120.25 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7045, from $1.7085 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.6945 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7065.
 
 
Late New York Rates
 Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.4525 marks, down from 1.4605; 1.2980 Swiss francs, down from 1.3015; 4.9325 French francs, down from 4.9620; 1,287.5 lire, down from 1,290.50, and 1.2480 Canadian dollars, up from 1.24795.

HEADLINE: Many Stocks Up, but Dow Slides 20.80

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Disappointing earnings news from two market leaders drove the Dow Jones industrial average down yesterday, while the broader market weathered the news to end higher.
The index of 30 blue-chip stocks lost 20.80 points to close at 3,174.68, as the Philip Morris Companies dropped 3 7/8, to 80 1/8, and the International Business Machines Corporation slid 4 7/8, to 73 1/8, after releasing worse-than-expected earnings. Their drops accounted for roughly half the loss on the blue-chip index. 
 In the broader market, advancers led declines, 888 to 831, on heavy New York Stock Exchange volume of 213.6 million shares, compared with 175.9 million Wednesday.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.23 point, to 409.60, and the New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.15, to 225.54. The average share rose 2 cents. The Nasdaq index gained 2.42, to 578.64.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of ew York Stock Exchange, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 3,959.094, up 4.485, or 0.11 percent, even though the American Stock Exchange index lost 0.54, to 365.63.
Another blue chip, Westinghouse, fell on investor concern over its credit unit.
"Participants had to be impressed that on a day when three of the Dow giants sustained such body blows, the broad market still turned in a plus for the day," said Robert Stovall of Stovall/21st Advisers.
Analysts said third-quarter earnings reports would be the market's guiding force for the time being.
 "People are reacting to situations on an individual basis," one trader said.
He said yesterday's trading was a prime example of investors' selectivity, given that broader measures held up despite the battering on the Dow.
"I.B.M. puts a dampener on the market, but it doesn't create a panic." he said. "It's not a bellwether anymore."
 
Deficit Is Reported by I.B.M.
 I.B.M. reported a $2.8 billion third-quarter loss, its second-biggest quarterly deficit. Philip Morris reported a 16 percent increase in third-quarter profits, but that rise was below market expectations.
"The market acted fine outside of those two stocks," said Gerald Simmons, head of institutional trading at Interstate/Johnson Lane. "The market is not in bad shape at all."
Government reports that the September Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent and jobless claims dipped to 383,000 from the expected 404,000 figure had little influence on the market.
"They were certainly nothing to get excited about," one trader said. Mr. Stovall said there was still speculation the Federal Reserve could cut interest rates before the election in November.
Chrysler rose 1, to 24 1/8. Bear, Stearns raised its third-quarter estimate on the auto maker.
St. Jude Medical gained 3, to 35. Several analysts raised their earnings estimates after the company reported strong third-quarter results.
Coca-Cola rose 1, to 39 1/2. It released a favorable earnings report Wednesday. Bear, Stearns upgraded its rating.

HEADLINE: Economy Continues to Limp Along

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose a tiny two-tenths of 1 percent in September despite a big jump in fruit and vegetable prices, the Labor Department said today in a report showing that the weak economy was keeping a lid on inflation.
In new signs of lethargy, economists pointed to two other reports, which showed that Americans' average weekly earnings fell 1.3 percent in September, the biggest setback in nearly two years, while businesses continued to accumulate unwanted inventories in August. 
 Even a report that the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell sharply in early October failed to lift economists' gloom.
 
 
'Economy Is Still Struggling'
 They said there was little evidence that the economy was poised to begin growing enough to make significant inroads into the unemployment rate.
"All the reports are consistent with the sluggish, languid growth path that we have been on," said Robert Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. "The economy is still struggling."
These were among today's economic reports:
*The two-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index left retail prices rising at an annual rate of just 2.9 percent through the first nine months of the year. If that rate holds, it would be the second-best inflation performance in 27 years. For September, fruit and vegetable prices jumped sharply for a second consecutive month, but virtually every other category, including energy, showed moderation.
*The 1.3 percent plunge in average weekly earnings was the biggest drop since October 1990 and reflected declines in the average number of hours worked and average earnings. The earnings decline was the third in the last four months and was consistent, economists said, with a stagnant economy that has been shedding high-paying manufacturing jobs.
* The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell to 383,000 for the week ended Oct. 3, the lowest level in seven weeks and the second consecutive big decline. The drop of 16,000 reflected big declines in claims applications in Florida and Hawaii, which analysts attributed to a more stabilized work force after disruptions caused by recent hurricanes.
*Business inventories climbed three-tenths of 1 percent, to $838.1 billion in August, the sixth increase in eight months, while business sales suffered a big drop over the same period, 1.2 percent. Economists said the combination of rising levels of unsold goods and slumping sales was likely to translate into production cutbacks in the months ahead.
Labor Secretary Lynn Martin called the two weeks of declining jobless claims "a strong sign that the labor market is continuing to improve steadily."
But Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, predicted that jobless claims figures would begin rising in coming weeks as the weak economy forces more layoffs. He noted that the four-week average was still above the 400,000 mark -- at 405,000.
 
 
Social Security Increases
 The September inflation report was used by the Government to compute the benefit increase for Social Security recipients. Based on the low inflation rate, 44 million Social Security recipients will get a 3 percent increase in benefits next year, the smallest rise in six years.
The increase will raise the average monthly Social Security check by $19, to $653.
Food prices in September rose four-tenths of 1 percent after a seventh-tenths of 1 percent gain in August. Both were attributed to a 12.1 percent surge over the last two months in fruit and vegetable prices.
In September, lettuce prices shot up 15.3 percent after a 23.4 percent surge in August.
Energy prices were unchanged after a two-tenths of 1 percent drop in August. Gasoline prices fell in both months, declining seventh-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Clothing costs were up two-tenths of 1 percent in September while housing costs edged up one-tenth of 1 percent. As usual, the biggest increase for any of the major categories was in medical care, which rose five-tenths of 1 percent in September and was up 7 percent over the last 12 months.
Excluding the volatile food and energy categories, the core inflation rate was two-tenths of 1 percent in September, indicating that price pressures throughout the economy remained well contained.
Through September, this underlying rate of inflation was rising for the year at an annual rate of 3.3 percent. If that holds, it would be the smallest yearly advance since 1972.

(Source: Commerce Department); "Consumer Prices" shows the percent changes of consumer prices from Oct. 1991-Sept. 1992. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

A Deal Fails
"Money and Friends," a play by the Australian playwright David Williamson, will go on as planned at the James A. Doolittle Theater in Los Angeles in January, but its move to New York has hit a snag. The show, directed by Michael Blakemore and starring Christine Lahti, was to open at the Richard Rodgers Theater in April. But two weeks ago the producer, Emanuel Azenberg, dropped out after failing to reach an agreement with Mr. Williamson's agent, Gil Parker. 
 The dispute involved subsidiary rights in particular and Broadway's dire economics in general. Mr. Azenberg, along with Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Center Theater Group in Los Angeles, and the film producer Ray Stark, had put together a package for the Los Angeles production, the Broadway production and a subsequent film. In return, Mr. Azenberg sought what both sides agree was an unusual concession: a share of the film rights up front, before the play came to Broadway. "By getting the movie company involved, we get to use a share of the movie money early," he explained. "So the regional theater benefits from the subsidiary sale and my costs are diminished because the scenery is built in L.A."
The deal was untenable, Mr. Parker said, because film rights are often incentives for investors in Broadway shows; if those rights are sold before the play gets to Broadway, the playwright has no protection if, for some reason, the rights-holding producer decides not to do the play in New York.
"Ordinarily, when someone doing a play out of town gets fully vested and doesn't bring it into town, no one else will get it because you have nothing to give them," Mr. Parker said. He added there are other producers interested and that he still had every expectation that the play would get to Broadway.
Mr. Azenberg said he understood he was asking for a break in precedent but added that such incentives might be the only way to draw investors to the ever-more-precarious business of producing straight plays on Broadway.
 
A Busy Mason
 Careful readers of theater advertisements will have noted that the hardest-working man in show business this fall is the director Marshall W. Mason. With his production of Larry Kramer's play "The Destiny of Me" now in previews at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Christopher Street, Mr. Mason began rehearsals this week on "The Sea Gull" for the National Actors Theater.
Then over the weekend, advertisements for "Solitary Confinement," the Rupert Holmes thriller starring Stacy Keach, which begins previews at the Nederlander on Oct. 27, declared that though the show would be "based on original direction by Kenneth Frankel," the Broadway production is to be "supervised" by Mr. Mason. The relative type sizes would seem to indicate that Mr. Mason's role has superseded Mr. Frankel's.
Explaining the unusual credit, Mr. Mason said he had been asked by Mr. Keach, with whom he worked on a production of "Sleuth," to advise him in New York. "Solitary Confinement," which had its premiere at the Pasadena Playhouse last fall and has since had limited runs in San Diego and Washington, has been without a director since it left the West Coast.
Mr. Frankel said the show, which relies heavily on video technology, has not been changed since he first staged it. He said he didn't go on the road with it because he had a commitment to direct an episode of "Doogie Howser, M.D." on television. He has no problem with Mr. Mason taking over, Mr. Frankel said.
"Obviously, I don't have much time to give it," Mr. Mason said, adding that he had seen a videotape of the Washington production and thought the show was in good shape. "I'm going to go three nights a week and act as a mirror for Stacy. He's been without a director for quite some time and he needs to feel someone's out there he trusts."
In the meantime, Mr. Mason said, the initial rehearsals on "The Sea Gull" are going well, a relief for all involved after Jon Voight nearly pulled out of the production when his participation was announced before the contracts were signed. Mr. Voight said the last-minute panic was his own fault; he had been uneasy that a film commitment might cause a schedule conflict.
"Actors can get very nervous about that," Mr. Mason said, referring to publicity before the fact. "I had a little bit of the same reaction myself when I saw my name connected to 'Solitary Confinement.' I haven't done anything yet."
 
Staging a Novel
 The Mitzi Newhouse Theater was nearly full on Monday night for the reading of an unusual work in progress: "Bailey's Cafe," Gloria Naylor's stage adaptation of her recent novel. The invitation-only event was sponsored by the playwrights' program at the Lincoln Center Theater and the Roger Furman Theater. In the novel, down-and-out characters, habitual customers of the title place, explain their own stories, creating a web of narratives that ends up suggesting that Bailey's is less an actual edifice than a mythical one, the place humanity has ended up.
It's a format that lends itself to dramatization, and with Ms. Naylor's alternately earthy and lyric prose, the reading, ragged and a little unformed though it was, still managed to rouse the house, occasionally cracking up the performers as well as the audience. (During a racy anecdote concerning lovemaking and a sweet-potato pie, the reading came to a halt because everyone was in hysterics.)
Ms. Naylor, 42 years old, a native New Yorker and a graduate of Brooklyn College and Yale, is a talkative woman with an earnest, investigative demeanor. She is the author of four novels -- her first, "The Women of Brewster Place," won the National Book Award -- but never before a play, and she spoke in an interview about the complications of turning one into the other, sounding very much like a nervous apprentice:
"I went through the monologues in the novel and asked about each one: What is most germane here? What is most dramatic? And then, I wanted to take the most musical elements from the book. What I'm discovering is the leaner the better."
As she was writing the book, she said, "the characters just kind of stepped forth to testify. Now I didn't plan that, but I thought, at the end, this could be for the stage."
It was to maintain that kind of independence in her characters that she created a new one for the play, Gloria Naylor, whom the others resent as their creator and with whom they occasionally bicker. "I like the idea that these are characters in a book," she said. "Because characters do come alive, and they do talk back to you."
The reading, she said, was very valuable.
"I needed to get my ears around the speeches," she said. "It's still a little too wordy."

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

A Disney Attack
The incident may seem a little Mickey Mouse. But it's Donald Duck, too. And bets are that when Goofy gets wind of it, he'll be growling mad. 
 Walt Disney is. And the company is making no secret of it, as the New York artist Dennis Oppenheim recently found out. As soon as "Virus," the artist's 10-foot-high jungle-gym-like sculpture decorated with Mickey Mice and Donald Ducks went up in Santa Monica, Calif., Mr. Oppenheim received a letter demanding that he "immediately remove and destroy" the sculpture.
The work sits in the atrium of Colorado Place, an office complex built by a Los Angeles developer, Maguire Thomas Partners.
The letter from Disney told Mr. Oppenheim to provide "an itemized statement certified to by an authorized officer stating that the 'Virus' sculpture has been removed and destroyed, in addition to providing us with the certificate of destruction."
"These characters are our birthright: we have to defend them," said Tom Deegan, vice president of corporate communications at Disney. "Mr. Oppenheim wasn't authorized to use either Mickey Mouse or Donald Duck."
But Peter D. Raymond, a copyright lawyer representing the artist, said Disney had overstepped its bounds. "Walt Disney has a reputation in the industry for taking a hard line on these type of issues," Mr. Raymond said. "But in this case we believe that Mr. Oppenheim's work constitutes a fair use of the characters in question because it is an artistic expression."
"Virus" was conceived as part of a larger body of work that used common, lighthearted images on "deadly structures," the artist said this week. " 'Virus' was supposed to have the characteristic of a biological model, but instead of using the usual round sphere, I used Mickey and Donald," he said. "The message was one of giving people image-jitters, of using common light figures in a heavier context."
Mr. Oppenheim said he was surprised by Disney's actions. "I didn't think anything would happen," he said. "I made the mock-up for 'Virus' four years ago and showed it all over the world. Disney has scared a lot of people, but I don't think they're going to get away with this one."
The developers aren't so sure. "We're right in the middle of what has become an awkward situation," said Robert Maguire, a partner at Maguire Thomas. "When we commissioned the piece we thought we had clearance from the outset. Now we're looking for a reasonable solution."
But Walt Disney does not appear to be backing down. "Unless the sculpture is removed," Mr. Deegan said, "I'm sure our lawyers will end up meeting Mr. Oppenheim in court."
 
Matisse Auctions
 Art collectors can be a shameless lot, at least when the opportunity to capitalize on the good fortune of a museum show seems likely. This week, Christie's announced yet another Matisse being sold right off the walls of the Museum of Modern Art's blockbuster "Henri Matisse: A Retrospective." That makes four Matisses from the show that are scheduled to be auctioned in two days in New York -- three on Nov. 10 at Sotheby's and one the next night at Christie's.
It has been years since even one important Matisse came on the block, but now sellers are hoping that the show's rave reviews will help inflate the Matisse market. "There probably is a selling advantage to having the picture in the show," said Nancy Whyte, head of Impressionist and modern art at Christie's in New York.
The work Christie's is selling, "Harmony in Yellow," from 1928, depicts a highly patterned room with a model resting her head on a table. The owner was identified only as a Swiss collector. Christie's estimates the work will bring $5 million to $7 million. It will leave the museum for only two days, Nov. 10 and 11, then return to the exhibition, which runs through Jan. 12.
Sotheby's three Matisses -- one from the estate of the dress designer Mollie Parnis Livingston, another from the estate of Wright Ludington, a founder of the Santa Barbara (Calif.) Museum of Art, and the third from the Everhart Museum in Scranton, Pa. -- will be at the auction house's 72d Street headquarters from Nov. 7 through 10.
Why does Sotheby's get to show its paintings for twice as long as Christie's? "That's a good question," Ms. Whyte said.
John Elderfield, the curator of the Matisse retrospective, said, "It's my job to make it as difficult as possible to let pictures leave the exhibition." In the case of the paintings being sold at Sotheby's, Mr. Elderfield said, allowing the works to leave the museum was part of the original loan agreement. That was not true for "Harmony in Yellow," he said.
"I cannot stop people from selling pictures, but we're trying to preserve our status as a tax-exempt, not-for-profit institution," Mr. Elderfield said. "The owner of 'Harmony in Yellow' wants his work in the show, but at the same time he realizes that now is the time to sell. It puts us in a very difficult position."
 
Sale in India
 Sotheby's tentacles are reaching further and further beyond its conventional venues. Four years ago, the auction house held its first sale in Russia. Last week, New Delhi was the scene of a two-day sale, Sotheby's first venture in India.
On Oct. 8 and 9, at the Taj Palace Inter-Continental Hotel, an array of art and objects, from European and Oriental paintings to Art Nouveau and Art Deco bronzes, were offered. "In 1989 we had a successful charity sale, which revealed a demand for Sotheby's in India," said Julian Thompson, the chairman of Sotheby's in Asia.
But judging from the results, the demand wasn't great enough. Sales for the two days totaled $1.9 million; 40 percent of the goods remained unsold.
"Different sessions had different results," Mr. Thompson said. Among the popular items were Indian and Asian sculptures and other works of art. Decorative objects like Oriental and European ceramics, bronzes, gold and silver, and European enamel boxes, clocks and watches did well.
What fared poorly were the 19th- and 20th-century European paintings. "The paintings were problematic," Mr. Thompson conceded. "When you're putting together sales in a new location, it's not always easy to get the consignments one wants."
But Sotheby's plans more forays into India. "There's a new group of buyers and a flourishing economy," Mr. Thompson said. "We'll be holding another sale here next year. And hopefully, next time it will be easier."
 
More Grooms
 "Grand Central Station," a construction by the ever-popular sculptor Red Grooms, is on the cover of this week's New Yorker. Mr. Grooms is the first big-name New York artist whose work has been on the magazine's cover since Saul Steinberg.
"He's someone I've always wanted to use," said Lee Lorenz, who has been The New Yorker's art editor since 1973. "While this is simply a photograph of a piece, Red is working on some original covers for us, too."
Mr. Lorenz said the magazine, whose new editor is Tina Brown, plans to feature other well-known artists but he declined to name them. "This is a high-security operation," he said. "And Tina wants us to remain tight-lipped."
