LENGTH: 713 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Lost Moment

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
In the inspiring sweep and profundity of the great October Debates, I can see why the one moment that haunts me was lost, disappearing with no notice at all.
It could not possibly compete. It could not arouse the admiring chuckle-chuckle Ross Perot gets when he covers his face with that Will Rogers mask. It could not make us purse our lips in criticism of Al Gore for daring to be serious or President Bush for putting his hand in his pocket. And we had to consider the engrossing question: Was Bill Clinton really sincere when he denied being a liar and a traitor? 
 Still, since that moment concerns the lives of 16 to 20 million human creatures living in hell, it might be worth the moment or two of attention that it has not received.
It happened in the first Presidential debate. The issue was American relations with Communist China. That touches inescapably on the export of the products of the slave labor camps, which are an official and central part of the Communist economy.
Mr. Rogers just skipped the slave labor thing, folks. He did say that while we should not cozy up to tyrants, remember that China one day would become our largest trading partner. And he announced usefully that China was a large country, broken into many provinces.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush did deal with the matter. Unfortunately they both got it wrong. They gave a free pass to the slave masters.
The Governor has been strong and American in his condemnation of the Chinese Communists. His badge is Beijing's horror of his election. He has stood consistently with the democratic dissidents. Unlike Mr. Bush, he backs economic penalties to push Beijing into granting its subjects a few social and political decencies.
But in the debate, Mr. Clinton said Beijing had finally agreed to stop sending us products of prison labor, because the Administration was pushed into "doing something about it." Mr. Bush swiftly accepted credit.
The fact is that an August "memorandum of understanding" that is supposed to persuade Beijing not to export slave labor goods to America is just a gimmick that Beijing can use to cover up the vast slave labor industry. Among the people who think that are Chinese freedom fighters and members of Congress, both parties, left, right and center, who refuse to turn their back on them.
The "understanding" prettifies the whole vicious system by speaking only of "prison" labor as if it were all a matter of criminals decently convicted and decently kept in prisons where they had to earn their keep.
In reality Beijing exports goods ranging from shirts to diesel engines, made in camps specifically designed to be factories. Manpower costs are zero. Political prisoners, criminals and people just rounded up are sentenced in kangaroo courts to expandable terms. They labor dawn to dark, year after year, beaten and starved to meet killing quotas.
And when they are "released" millions are forced to remain on the site of the slave camps, continuing to work under virtually the same condition; an evil mockery of "freedom."
Representative Nancy Pelosi, the San Francisco Democrat and a perennial flower in the garden of Congressional human rights activists, states the moral truth: The very use of the term "prison labor" is a concession to Beijing.
Then: Beijing can decide which small part of its gulag falls within even the "prison" definition. Conveniently, most of the gulag is listed by Beijing, straight face, not as prisons but "reform through labor" camps. Institutions of self-betterment, kind of.
Exactly one member of the American customs service is permitted to be stationed in Beijing to look out for "prison" exports. Human rights or Red Cross groups remain barred from the camps.
Most sickening of all: The memorandum contains no denunciation of slave labor, calls for no changes, reforms or regrets. Nothing -- no drop of water for the tortured.
The U.S. may not be able to pressure Beijing to eliminate slave labor because it is so central to Communist economics. We will not know until we try the economic penalties Congress and Governor Clinton support, and which Bushbaker keeps vetoing.
Until then I will buy shirts made elsewhere, where there is no chance that they are woven with blood and tears.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign;
Clinton: Attacking Bush's Record

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
The Clinton campaign began broadcasting this 30-second commercials yesterday. Officials said it would be used for about a week in 20 markets, but they would not say where.
ON THE SCREEN -- Opens with "1988" on a white background. Images of President Bush at assorted public appearances four years ago, including the 1988 Republican convention.
 
 After each statement Mr. Bush, his image freezes and the narrator, whose words also appear on screen, disputes the President's remarks. Ends with these words on screen: "We can't afford four more years."
PRODUCER -- Clinton/Gore Creative Team.
TELEVISION SCRIPT -- Announcer: "1988"
President Bush: "We will be able to produce 30 million jobs in the next eight years."
Announcer: "Under George Bush, more private sector jobs have been lost than have been created."
Bush: "And I am an environmentalist."

Bush: "I want to be the education President."

Bush: "I want a kinder and gentler----"
Announcer: "Uh-uh. We can't afford four more years."
ACCURACY -- Clinton campaign backs is arguments with statistics from the Bureau of Labor Statistics and House Budget Committee.
 The Sierra Club, source of the quotation on clean air rules, has long criticized the Administration's environmental policies.
 While it is true that the Administration sought to cut college aid for families making more than $20,000, it also sought to provide more grant money for students with family incomes below $20,000, a move welcomed by financial aid experts.
SCORECARD -- This commercial seeks to drive home a point the Democrats have emphasized in debates: that the economy is in trouble and another four years of the Bush Administration would not turn things around. The ad also seeks to portray Mr. Bush as not fulfilling his 1988 pledges. Making the President himself the central voice of the ad tends to disguise its harsh attack.

HEADLINE: U.S. Misses Chances In Currency Scuffles

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your excellent explanation of the British pound, the German mark and why a currency crisis erupted (front page, Sept. 17) spells out the technical reasons, but does not dwell on the economic philosophical reasons or matters of perception, which are all important in an unregulated market. Two crucial points are unaddressed: 
 (1) Most countries in the European Monetary System are interested in a stable currency, for which they rely on their own usually well-developed industrial policy. To the Reagan-Bush Administrations, such ideas have been heresy.
For the last 12 months the Bush Administration, except for some perfunctory noises, has calmly watched Helmut Kohl's German Government make its European partners pay for German unification. The increasing interest spread caused a devaluing dollar, benefiting many large American financial institutions. At the same time the Administration hoped for increased exports to offset the slowdown in the United States economy.
(2) The much-vaunted strength of the mark is a perception one has to question. A relatively unimpressive sum, by United States bailout standards, was needed for integrating East and West Germany, yet German interest rates had to be more than doubled to curb inflation; even so, foreign money had to be brought in.
During the last 12 months the Bush Administration has failed to take advantage of an excellent opportunity to challenge the myth of the strong mark and thereby strengthen United States economic world leadership, maintain the value of our currency and allow maneuvering room to stimulate the flagging United States economy.
 
BERNARD L. HOHENBERG
 New York, Sept. 27, 1992
The writer is in foreign trade.

HEADLINE: 'Yes' to One Canada? If Jays Win the Series, Stay Tuned

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
A surge of national pride as a baseball team from Canada plays in the World Series for the first time could give a sorely needed lift to the beleaguered "yes" camp in the country's divisive national unity referendum.
In a close political contest, some poll takers and political analysts here say, the national euphoria may be just enough to tip the scales to "yes" on Oct. 26, the day of the national vote. That would be the day after Game 7, if the Series, which begins on Saturday night, goes the full distance. 
 The Toronto Blue Jays' 9-2 rout of the Oakland Athletics on Wednesday gave Toronto its first American League pennant. The Jays will face the Atlanta Braves.
 
Canadian Soul-Searching
 Canadians are going through one of their periodic bouts of national soul-searching. They have been asked to vote "yes" or "no" on a complex constitutional agreement reached unanimously by political leaders of all major parties on Aug. 28 in Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island.
Although a "no" victory could make it more difficult for English and French Canada to live together and might even lead to a final rupture, the opponents of the accord now have the edge for a number of reasons: distrust of politicians, dislike of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, regional rivalry, criticism of individual sections of the accord that fail to meet demands of influential interest groups, a general malaise.
The most recent poll by The Globe and Mail found 45 percent of voters in the country as a whole in the "no" camp, against 36 percent on the "yes" side, with 16 percent undecided.
"People are terribly grumpy, and this might just change the tone of the last 10 days and put the constitutional debate in a more sane perspective," said Patrick Gossage, a Toronto communications consultant who used to be press secretary to former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau. "It's a positive and reinforcing distraction for the 'yes' side."
In British Columbia, Ray Perrault, a provincial legislator who has led the drive to bring major league baseball to Vancouver, said the Series appearance will be a good thing for all Canadians.
"This is going to set a good mood in the country," he said. "Baseball fans from Quebec will be cheering this along with baseball fans in western Canada. They're going to bury their prejudice."
Canada is wild about the Jays, even though there are no Canadians on the team. The Globe and Mail proudly spoke of the "all-Canadian Jays" who for the next week "are as Canadian as fiddleheads, block heaters and, um, Alexander Graham Bell." Fiddleheads are ferns eaten as greens mainly in eastern Canada, block heaters keep car engines warm on cold winter nights, and Bell was once a resident of Brantford, Ontario.
Prime Minister Mulroney, campaigning hard for the "yes" forces, was quick to link the pennant victory with the referendum.
 
Battered Canadian Dollar
 "The Toronto Blue Jays just won the pennant, and on Oct. 26 the 'yes' is going to win our World Series," he said Wednesday.
But at "yes" headquarters in Ottawa, there was a little reluctance to be seen trying to capitalize on the sports victory. Trailing in the most recent polls, officials there feared they would be perceived as graspers of straws.
"Canadian spirits are buoyed by the fact that for the first time in our history we're playing in a World Series, but I wouldn't want to go further than that," according to a cautious statement from Cindy Boucher, press secretary to the Canada Committee. That is the umbrella organization representing the three main political parties, leading organizations of indigenous peoples and other groups and individuals backing the Charlottetown pact.
But baseball has already figured in some of the advertising for the "yes" side and is likely to be even more prominent in the coming week. One television commercial this week showed a batter striking out, suggesting that a "no" vote will put Canada "out" as a nation and that therefore people should vote "yes."
One of the themes of the "yes" campaign has been that gloom and doom face the nation if voters turn thumbs down on Charlottetown. Financial markets have given that view tacit support by battering the Canadian dollar, which in turn has led to a sharp increase in interest rates, making economic conditions worse for everyone.
But the no side counters that nothing dramatic will happen with a "no" victory and that the markets' fury has been unleashed by intemperate, imprudent statements by "yes" supporters, led by the Prime Minister.
Poll takers and political scientists said they thought the Blue Jays' pennant victory could induce some of the undecided to vote yes, in Quebec and English Canada.
"The Blue Jay element is there on the 'yes' side, certainly," said Nelson Wiseman, political science professor at the University of Toronto. "As in the U.S., baseball is avidly watched here and followed."
The senior vice president of Gallup Canada, Lorne Bozinoff, said he thought it would take "a miracle" for the 'yes' side to turn the referendum around.
But he estimated that if the Jays win on the last day of the Series, that might be worth "an extra point or so" in the percentage of "yes" votes, so that if the final count were in the 50-49 percent range, that could make a critical difference.
"It puts people in a good mood across the country, no doubt about that," he said.
Quebecers, who have their own major league team, the Montreal Expos, shared the joy. The news was page 1 in all the papers. Not even Le Devoir, a highbrow journal that usually ignores sports, could resist a photo of the reveling Jays on page 1. There were banner headlines in La Presse, Quebec's largest paper.
Claude Andre, political editor of La Presse, said, "People here will cheer for the Blue Jays and say 'Hurray' for the Canadian team."

HEADLINE: EUROPEAN LEADERS RENEW UNITY VOW IN SPITE OF STRAIN

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, England, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Leaders of the European Community pledged today to continue to push for a treaty to bring about political and monetary union, but economic strains continued to pull their nations' economies further apart.
The leaders held an unusual summit meeting to try to reassure Europeans that their drive for unity would not dilute separate European national identities and to repair the damage done by recent turbulence on the European financial markets to the monetary system. 
 Britain, the host of the meeting, has always been skeptical about the goal of a common currency in Europe, but today the idea seemed to recede even further into the distance.
 
Interest Rate at 8%
 Even as Prime Minister John Major was telling his colleagues here that he wanted "to get the Community back on track to achieve a period of stability," his Government lowered the Bank of England's basic interest rate by a full percentage point to 8 percent, and the pound sterling resumed its downward slide against the value of the powerful German mark and the dollar.
The lowering of the British interest rate was further evidence of the gulf between the economic needs of the individual nations and the community's professed desire for greater economic unity. [Page 4.]
 
Aid to Yugoslavia Approved
 The drop in the value of the pound was a reminder of Mr. Major's embarrassment in being forced to pull the pound out of the system of fixed exchange rates making up the European monetary system. The system was created to be a precursor to a common currency in Europe as early as 1997.
In other actions, the European leaders agreed to speed up aid to refugees in Yugoslavia over the winter, providing $288 million for immediate purchase of 120,000 tons of food, plus medicine, temporary shelters and 40 trucks. They also discussed the negotiations for a new global trade agreement, agreeing to continue talks with the United States in Toronto this weekend.
Mr. Major called today's meeting after last month's monetary turbulence, which erupted just before a French referendum on the treaty on political and monetary union signed by European Community leaders in Maastricht, the Netherlands, last December. The French narrowly approved the treaty after a heated campaign in which voters' concerns over a loss of national identity were voice.
Though a single market without internal tariff barriers will go into effect as scheduled next Jan. 1, uncertainty continues over how much further toward union Europe will move, since the Maastricht treaty cannot go into effect unless all 12 countries ratify it. Danish voters rejected the treaty by a narrow margin last June.
The European leaders reaffirmed their intention today to press ahead with European union without renegotiating the treaty, but in a statement called the "Birmingham Declaration" they tried to answer some of the concerns about it as well.
"The Community must develop together as twelve, on the basis of the Maastricht treaty, while respecting, as the treaty does, the interests and diversity of member states," the leaders said in their final communique. The leaders also agreed to give the Danish Parliament and Government until mid-December to decide how they propose to ratify the treaty in light of the negative outcome of their June referendum.
The European leaders also reaffirmed the goals of the treaty, which lays down strict criteria for economic and monetary convergence before monetary union can occur. But many European bankers, particularly in Germany, the community's dominant economy, believe that even if the treaty is ratified, monetary union will not be achievable for many years.
"I don't believe that at all," Chancellor Helmut Kohl said after the meeting, referring to the doubts about achieving monetary union. "There have always been periods of defeatism, but we've always managed to go forward step by step despite them."
Other leaders today also voiced optimism, though in chanceries all around Europe, many of their subordinate officials now say that the Maastricht treaty was a step too far, too soon, one that all European Governments failed to explain convincingly to their voters.
"The Maastricht treaty will bring direct benefits to individual citizens," the leaders said in their Birmingham declaration. "All of us must do more to make this clear." They vowed also to "make the Community more open" and "to ensure a better informed public debate on its activities."
The meetings today were held behind the closed glass walls of the new Birmingham conference center, in the heart of one of Britain's most battered industrial cities, though Mr. Major had proposed letting television cameras in for the opening statements and a discussion by the Foreign Ministers.
 
Reports on Mitterrand's Health
 The BBC reported that President Francois Mitterrand took ill today at the meeting, but the Associated Press quoted French officials as saying the reports were untrue. Mr. Mitterrand has recently been treated for prostate cancer.
Answering widespread fears that further movement toward union would come at the expense of member states' national identity, the leaders agreed that "greater unity can be achieved without excessive centralization."
Mr. Major, clearly the European leader who is now under the most acutepolitical pressure, affirmed tonight that he would submit the Maastricht treaty to Parliament for ratification soon after the House of Commons reconvenes next week.
He originally wanted the summit meeting to discuss the strains in the European monetary system that caused Britain to pull out last month. Britain's withdrawal came after Germany refused to lower its own interest rates because of fears by its independent central bank that such a move would trigger inflation in Germany.
Mr. Major did not even tell the other leaders this morning what the Bank of England was about to announce. "The question of British interest rates wasn't discussed," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister John Major, left, said he wanted "to get the community back on track to achieve a period of stability." He and President Francois Mitterrand arrived in Birmingham, England, yesterday for a meeting. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The U.S. trade deficit widened sharply in August, to $9 billion, as American exports suffered their biggest drop in five years, the Commerce Department reported, while imports fell moderately. In another dismal economic report, the Government said that industrial output fell two-tenths of 1 percent in September. [Page 41.]
President Bush was to unveil a plan to cut car insurance premiums nationwide in a New Jersey campaign speech, his aides said, but he became so rattled by jeering Clinton supporters that he railed against the Democrat, accusing him of evading the draft. [1.]
Insurance regulators are intrigued by the President's bold plan, which is intended to drive most auto injury claims out of court and pare individual premiums by 20 to 30 percent. [41.]
Ross Perot contended a $754 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts would produce a budget surplus in six years, during a half-hour telecast for which he paid NBC $150,000. [7.]
 
Companies
Pratt & Whitney said it would lay off 3,600 workers in Connecticut over the next eight months because of a steep drop in orders for its aircraft engines from commercial airlines. [1.]
G.M. projected a large loss in an S.E.C. filing, around $845 million for the third quarter, or 20 percent better than the $1.06 billion deficit a year earlier. [41.]
Barry Diller denied he was negotiating to buy NBC. Shares of parent G.E. rose $1.125 to $76.25, but analysts cited its recent strong earnings, rather than the published report involving the former Fox chairman's interest in the network. [41.]
American Airlines' Robert L. Crandall is winning praise from analysts, travel agents and airline consultants for his efforts to institute a new fare structure, although he himself told analysts in New York that the four-tier structure was a failure. [41.]
Eastman Kodak said it would take charges of $140 million against third-quarter earnings because of costs associated with selling businesses and with an early-retirement program. [43.]
Texas Instruments reported a sharp improvement in earnings for the third quarter, with its chip unit posting its first profit since the last quarter of 1989. The company earned $57 million, or 58 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $113 million a year ago. [43.]
 
 International
European leaders pledged to continue working for political and monetary union, as economic strains continued to pull them further apart. Britain, the host country, lowered interest rates a full percentage point to 8 percent, sending the pound down. [1.]
Britain's rate cut was clear evidence of the wide gulf between the European nations' individual economic needs and their professed desire for greater economic integration. [4.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks closed nearly unchanged after a recovery in bond prices rescued the market from earlier losses of more than 30 points. The Dow industrials slipped 0.27 to close at 3,174.41. [44.]
The negative economic news helped bond prices, but they still fell as traders reacted to fears of the Federal deficit. [44.]
The dollar advanced against most major currencies except the yen after the Bank of England cut key lending rates and traders sold the pound. [51.]
Oil prices slipped 5 cents a barrel, as traders cashed in profits from two days of gains. [51.]
 
Today's Columns
Straphangers could get a tax break -- one of several tax provisions in the energy bill that President Bush is expected to sign. But deductions for employer-provided parking spaces would be capped at $155. John H. Cushman Jr.: Your Taxes. [42.]
Dried-out seaweed is used to fight fires in a compound patented by a small California company, taking the kelp left over after algin is removed. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [42.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Independent;
In Half-Hour, Perot Details Plan for Cutting Deficit

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 16

 BODY:
With his campaign for President still lagging far behind his Republican and Democratic rivals, Ross Perot took to the airwaves tonight to lay out his plans for eliminating the Federal budget deficit and radically changing Federal elections laws.
Using a half-hour block of time he bought from NBC for $150,000, the Dallas billionaire detailed a $754 billion package of tax increases, spending cuts and additional Federal spending that he said would produce a Federal budget surplus in six years and would spur economic growth. The format of tonight's show was similar to his last 30-minute broadcast last week when he detailed what he saw as the problems wrought by the $4 trillion national debt. 
 Mr. Perot has often spoken of the "shared sacrifices" that his plans would require of Americans, but this was the first time he has publicly discussed just how painful those sacrifices might be.
Seated at a polished wood table, Mr. Perot used a stack of more than 20 hand-held charts to illustrate his points. This time, however, the writing on his charts was much larger, in response, he said, to viewer complaints about the small-sized print on his charts in his last program.
 
'This One Does Add Up'
 In providing specifics of his deficit-reduction package Mr. Perot chastised both President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton for what he said were, in essence, bogus plans for ending Federal red ink.
"The Wall Street Journal asked the President and Governor Clinton after they looked at their economic plans and said, 'Can either one of you folks add?' " Mr. Perot said during the broadcast. "This one does add up. It is real."
Almost all of the proposals outlined by Mr. Perot tonight are in his book, "United We Stand: How We Can Take Back Our Country." But tonight was the first time the independent candidate had presented his plan in person and in his own folksy style. By choosing to present the plan on his own 30-minute program, and by refraining, as he did Thursday night, to speak of it in any detail in the Presidential debates, Mr. Perot has, so far, avoided having to answer questions about it.
Under his plan, Mr. Perot would cut Federal spending on optional programs by $315 billion and automatic spending that benefits certain classes of people, like the elderly or the poor, by $268 billion. He would raise taxes on individuals by $293 billion and on businesses by $49 billion. Changes in benefit programs, including higher Medicare premiums and increased taxes on benefits for some Social Security recipients, would produce an additional savings of $268 billion, Mr. Perot said.
To spur the economy, Mr. Perot proposed increasing Federal spending by $109 billion and cutting certain taxes, including some capital gains taxes, by $62 billion.
 
Pledge to Be Flexible
 Responding to criticism that his plan was too harsh a jolt for an already troubled economy, Mr. Perot said he would be flexible and would modify his program if it hampered economic growth. "If common sense and the interest of the American people dictates slowing down, we will slow down," he said. "But the thing you can't do, is do nothing."
But cutting the deficit and invigorating the economy were not the only subjects Mr. Perot took up. Much of his presentation was devoted to his ideas for overhauling the political process and what he termed making the Federal Government more responsive to average citizens.
"We must make adequate television time available in equal amounts to competing candidates," he said, though he did not mention whether such a proposal would extend to minor parties like the Communist Party or the Libertarian Party.
Mr. Perot proposed limiting political contributions to $1,000 and eliminating "all possibilities of special interests giving large sums of money to candidates." He emphasized that "we must leave no loopholes." He said he would require members of Congress and the President to turn over unused campaign contributions to the Treasury and he proposed requiring that pay increases for Congress, the President and Federal employees be subject to voter approval.
"That'll keep their heads clear on who they work for," he said.
He also said he would eliminate all of the perquisites, including free haircuts, use of a gymnasium and free prescription drugs, currently enjoyed by members of Congress and the executive branch, and he would subject Congress to the provisions of Federal civil rights and occupational safety laws.
While a number of Mr. Perot's suggestions are ones that have been advocated in the past by government reformers, some experts say they might be unconstitutional.
While, Mr. Perot is critical of both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton for offering economic plans that do not add up, there are some elements of his program where his math seems shaky.
For example, Mr. Perot suggested that $268 billion could be saved by overhauling entitlement programs. Among his ideas are increases in Medicare taxes for those earning more than $130,000 a year, higher Medicare premiums, an increase in the taxes on Social Security benefits for upper-income recipients and a 33 percent reduction in cost of living increases over five years for military and Federal pensions.
But, under Mr. Perot's plan, $141 billion in the savings from changing entitlements comes from containing the increase in health care costs. Yet, Mr. Perot offered no detailed plan on how to achieve this.
 
Plan for Better Health Care
 During his television show, the Dallas businessman noted that Germany spends 8 percent and Japan spends 6.5 percent of their gross national product on health care, while the United States spends 12 percent of its G.N.P. "We can save money, have world-class health care," Mr. Perot said. "Or if all else fails, just copy the countries in the other part of the world that have better health care than we do at a lower cost."
In his book, Mr. Perot makes the same claim of a $141 billion savings as a result of health care changes. But the only plan he outlined for short-term savings was to say that "various health-care experts and representatives of affected groups should have a series of work sessions with Government officials" to develop a strategy.
For the long term, Mr. Perot's program seems to be more bromides than concrete proposals. For example he called for such things as the establishment of "an independent Federal agency" to oversee cost containment efforts and the "reaching of a consensus on a set of principles for reform."
He also advocated a "basic package of universal coverage and appropriate tax treatment of health benefits." But he did not say how much such a package would cost and how it would be financed.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Budget Deficit Is the Thorn In Clinton's Economic Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton's campaign is struggling with a tricky economic puzzle: how to give the economy a quick boost without increasing the Federal budget deficit.
Campaigning today in Richmond, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to figure out some new policies "to bump this economy some" without widening the deficit. 
 But concerned that it may not be possible to spur job growth without a short-term jump in the deficit, Mr. Clinton's economics advisers are debating whether to urge him to raise spending and embrace new tax breaks for business if he is elected.
Even to discuss the issue in public is risky because the mere mention of measures that might increase the deficit could frighten voters as well as financial markets that are worried about inflation.
 
Deficit-Cutting Program
 Campaign officials said today that if continued slow growth pushed a Clinton Administration to increase spending or approve tax credits to stimulate business investment, the effort would be coupled with a long-term program to cut the budget deficit.
"If the economy ever got so weak that stimulus was needed, it would only be done in combination with very specific, defined hard-deficit reduction plans," Gene Sperling, the Clinton campaign's economic issues coordinator, said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Clinton's advisers are snagged over what is the best advice to give him on fiscal stimulus because they, like many of the nation's leading economists, are puzzled over whether the economy is picking up steam or is dead in the water.
"A lot of people are talking about stimulus now because they think the economy is deteriorating again, not just stuck," said Robert Shapiro, a Clinton adviser who is at the Democratic Leadership Council, an organization of centrist Democrats. "I think the jury is still out on that."
Today in Richmond, Mr. Clinton was careful to steer clear of advocating a stimulus program that would widen the deficit.
"There may be some way to increase investment without increasing the deficit," he said. "We have to keep these things in very careful balance."
He noted that he was "absolutely" concerned about the harmful effects that a short-term stimulus package could have on financial markets if it was perceived as adding to the deficit.
 
Goal to Stimulate Investment
 Perhaps mindful of President Bush's repeated accusation that he plans to raise taxes sharply, Mr. Clinton also made a point today of saying that he wanted to find new ways to cut spending to clear the way for more tax cuts to stimulate investment, including an investment tax credit.
In the Presidential debate Thursday night, he said it was more important to stimulate the torpid economy than to take stern measures that would reduce the Federal deficit, because he said this could abort the nation's weak economic recovery. But he has stopped short of embracing traditional Democratic notions of creating jobs through increased deficit spending.
Mr. Sperling, the Clinton official, who is a former aide to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and to Michael S. Dukakis in his 1988 Presidential campaign, said of the Arkansas Governor: "He has gotten criticisms from people who say he should reduce the deficit faster, even if it hurts growth in the short term, and he has gotten criticisms from people who say, 'Ignore the deficit so you can get a little economic kick in the short term.' He has resisted pressure on both sides."
Clinton campaign officials said one idea to create jobs without increasing the deficit was to speed spending of money authorized under the existing Transportation Act. They also favor speeding spending on the $20 billion that Mr. Clinton plans to invest annually on highways, bridges and other public works. Clinton officials say this spending would not increase the deficit because it is part of the Governor's overall economic plan, which promises to cut the deficit in half in four years.
Mr. Sperling said that if Mr. Clinton was elected, Clinton aides would tell states and cities to get ready to move ahead in early 1993 with highway projects that have been shelved because of lack of cash. This, he said, could put people back to work and raise consumer confidence, thus giving the economy needed momentum.
 
Results Hardly Noticeable
 But Government economists say that spending money for public works projects early in the year instead of later would have no important effect on the economy. "You're talking about spending a few billion in March that you would spend anyway in July in a $6 trillion economy," said one economist, who asked not to be identified. "That would not give you very many more jobs, if any."
In its own effort to stimulate the economy without raising the deficit, the Bush Administration this year advanced the spending for airport construction, rural housing, waste treatment plants and several other projects.
Budget officers said the result was hardly noticeable.
Robert Reich, a Harvard professor who is a longtime adviser to Mr. Clinton, has said recently that he would support increased deficit spending to create jobs if the economy remained weak into January. But other advisers fear that increased deficit spending could alienate voters and send chills through the nation's financial markets.
Talking about the possibility of pump-priming, Roger Altman, an investment banker who is a top economic adviser to Mr. Clinton, said: "I think that depends on conditions in the economy over the next three months. You have to be very respectful of the need to reduce the deficit over the medium- and long-term and you have to be very respectful of the financial markets' sensitivities."
One concern is that a higher deficit, by creating fears of inflation, would push up long-term interest rates, undermining recovery by hurting home building and business investment.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widens on Export Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit widened sharply in August, to $9 billion, as American exports suffered their biggest drop in five years, the Commerce Department reported today. Imports fell moderately.
A separate set of data released today showed industrial output falling two-tenths of 1 percent in September. The decline was the third in the last four months for this indicator of activity at factories, mines and utilities, which together account for about 30 percent of the economy. 
 Both reports were the latest in a procession of economic setbacks. The trade figures were so weak that some analysts predicted that gross domestic product for the third quarter, to be reported on Oct. 27, would be barely positive after a quite modest 1.5 percent rate for the second quarter.
 
Overseas Demand Weakens
 The worsened trade picture seems to have been caused mainly by the weakening in the economies of American customers in Europe and by lethargy in the Japanese business climate as well. The gloomy report came as European leaders met in Britain to seek a breakthrough on long-stymied negotiations to overhaul the world trading system.
Though the figures gyrate from month to month, the report also tended to undermine the Bush Administration's contentions that the nation was transforming itself into an export superpower.
"Last night during the debate President Bush sounded out of touch when he said that exports save the economy," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who is the House majority leader. "The President's so-called export engine is running out of gas."
Michael J. Boskin, chief economic adviser to Mr. Bush, was traveling, his office said, and was unavailable to comment.
 
Broad-Based Decline
 The slump in exports was $2.3 billion, or 6.1 percent, to $35.5 billion. It was registered in most product categories and with a wide array of countries.
"This is symptomatic of the worldwide economic slowdown we observed last summer," said Barry Rogstad, head of the American Business Conference, an association of rapidly growing companies.
He said the trade deficit is not likely to improve soon, with import growth probably exceeding export growth in the coming year because economic recovery would come earlier to the United States than to its trading partners.
For August, imports, at $44.5 billion, declined about $600 million, or 1.3 percent, from the peak of $45.1 billion reached in July.
 
Some Figures Revised
 The month-to-month deterioration of $1.7 billion was enlarged by the fact that recalculation of July's deficit brought it down to $7.3 billion compared with the $7.8 billion originally reported. Still, August's $9 billion merchandise deficit -- services, tourism and the like are excluded -- was the highest since November 1990, which had been the last of five straight months to register $9 billion or more.
The dive in exports was particularly evident in a $900 million drop for industrial supplies and materials and a $700 million drop in capital goods. But automotive products, consumer goods and foods and beverages also fell by $200 million each.
Among imports, the biggest change was a $300 million decline in industrial supplies and materials, the report also showed.
By specific product, exports of raw tobacco fell $160 million, but this was largely offset by a $125 million increase in foreign sales of manufactured tobacco products.
When frequently recurring seasonal factors are excluded, the deficit widened far less -- to $9.9 billion from July's revised $9.6 billion. This is the basis on which geographic breakdowns are reported, and a vast improvement was shown in trade with Western Europe, as a $1.1 billion July deficit shriveled to less than $100 million in August.
Still, Patrick J. Moriarty, chief investment officer at Bank Julius Baer in New York, noted there was fresh evidence this week of faltering demand in Japan and Germany. "I don't see where the improvement's going to come from," he said.
 
A Mixed Picture

 
 The deficit with Japan narrowed $200 million, to $3.7 billion, but it more than doubled with Canada, to $825 million, and expanded by $400 million with the newly industrialized Asian countries of Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong.
The nation's bill for imported crude oil eased $300 million in August, to $3.5 billion, as volume fell 17 million barrels and the price per barrel fell 22 cents, to $17.96.
The American surplus in advanced technology products slumped to $1.6 billion, from $2.1 billion in July and $2.3 billion in August 1991.
The industrial production data, compiled by the Federal Reserve, showed declines of four-tenths of 1 percent for factories and 1.2 percent at mines. Those drops were not fully offset by a 2.6 percent surge in output by the nation's utilities.
The overall output decline of two-tenths of 1 percent was only half as large as those of June and August, but analysts have become disheartened, especially since their hopes had been buoyed by an advance in July of eight-tenths of 1 percent.
 
A Fear of Stagnation
 Referring to both industrial production, considered a reliable coincident indicator, and the trade data, Norman Robertson, an economist at Mellon Bank, said: "This is very unsettling news. It raises the possibility of a longer period of stagnation than has been widely expected."
C. Fred Bergsten of the Institute of International Economics -- and an occasional adviser to Gov. Bill Clinton -- noted that a deterioration in trade had cut second-quarter economic growth in half and that if September figures showed no improvement the third quarter might register no growth at all.
The Fed's report showed that production of consumer durables eased last month, mainly because of a decline in goods for the home. Nondurables rose, however, with the aid of sharp increases in electricity and gasoline. Business equipment declined three-tenths of 1 percent after rising twice that much in August.
Assemblies of motor vehicles were at a 9.5 million rate for the third straight month as higher output of cars was offset by lower output of light trucks.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congressional Races;
2 Women Take On Tough Incumbents

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
November's elections are sure to bring a sharp increase in the current total of 31 women in Congress. But defeating an incumbent is still the hardest way to get there, for a man or a woman, even in a year when the institution's popularity has sunk.
Most of the women likely to be elected are running in open seats, where the incumbent did not seek re-election, or in new House districts, created either to account for increased population or to give black or Hispanic voters a chance to control a district. 
 But other women hope to win uphill races against veteran lawmakers like Ron Mazzoli, a 22-year Kentucky Democrat, and Philip M. Crane, a 23-year Illinois Republican. Each challenger campaigns for abortion rights and labels her opponent as a typical obstacle to change.
 
Congress Itself Issue In Kentucky Battle
 Susan Stokes is running against a Congress she argues is so concerned with its own re-election that it is dominated by special interests and cannot cope with the deficit or the health-care crisis.
She also has an advantage few challengers can dream of: She is outspending a long-term incumbent. For her opponent, Mr. Mazzoli, is so far from being a captive of those special interests that he not only refuses to take money from political action committees, he takes no individual contributions of more than $100. He will probably be outspent, $325,000 to $225,000.
She uses much of her financial advantage on television advertisements that suggest he is part of the mess in Washington, as reflected in the House Bank affair and other scandals. Mr. Mazzoli had no overdrafts, but Ms. Stokes contends that while he is a man of "high integrity," he has done nothing to reform the Congress, and not much else either.
A former schoolteacher who was gerrymandered out of her seat in the State Legislature last December, Ms. Stokes, 49 years old, says she is a pro-choice Republican who does not want the Government involved in personal decisions, like abortion, or business decisions, like whether to grant employees family and medical leave.
Though she does not emphasize it, abortion is the critical issue that gets her a hearing from women and younger Democrats in the Third District, which gained some suburban Republicans in reapportionment but is still solidly Democratic.
Mr. Mazzoli, 59, tries to counter that appeal with endorsements from women who disagree with his all-out anti-abortion voting record but applaud his other generally liberal stands. He attacks Ms. Stokes for voting against an education reform package in the Legislature and opposing family leave legislation, and he says she has not matched his courage in supporting gun control.
And he works at rebuilding ties with unions he has sometimes opposed. He told electrical workers on Sunday that he wanted to be part of the Clinton-Gore revolution that would "squeeze the big guys out, put the little people back in."
And he argues that he, too, represents change in spurning big contributions from the "special interest money that is distorting American politics." Incumbency, he argues, is not a matter of being in office, but "a state of mind."
But Ms. Stokes argues that Congress has to be shaken up, has to get out of its old spending habits so it can find the money to solve serious problems. And, to a suburban book club, she defended her campaign's style: "Those are issues; those are not personal attacks. But we can't just talk about how nice I am and win this election."
Mr. Mazzoli was first elected in 1970 as an anti-war Democrat. In 1992, he says, "I smell change in the air." He is talking about a Democrat in the White House -- and hoping he's not also talking about a particular Republican in the House of Representatives.
 
Veteran Republican Challenged in Illinois
 On the surface, Sheila A. Smith is running a traditional challenger's campaign, saying her opponent is more interested in abstract theory and special interests than in the problems of the Eighth Congressional District, northwest of Chicago.
She argues that Representative Crane, a doctrinaire conservative, is so busy "looking at life through a rear-view mirror" that he has missed the point that business, government and labor have to work together.
But in what is probably the most Republican district in the state, Ms. Smith, 46, needs more to compete with an incumbent who never had a tough race before a tough primary in March. Her way to voters' attention is to talk about the small business she runs, Glowlite, which makes appliance bulbs.
And, like most female challengers in 1992, she hopes to win votes from the other party's women by supporting abortion rights. She contends that Mr. Crane is inconsistent if he wants less government everywhere else but favors laws limiting abortion.
Mr. Crane argues that the issue won't swing many votes. He told a forum last week, "I cannot condone the idea of abortion for convenience because suddenly you've got an opportunity to make a European trip and you don't want to do it pregnant."
But Mr. Crane, 59, has an anti-incumbent pitch of his own. He told his opponent in a cable-television debate Monday that "the most profound, significant change would be, for the first time in 38 years, to elect a Republican Congress." He doesn't talk about scandals like the one involving the House Bank as much as he does about the power House Democrats use to handcuff Republicans.
Arguing that the economy was ready to rebound, he told Ms. Smith: "Business inventories are down. Business debt is down. Personal debt is down. Inflation is down. Interest rates are down. And most important----"
"Jobs are down," she interrupted.
A onetime leader of the conservative movement who preached a return to the gold standard, Mr. Crane is less visible these days in Washington. But he insists he has served the generally affluent district by never voting for a tax increase.
Neither campaign is expected to spend much over $100,000. A third candidate, Joe Dillier, seems to have almost no support.
Ms. Smith came to this district only after the Democrats had fielded no primary candidate and she had seen signs of vulnerability in Mr. Crane's 55 percent primary showing against Gary Skoien, a supporter of abortion rights. Her brother, an aide to Senator Alan Dixon, thought of running. But party leaders asked her to run, and she rented an apartment in the district.
Now, others in her company are making the fall trip to Japan she usually takes for business. Her travel goals are defined by campaign buttons parodying the Jimmy Stewart movie: "Ms. Smith Goes to Washington."

HEADLINE: Bush's Bold Plan for Car Insurance

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
President Bush's plan to contain exploding auto insurance premiums, which was all but drowned out by campaign protesters at a speech yesterday in Edison, N.J., will not become law anytime soon; the plan has not yet even been translated into a legislative proposal.
But state regulators and insurance companies, now trapped between the reality of rising costs and the public's fury over rising premiums, are likely to welcome the effort to elevate the debate over auto insurance affordability to a national forum. And many policy analysts will no doubt be intrigued with the President's bold plan, which could drive most auto injury claims out of court and pare individual premiums by 20 to 30 percent. 
 "It offers a choice in what is now a one-size-fits-all system dominated by attorneys," said Michael J. Horowitz, the director of the judicial studies program at the Manhattan Institute, a public policy research organization, who wrote the proposal with Jeffrey O'Connell of the University of Virginia Law School.
 
Reliance on Legal System
 Twenty-eight states, among them California, Ohio and Illinois, rely exclusively on the legal system to settle liability claims in injuries caused by auto accidents. To collect, you must settle with the other party's insurance company or win a negligence suit in court.
Other states, among them New York, augment this liability approach with "no fault" protection, in which those injured are guaranteed some standard compensation for out-of-pocket losses from their own insurance companies. To sue for negligence, they must pass some test of injury, ranking from very modest medical bills to very severe impairment.
Numerous states have attempted to cap the rise in auto insurance premiums, which increased three times as fast as inflation during the 1980's and have become a thorn in the body politic.
Indeed in New Jersey, where by no coincidence the President tried to unveil his plan, the state government's effort to contain premiums without containing the cost of accidents led to the collapse of the private insurance market.
In California, politicians are still scrambling for a fix that will either stabilize rates or put the blame on the insurance industry.
The White House plan is elegantly simple in conception if complicated in design. It would leave with the states the basic responsibility for regulating automobile insurance. But it would require the states to give drivers the choice of buying less expensive coverage that eliminates the chance to collect for "pain and suffering" -- thus avoiding the drawn out and costly trial process that has pushed up prices.
Under this approach, the primary responsibility for compensation would rest with the injured person's own insurer. Someone who bought this insurance could neither sue someone else to collect for pain and suffering, nor be sued by anyone to cover their pain and suffering.
Where an accident involved parties who had both elected to stay with the old system, it would be business as usual; juries could still be called up and still award huge sums to the injured for pain and suffering.
But when both parties in an accident had elected the new-style coverage, the victim would look to his own insurance company to cover medical bills and lost income, regardless of fault. If his coverage were inadequate, he could sue the other driver for the balance. Awards for negligence, however, would be limited to economic losses, and not pain and suffering. The only exception: when the injury was linked to alcohol or drug abuse.
What would happen if a driver who chose to pay extra to maintain old-style insurance is injured by someone who had opted out of pain and suffering claims? The fully covered driver could only collect from the negligent driver's insurance company for economic losses. But he would be permitted to make a claim against his own insurance company for pain and suffering -- and even sue it for compensation.
This might seem an odd solution. But Mr. O'Connell, the co-author, notes that it is precisely analogous to what happens today when an insured driver is injured by an underinsured one: the injured party is compensated by his own insurance company under his own "uninsured driver" coverage.
 
Savings Are Estimated
 The White House estimates that the payoff for those who give up the right to claim for pain and suffering would be a 50 to 60 percent cut in the bodily injury liability portion of their insurance premiums. And since bodily injury represents about half the cost of auto insurance, the overall savings would run to 25 to 30 percent. It is not known, of course, how many people would sign up.
This estimate is independently confirmed by Stephen Carroll, an economist at the Rand Institute for Civil Justice in California. Mr. Carroll cautions, however, that just one-third of the savings -- roughly $10 billion annually if everyone opted for lower premiums -- would come from reduced costs in processing and litigating claims. The remaining two-thirds would come out of payments for injury claims.
Is the implicit trade, the loss of $2 in potential compensation to save $3 in premiums, a fair deal? Robert Hunter, the president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, worries that consumers would too casually give up the right to sue for pain and suffering, and perhaps also fail to buy enough no-fault protection to cover potential economic losses. "People would make the wrong choices." he concluded.
George Priest, a professor at the Yale Law School, has a different complaint. He thinks that shifting the burden to the injured parties' insurers would serve the interests of bad drivers, who are currently punished for their transgressions with sky-high premiums. "This system would be very good for high-risk drivers," he said.
 
A Matter of Luck?
 But supporters think the critics have missed the point or, more charitably, are too willing to sacrifice the good in their quest for the best. In the real world, Mr. O'Connell said, pain and suffering is a lottery in which awards have little to do with injury and much to do with luck. Most people, he said, would be better off with certain access to modest no-fault compensation for economic losses.
And while high-risk drivers would pay less than they would under the current system, Mr. O'Connell argues that the high cost of insurance is not an effective deterrent to accidents. Many who are priced out of insurance today, he notes, simply drive without coverage: In California, for example, a quarter of the drivers involved in accidents are uninsured.
Mr. Horowitz, the co-author, offers another twist. The switch to a system in which drivers insure themselves against injuries caused by others, he says, would give insurers incentives to reward drivers who purchased safer cars. It hardly pays, after all, to offer premium discounts for air bags if the life they save is not the life covered by the insurance policy.
Issues of equity and safety surely matter. However the prospects for translating the proposal into law probably depend less on the policy debate than on the push and shove of the interests most directly affected.
 
Trial Lawyers Against
 On one side are trial lawyers. Roxanne Conlin, president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, scoffs at President Bush's dismissal of coverage for pain and suffering. "He makes the proposal to harm injured people," she said.
On the other side are insurance companies, which are no longer able to pass on the rising cost of accidents to their customers. While the industry hardly speaks with a single voice, Mr. O'Connell reports there was "considerable enthusiasm" for the plan from Geico, State Farm and USAA.
The balance of political power, suggests Orin Kramer, an insurance industry consultant in Princeton, N.J., may rest with state regulators who have been wrestling with cost-containment proposals ranging from utility-style rate regulation to generous no-fault insurance financed by gasoline taxes. "The state insurance commissioners have a natural role as the ombudsmen of cost reduction," Mr. Kramer said.

HEADLINE: New York, New York, A Goodwill Games Town

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
From 64 cities nearly two years ago to 4 finalists when the winner was chosen on Thursday night in Atlanta, New York became the unexpected choice to stage the Goodwill Games in 1998, for a reason none of the other candidates could possibly match.
It's New York. 
 In the end, after considering all the swimming pools, track and field stadiums and velodromes necessary for the Olympic-style competition held every fourth year, New York and surrounding areas of New Jersey and Long Island prevailed over bids from Dallas-Fort Worth, South Florida and St. Louis because of Ellis Island, the United Nations, the Statue of Liberty, Broadway, Wall Street, Madison Avenue, television networks and 175 ethnic groups that live in the region.
 
High-Placed Help
 It helped considerably that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Gov. Jim Florio and Mayor David N. Dinkins played visible roles in supporting the efforts, and that a slew of business leaders from the region committed their support, financial and otherwise. But in the last hours of consideration, when a nine-member committee was reviewing what Sandy Knapp, a chairwoman, called "four absolutely fantastic bids," New York swayed the panel on the sheer weight of its role as the country's largest city.
Of course, the negative aspects of the metropolitan area were taken into consideration. The committee sought assurances that traffic would not become a problem, that adequate security of athletes and officials could be maintained and that the Games' effort to gain media attention would not become lost among the region's other daily events.
"But it came down to this," Ms. Knapp said yesterday after a news conference in Madison Square Garden with the Governors, the Mayor and dozens of civic, business and sports leaders. "Every major city in the country is the center of something. But here, you have the center of commerce and trade in the United States, media, communications, culture, entertainment; everything that's important to the future of the Goodwill Games."
The economic projections of the Goodwill Games could make them important for the future of the region. Officials from the Goodwill Games contend that the Seattle area benefited by $350 million for the 1990 event. They estimated that the 1998 event could generate $500 million.
Don Smith, president of the New York City Sports Commission, which coordinated the bid, said the operating budget would be $50 million. But that figure would be offset by ticket sales, television rights fees, contributions and government subsidies.
 
A Gesture of Peace
 The Goodwill Games were hatched six years ago by Ted Turner, the president of the Turner Broadcasting System, disappointed over the boycotts of the two previous summer Olympics. They began in 1986 in Moscow primarily as a gesture of peace but also as programming for the cable system he owns. Then, with a format that alternated the Games between the United States and Russia, they were held a second time, in Seattle. In 1994, they are scheduled to be staged in St. Petersburg, Russia.
The Goodwill Games have achieved status as a prominent international sports event just below the level of the Olympics, which in Barcelona, Spain, last summer involved four times the 2,500 athletes expected to participate in St. Petersburg.
But organizers said yesterday that awarding the 1998 Games to New York was an important step in helping the event expand its profile.
"I could not be more excited," said Mr. Turner, who was lobbied personally by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Dinkins for nearly an hour on Wednesday afternoon in Atlanta. "Your guys, your political leaders, the Governor and the Mayor, made a phenomenal presentation, a great presentation, and it will be a blast."
Through most of the campaign to stage the 1998 Games, New York's bid ranked far off the lead, Ms. Knapp and others said. Members of the site selection committee were concerned that some of the venues proposed for use were inadequate. There was particular concern that the proposed center for aquatic sports, at Rutgers University, in Piscataway, N.J., lacked seats, and the region was without a suitable velodrome for cycling events.
It was only last spring that the concerns were addressed, Mr. Smith said, starting with the appointment of a new board to oversee the bid process. The group consisted of business, civic and cultural leaders, to reflect a wider commitment by the region.
The problem with the aquatic center was apparently solved by New York State, which committed $4 million for construction of an outdoor complex at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. A new or refurbished velodrome was assured by Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the New York City Council, who added a $2 million line to the 1993 city budget to be spent in 1995 to refurbish a velodrome last used for the 1964 Olympic trials or to purchase a new one.
By this week, Ms. Knapp said, there was little tangible difference among the bidding groups, other than that New York could provide the Games a cachet they have not yet achieved.
The remaining uncertainties about support were answered on Wednesday, when 49 representatives of New York's bid group, including Governor Cuomo and Mayor Dinkins, flew to Atlanta on two private jets. Dallas-Fort Worth sent 15 people, South Florida 11 and St. Louis 6. Unlike any other political officials, Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Dinkins, with several associates, met with Mr. Turner privately for 45 minutes. Mr. Turner had no vote in the final decision, but several people close to him, who did not want to be identified, said he was impressed with their presentations and excited by the possibilities of his Games in New York.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 NEW POLICE CHIEF
IS A VETERAN
Mayor Dinkins appointed Raymond W. Kelly, a New York City police veteran, as the city's 37th Police Commissioner. The selection ended a candidate search and deliberations that took two months and put Mr. Kelly in charge of a Police Department shaken by allegations of corruption and racial insensitivity. Page 1.
 
 TEACHER SHOT AT SCHOOL
A 23-year-old machine-shop teacher was shot in the shoulder in a stairwell at a vocational high school in Brooklyn by an unknown assailant who apparently melted into streams of students entering and leaving rooms between classes. The police said the assailant's motive and identity were unknown. Page 29.
 
 RUCKUS AT CROWN HEIGHTS TRIAL
The trial of a black teen-ager charged with murdering a Hasidic scholar in Crown Heights degenerated into a series of screaming matches, as the judge and the lawyers sniped and sparred over the way the defense lawyer was conducting his case. Page 29.
 
 CARDINAL O'CONNOR GOES HOME
John Cardinal O'Connor left St. Vincent's Medical Center 20 hours after he was taken there by ambulance after complaining of nausea and light-headedness during the annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. Doctors determined that the 72-year-old Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York had suffered an intestinal virus. Page 30.
 
 REGION
 
 MORE LAYOFFS
IN CONNECTICUT
Pratt & Whitney, the jet-engine maker, said that it would lay off 3,600 workers in Connecticut, more than 16 percent of its local work force, over the next eight months because of a steep drop in commercial-airline contracts. The news sent shock waves through a Connecticut economy that had begun to stabilize in the recession, and it seemed certain to deepen President's George Bush's re-election problems in a state he once called home. Page 1.
 
 AN AGREEMENT ON SEIZED ASSETS
The Suffolk County District Attorney, James M. Catterson, agreed to make a public accounting of money he has seized from criminals, a source of revenue that some county legislators have described as a secret "slush fund." In return, Mr. Catterson will retain complete control of the money. Page 31.
 
 AN APPEAL TO JURY IN ABUSE CASE
Defense lawyers in the Glen Ridge sex-assault trial denounced the state's case, saying that their clients were not criminals, but teen-age boys who were swayed by their hormones and a young woman's sexual aggression. In nearly four hours of opening statements, they appealed to the jurors to be fair and open-minded but not to apply their own sense of morality to the case. Page 31.
 
 A NEW FACE FOR 7th DISTRICT
The Seventh Congressional District, once the most ethnically varied political caldron in New Jersey, has been the fief of Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo for 20 years. But heading into next month's election, the redrawn Seventh District has lost its huge blocs of immigrants. And it has lost Mr. Rinaldo, who announced his retirement in September. All this means a once predictable district is now up for grabs. Page 31.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues -- Welfare;
Talk of Cutting Welfare Rolls Sounds Good, but Progress Is Far From Sure

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Since President Bush took office, the nation's welfare rolls have exploded to record highs.
What he and Gov. Bill Clinton propose to do about that offers a study in contrasts: Mr. Bush has a modest plan that is unlikely to do great good or harm, while Mr. Clinton calls for sweeping changes that will be difficult to enact and whose effects are impossible to predict. 
 Mr. Bush was virtually silent about welfare for three years and began discussing it only this year, after his poll takers found the subject played well to the public. This summer he issued a plan that calls on states to try more experimental programs, a modest change to what virtually everyone calls a deeply flawed system.
His aides acknowledge that their proposal would do little to reduce the welfare rolls in the short term. But they argue that the nation does not yet know how to cure long-term welfare dependency, and that the experiments might help find the key to future success.
 
Promising Radical Change
 The President's Democratic challenger, Mr. Clinton, has been active in welfare policy for a decade, and he is promising radical change. He calls for increased spending on education and training for welfare mothers, while promising to reduce the grants after two years, unless the recipients work or perform community service.
But for all his seeming specificity, Mr. Clinton has not committed himself on the crucial details that will spell the difference between significant and cosmetic change. And it is doubtful that the changes would be as bold as Mr. Clinton suggests once Congress, the bureaucracy and the budget weigh in.
It is also unclear whether a national work program would help welfare mothers, as Mr. Clinton suggests, or simply add to their already considerable stress. Its critics say it could leave them twice as busy but just as poor.
"I don't think the President has a plan," said Isabel V. Sawhill, an economist at the Urban Institute who is among the nation's leading welfare experts. "He has a few worthwhile notions, but they're certainly not going to solve the problem."
 
Common Sentiment
 Speaking about Mr. Clinton, she echoes a sentiment common to many welfare experts. "Clinton has adopted some of the most creative ideas in welfare policy," Ms. Sawhill said. "The question is whether he will put them into effect."
The third Presidential candidate, Ross Perot, has joined the others in proclaiming welfare undesirable. But his policy blueprint, "United We Stand; How We Can Take Back Our County," offers no specific welfare proposals, and he seldom mentions the topic.
Mr. Bush's first Presidential mention of welfare came in his inaugural speech, in the same paragraph as his famous promise to "make kinder the face of the nation and gentler the face of the world." He cited a litany of social ills he aimed to address, including homelessness, drug addiction and welfare. "My friends," he said, "we have work to do."
 
Scarcely Mentioned Topic
 But a computer search of Presidential documents shows that Mr. Bush scarcely mentioned welfare in the next three years. He finally returned to the subject in this year's State of the Union Message, quoting Franklin Roosevelt's admonitions that welfare not become a narcotic.
Mr. Bush's poll takers assembled a sample group of citizens on that night in January, in Arlington Heights, Ill., giving participants devices to register their responses on a computer. Fred Steeper, a poll taker, said the President's comments on welfare were among the most popular of the evening.
"It just confirmed that welfare reform is something people wanted to see done," he said.
A month later, Mr. Bush seized on welfare as a campaign issue in the primaries, with television commercials that promised to "change welfare and make the able-bodied work."
 
Switch to Harsh Words
 The switch to harsh language, from inaugural talk of kinder and gentler, continued. "We need to say, Get a job or get off the dole," Mr. Bush said in a July 31 speech devoted to welfare.
This talk has distressed some welfare experts, who call it an appeal to racial hostility. "It was a David Duke kind of signaling," said Richard Nathan, a former Nixon aide who wrote speeches on welfare for Mr. Bush in his 1980 campaign.
Mr. Bush's plan, announced in his July 31 speech, is not as bold as his talk. Its main plank would give states more flexibility to conduct experiments.
Some of these have been well-publicized. Wisconsin, for instance, has permission to cut the grants to welfare mothers if their children do not attend school.
Gail Wilensky, the chief White House welfare adviser, acknowledges that the changes are likely to bring large reductions in welfare rolls. "We -- and I mean the global we, the country -- do not know how to bring down long-term dependency," she said. She described the White House strategy as an effort "to learn as much as we can" through careful experiments.
Ms. Wilensky argues that Mr. Bush's welfare record should be viewed in a broader context that includes related areas like education, taxes and urban development.
In 1990, for instance, Mr. Bush signed a law that provides $18 billion in tax credits over five years for low-income workers, making it easier for welfare mothers to leave the rolls. Mr. Bush also signed a bill that provides more than $1 billion a year to subsidize child care, which also helps welfare mothers to seek jobs.
Mr. Bush also supports tax breaks intended to attract businesses to special inner-city zones. He has called for a voucher plan that would allow parents to send their children to the public or private school of their choice. And he has started a program to sell public housing to tenants, which he said would help stabilize distressed urban areas.
At the same time, he has presided over the largest increase in welfare rolls in two decades. About 4.8 million families now receive Aid to Families with Dependent Children, a 27 percent increase since Mr. Bush took office. The sudden rise, after more than a decade of stability, is largely a product of the recession rather than a change in policies by the Bush Administration.
Unlike Mr. Bush, Mr. Clinton accompanies his promise to "end welfare as we know it," with a seemingly detailed plan. As Governor, he ran one of the nation's first experimental job-search programs for welfare mothers. And he led the nation's governors in lobbying for the 1988 Family Support Act, which requires every state to run a training or work program for welfare mothers.
Mr. Clinton's plan to spend an additional $6 billion a year on training programs and tax credits is far more generous than the current system. But his plan to require work or community service after two years would also be far more strict.
Of the $6 billion, Mr. Clinton would devote $2 billion to an additional expansion of tax credits. His goal is to lift the earnings of all full-time workers to at least $13,924 a year -- enough to raise a family of four out of poverty.
Mr. Clinton would spend the remaining $4 billion to expand education and training, adding that sum to the $1 billion the Federal Government offers now. But even with this vast expansion, there is reason to question that the programs would have a great impact.
Much research on similar programs has shown that the effects are beneficial but small. Most recently, a study in Riverside, Calif., found that such a program had raised the annual earnings of welfare mothers by 65 percent. But their overall earnings still remained quite low: just $2,468, on average. The results in five other California counties were even more modest.
Other questions about Mr. Clinton's plan focus on the work requirements. The history of welfare reform is filled with measures that sounded strict but turned out to have large loopholes. And while Mr. Clinton's time limit of two years sounds air tight, he has already said there would be exceptions.
"I would go beyond two years if they were in a meaningful training program," he said in an interview in February. Other exemptions are bound to follow.
Mr. Clinton has also failed to specify what he means by "community service." He borrows many of his welfare ideas from David T. Ellwood, a Harvard professor working as an informal adviser to the campaign. Mr. Ellwood calls for the Government to create jobs for welfare mothers who cannot find them in the private sector.
But a public employment program for all the welfare mothers who cannot find jobs is likely to cost tens of billions of dollars; even at the minimum wage, a full-time job would pay almost twice the average welfare grant. "I don't want to promise to do that until I know we have the money," Mr. Clinton said in the interview.
Instead of offering real jobs, Mr. Clinton is likely to require welfare mothers to spend some time working off their grants -- by sweeping public buildings or working at day-care centers.
Critics say simply giving welfare mothers a broom does not leave them any less poor, just busier. "Most mothers with young children don't need to be busier," said Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University.
There are two reasons to suspect Mr. Clinton's plan will end up less bold than it seems: money and ideology. Ms. Sawhill said $4 billion is "probably too optimistic" a figure to run a national program. And Mr. Clinton would have to work with a Democratic establishment, in Congress and within his Administration, that has traditionally opposed work requirements as being punitive. The pressure to water the requirements down will be intense.
 
 
 
CANDIDATES ON THE ISSUEES: WELFARE
 The nation's welfare rolls reached a record high this year; 4.8 million families, or 13.7 million people, now relying on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal program. Studies show that 22 percent of all American children now spend at least a year on welfare before they turn 18 years old; for black children, that figure is 72 percent. Welfare benefits have eroded sharply in the past two decades, with the average mother with two children now receiving $372 a month.
The major-party Presidential candidates, President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, agree that the current system is flawed, but Mr. Clinton has proposed the more sweeping plan for changing it.
The independent candidate, Ross Perot, has issued vague calls for welfare reform but produced no specifics.
 
The proposals:
The heart of President Bush's plan is to allow states more latitude in experimental programs. Mr. Bush's aides concede that this will do little in the short term to reduce the welfare rolls, but they say careful experiments are the key to finding a long-term solution.
Bill Clinton proposes spending an extra $6 billion a year on tax credits and training for welfare mothers. He also vows to reduce cut aid to welfare mothers after two years, unless they find a job or perform community service. There is no precedent for such a sweeping welfare change, and many experts doubt Mr. Clinton's ability to enact it.
 
The records:
 In his first three years as President, Mr. Bush rarely mentioned welfare. He issued no specific welfare proposals until last July, when he issued the plan calling for welfare experimentation.
 Mr. Clinton has a decade-long record of running experimental programs for welfare mothers. He played an important role in lobbying for the 1988 Family Support Act. That law requires every state to enroll some of its welfare mothers in work or education programs.
 
The philosophies:
 Mr. Bush began his Presidency with a famous call for kinder and gentler policies, including those affecting the poor. But in recent months, he has adopted a harsher tone, calling for welfare mothers to "get off the dole." His critics, including some Republicans, have accused him of using attacks on welfare to appeal to racial hostility.
Mr. Clinton's call for more training programs reflects a typical liberal belief that welfare mothers need better skills. But his plan to demand work from welfare mothers after two years is a conservative proposal opposed by many within his own party.
 
The scorecard:
Mr. Bush's tough talk may appeal to voters but he has offered few ideas about how to change the system. And his record conflicts with his oratory: burdened by recession, more people are now on "the dole" than ever.
 Even Mr. Clinton's critics admire his knowledge. His proposal may be the most sweeping ever backed by a Presidential candidate. But there is reason to doubt that the actual changes will be as bold as he implies, and if they are, no one can be sure of their effects.
