HEADLINE: Child Killings In City System Reach Record

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Twenty-seven children, whose families had been identified by New York City's child protection system as abusive or neglectful, were killed last year, the highest number since the city began keeping the statistic in 1986, a panel reported yesterday.
The number has risen in each of the last three years. In 1989, the number of children killed in troubled families known to the city's Human Resources Administration was 7. It rose to 16 in 1990. 
 The report, prepared by a panel of experts who examined confidential city records, criticized city caseworkers for frequently overlooking the role of various men in the dead children's homes.
Twelve of the children were killed by fathers, boyfriends or other men who regularly visited the homes, acting alone or with the mothers. Yet, the experts found that city caseworkers had generally failed to thoroughly investigate the men, focusing instead "almost exclusively" on mothers and other female caretakers.
 
Changes in Training Asked
 The 44-page annual report recommended that the city's Human Resources Administration re-emphasize the importance of men in understanding the dynamics of troubled families -- a subject that has been taught in the training academy for city workers, but apparently failed to sink in. The report also called for more emphasis on recognizing the sometimes subtle signs of domestic violence.
The city's Human Resources Administration, responding to the panel, said that it was strengthening training of workers in the recommended areas. City officials have noted, however, that budgets cuts have reduced the number of caseworkers who investigate allegations of child abuse, making it harder for them to leave work for extra training.
The yearly report is the only public accounting of how the city handled the cases of the 48 children who died in 1991 and whose families had been known to the city. The records of individual cases are protected under state confidentiality laws.
Besides the 27 children who died of homicides, 21 children died from from natural causes, accidents or undetermined causes.
Another 54 children died of suspected abuse last year, but their families were not known to the agency.
Barbara J. Sabol, the Human Resources Administrator, appointed the panel of city officials and 13 doctors, child abuse researchers, social workers and other experts to review the agency's performance in cases that ended in a child's death.
 
Many Family Problems
 The children came from families with many social problems: 70 percent of the families were plagued by domestic violence, half had a history of drug abuse, 40 percent of the families had parents who were mentally ill or retarded, and one-third had experienced homelessness.
The leading type of homicide, the report said, was "blunt trauma." Thirteen children died of it, and seven of them had been beaten repeatedly over a period of time. The second leading type of homicide was malnutrition: Five children starved to death. Other children died of such causes as strangulation, scalding, stabbing, forced feeding, and drowning.
The panel strongly recommended that caseworkers be trained in the stages of child development so they are able, for example, to recognize children who weigh too little for their ages. In one case, a caseworker visited a home and noted in the record that the children "appeared to be fine, in good health and not at risk." The next day a visiting nurse had one of the children hospitalized for malnutrition.
The report said it was difficult to conclude why homicides had increased because the number of deaths was still relatively small.
The child homicide statistics for 1989-91 that are cited in the panel's report are based on the medical examiner's determination of cause of death. Between 1986 and 1989, the Human Resources Administration did not classify the deaths by the medical examiner's rules. But the city determined, by examining its records, that the number of homicides of children known to the agency was 14 in 1986, 8 in 1987 and 15 in 1988.
"The sample is too small to definitively say that the increase in homicides is a trend," said Sheila Jack, a spokeswoman for the Human Resources Administration. "But we do know that child homicides have increased nationally, so this would be consistent with that larger trend."
The National Association for the Protection of Children estimated in the report that between 1985 and 1991 the number of children killed from abuse and neglect in the United States increased 57.5 percent, to 1,383 from 878.
Douglas Besharov, a child abuse expert who served on the panel, said he believed the rise in homicides reflected the worsening mayhem in the city's poorest neighborhoods -- a condition that, he said, the child welfare bureaucracy has not yet adjusted to.
"We've seen an increase in street violence, in part caused by crack," said Mr. Besharov, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. "That violence is seeping into the home."
The families of the dead children are often headed by single women who abuse drugs and depend on men whom Mr. Besharov called "unsavory characters" to look after their children when they go out. The men may be unemployed drug abusers who do not have the patience or understanding to change diapers and feed infants and toddlers, who are by far the most common victims.
On the other hand, Mr. Besharov credits the city for improving the training of caseworkers in the late 1980's so they could better cope with the explosion of medically fragile, drug-exposed babies. That contributed to the decline in child fatalities due to natural causes, he said.
The number of medically fragile children who died of natural causes, including AIDS, premature birth due to the mother's drug use and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, dropped from 22 in 1990 to 11 in 1991.

HEADLINE: Dow Ends Flat After Big Early Drop

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed nearly unchanged yesterday, after a recovery in bond prices rescued the market from earlier losses of more than 30 points.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down only 0.27 to close at 3,174.41 after earlier slipping as low as 3,142.53. 
 Analysts said the market was encouraged by signs that the shares of International Business Machines and Philip Morris were trying to stabilize after two days of steep losses.
 
Thursday's Disappointments
 The shares of both companies tumbled on Thursday after I.B.M. reported earnings that disappointed Wall Street and Philip Morris said its cigarettes were losing market share to generic competitors. But late yesterday the selling pressure seemed to be abating.
I.B.M. closed at 70 3/4, down 2 1/8; Philip Morris ended at 77 1/4, down 2 1/2.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines, 973 to 800, on heavy volume of 235.9 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, compared with 213.6 million on Thursday.
For the week, the Dow rose 37.83 points.
Because of the market's sharp losses in recent weeks, stock prices may be set for a rebound. But analysts said they remained guarded in their outlook.
"The market still looks vulnerable," said Mark Tincher at the Chase Global Private Bank. "You may see a bounce, but I would still be more cautious."
Trading could be volatile at least through the Presidential election, analysts said.
Bonds were hurt early in the day by a report in The Los Angeles Times that Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential candidate, was considering an accelerated economic recovery plan, urging more spending and expanded tax cuts. This raised worries about a bigger budget deficit.
"I think the odds of Clinton winning keep going up, and the markets are identifying that," said Jay McElroy, a principal at 1838 Investment Advisers L.P.
Bond prices recovered before the close yesterday. The 30-year Treasury bond ended with a loss of 3/16 point, raising its yield to 7.52 percent, from 7.51 percent late Thursday.
 
Setback for Westinghouse
 The shares of Westinghouse Electric lost 1 1/2, to 11 3/4, yesterday after Duff & Phelps said it had lowered the credit rating of both the company and its Westinghouse Credit unit.
Apple Computer jumped 3 1/2, to 49; it had reported strong quarterly results on Thursday.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 2.13, to 411.73. The American Stock Exchange index rose 1.70, to 367.33
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks was up 0.90, to 226.44. The average share gained 14 cents.
The Nasdaq index rose 3.97, to 582.61.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 3,975.456, up 16.362, or 0.41 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Profit For Maker Of Chips

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Texas Instruments Inc. reported a sharp improvement in earnings today for the third quarter, with its computer chip unit posting its first quarterly profit since the last quarter of 1989.
The company earned $57 million, or 58 cents a share, in the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, in contrast to a loss of $113 million in the corresponding period a year ago. Revenues rose 11.2 percent, to $1.89 billion from $1.70 billion. 
 Texas Instruments is among several large American-based chip makers including Motorola, Intel and Advanced Micro Devices that have benefited from surging orders this year, mainly from personal computer manufacturers in the United States and Asia. Intel reported record earnings earlier this week.
 
A Record Is Set

 
 Texas Instruments said its backlog of chip orders soared by 30 percent in the quarter and that chip sales for the period were the highest in its history.
The rebound to profitability has been painful and slow for Texas Instruments, the world's seventh-biggest chip manufacturer. The company has cut 4,400 jobs in the last two years, reducing its global work force to 62,000 in a step calculated to save $220 million a year. The company lost $409 million in 1991, the biggest yearly loss in its history.
In trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Texas Instruments were unchanged, closing at $45 each.
Analysts said the company's resurgence should continue unless the global economy grew worse. James L. Barlage, semiconductor analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham, said the chip-making business at Texas Instruments was "at the very early stages" of a turnaround.
Operating profit for the entire company was $116 million, in contrast to a loss of $61 million in the quarter a year ago.
The company returned to profitability in this year's second quarter. The small net income that it reported then was its first overall quarterly profit after six quarters of losses.
For the latest quarter, Mr. Barlage estimated that the semiconductor unit contributed half of the company's revenues, including $83 million from royalty payments on licensing agreements with several Asian and American chip makers, up from $70 million in the quarter a year ago.
 
Fast-Growing Specialties
 The company's chief financial officer, William Aylesworth, said in an interview that Texas Instruments plants were producing new specialty chips, like 486 microprocessors, for several customers and a reduced-instruction-set computer chip for Sun Microsystems' work stations in high volumes.
To compete in these fast-growing market niches, the company has invested heavily in new plant capacity despite its losses in the last three years. Less profitable memory chips still contribute most of the unit's sales, but specialty chips accounted for 35 percent last year and have been growing at a faster rate this year, Mr. Aylesworth said.
In a statement, Jerry R. Junkins, chairman and chief executive, said growth in the global chip market would remain sluggish, especially in Japan. He said the company's military electronics unit had "stable profitability" in the quarter.

HEADLINE: Air Fare Plan Fails, American Admits

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
After vigorously defending the simplified fare structure he announced in April, Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines, recently told a group of airline financial analysts in New York that the four-tier structure had been a failure.
He suggested that there were limits to how far American might go to defend it. As if to prove that point, the airline recently matched USAir and Trans World Airlines in offering two additional low-priced tiers in selected markets, below its lowest tier. 
 This sort of backpedaling might seem an embarrassment. But few people think it has discredited Mr. Crandall, who as head of the nation's biggest carrier remains one of the industry's most powerful figures.
Analysts, travel agents and airline consultants praise his attempts to institute lower everyday prices, which they say have helped stanch the number of discounts, though not the industry's losses. But they add that the plan might have had a better chance had he persuaded other airlines to go along rather than undercut American.
Even if value pricing, as American calls it, does not stick, these observers say, the industry will eventually have to reinstate the plan, or something similar, to stem the financial hemorrhaging of the industry, which has lost about $7.5 billion in the last two and a half years.
"In this world, timing is everything, and maybe the time is not right for what Crandall proposed," said Daniel A. Hersh, an airline analyst with Kemper Securities Group Inc. in Denver. "If not, when the economy improves we'll probably see value pricing again, although American might not be the carrier to bring it up."
American's initiative, which was followed by United and Delta, eliminated about 85 percent of the tens of thousands of fares in computer reservations systems.
That made life easier for travel agents. "Probably 95 percent of them are completely in favor of the simplified fare structure," said Paul Bessel, president of the 3,000-member Association of Retail Travel Agents. "It drives travel agents crazy trying to explain to a rational human being why it sometimes costs more to fly one way than round trip. And if the passenger decides to buy the round-trip ticket and throw away the return portion, carriers warn agents it's a violation to sell them."
Some carriers, he said, have recently warned travel agents that if passengers are caught violating that policy, the agency will be billed for the difference.
In prescribing the new system, American hoped to narrow the spread between leisure fares and the much higher-priced unrestricted fares, which are purchased primarily by business travelers. Under the old system, 93 percent of American's tickets in 1991 were sold at an average discount of 63 percent. Leisure travelers could change their flights, previously not refundable, for a nominal fee.
"To that extent, Crandall succeeded," said Donald S. Garvett, a vice president of Simat, Helliesen & Eichner Inc., travel industry consultants specializing in aviation. "Before, the normal economy fare was roughly three times more than the lowest fare, and perhaps one in 20 passengers paid it. Now economy fares are 75 to 100 percent higher than the lowest fares, excluding short-term promotions, and about one in five passengers will pay it. So Crandall's reforms were effective."
Before last summer's half-price sale, 30 percent of American's bookings were for full fare, the carrier said, compared with fewer than 10 percent before its value plan. Three times as many passengers paid full fare for domestic flights on the major United States airlines in May, June and July of this year as did in the comparable three months of last year, the Air Transport Association reported.
 
Industry Still Losing Money
 So why has the industry continued to lose money even after the new structure was imposed? "By my reckoning, the industry has lost about $1 billion since restructuring," said Lee Howard, the president of Airline Economics, an industry research group.
While critics at airlines that did not go along with value pricing say the losses prove that the American plan has not worked, Mr. Crandall contends that it would have worked but for those airlines' continued "discounting, couponing and give-aways." He told analysts that if competitors did not adhere to the simplified system, "it will be back to death by a million cuts."
Joseph P. Schwietzerman, a transportation specialist at DePaul University in Chicago and a specialist in airline pricing, said American had not done enough to forge an industry consensus by convincing the weaker carriers that it was in their long-term interest to end corporate discounts.
Mr. Schwietzerman said Trans World Airlines had undermined the plan by aggressively recruiting with discounts those corporate customers turned away by the bigger carriers. Northwest Airlines also failed to go along when it allowed an adult to fly free with a child holding a full-fare ticket in May.
Most analysts say there is nothing sacrosanct about a four-tier structure, and several analysts say a pricing plan ideal for American, United and Delta would not necessarily be suitable for other carriers.
 
More Business Travelers
 "The Big Three have more business travelers, so their mix of traffic tends to produce higher yields than Northwest's does," said Daniel M. Kasper, a transportation specialist for Harbridge House, an international management consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "The simplified structure favored the Big Three's key passengers. Northwest's initiative wasn't so much a criticism of value pricing as it was an attempt to stimulate leisure traffic."
The difficulty of making value pricing stick, American says, proves the improbability of claims in lawsuits by Continental, Northwest and the shareholders committee of America West, that the plan amounted to "predatory pricing" designed to drive competitors from the market.
"It shows that no carrier controls or dictates pricing, as some other carriers charge," said Tim Smith, an American spokesman. At the same time, Mr. Smith defended value pricing, saying, "I don't think anyone's going to wake up anytime soon and find 18 to 20 fares on one route, like before."
Mr. Kasper said that while the fewer tiers there were, the better, a fifth or possibly even sixth tier might be necessary to take into account the interests of the other airlines. "Simplicity is a virtue to a point," he said, "but you still need a structure that suits the players in the market."
 
Affordable Excursion Fare
 Donald L. Pevsner, a Miami lawyer and aviation consumer advocate, said the industry needed an affordable excursion fare that did not require purchase at least 14 days in advance. "If American lowers some fares, I don't have a problem if it does away with the current fare structure," he said. "But if it backs away from the structure by raising unrestricted fares back to their former rapacious levels, I'll personally lead a crusade to impose caps on those fares."
Several analysts do not blame the lack of consensus building for the breakdown in value pricing as much as they blame American's timing. "Crandall announced value pricing in April," Mr. Hersh of Kemper Securities said, "and we started seeing more layoffs in April, May and June, so there were fewer business travelers than expected."
But those shortcomings were magnified by the effects of the weak economy. Mr. Kasper said: "If the economy were strong, even the carriers in Chapter 11 would be making money. So the trouble is not Bob Crandall. The problem is soft demand."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Rate Cut In Britain and Gold Is Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against most major currencies yesterday after the Bank of England cut key lending rates, but reaction was muted by built-in expectations of the reduction.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $342.40 a troy ounce, up $1.40 from late Thursday. In New York, the Republic National Bank said gold had risen $1.20 an ounce, to a late quote of $342.20. 
 The Bank of England early in the day cut key lending rates by a full percentage point, to 8 percent, the lowest rate in four years, to stimulate Britain's economy.
The move sent the pound lower because a lower interest rate makes the currency less attractive to foreign investors. However, traders said that the foreign exchange markets had expected a rate cut and that that had tempered the pound's fall.
In London, the British pound slid to $1.6548, from $1.7045 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.6495 to buy 1, less expensive than late Thursday's $1.6945
Currency market participants said the pound's fall had set off a chain reaction that eventually supported the dollar. Traders selling the pound put their money into yen, and then also sold German marks for yen. The mark weakened against the dollar and dragged other European currencies down with it.
"The dollar rallied by consequence," said Frank J. Pusateri, vice president for corporate foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston. "There were very many crosscurrents and not a lot of conviction one way or another. The only conviction was, 'Sell sterling.' "
The yen rose. In New York, the dollar settled at 119.50 yen, down from 120.25 late Thursday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 120.53 yen, down 0.02 yen from Thursday's close. In London, the dollar was quoted at 119.90 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4798 German marks, up from 1.4525; 1.3220 Swiss francs, up from 1.2980; 5.0250 French francs, up from 4.9325; 1,302 Italian lire, up from 1,287.50, and 1.24505 Canadian dollars, down from 1.24775.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $342.55 a troy ounce, from $342.20 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $342.25, from $342.00 bid late Thursday.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT HIT BY 3,600 LAYOFFS

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Pratt & Whitney, the jet-engine maker, said today that it would lay off 3,600 workers in Connecticut, more than 16 percent of its work force here, over the next eight months because of a steep drop in commercial-airline contracts. Nearly 470 of those people got notices today.
The company, long a mainstay of the Connecticut economy, had announced a job-reduction plan in January that would have gradually reduced employment through the mid-1990's because of declining military orders for jet engines. Today's cuts both accelerate and expand that plan and are centered in the commercial sector of the business, which company officials said had looked secure only nine months ago. 
 Nationwide, about 4,800 Pratt & Whitney workers, or 11.4 percent of the company's 42,000 employees, will be let go.
 
Shock to Connecticut's Economy
 The news, and the expectation that smaller machine shops and other suppliers to the company will be affected, sends a shock to a Connecticut economy that in some aspects had begun to stabilize in the recession, economists said. It also seemed certain to deepen President Bush's re-election problems in a state he once called home.
Connecticut's two United States Senators, Joseph I. Lieberman and Christopher J. Dodd, both Democrats, issued a joint statement calling the cuts "devastating," and laying the blame squarely on the shoulders of the Bush Administration for not sufficiently stimulating the economy. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a third-party independent, said all the "clowns in Washington" who have not addressed the recession should be held accountable.
"It stretches the Connecticut recession out," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist at Shawmut National Corporation, a bank holding company with offices here and in Boston. "The main reason now is the lack of lift from the national economy."
Pratt, which has about 22,000 workers in the state, is a division of United Technologies Corporation, which also owns Otis Elevators, and is Connecticut's largest private employer. United Technologies officials said in January that falling defense orders had forced a reorganization of the company across Pratt and other divisions and that nearly 14,000 jobs, including 6,412 in Connecticut, would be cut by 1995. That represented about 7 percent of the company's work force of 193,000 employees.
A spokesman for United Technologies, Martin Moore, said today that only Pratt & Whitney was affected by today's announcement, and that reductions in the company's other divisions would continue on the previous schedule. He said that since January about 7,000 jobs in United Technologies units have been cut in Connecticut, through early retirements, voluntary severance packages and layoffs.
 
Canceled and Deferred Orders
 Since January, Pratt & Whitney has cut 2,400 jobs and was scheduled to cut another 2,400 nationwide by 1995. Under the accelerated and expanded schedule, all those reductions, plus about 2,400 more, will be completed by June 30, 1993. For Connecticut that will mean about 1,200 more jobs lost than expected, over a drastically shortened time.
The culprit is not the Pentagon. A Pratt spokesman, Curtis G. Linke, said that in just the last 12 months, about $9 billion in commercial aircraft orders for planes using Pratt engines had been deferred or canceled because of declining air travel, reduced profits and price competition among carriers.
The division's president, James G. O'Connor, said in a letter to employees that recent cutbacks by just three companies -- Boeing, Airbus and McDonnell Douglas -- had cut 1993 orders by 21 percent, compared to 1992.
Orders for spare parts, one of the most lucrative parts of the company's business, are down 25 percent from 1990, Mr. O'Connor said. The company will make only 100 military fighter jet engines in 1993, down from an annual output of 700 engines a year in the early 1980's, although company officials said that those declines had already been taken into account in the earlier job-reduction plan.
 
A Psychological Blow
 Mr. Linke, the Pratt spokesman, said that today's layoffs included 120 jobs cut in East Hartford, 132 in Southington, 180 in North Haven and 227 in North Perwick, Maine. Another 181 workers took voluntary terminations that give them extended benefits and severance pay, he said.
But that voluntary program has now closed, and Mr. Linke said that the next round of layoffs will occur sometime after the beginning of the year. He said that a determination had yet to be made about what plants or what jobs would be cut, or when the axe would fall.
But economists said that a potentially larger impact could come from the psychological blow of the job cuts. Mr. Perna at Shawmut National said that across much of New England, which suffered through some of the first blows of the recession, beginning in 1989, there have been signs that the bottom has finally been hit. The housing industry has stopped its free fall, he said, and the domino-like effect of failing banks has slowed as well. State budgets in Massachusetts and Connecticut have been brought under control.
Mr. Weicker said the Pratt & Whitney cuts point up the need for national action to fight the recession because the declines are so clearly caused by a national slump. If the recession in the Northeast could once have been explained as a result of one region's excesses in real estate or banking or dependence on military contracts, it now clearly cannot, he said.
"We're holding up our end of the line, but we can't do it alone," Mr. Weicker said.

HEADLINE: GOODWILL GAMES;
16 Venues, Here's What You'll Get

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
There might be a new aquatic center. Or two. Or none. Ticket sales could mean revenues of $15 million. Maybe a little less. Or much more.
Such prickly details hardly seemed to matter yesterday, as blissful New York organizers and politicians celebrated their surprisingly successful bid to play host to the 1998 Goodwill Games in New York City, Long Island and New Jersey. 
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins and community leaders insisted there was no reason to panic. With a lead time of nearly six years, everybody believed the kinks could be worked out of any massive sporting blueprint.
"If there's a garbage strike," said Jack Kelly, the Goodwill Games' president, "we'll step around the garbage."
Despite such can-do confidence, there was much to work out for the New York-based group, beginning with the question of financing a minimum of $55 million in organizational costs, plus at least $6 million in capital improvements to stage the 24-sport competition that will sprawl over 16 venues for two weeks.
Matt Scheckner, the executive director of the New York City Sports Commission, said organizing funds could be raised through a variety of methods. In the first two years, a Founders Club would solicit contributions from private sources.
Plans are being drafted for special fund-raising events at the United Nations and Ellis Island. A joint New Jersey-New York lottery could attract a substantial amount, along with ticket sales and the city's share of sponsorship funds. The slice of this endorsement pie is being determined in negotiations between the New York Goodwill Games Organizing Committee and the Turner Broadcasting System, whose president, Ted Turner, is the catalyst behind the quadrennial event.
Scheckner insisted that transportation and security costs would not be prohibitive, because of the city's substantial mass transit system and police force. "These are nonissues for us," Scheckner said. "We move five million people every day already, and the New York City police are the best in the world."
The City Council already has budgeted $2 million to improve the Kissena Velodrome cycling track in Flushing, Queens, a commitment that obviously impressed Goodwill selection committee members and Cuomo.
"If Council Speaker Peter Vallone can find $2 million in his skimpy budget, we can find what we need," Cuomo said, pledging support.
 
Some Natural Fits
 Some of the proposed venues for the extravaganza are naturals, with little or no renovations necessary. Madison Square Garden is perfect for men's basketball and volleyball. The Byrne Meadowlands Arena is equally fit for gymnastics, and Nassau Coliseum's ice surface can easily stage figure skating.
But there are other sites that are more problematic. Columbia University's Wien Stadium requires some expansion of the existing track to be host to a full-blown track and field meet, and has limited seating. The stadium, at the upper end of Manhattan, is still a better choice than Randalls Island, the disastrous host for the 1991 United States National Track and Field Championships.
Scheckner called Randalls Island "a great stadium when Jesse Owens used it." It drew few fans for the track championship and provided a less-than-luxurious setting for those who actually attended.
St. John's University will provide a bare-bones home for women's basketball and women's volleyball, and will perhaps create an argument about inequality in facilities at these Games for males and females. Soccer will be played on the artificial surface of Giants Stadium, or at far-smaller Cantiague Park in Long Island.
 
Where Does the Pool Go?
 The aquatic center has been a sticking point for years, an issue that has arisen whenever New York has attempted to attract a major multisport event. The organizers are hoping to get $4 million in state funding to build a site on, or near, the Hofstra campus in Hempstead, L.I. In addition, they are considering a site in the Bronx.
Scheckner, prepared for anything, said the swimming and diving events could be held in an existing facility at Rutgers University in Piscataway.
Housing for the 2,500 or more athletes will be spread over at least two sites. Dormitories at Hofstra will be used for those athletes competing in events in Long Island, Queens and parts of Manhattan. A midtown Manhattan hotel, perhaps one belonging to one of the sponsoring hotel corporations, will house another group of competitors who must perform in Manhattan and in New Jersey.
The New York organizers yesterday promised to send a large contingent of observers to the 1994 Goodwill Games in St. Petersburg, Russia. They have already studied the successes and failures of the 1990 host, Seattle, which sold about $15 million in tickets but claimed a positive economic impact of $350 million for the region.
Ultimately, the success of the Goodwill Games could depend on the city's ability to bounce back from its current recessionary woes.
"By then, we'll be back in the halcyon days," Cuomo said. "We'll be at our boasting best in 1998."

HEADLINE: Animation Auction Is Questioned

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Although the auction at Sotheby's in Los Angeles today is advertised as "the only opportunity collectors will have to buy production artwork" from the film "Beauty and the Beast," the animation pieces on the block aren't entirely the real thing. The background watercolors of trees and castle walls are from the Walt Disney movie, but the gouache images of Belle, the Beast, Gaston and Mrs. Potts are not.
Because of this, purists among collectors and dealers question the validity of the 250 items, which are estimated to bring a total of $670,000. Each piece consists of a watercolor-on-paper from the film, painted with a landscape or interior, and a gouache on celluloid, called a cel, not used in the film, on which one or more of the animated characters is depicted. The movie was animated by computer, and the cels were produced after the computer imagery was completed so that the artists who hand painted them could match the colors on the cels with those in the film. Most of the 988 cels produced were made to be stored in the Disney archives. 
 "These cels weren't used in the production of the film," said Alexander Acevedo, a Madison Avenue dealer. "They're copies. Now we're imitating the computer because the images are getting away from us. I'm not buying re-creations of animation art."
 
Question of Definition
 Peter Merola, a Staten Island collector, said Disney had created a "gray area" by producing cels not used in "Beauty and the Beast." "What are they?" he asked. "They were hand painted but are they originals? I think these new cels will increase the desirability of vintage cels."
Critics say Disney Studios is capitalizing on the booming market for vintage animation art, which rose rapidly in popularity and price throughout the 1980's, remaining recession-proof until six months ago, when buying became more selective. With the prices for Mickey Mouse and Snow White soaring, Disney Studios decided in 1989 to test the market for contemporary images, selling the production art from "Who Framed Roger Rabbit?" at Sotheby's. When the sale was successful, cels from "The Little Mermaid" were auctioned.
Now Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chairman of Walt Disney Studios, envisions another coup. "With 'Beauty and the Beast' we decided we would only issue a piece of animation foreground with a matching background," said Mr. Katzenberg. "There are no plans now to sell any additional art from this film."
Harry Matetsky, a Long Island collector of animation art, said Disney was expanding the market by selling images from its new films. "Vintage animation is beyond the pocketbooks of most collectors," he said. "The only way most people can play is to buy the new material."
Russ Cochran of West Plains, Mo., a major dealer in animation art, praised Disney for limiting cel production. "These recreated examples are the next best thing to the real thing," he said. "With other films, Disney has let out a few thousand cels in an auction and a few more thousand to their dealers. The cels created for 'Beauty and the Beast' are the only cels -- unless Disney intends to create more."
When asked whether Disney intends to renew cel production, Mr. Katzenberg said: "Will there be a special edition someday? Maybe."
 
The VCR Generation
 Sotheby officials hope the popularity of "Beauty and the Beast," the only full-length animated feature to receive an Oscar nomination for best film, will push the auction total to more than $1 million. (So far, the movie has grossed $145 million, the highest box-office total ever for an animated film.)
"And that's only the beginning," said David N. Redden, a Sotheby's senior vice president. "My enthusiasm has a lot to do with the fact that I have a 3 1/2-year-old son at home. He's part of the VCR generation. No one will know animation art better than the children of today who see videos of their favorite animation stories again and again and again and again and again."
To promote the auction, Sotheby's printed 17,000 catalogues, a record number, and sent the animation art, as if it were van Goghs and Renoirs, to New York, Tokyo, London, Milan, Paris and Orlando, Fla. At Disney World in Florida, 1,000 collectors and dealers were dined and entertained for three days at the first Disneyana Convention.
The items in Sotheby's sale carry estimates ranging from a low of $1,000 to a high of $10,000 each.
"Why does Walt disney put out re-creations?" Mr. Acevedo said. "Money. And some collectors are not polished enough to care. As long as it has Disney's approval, they'll buy anything."

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Change and Trust (Sound Familiar?) on Hardwood

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 16

 BODY:
Change and trust were the two recurring themes here tonight as players from the New Jersey Nets and the Detroit Pistons debated their common issues of the 1992-93 National Basketball Association campaign.
"With every new relationship comes trust," said the Pistons' captain, Isiah Thomas. Thomas was referring to the team's rapport with its new head coach, Ron Rothstein, who has succeeded Chuck Daly, who moved on to the Nets after nine years in Detroit. 
 The implication of Thomas's remark was unmistakable. The chemistry the Pistons had developed under General Manager Jack McCloskey and Daly was long gone by last season. It was time, as Daly said earlier in the week, for change. And for Daly, the opening two nights of the exhibition season was a time of coincidence.
 
Face to Face
 On Thursday night, in Grand Forks, N.D., when Daly walked into the arena for an afternoon shootaround, one of the first faces he saw was that of McCloskey, now the general manager for the Minnesota Timberwolves. In keeping with the spirit, or lack of same, of a crumbling regime, Daly and McCloskey had little to say to each other last season.
But neither man wound up an unemployment statistic. As one insider put it, "They didn't go out to dinner but they did talk."
What did they say? "Jack said, 'Little did we know a year ago that we'd end up in Grand Forks, N. D.,' " Daly said tonight before his Nets made it two straight preseason victories, 115-87, over the Pistons, despite the absence of Derrick Coleman (sprained foot), Sam Bowie (bruised finger) and Mookie Blaylock (flue).
Despite a charter flight that didn't land here until 3 A.M., this was more familiar territory. Daly was surrounded by the Detroit area news media the moment he stepped into the arena. When he was introduced, the fans at the Crisler Arena on the University of Michigan campus welcomed him with a warm ovation.
 
Mills's Homecoming
 A more rousing cheer greeted Terry Mills, the other link between these teams. For the 6-foot-10-inch forward, who played for the Wolverines, this was a genuine homecoming.
"To come back here as a Piston is really special," said Mills, who did not want the Nets to match the five-year, $9.4 million Pistons's offer sheet, which they didn't.
Mills, who is from Romulus, a nearby suburb, said he was intrigued by the possibility of returning home, but unsure of the Pistons' stability, until he had a heart-to-heart talk with Thomas.
"He convinced me that this team wasn't going downhill," said Mills, who apparently celebrated his new wealth in the dining room. At 265, he's 15 pounds above the weight he must reach to prevent having $125,000 deducted from his salary.
Actually, a Pistons' upswing is hardly a certainty, and even Thomas, when asked if the Pistons as presently constituted could challenge Chicago, answered: "At this time, no."
The Pistons have an unspectacular mix of veterans on the downside and youth with questionable upside. They also have a crisis on their hands in Dennis Rodman.
Though he marched into the arena wearing dark glasses, took a seat in the second row behind one of the baskets in the second quarter and provoked Thomas to throw a ball in his direction during a timeout, Rodman has not reported to the Pistons' camp.
Adding to bizarre nature of the Rodman mystery, he met at halftime with Daly, with whom he remains close, and presented his former coach with a large framed action photo of himself.
"Based on my conversation with him, I don't know whether he'll play or not," said Daly.
 
'Things Could Happen'
 When Thomas cryptically said, while discussing the strength of the team, "Things could happen over the next two weeks that would change my opinion," a Rodman deal was not difficut to imagine.
With the ear of ownership, Thomas has long been a powerbroker in Pistons' affairs, which is why, he said, he helped recruit Mills, whom he's known since Mills's high school days.
Asked if the temptation to airlift a player out of Daly's lineup was too much to resist, Thomos flashed his famous smile. "No comment," he said.
None of the Pistons' veterans was in the mood to discuss Daly, though Bill Laimbeer told the Detroit news media earlier in the week that the team was working harder under Rothstein. When one listener responded, "Tell me you guys would've won two championships with Ron Rothstein, Laimbeer said, "That's something different."
Meaning: Daly deserves his due. But it was still time for a change.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Unraveling of Measure to Revamp Consumer-Credit Reporting

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Legislation to change the way credit bureaus operate bit the dust late last month just before Congress adjourned, and the story of how and why demonstrates the interplay of the consumer movement, the nation's credit bureaus and politics.
For four years, both the House of Representatives and the Senate have considered changes in the Fair Credit Reporting Act of 1970, the law that governs how credit bureaus function. Among them were provisions to reduce the cost of getting a credit report and to require credit bureaus to establish toll-free numbers to handle complaints from the public. 
 As Congress was preparing to wrap up its business for the year, the House bill on credit reporting was brought to the floor on Sept. 24. But the measure never came to a vote because a make-or-break amendment failed by a vote of 207 to 203, and its chief backer, Representative Esteban E. Torres, Democrat of California, then persuaded the House to suspend further action on the bill.
The amendment called for removing an important part of the bill specifying that Federal law would overrule state laws regarding credit bureaus. Consumer advocates pushed hard to do away with this provision, known as pre-emption. Industry representatives fought equally hard to retain the provision. And the industry won.
"Pre-emption is a fundamental issue," said Michelle Meier, government affairs counsel of Consumers Union. "You don't tell the states they can't protect their own citizens with stronger provisions than Congress can muster."
Barry Connelly, executive vice president of Associated Credit Bureaus, the trade association for these bureaus, said: "We truly did not want to have the potential of 50 different state rules. But it was a bittersweet victory."
That victory for advocates of pre-emption came when Mr. Torres prevailed on his colleagues in effect to kill the bill after his amendment failed. He said pre-emption was "an outrageous attempt to gut the bill" and would have overwhelmed the dozens of elements in it that most participants in the battle agreed were beneficial to consumers.
Many Republicans on the House Subcommittee on Consumer Affairs, which Mr. Torres heads, saw the issue differently. William Binzel, the Republican counsel for the subcommittee, said, "It's almost a classic case of 'If you're not going to let me win, I'm going to take my football and go home.' If it's a good strong pro-consumer bill, it should apply uniformly throughout the United States."
In its other provisions the bill would have addressed many credit-reporting issues that consumers have complained about in recent years. It would have made it easier for individuals to fix mistakes in their credit reports, required greater disclosure of consumer rights and offered protections against invasions of privacy.
Nevertheless, pre-emption became the focal point around which the floor debate revolved. Representative John Bryant, a Texas Democrat, termed it "a very important across-the-board principle" that he said would be welcomed by the public. Another opponent of pre-emption, Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, "This was a chance for the Federal Government to follow the lead of progressive states like New York."
By contrast, members of Congress favoring pre-emption were outraged that the bill did not become law. Representative Al McCandless, Republican of California, said he found it inconceivable that the leadership would kill a bill "that represents months of hard work and truly bipartisan effort."
He added, "At a time when we are trying to get the economy moving, ease the credit crunch, reduce bureaucracy and enhance interstate commerce, we need a uniform standard."
What happens now that the planned overhaul of Federal credit-reporting is dead for this year? As might be expected, new bills amending the 1970 legislation will be proposed in Washington to get the process started again. Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, said one of the first things he would do next year would be to introduce such legislation.
Activity on the state level is also expected to increase. "One of the messages here is that states can move more quickly than Congress can," said Jeffrey L. Amestoy, Attorney General of Vermont and president of the National Association of Attorneys General. "There are 20 states now with fair-credit reporting acts, and I would expect you'd see other states move ahead with laws."
Gerri Detweiler, director of the Bankcard Holders of America, added: "At a minimum, the consumer groups are going to the states with a model bill. But our eventual goal is to get Federal legislation passed."
And Edmund Mierzwinski, the consumer advocate for the United States Public Interest Group, said: "We lost the fight this year, but the bills in 1993 will be tougher stuff. We're not going to compromise next year if we don't have to."
On the industry side, voluntary changes in policies and procedures encompassing some of the consumer-protection provisions in the House bill are under consideration. Mr. Connelly, the trade association official, said: "Our board meets in January and we're going to extract those doable things that don't need a law. We hope the board will approve them as a voluntary standard."

HEADLINE: Care to Blow Your Own Horn? First, Decide on New or Used

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
The $3.4 billion-a-year musical instrument business usually reaches a crescendo at this time of year. The start of school and the pre-holiday season is a time when many parents try to instill a love for music in their children with the gift of a first violin, guitar, trumpet or piano.
Parents and young musicians as well as professionals face the fundamental question of whether to buy a new or used instrument. There is no simple answer, experts say, for the choice depends as much upon individual needs as it does on economy. 
 Savings on used equipment can be substantial -- 30 percent or more, people in the industry say -- but the risks are high.
"You can get some fabulous deals," said John DeBlass, owner of City Music Schools in New York. But, he added, "there are also some terribly abused instruments out there that may be damaged beyond repair."
The used musical instrument market has three major outlets: retail stores, private sales advertised in newspapers and trade journals, and pawnshops.
Musicians, teachers and retailers tend to agree that pawnshops are the riskiest sources. "Pawnshops are a little dicey," said Kenny Kosek, a professional fiddle player based in New York City, who cautioned that pawnshops and secondhand stores are only for experienced players who can recognize quality.
The shopper, he said, "needs basic knowledge of violin making, signals of craftsmanship, carving, the type of wood, the scroll on the peg head and all of that."
Pawnshops and other secondhand outlets normally do not offer warranties or allow customers to take instruments home to test them. Some retailers allow professionals to try out an instrument in performance. One outlet that provides a warranty is We Buy Guitars, a large retailer in New York City that deals in used guitars. A used Fender Stratocaster in decent condition can cost as little as $300, compared with $600 or more new.
When it comes to guitars, especially acoustic guitars, a buyer needs to know the basics of how the instrument is assembled.
"I always look at the neck to make sure that it's true," said Dennis Koster, a classical and flamenco guitarist and teacher in New York City. "And you look carefully for any cracks on the body, and also tap the guitar all over and listen for strange sounds." He advises students to take along a professional player when shopping for a used classical guitar.
Andy Nitkin, director of the American Institute of Guitar in New York, a school and retail center, said students often come to class with woefully unplayable instruments that they bought secondhand. "It happens all the time, like once a week," Mr. Nitkin said. "A student will come in with a guitar that's neck is so warped the strings are an inch off the frets. It costs more to repair a guitar like that than to buy a new one."
Beginner-quality guitars imported from Korea and Taiwan are available at many music shops starting at about $150, making used guitars a dubious investment, Mr. Nitkin said.
Pawnshops and exchange stores frequently have high markups -- 50 to 100 percent or more depending on the instrument, as opposed to 30 percent markups in retail stores -- that they expect the savvy consumer to negotiate lower. Good deals are possible if you know your instrument, or take along someone who does, and can drive a hard bargain.
Many retail music stores now deal in used and new equipment to appeal to both markets. Many musicians interviewed said that reputable music stores can be reliable sources of used instruments. Look for outlets that make repairs on the premises in case there are problems.
"Business is very good," said Chris Walsh, sales manager for the Guitar Center in Hollywood, talking about used equipment, a substantial part of the store's business.
Like most musical instrument retailers, even those who carry used equipment, Mr. Walsh said he still advises most beginners to buy new because "these days you can buy instruments so uniform, of such good quality and for reasonable prices." The exception is the booming vintage guitar market, a realm of the serious collector that is akin to investing in fine art.
Mr. Walsh added that the music business is so competitive that consumers can negotiate with retailers. "Not only price," he said, "but repair terms, the chance to check instruments out and the opportunity for partial refunds if an instrument doesn't live up to its billing."
Much the same seems to hold true in the used piano market, which is enormous, partly because a piano tends to last a long time and because so many players give it up after their childhood lesson days end.
Several teachers and repairers interviewed advised consumers to shop at reputable dealers for both new and used pianos, especially those stores that have repair shops. Used pianos in good condition start at about $700. The least expensive beginner pianos, like the Samick made in South Korea, cost close to $2,500.
John Serkin, a piano technician based in Manhattan, strongly discourages young students from buying so-called starter pianos. "A young student should touch the keys and hear the most beautiful tone possible to become inspired," Mr. Serkin said. "Plus, a quality instrument is a long-term investment."

HEADLINE: Last Call for the Khmer Rouge

 BODY:
Faced with a delicate test of its credibility, the U.N. Security Council made exactly the right call on Cambodia this week.
The Khmer Rouge faction has been openly defying the peace treaty it signed last year by refusing to demobilize its guerrillas and barring U.N. monitoring and voter registration teams from areas it controls. As the price for compliance, it seeks revisions to the agreement. 
 Allowing the Khmer Rouge to write its own rules would undermine the U.N.'s most ambitious peacekeeping effort to date. Yet too aggressive a response could shatter the international consensus pushing for peace in Cambodia.
The Council has now firmly committed itself to holding free, internationally supervised elections on schedule next May. Unless the Khmer Rouge begins cooperating by January, it will effectively exclude itself from the vote. The Council also agreed to consider further steps, like clamping an economic embargo on Khmer Rouge territory, if needed to protect the vote.
Americans may wonder why even this much patience should be extended to a group that murdered a million Cambodians in the late 1970's. There are at least two good reasons: Not all of today's Khmer Rouge fighters are genocidal murderers. And international cooperation offers the best hope of containing those that are.
Cambodia has been at war for decades. Some now in Khmer Rouge ranks are there mainly by accidents of geography or imperatives of physical survival. Reintegrating these people into the elections will make it easier for the new government to survive the U.N.'s departure.
The Khmer Rouge hard core around Pol Pot has remained a military threat mainly because of arms from China, delivered through Thailand. This core also drew diplomatic support from Southeast Asia and, shamefully, the U.S. Inclusion of the Khmer Rouge in the peace settlement brought commitments to cut off this outside cooperation. China, Thailand and Indonesia now seek to persuade the Khmer Rouge to end its boycott.
By proceeding patiently, the Security Council maintains this crucial Asian support. By insisting on the election timetable, it keeps faith with factions who have fulfilled their treaty obligations. And by threatening an embargo, it warns Khmer Rouge leaders against mistaking patience for impotence.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
WESTINGHOUSE SHARES TOUCH A LOW OF $10.75

 BODY:
A division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced plans yesterday to lay off about 1,400 Maryland workers by the end of the year, blaming cuts in military spending and continuing economic stagnation. The company's Electronic Systems Group, headquartered in Linthicum, Md., laid off 2,500 Maryland employees last year. The new round of job cuts will affect management, professional, clerical, technical and manufacturing employees. Pittsburgh-based Westinghouse employs about 17,200 workers in the Electronic Systems Group. About 12,000 of them are in Maryland. The group, which had 1991 sales of $3.2 billion, makes airborne and ground radar, space electronics, air traffic control and command systems. 
 On the New York Stock Exchange, Westinghouse's shares plunged $1.50 a share, or 11 percent, to close at $11.75. A week ago the stock was at $14.625, but it has been dropping since the company reported third-quarter earnings on Monday that showed a $155 million charge related to its financial-services subsidiary.

HEADLINE: FOOD;
Home on the Range

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:
Riding the Montana range with George Kahrl, one of the rising generation of organic-beef growers, I am conscious of the land, the way it rolls flat and dry and lonesome as an abandoned river bottom.
The plains inch up to foothills that are occasionally seamed by brush-lined creeks and straggly fences. But these demarcations, along with our two horses and a grazing herd of 145 cows (each with a calf), are only passing through, like the wind or a spatter of rain. I adjust my world view accordingly. And for a moment I understand the taste for a big, juicy steak. 
 I know that beef has an average of 22 percent fat, and is cited by cardiac specialists as a leading dietary contributor to heart disease.
I know it is embarrassingly decadent to eat beef in a world where famine and hunger are still pervasive. Economists estimate that the water and acreage required to raise beef for one person could feed up to 20 people if it were used to raise grains.
I know that a rampant appetite for beef has powered the destruction of rain forests, the erosion of topsoil, the pollution of table water.
I know that slabs of beef have gone the way of the Old West. Even knowing all this, a two-hour trot across Kahrl's ranch, which sprawls over 5,000 acres 35 miles west of Bozeman, Mont., leaves me crazed for red meat.
What can explain this primal and, for now, at least, politically incorrect and socially suspect appetite? Do lungs full of fresh air trigger a craving for the trophy of a hunt?
Perhaps it is the nip in the air, as much as the air itself, that pushes my thoughts fondly toward a thick porterhouse blackened on the grill, a flank steak seared in a red-hot cast-iron skillet dusted with salt. Because Mother favored the salt-in-a-hot-skillet technique, my thoughts linger there, warmly, before proceeding to rump roast, meatloaf, a good beef stew.
Despite startling statistics about diet-related mortality, America has retained the third-highest consumption of red meat per capita of any nation (behind Argentina and Uruguay), though, over the last decade, consumption has dropped from 76 pounds to about 67 pounds per person annually. What began as a necessity -- frontiersmen hunting and eating those ruminant creatures on the plains -- became a ritual. Consider the hamburger. Consider barbecue. Consider the steak.
Many have found the appetite for beef can be curbed but, in terms of the national consumption, so far, it has not been quelled. Instead of frequent heavy steaks, Americans have infrequent heavy steaks, or go lighter on the steak and heavier on the accouterments, stir-frying and side-dishing beef. But beef remains. As do the sticky underpinnings of yearning, the checkmate of violence and reassurance involved in any sacrificial slaying, the interplay of guilt and indulgence at eating so high on the food chain. Deeper than that, I realize as I shiver on the Montana range, is yet another two-sided coin of desire: the passion for freedom and self-determination, the fight against loneliness and isolation. To eat meat is to know you are not alone.
This may have as much to do with communion as it has to do with anthropomorphic identification and domination. Meat, particularly beef, has long been a conduit of camaraderie; what bread and wine are to the French, beef is to Americans. Leaf through community cookbooks from Montana, and note the frequency of the campfire image. And what is barbecue, whether made of beef and pork, if not a celebration of clan and place? What is a burger if not a national symbol of good times and camaraderie?
And what is all of this but a variation on the "make hay while the sun is shining" theme? Anyone traveling through the Western landscape knows the chill of insignificance that washes over you there.
"The land is bigger than me, older than me; it's going to be around a lot longer than me," said Kahrl, who chose to be a cowboy when he and his wife, Kathleen Crawford, bought the Sarah Faith Ranch in 1987. One reason he ranches, rather than farms, is that soil erosion in this type of landscape can be controlled through prudent grazing. Generally, he grazes a given 15-to-20-acre patch for one week, then he moves his herd and allows the grazed land to rest for at least 90 days.
Due to careful husbandry, 50 percent of his herd never requires antibiotics and can therefore be sold as organic. "It's healthier for the land, healthier for the animals, healthy for people," he says.
By an odd twist, this style of ranching places Kahrl, and a few dozen other organic beef ranchers across America, back on a frontier. They are preservationists, but most preservationists scorn their methods. They are health-minded, but most health advocates disdain their product. They are cattle ranchers but their slow, costly methods threaten conventional beef producers. They are modern cowboys.
Occasionally, these growers join small cooperatives like O-M of Great Falls, Mont., which Kahrl and a handful of like-minded organic beef growers joined several years ago to market and sell their beef. Specialty butchers across the country are beginning to carry the well-marbled beef from O-M and other ranches. Its clean, rich, distinct flavor delivers hints of lonesome cowboys and wide-open plains. It's a balm to wind-chapped cheeks and achy, well-exercised limbs. Sure, the craving is archaic. But, for me, it is irrepressible.
Circle the wagons, let's eat.
 
BOZEMAN FLANK AND BEANS
 
 1 pound dry pinto beans, rinsed
 6 plum tomatoes, cut in half lengthwise
 4 frying peppers, cut in half lengthwise, cored, deribbed and seeded
 1 hot red pepper, seeded and cut across in 1/4-inch slices
 1 teaspoon dry mustard
 3 tablespoons molasses
 4 teaspoons salt, plus more to taste
 1 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 1 teaspoon olive oil or bacon fat
 1 medium onion, minced

The steak:
 1 1-pound flank steak
 2 teaspoons kosher salt
 1 teaspoon coarsely ground black pepper.
1. Place the beans in a large, heavy-bottom pot. Cover with 2 inches of water. Bring to a boil for 3 minutes. Remove from heat. Cover and let stand for 2 hours.
2. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Place the tomatoes and frying peppers, skin side up, on a baking sheet. Roast for 25 minutes. Carefully transfer the vegetables with their juices to a food processor or blender. Add the hot red pepper. Puree until smooth. Set aside. In a small bowl, stir together the mustard, molasses, salt and pepper. Set aside.
3. Drain beans, discard liquid and dry the pot. Set beans aside. Place the olive oil or bacon fat in the pot and warm over medium heat. Add the onion and cook until soft, about 5 minutes. Add the beans to the onion. Pour in enough water to barely cover the beans. Stir in the tomato-pepper puree and the molasses mixture. Cover. Bake until tender, about 1 3/4 hours, adding water as needed to keep beans very moist but not soupy. Add salt to taste.
4. Fifteen minutes before serving, season the steak with 1 teaspoon salt and pepper. Set aside. 10 minutes before serving, place a cast-iron skillet over high heat. Add the remaining salt to the skillet. Heat until hot. Quickly sear the steak, allowing it to cook 2 to 3 minutes on each side, depending on its thickness and how you like your steak cooked. Remove from pan. Let stand for 5 minutes. Slice and serve around beans.
Yield: Six servings.
 
DAUBE PROVENCAL
 
 2 tablespoons vegetable oil
 2 pounds beef-stew meat, cut into 2-inch cubes
 1/2 cup flour
 1 large onion, peeled and minced
 4 cloves garlic, peeled and minced
 1 cup dry red wine
 6 large carrots, peeled and cut into 1-inch-thick diagonal slices
 1 medium celery root, peeled and cut into 1-inch cubes
10 fresh artichoke hearts
 2 cups cracked green olives, pitted
 2 tablespoon fresh rosemary leaves
 1/4 cup grated orange rind
 1 allspice berry
 1 clove
 1 quart beef broth
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper
 1 cup minced parsley.
1. Heat the oil in a heavy-bottom saucepan over medium heat. Sprinkle the beef with flour. Brown the meat in the oil until golden, about 3 minutes per side. Remove meat from pan. Set aside. Add the onion and garlic. Saute until translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the wine. Increase the heat to high and simmer until reduced to 1/2 cup, about 5 minutes. Return the beef to the pot.
2. Add 3/4 of the carrots, 3/4 of the celery root, 4 artichoke hearts, olives, rosemary, orange rind, allspice, clove and broth. Stir to combine. Cover partly and simmer over medium-low heat until the meat is tender, about 1 1/2 to 2 hours. Add the remaining artichoke hearts, carrots and celery root. Continue cooking until tender, about 20 to 30 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Divide among 4 bowls. Garnish with parsley.
Yield: Four servings.
 
SEARED STEAK WITH CARAMELIZED SHALLOTS
 
 1 teaspoon whole green peppercorns
 1 teaspoon whole black peppercorns
 1 teaspoon whole pink peppercorns
 4 juniper berries
 1 1 1/2-2 pound porterhouse steak, 1 1/2 inches thick
 12 large shallots, peeled
 3 teaspoons vegetable oil
 4 baking potatoes, peeled and cut into 1-by-2-inch rectangles
 1 cup red wine
 2 cups beef broth.
1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Combine the peppercorns and juniper berries in a spice mill or coffee grinder. Grind until smooth. Dust the steak with the spice mixture. Refrigerate.
2. Brush the shallots with 1 teaspoon of the oil. Place them in a small roasting pan. Set aside. Using a sharp paring knife, shape the potatoes into rounded ovals. Brush with 1 teaspoon oil and add to the shallots. Roast until shallots and potatoes are tender and golden, about 45 minutes to 1 hour. Set aside.
3. Heat the remaining vegetable oil in a large, cast-iron skillet until hot. Add the steak and cook over medium heat until medium rare, about 5 to 10 minutes per side. Transfer to a cutting board and set aside for 15 minutes. Meanwhile, pour the wine into the pan and bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Simmer until reduced to 1/2 cup. Add the broth and continue simmering until reduced to 1 cup. Pour through a fine-mesh sieve. Set aside.
4. Cut the steak into thin slices, crosswise. Divide the shallots and roasted potatoes in the center of 4 plates. Drape equal slices of meat over the vegetables. Drizzle with 1/4 cup of the sauce. Serve immediately.
Yield: Four servings.
 
FILET MIGNON OF BEEF WITH ROGANJOSH SPICES
(ADAPTED FROM RAJI JALLEPALI, RAJI'S RESTAURANT, MEMPHIS)
 
The meat:
 2 teaspoons ground coriander
 1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
 1/2 teaspoon ground turmeric
 1/4 teaspoon ground fenugreek
 1 teaspoon red chili-powder
 1 large clove garlic, peeled and smashed to a paste
 2 tablespoons fresh grated ginger
 2 tablespoons grape-seed oil
 4 6-ounce tournedos
 1 teaspoon vegetable oil
 
The salad:
 1/2 cup fresh lime juice
 1 tablespoon apple-cider vinegar
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1 teaspoon minced jalapeno chili pepper
 2 tablespoons olive oil
 1 medium celery root, peeled and grated
 1 large red delicious apple, peeled and grated
 1 small jicama, peeled and grated
 1/2 cup minced mint leaves
 1/2 cup minced coriander leaves
 
The vinaigrette:
 1/4 cup fresh lime juice
 1 teaspoon grated orange rind
 1/4 teaspoon salt
 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground pepper
 1 tablespoon olive oil.
1. Combine all of the spices, garlic, ginger and grape-seed oil in a blender. Puree until smooth. Place tournedos with marinade in a large glass or ceramic bowl. Marinate in the refrigerator for 6 hours.
2. To make the salad: Combine lime juice, cider vinegar, salt and minced jalapeno in a large glass or ceramic bowl. Whisk in 2 tablespoons of olive oil. Add celery root, apple and jicama. Toss. Refrigerate for 4 hours.
3. To make the vinaigrette: Combine lime juice, orange rind, salt and pepper in a small glass or ceramic bowl. Whisk in 1 tablespoon olive oil. Set aside.
4. Heat the vegetable oil in a seasoned cast-iron skillet. Add the tournedos and cook over medium-high heat until medium rare, about 5 minutes per side. Set aside to rest for 5 minutes.
5. Add mint and coriander to the salad and toss. Divide among four plates. Cut the meat into thin strips. Drape the meat around the salad. Drizzle with the vinaigrette. Serve immediately.
Yield: Four servings.
