SECTION: Section 6; Page 42; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3269 words

HEADLINE: Fast Money

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell writes about economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:
The office building, a dreary block of reinforced concrete and glass on the seedy western fringes of midtown Manhattan, hardly rates a second glance. Nor does a dimly lit extension to the marble and steel lobby tucked beyond the elevator bank and leading to an unmarked beige door, discreetly monitored by a television camera recessed in the ceiling.
If it all seems unremarkable and uninviting, that is by design, something you begin to understand the moment you walk through the door. For you enter a maze of locked anterooms, rigged to trap, or at least slow, a determined intruder. And beyond the maze sits the object of these security measures, the computer system that is the heart of global capitalism. Here, coded requests to make payments of tens or hundreds of millions of dollars on behalf of this emir or that aerospace conglomerate pour in through 134 dedicated telephone lines. Twenty-two electronic black boxes made by the Racal-Guardata Corporation screen the incoming requests for coding flaws that would expose an illicit message before handing off the orders to a pair of Unisys A-15 J mainframe computers. In less than a second, the funds are on their way to Tokyo or Riyadh, or anywhere else money talks. 
 While the featureless facades of the refrigerator-size mainframes and the casual slouch of a few technicians in front of their video monitors give little hint of the scope of the operation, the stream of messages is really a torrent of unimaginable scale. Each business day, nearly $1 trillion -- more than the entire money supply of the United States -- moves through the machines. Were the flow to stop unexpectedly, financial empires would teeter and governments tremble.
The scene could be the prop for a running joke in a Vonnegut novel -- the one in which the fate of civilization rests in the hands of a bored switchboard operator. And there are unmistakable overtones of "Star Trek" and "Mission Impossible."
Actually it's not fantasy at all, but Chips, the Clearing House Interbank Payments System owned by 11 big New York banks. And to the thousands of businesses and government agencies that have come to depend on it, there is nothing sinister about a computerized system that reliably zaps multimillion-dollar payments around the globe for less than the price of a first-class postage stamp. Indeed, Chips is widely admired as a triumphant marriage of information processing technology and free enterprise, the next best thing to a perpetual-motion money-market machine.
But not every economics heavyweight gazes so benignly at Chips -- or, more generally, at the uncharted frontiers of finance of which Chips is a part, where money consists of magnetized specks of iron oxide in computer memories and great fortunes move from continent to continent as weightless photons through the electromagnetic ether.
Some worry that electronic money and the speed of its transfer are pushing the control of the world's money beyond the conservative reach of the Federal Reserve and other central government banks. Some focus on the coincidence of electronic transfer and increased volatility in financial markets, which they believe gives lie to the hallowed axiom that markets can never be too cheap or too easy to use. Certainly, the recent currency crisis in Europe did nothing to allay these fears.
The most widespread concern, though -- one that could make Europe's currency woes look like the failure of a small-town bank by comparison -- is financial gridlock. In the old banking world of paper money and clerks in green eyeshades, the wheels of financial commerce ground slowly, but with predictable regularity. By contrast, if something were to go seriously awry in the nearly perfect world of electronic money, the whole system could come to a wrenching halt in the twinkling of a gigabyte.
First things first. People make most of their purchases with coins or currency. Indeed, according to a back-of-the-envelope calculation by the Federal Reserve, a shade less than 85 percent of all dollar payments -- everything from tipping the bartender to buying the Sunday paper -- is made in cash. Checks account for most of the rest, while electronic transfers bring up the rear with a mere 2 percent of total transactions.
But this order is reversed if the count is made in total dollars in transit, rather than by the number of times money changes hands. Cash covers less than 1 percent of the total value of transactions, while money flashed from computer to computer accounts for five out of every six dollars that move in the economy. And while just one transaction in a thousand is made on the two great "wholesale" electronic transfer systems, Chips along with the network run by the Federal Reserve push around a stunning $1.7 trillion a day -- 80 percent of the total payments made worldwide in dollars.
What's more, the volume of business on these lightning-fast systems has grown at a rate hardly anyone would have imagined possible a few years ago. In 1980, the daily flow of electronic money was roughly 12 times the balances held in accounts at the Federal Reserve -- the money that banks use to settle their debts at the end of each day. By 1991, the daily flow had reached 55 times this base of bank reserves.
Why the explosion of electronic money? Start with the spectacular expansion of Government securities, used to finance the Federal deficit. These securities are, in effect, money that pays interest -- the perfect medium for speculating or hedging in dollars. Add the fact that the Government securities market was automated in the 1980's, reducing the mechanical obstacles to transferring ownership by wire: "A Treasury bill," points out James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, "no longer exists except as an entry on a computer tape."
Now factor in the growth of the global economy. When securities brokers in Milan or shirt factories in Thailand do international business, they usually conduct it in the only truly international money, the dollar. And when they convert their own money to United States currency (or back again), the dollar "leg" of the transaction usually goes through Chips in New York because the process is swift and cheap. Chips charges the 122 banks now on line to its computers a mere 18 cents per payment order -- no matter what the size -- and even less if their monthly transactions exceed 80,000.
Cheap and easy is precisely what modern telecommunications and data processing is supposed to be about. And the fact that the world's big economic players want to do most of their playing in American dollars under the rules set by American institutions is surely a tribute to the efficiency and stability of the American financial system.
So what's the beef? Some analysts worry that the speed, scale and complexity of electronic funds transfer has left the global payments system vulnerable to accident or malice -- or worse, a planetwide financial stall caused by a sudden loss of confidence.
JOHN F. LEE, President of the New York Clearing House Association, which runs Chips, hastens to point out that Chips has certainly not ignored the risks of fire, mechanical failure or even terrorism. The Manhattan site houses two computers, either of which could handle the business on its own. And the computers themselves are insulated from potential disaster in a variety of ways. The machines run on current from storage batteries fed by the city power grid; that way, the system is protected against surges and outages. A fire in the control room could be snuffed out in seconds by filling the chamber with Halon gas. Moreover, somewhere in New Jersey -- Lee is not eager to say just where -- Chips has two backup computers linked to an independent communications grid that are ready to process funds transfers at a moment's notice.
The one time backup was needed (Oct. 18, 1991, after a hardware breakdown took out both New York computers), the system worked flawlessly; processing was interrupted for just five minutes. Lee notes that users of the system would never have known about the failure if they hadn't been told.
Chips is well armored against theft. While the speed of transfer and the staggering sums routinely processed make fraud tempting, Lee argues that the problems in penetrating the system and making off with the cash are daunting.
A thief would have to tap into the dedicated phone lines that link member banks with Chips. Then he would have to crack the electronic authentication barrier -- the supersleuth equivalent of a mathematical password -- that stands between the central computers and the outside world.
Simply intercepting a message and changing a funds-transfer instruction would get the miscreant nowhere: the code that must be attached to each message is uniquely linked to the content of the message. An order to move, say, $4.2 million requires a different code from one for $42 million. And when a message cannot be authenticated by the black boxes, the dedicated phone line to the transmitting financial institution is automatically severed.
Finally, a thief would have to lay his hands on the fraudulently transmitted funds at the receiving end before the discrepancy was discovered -- most likely before the end of the day in which the evil deed was done.
There has, in fact, been a theft using Chips. But that was an inside job, one in which thieves used the system to wire money embezzled from the second-largest bank in Switzerland to the New York branch of an Australian bank. The coded message received by Chips was entirely legitimate.
The story of that robbery, pieced together from Australian news accounts and confirmed by bank representatives, is remarkable for both its simplicity and ingenuity. Vannyasingham Sothirasan, a Malaysian con man, apparently convinced two employees of the Swiss Bank Corporation in Zurich, Basant Singh and Martin Hauseder, to serve as inside men in the plot. They succeeded in forging an order to wire some $20 million to the State Bank of New South Wales on Dec. 7, 1989 -- money that had supposedly been deposited in the Swiss Bank Corporation the day before.
But how to claim the money once it arrived and make a clean getaway? Posing as an investment banker, Sothirasan had earlier cut a deal with Malcolm Edwards, an Australian tycoon in desperate need of cash to keep his real-estate empire afloat. The $20 million was to be the first installment of a $500 million loan coming from a fictitious bank, the Beyina Merchant Bank located in the West African nation of Cameroon.
Of the $20 million and change that was transferred to Edwards's account, some $10 million was apparently owed to Sothirasan and his associates by the "borrower" as a fee for arranging the "loan." These funds were quickly wired out of the State Bank of New South Wales by Edwards, broken down into smaller bites and then rewired to other banks.
Edwards used part of the balance to pay off debts and shipped the rest to Edwards-owned companies in Hong Kong and Fiji. Days later, when the Swiss Bank Corporation discovered there had never been a $20 million deposit received on Dec. 6, less than $100,000 was left in the New South Wales bank account.
This crime didn't pay -- or, at least, it probably won't. Sothirasan, Singh and Hauseder were tracked down and returned to Switzerland. All three were convicted; if their legal appeals fail, they will serve sentences of two and a half to three and a half years. At last report, though, only $8 million of the $20 million had been recovered. Civil suits against Edwards's companies and the State Bank of New South Wales are pending in Australia.
THE REMOTE THREATS of computer failure or fraud in Chips or one of the other big money networks are enough to keep the techies on their toes. But the scenario that really causes heartburn among the economists who pay attention to electronic transfers is something called systemic credit risk.
If you pay the dry cleaner in currency of the realm, the payment is final -- that's why the stuff is called legal tender. If you pay the dry cleaner by check, the settlement is "subject to collection," as they say in the fine print on your bank statement. But even if the check bounces and the dry cleaner takes you to court, the national system of making payments with written orders to transfer money from one bank account to another would hardly be threatened.
Now look again at Chips, where 122 banks are zapping orders to pay to each other at a rate of about $2 billion a minute. These payments aren't final until the end of the day, when all debts are cleared by shuffling dollars among the accounts the banks keep with the Federal Reserve.
Note, too, that the large number of banks and the incredible volume of transactions (typically 150,000 a day and, on occasion, as many as 300,000) make it impractical to make settlements on a bank-to-bank basis. Instead, what everybody owes everybody else is netted: Each institution that is in arrears makes payments into the kitty, much the way the "bank" settles accounts for a half-dozen players at the end of a night of poker.
"Multilateral" clearing of accounts through Chips is thus a daisy chain in which each bank's ability to meet its obligations depends on every other's. And that raises a natural question, one that people have been asking since the early 1980's, when the sums moving through Chips began to approach gee-whiz magnitudes: What would happen if a bank that owed money to the system failed to come up with the money at settlement time?
Under the rules of last resort adopted by Chips, the deceptively simple answer is that the day's transactions would be "unwound." That means that every transfer involving the defaulting bank would be removed from the day's settlement. But apart from the inconceivable complexity of sorting through the enormous volume of transfers and informing everyone from Exxon to the central bank of Burundi that the money never arrived, an "unwind" could also generate a cascade of failures in other banks that were owed money by the defaulting institution.
That's not just a guess. David B. Humphrey, a former Fed official now teaching at Florida State University, used the actual transactions from a day in 1983 to simulate the consequences of unwinding after the hypothetical failure of just one large bank. Humphrey found that 24 banks ended up owing more money than the capital of the banks' owners.
This does not mean all 24 would have gone belly up. Presumably most of the payment orders flowing through the defaulting bank would have been honored in the end; thus, most promises to pay by the bank would eventually have been collectible. But the likely consequence would still have been days or weeks of financial gridlock, in which tens or even hundreds of billions of dollars would have been frozen and hundreds of corporations would have faced a harrowing struggle to find cash.
And while the experts are reluctant to speculate about it on the record, there is a chance a settlement crisis in Chips could interact with a crisis in the securities markets, turning a merely hairy situation into a catastrophe. Imagine, for example, the fallout if Chips had failed to settle according to Hoyle during that awful day in October 1987, when America's stock markets lost $500 billion in value in a single trading session.
One way around this systemic credit risk, suggests Prof. Elinor Solomon, an economist at George Washington University, would be to work out a way to make every payment final the microsecond it is completed. That, in effect, is just what the Federal Reserve does with the transfers on its own electronic system: If a bank cannot settle at the end of the day, the Fed covers its obligations with a loan. Once, it actually made an overnight advance of $23.6 billion -- yes, billion -- to the Bank of New York in order to settle the day's accounts on transfers of Government securities that got fouled up in a software snafu.
This story had a happy ending: The Fed got its money back the next day, with interest at a 7.5 percent annual rate. And truth be told, Uncle Sam was never in danger of ending up out of pocket, because the loan was fully collateralized: the Government securities whose sale had caused all the problems never left the Fed's metaphoric vault. But one might ask what would have happened if a similar accident had occurred on Chips, where daylight overdrafts are not backed by the full faith and credit of the United States.
The best answer is that this kind of accident could not have happened. Chips payments must be initiated by the payer, making an involuntary, sorcerer's apprentice-style accumulation of overdrafts impossible. Besides, Chips places a cap on the level of debt that may be incurred by any single bank.
THAT STILL LEAVES THE question of how to guard against the Big One, the accident no one imagines before it happens.
Emergency loans to cope with liquidity problems are available to any solvent bank -- that, in fact, is what the Federal Reserve was invented to do. Thus, any American bank that couldn't settle its daily bill with Chips simply because it lacked liquidity would be eligible for a helping hand from Uncle.
Robert E. Hall, an economist at the Hoover Institution in Stanford, Calif., points out that a broader form of Government insurance against default -- even default generated by true insolvency -- is conceivable. But Hall is hardly enthusiastic about assigning a new insurance function to the good folks who brought us the savings-and-loan crisis.
Chips's own answer to the challenge of systemic risk is a combination of "real time" credit surveillance combined with group self-insurance. Each Chips bank now sets a limit on how much it is willing to be owed by every other Chips bank at any moment in the day. And the total amount any single bank can collectively owe to the others is automatically capped. Chips's computers give all member banks, as well as Chips's own staff, the capacity to monitor the ebb and flow as it is happening.
Moreover, since 1990 all the banks have been required to put up securities as collateral against the risk of failure by any other participating bank -- enough, collectively, to cover the risk of three big bank failures. If, say, one member of Chips couldn't come up with $2 billion at settlement time, the others would absorb the losses as a group and then try to get the money back through negotiation or litigation.
E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, while not "declaring victory," is confident that Chips could now withstand a very large shock. Michael Urkowitz, an executive vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank who is in charge of Chase's mammoth funds-transfer operations, is more emphatic: "I believe in my heart and soul," he says, "that the gridlock potential is small to nil."
What all the experts fear is what they do not know. Could the technology of funds transfer outrace the mechanisms for control, as it may have done in the early years of Chips? Could Wall Street, in its relentless quest for new products to peddle, invent one that unwittingly destabilizes the payments system? Could a competing payments network offshore, operating under other rules in other time zones, generate some perverse synergy that fatally damages Chips?
Almost anything is possible, suggests James Grant, "in a world in which electronic leverage -- the ratio of newfangled photons to old-fashioned banking dollars -- is enormous."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1421 words

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
In the Wings, Survival Tactics

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF

 BODY:
Whither American Ballet Theater?
If the answer were obvious, the question would not be asked. Yet after months of uncertainty, stemming from an increasingly unmanageable deficit and the resignation of its artistic director, a major American cultural institution has an opportunity for rebirth. It is a renewal that could go beyond mere survival. 
 The appointment earlier this month of Kevin McKenzie as artistic director to succeed Jane Hermann and of Gary Dunning as the company's executive director are excellent choices. Both are Ballet Theater alumni, and while financial constraints might oblige them to administer some questionable shock therapy, they understand the artistic distinctiveness that stems from the company's wide-ranging repertory.
It might be presumptuous to demand that a company in a cash-flow crisis hold on to an uncompromising vision. Yet without that vision -- and one can still define it as rooted in classical technique and esthetic eclecticism -- all is lost. Any drastic reduction in standards might even turn Ballet Theater into a regional troupe that happens to be based in New York. There would be a grim irony here: the little-noticed reality is that Ballet Theater has become the premier victim of the dance boom of the last 25 years. It is the growth of regional ballet that has siphoned support away from Ballet Theater in cities where it was once welcome.
Ballet Theater is still an international-rank ballet company, but it is not necessarily a national ballet company. On the one hand, it retains a world-class stature; the troupe's dancers can hardly be bettered elsewhere today and its repertory includes acknowledged masterpieces. On the other hand, Ballet Theater, which is dependent on touring, can no longer find local producers in many American cities to present it regularly with a guaranteed fee. Today, it is treated as an intruder.
Supporters of regional ballet jealously or protectively (depending on your point of view) look out for their own organizations' interests. Their loyalty and contributions go to the home team.
Is there a big enough audience, especially in a recession, for both Miami City Ballet and Ballet Theater in Miami? Will San Francisco Ballet's patrons give their money to that company, which has a $3 million deficit, or to Ballet Theater, which has a $5 million deficit? With no producer to guarantee a season's fee in such cities, Ballet Theater has now dropped the engagements it was to present under its own financially risky auspices in San Francisco and Chicago.
Admittedly, a national company's ethos does not derive from the financial structure of its tours. Yet when Ballet Theater faced a cash-flow crunch last month and its board of directors did not announce a new artistic director as promised in September, there was no show of alarm from foundations, civic fathers or the dance establishment across the country. (The Washington Post did write an editorial in support.) It is impossible to believe that concern for regional turf was not a factor in this indifference.
As it turns out, Stephen J. Friedman, the Ballet Theater board chairman and a relative newcomer to ballet, along with the board members most active in exploring various options (including a discarded idea for a merger with the Joffrey Ballet) deserve credit on two crucial points: in their insistence that Ballet Theater would continue and in their imagination in seeking out two dark-horse appointees, Mr. McKenzie and Mr. Dunning. (Rumored front-runners were current artistic directors of other companies.)
Mr. McKenzie is one of America's most eloquent classical dancers, a danseur noble with a high degree of versatility. Now retired from dancing, he was a principal with Ballet Theater from 1979 to 1991, after distinguishing himself in the Joffrey and the now-defunct National Ballet of Washington. Mr. Dunning, who will leave his post as the Houston Ballet's executive director, was with Ballet Theater from 1978 to 1986, serving as company manager and general manager.
Both men are 38 and, as Americans, grew up professionally amid the euphoria and the economic realities of the dance boom. When Mikhail Baryshnikov abruptly quit as artistic director in 1989 in a dispute over financial and personnel issues with the board and Ms. Hermann, then his handpicked executive director, he made a telling statement: "Nothing is ever too expensive if it furthers the repertoire and artistic standards of a dance company." It is unlikely that Mr. McKenzie will say the same.
Rather, the danger is that the company will retrench artistically because fiscal wisdom dictates that no major new production proceed until financing is already in place. Plans for a costly new "Swan Lake" for next year have been dropped, and the projected company premiere of Kenneth MacMillan's "Manon" is unlikely for the 1992-93 season.
The shock therapy under consideration, according to those acquainted with internal discussions, is a drop from an $18 million annual budget ($23 million was projected in 1989-90) to one that that will range from $12 million to $15 million. This is close to last season's budgets for regional companies ($16 million for San Francisco Ballet, $11 million for Houston Ballet, $10.7 million for Boston Ballet).
If donors remain reluctant to contribute to Ballet Theater before further cost-cutting measures go into effect, if the number of dancers is drastically reduced and if touring shrinks because of financial risk, the repertory and the standard of dancing will eventually be affected. The reason Ballet Theater has attracted dancers of Mr. Baryshnikov's caliber is that its standards in both dancing and repertory were compatible with his own. He did not join a regional company.
Ballet Theater does, moreover, have a distinct artistic profile, and Mr. McKenzie can be expected to keep to the original generic vision of an eclectic classical company -- a living museum with separate stylistic wings, dominated by no single choreographer.
At its beginnings in 1940, Ballet Theater was anything but a showcase for the 19th-century classics. Rather, new works were welcomed. It will not be surprising if Mr. McKenzie, with his penchant as a dancer for developing characterization, favors premieres that emphasize the "theater" in Ballet Theater.
Mr. Baryshnikov, who succeeded Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith in 1980, was right in believing that the company had to evolve. But he upset the repertory's balance, favoring Soviet-influenced classicism, Balanchinean neo-classicism and modern-dance choreographers who were inexperienced in ballet.
When Jane Hermann became artistic director in 1989-90, with Mr. Smith as co-director, she tried to return to Ballet Theater's roots in dance-drama. She brought back Agnes de Mille's only two enduring ballets ("Rodeo" and "Fall River Legend") and more works by Antony Tudor. Ms. Hermann, who left on Sept. 1, found that audiences preferred full-evening blockbuster ballets to 1940's dance-dramas.
The solution may be new dramatic ballets, but without the dated psychological baggage of earlier narrative works. As a showcase for an experimental dramatic genre, Ballet Theater could encourage young choreographers and entice veterans. Would Jerome Robbins, now technically a freelancer, be interested in working experimentally with his first company? Could the Glen Tetley who created vibrant dramatic works like "Alice" and "La Ronde" for the National Ballet of Canada be inspired to do the same for Ballet Theater?
Can Ballet Theater afford such choreographers? Perhaps the question is whether American choreographers can afford to let Ballet Theater go under. The current crisis stemmed in part from a $575,000 loan made in 1989 to finance Twyla Tharp's unsuccessful ballet "Everlast." Ballet Theater was restricted from obtaining further loans as long as that one remained unpaid.
The lesson is not that American choreographers should work for less than they deserve but that they might, on occasion, agree to work for a little less and without extravagant production values at Ballet Theater. Similarly, a board that has acquired -- rightly or wrongly -- a reputation for not raising needed money might feel inspired if a dialogue were set up between itself and the new artistic regime. What if everyone pulled together on this one?
"The chemistry has never been right at Ballet Theater," Mr. McKenzie says. The ingredients could well be different this time.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 33; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1104 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Two Blockbusters For the 90's

BYLINE: By Roberta Smith

 BODY:
It might almost be called the battle of the blockbusters. With much of the Museum of Modern Art taken up by its splendid Matisse exhibition and the Guggenheim Museum nearly filled to the brim with a cacophonous survey of the Russian avant-garde, the museological equivalents of Godzilla and King Kong, or Goya's snarling giants, are looming over Manhattan's cultural skyline.
The coincidence of two big shows is a little surprising, because over the past few years the blockbuster has often seemed like a concept whose time has gone. With the 80's art boom fading and the recession tightening budgets everywhere, it looked as if museums were going to settle in and cultivate their gardens, mounting exhibitions that used their own collections in new and revealing ways. 
 At the moment, that phase seems to have been indefinitely postponed. Both Matisse (400 works) and the Russians (800) are big, big shows that deal in exhaustive detail with
their subjects -- and getting through them can also be exhausting, especially when the galleries are crowded.
Their combined presence provides a chance to consider some of the pluses and minuses of the blockbuster, as well as its vicissitudes since the word gained prominence with the Tutankhamen exhibition at the Metropolitan in 1978. Has it matured or degenerated? More important, whom are these exhibitions for? Do they serve the public or specialists? Is it possible they are getting both bigger and more elitist?
Blockbusters have always varied in scale, scholarly ambition and sheer difficulty. Faced with the large size of the Matisse and Russian shows and the in-depth views they offer of their subjects, it is instructive to remember that the mother of recent New York blockbusters, Tut, contained only about 50 objects. What helped to draw more than a million visitors to the show was the carefully cultivated aura of rarity, power and mystery that surrounded the objects, from the story of the Egyptian boy-king and the dramatic discovery of his virtually intact tomb in the 1920's to the ominous fiction of King Tut's curse.
In the 1980's, blockbusters often seemed fueled by another extra-visual component -- the cult of personality, the artist as a hero whose life story filled the gaps between the paintings. The first and most famous of these was the Modern's huge (1,000 works) and hugely popular Picasso exhibition in 1980, followed by the Met's more modestly scaled (about 100 paintings each) but heavily attended van Gogh exhibitions in 1984 and 1987.
The Matisse and Russian shows are something else again. They are blockbusters that rely less on the popular fascination with the artists' private lives; their scope and detail may actually make them a kind of specialist's spectacle. When visiting these shows, I couldn't help wondering what the public would actually get out of them, although for very different reasons.
With Matisse these reasons are primarily logistical. As the largest and most complete retrospective of the artist's work ever assembled, this show may be the most nearly perfect blockbuster yet. Matisse's art is widely loved, yet the coherence of its many phases has never been spelled out as it is here. The result is a show with immense appeal for everyone, layman and specialist alike. (In more specific terms, the show's completeness will unquestionably be a boon to Matisse scholarship, and, like the Picasso show, it may have a salutary effect on contemporary painting.)
Yet the Matisse show may be done in by its own popularity. The three times I've visited it, crowds have been so thick that it was more like being at the theater during intermission. Only the most intense concentration made picture viewing possible, and it was never very pleasant. (According to a museum spokesman, one reason the show is crowded is that people are spending more time looking at it than was expected when the entrance rate of 500 visitors per half hour was determined.)
At the same time, one can't help wondering whether the public, whose tickets are paying for a large portion of the show's cost, might not actually experience more, esthetically speaking, in a show that occupies the same number of galleries but with fewer works.
The problems of the Russian show are considerably thornier. Billed as the largest survey of its kind, this exhibition of painting, sculpture, drawings, photographs, books, posters, architectural models, ceramics, and fabric and stage designs is an undertaking that essentially buries itself in trivia. In essence, the show is a blockbuster run amok. It contains quantities of mediocre works by obscure artists, is confusingly organized, and requires a fairly sophisticated knowledge of Russian modernism to be even roughly deciphered. Organized by a team of 13 curators and drawn largely from the collections of Russian museums, "The Great Utopia" often resembles an archive -- and not a very good one at that.
But in what may be a new twist in the history of the blockbuster, this exhibition absorbs to a new degree the spectacle that used to surround such exhibitions. In many ways the sometimes dazzling, often intrusive installation designed by the architect Zaha Hadid is the most dominant artwork on view at the Guggenheim. With its enormous protruding beams, irregular walls and large-scale Suprematist-like graphics that mimic the paintings, it conveys the sense of iconoclasm that was at the center of the Russian avant-garde with a force that the actual art in this context often fails to convey.
These two shows also seem emblematic of the institutions that house them. Unfolding in a series of smooth yet clearly articulated phases, chronologically arranged in plain, mostly white rooms, the Matisse retrospective exudes the kind of austere single-mindedness and purifying impulse that is the essence of both the Modern's house style and its particular view of the history of modernism. Just like the great collection that usually fills these same galleries, Matisse's career begins in late-19th-century French post-Impressionism and moves toward an increasingly abstract, large-scale and pictorial statement that culminates in the middle of the 20th.
The Guggenheim's esoteric extravaganza conveys the sense of hollow, yet oddly narrow, showmanship that seems to have overtaken the museum under its present administration. In one sense art is almost incidental to the visual circus set before us in Frank Lloyd Wright's spiral; yet, once beyond the installation, what transpires there is truly and impenetrably a blockbuster for the few, and in that, an oxymoron.

HEADLINE: Sweeteners for the Relocated to Sell

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
LIKE many couples scouring the residential real estate market these days, Chuck and Eileen Slater were looking for a steal. They had outgrown and sold their three-bedroom Cape Cod in Ridgewood, N.J., and wanted to take advantage of depressed home prices in the New York metropolitan region.
The Slaters weren't disappointed. After a brief search, they found a four-bedroom, Federal-style home on a third of an acre in Ramsey, N.J., for $340,000. Not exactly a fire-sale price, but substantially lower than comparable homes in the affluent community. 
 "We were very lucky," Mrs. Slater said. "I know I could have turned around and, two weeks later, sold it for at least $15,000 more."
The house the Slaters stumbled on was not in foreclosure or financial distress; rather, it was part of a corporate relocation, a "relo" in industry argot. It had been owned by an I.B.M. employee who had been transferred to Atlanta.
Relocation homes have never been a large part of the resale market; only about 350,000 home sales, or 10 to 15 percent of the market, involve corporate relocations each year.
Moreover, the number of transfers appears to be declining as companies, hard hit by the recession, become more cost conscious. An employee transfer can cost up to $100,000; the average was $44,804 in 1991, according to Runzheimer Reports, a travel and relocation research newsletter published in Rochester, Wis.
In recent years, relocation policies at many companies have been changed to give employees greater financial incentives to sell their homes rather than have them taken over by their company or by a concern specializing in relocation management.
By paying bonuses to employees who sell their own homes, companies hope to minimize the expenses of owning and maintaining an inventory of housing.
Figures on the number of homes owned by relocation companies, or by concerns that have transferred employees, are not made public. Sometimes, however, major corporate moves can have a noticeable effect in a specific area. This was the case in recent months after United Parcel Service moved its corporate headquarters from Greenwich, Conn., to Atlanta and W.R. Grace & Company moved its main offices from Manhattan to Boca Raton, Fla.
"Generally, relocation homes are very good opportunities for the general consumer," said John Featherston, publisher of National Relocation and Real Estate magazine in Westport, Conn.
STEVEN E. BETTI, an amusement-games distributor, believes he saved 10 percent off the price of a two-bedroom condominium that he bought for $122,000 last May in Tenafly, N.J. It had been owned by a transferred I.B.M. employee and been vacant for four months. Mr. Betti, 32 years old, said he had found it after telling a broker he was looking for something that had been repossessed, was in foreclosure or was being offered for sale by a corporate relocation company.
The unit Mr. Betti bought had been appraised at $135,000. "You always hear about these great bargains out there," he said. "Well, I'm comfortable with what I paid. I don't feel like I did too bad at all."
For the most part, when an employee who owns a home is transferred, he or she has up to 60 or 90 days to sell the home. If it is sold at a loss, the company, in many cases, reimburses the employee for some or all of the loss; if the home doesn't sell, the company buys it at the current appraised value. Meanwhile, the company hires a relocation company to manage and market the home. Any loss incurred in selling the home, plus the maintenance costs, will be absorbed by the company.
The cost of an employee's selling his own home is estimated by Runzheimer Reports to be 11.3 percent of the cost of the sale price. That figure includes broker fees, taxes and the 1.5 to 2 percent fee paid to the relocation company for marketing assistance. If a company acquires the home, however, the cost jumps to 23.3 percent.
"A lot of our efforts nowadays are geared to helping transferred employee sell their home before we have to acquire it," said Rick Schwartz, a senior vice president at Prudential Relocation Management in White Plains, which handles corporate transferees. "About 60 percent get sold that way -- five years ago it might have been 40 percent."
Relocation homes may look particularly attractive these days because companies have started offering employees financial incentives to sell their homes themselves rather than let the company and a corporate relocation service, such as Prudential or PHH Home Equities of Wilton, Conn., take them over for the current appraised value.
From a buyer's standpoint, homes in and around communities that house large corporations, such as Greenwich, Stamford and Danbury, Conn., White Plains and Princeton, N.J., are hotbeds of corporate relocations. "They are also liable to be based anywhere in the New York metropolitan area," said Gary Daniels, a vice president for marketing services at Coldwell Banker Schlott Realtors in Wayne, N.J.
The particulars of one of the most important parts of a relocation package, "loss on sale" policies, vary just as widely.
The Union Carbide Corporation in Danbury, for instance, offers a bonus up to 3 percent of the appraised price if an employee sells a home within 60 days for a price not less than 98 percent and not more than 103 percent of the appraised price.
If the sale or appraisal price, with or without the bonus, is less than the original purchase price plus improvements, the company makes up the entire difference. If the home is not sold, the company pays the employee the original purchase price, plus the cost of improvements.
"They are actively marketing the houses now that they have the chance of a bonus," said Irene F. Romano, a relocation administrator for Union Carbide. "In the past, they just sat back and waited for their 100 percent from Prudential." Ms. Romano added that in recent years the company had modified its relocation policy as it pertained to homeowners. "It used to be that if you added a doorknob, it was an improvement," she said. "No more."
She also said that Union Carbide executives were now studying whether to place caps on its unusually generous policy of guaranteeing transferred employees the original purchase price of their home. "We have had some very big 'losses on sales,' " she said.
AT W.R. Grace, which last summer moved 250 employees from Manhattan to Boca Raton, Fla., the relocation policy was similar to Union Carbide's, except that it placed caps on the amount of a loss on sale that the company would reimburse. The maximum was $45,000 -- 100 percent of the first $20,000, 75 percent of the next $20,000 and 50 percent of the next $20,000.
The policy is less generous at I.B.M., which has its worldwide headquarters in Valhalla, N.Y., and 11,000 employees based in Westchester County. The company has no "loss on sale" program for transferred employees, although it does provide an incentive bonus of 1 percent of the appraised price of the house to employees who sell on their own rather than have the company take over the home.
Company officials said the lack of a "loss on sale" program was not disturbing to most I.B.M. employees because transfers generally involved career advancement or long-term opportunities.
"The majority of employees do not take a loss," said Suzane W. Parker, manager of relocation and expense reimbursement services for Workforce Solutions in Purchase, N.Y., an I.B.M. subsidiary in charge of transferring 4,000 to 5,000 people a year. "Overall, it is still a positive situation."
A markedly different policy was in effect last year at United Parcel Service, whose move to Atlanta involved about 700 employees and 400 employee-owned homes. There, if employees took a loss and sold the home themselves, and the price was greater than or equal to the appraised value, they received up to 100 percent of the loss, up to $133,000. If they could not sell the home, and the company bought it for the appraised price, only 75 percent of the loss was reimbursed. A similar policy is in place for transferred employees.
"My neighbor worked for I.B.M. and was being transferred at the same time," said John H. Flick, an international public relations manager at U.P.S. "He was ready to kill me because we were letting our house go for so low."
Mr. Flick was one of the many home-sellers facing a loss. He had bought a three-bedroom ranch in Danbury for $220,000 in 1988. In 1991, the house was appraised at $200,000. He sold it for $190,000 and was reimbursed $30,000 for his loss. "I jumped at it," he said, adding that his home in Atlanta, which cost about the same as his old home in Danbury, was more than twice the size -- 3,600 versus 1,600 square feet. He is also 10 minutes from work as opposed to an hour when he lived in Connecticut.
In the last year, the Danbury area, in northern Fairfield County, may have been one of the attractive areas for buyers seeking the homes of corporate transferees. Because of the high cost of housing in Greenwich and lower Fairfield County, many U.P.S. workers lived in the Danbury area.
"AT one point there was a whole page of U.P.S. homes for sale in the newspaper, 90 people," Mr. Flick said. "And people all knew we were moving all at once. It was almost like a fire sale. People were making ridiculously low offers."
Of 50 U.P.S. homes being offered for sale by William Raveis Real Estate in Danbury, 49 were sold by their owners before going into inventory.
"They were very, very negotiable," said Karlene M. Anderson, real estate agent with Raveis in Danbury. "U.P.S. wanted to get rid of the homes and didn't want them in inventory as a 'relo' home."
To find a home being offered for sale by either a relocating executive or a corporate relocation company, prospective buyers need only mention the possibility to a real estate broker or contact one of the relocation companies for a list of homes in their inventory. Prudential, PHH Home Equities and Coldwell Banker/Relocation One are three of the largest.
"It was something that I didn't even think about when we started looking," Mrs. Slater said, referring to homes being sold by corporate transferees. "My father is a realtor and he went through all the books for us, and he found this one. It looked picture perfect and with the price it was almost too good to be true."
"But if I were looking again," she added, "this would be something that I would definitely pursue first."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Conference in Newark;
Urban Housing

 BODY:
The often vexing problem of providing low-income housing while retaining and attracting middle-income residents is a challenge shared by municipalities across the country.
To examine how design can be part of the solution to these and other prickly urban-housing problems, the New Jersey Institute of Technology School of Architecture in Newark will be host at a daylong conference next Friday. 
 "We will be asking, 'What are the physical models and what is the new thinking in terms of urban policy, that can be applied to creating low-income housing?' " said Tony Schuman, a professor of architecture at the school and chairman of the housing conference.
Conference panelists will include municipal housing officials, architects and planners, as well as builders and developers from across the country. Professor Schuman expects the debates to be lively because of the diversity of opinions and approaches to housing development taken by conference participants.
The conference, which will begin at 9 A.M., will be held in the School of Architecture Campbell Hall gallery at Warren Street and Martin Luther King Boulevard in the University Heights section of Newark. The registration fee, which includes lunch, is $30. For further information call Renada Woodford at the School of Architecture, (201) 596-3080.

HEADLINE: Talking: Co-op Loans;
Refinance Eases for Buildings

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THERE'S been a slight thaw in the icy attitude lenders have been taking lately toward co-op buildings eager to refinance their underlying mortgages.
"I think the worst is over," said Harry Avradinis, president of NYM Capital Group of Manhattan, mortgage brokers. 
 New options are available for both buildings where all the units are owner-occupied and those where most are still owned by the sponsor. But it remains a highly restricted market compared to the heady days of the 80's, and a lot still hinges on where the building is, its physical condition and the sponsor's financial strength.
One harbinger, Mr. Avradinis said, came this fall when his company refinanced the mortgages of two large Manhattan co-ops in both of which 52 percent of the shares were still owned by a sponsor. Typically, 50 percent has been the cut-off line above which it was impossible to interest a new lender.
He had the same experience, he said, with a co-op in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn where only 39 percent of shares had been sold. However, in all instances the sponsor had a positive cash flow.
Irrespective of whether the units are sold out, lawyers are increasingly suggesting that co-op boards search for a willing lender through a mortgage broker.
"It's becoming too time-consuming to do it any other way," said Marcie Waterman, a New York City lawyer specializing in co-ops.
For one, it's tough for an outsider to find out which lenders remain in this market and their current eligibility requirements. And many newer ones are relatively unknown because they are from out of state or upstate.
However, because lenders aren't competing heavily for this market, the co-op will have to pay the broker -- traditionally a lender's responsibility. Expect to be charged about 1 percent of the loan amount. Some, such as Patrick B. Niland, managing partner of First Funding of Rochester, may offer to negotiate a slightly lower flat amount.
Boards should also select someone with experience in this type of lending, since it remains an arcane area requiring specialized knowledge, Ms. Waterman said.
Co-ops that are at least 70 percent sold out and whose loan requirements are less than 50 percent of the building's value will be offered many opportunities and attractive terms, maintained Gregg Winter, president of Winter & Company Mortgage Services of Brooklyn. Not only are interest rates at a historic low, but also points are being waived for many loans over $500,000.
That is important because the drop in overall costs could also reduce maintenance fees, making the difference between a negative and positive cash flow for the sponsor and between acceptance or rejection, said Mr. Avradinis.
Mr. Winter said that an even more significant drop in debt service could be achieved if the building were willing to reconsider the customary strategy of taking out a fixed-rate loan each time its 10-year term was up.
Instead, he recommended switching to a variable rate loan tied to the prevailing prime rate. Although he concedes this is a radical departure that carries some risk should rates rise precipitously, the advantage, he maintains, will be twofold. First, the interest rate could immediately drop to less than 7 percent instead of 8 or 9 percent. Second, the extra saving could be crucial to controlling maintenance fees, especially if the building is simultaneously facing sharply rising taxes from the phasing out of its J51 tax abatement -- as many now are.
THE second benefit is that the floating rate would not carry the punitive prepayment penalties that in the last few years have become standard for co-op underlying mortgages -- penalties so onerous that it's now almost impossible to consider refinancing until each 10-year term is complete, Mr. Winter said. And if rates start to inch up, the co-op would have kept the right to change to a fixed rate without facing major penalties.
Such an approachis also useful, he maintained, if the co-op's financial circumstances are in flux. For instance, in September it became the loan of choice, he said, for a 120-unit co-op on the Upper East Side that was about to sell first-floor retail space. The co-op planned to use the proceeds from the sale to reduce its current loan balance of $4 million. But the sale was not due for a year.
This way, Mr. Winter said, the co-op could take advantage of low rates by refinancing now while keeping open its option to pay off some of the loan next year without penalties.
Another wrinkle, said Gary Kokalari, vice president of Washington Mortgage Financial Group of Jersey City, is a greater willingness by some bankers to accept a special escrow to cover a sponsor's negative cash flow, rather than simply turning the building down. Similar compromises are being worked out when a sponsor refuses to divulge his personal finances.
For instance, Mr. Winter recently negotiated this sort of compromise for the 23-unit co-op at 75 Prospect Park West in Park Slope. The sponsor's apartments were bringing in rents that were $30,000 a year short of the amount he owed the co-op for maintenance. An escrow of $100,000 was set up to cover at least a three-year shortfall should he not be able to meet his obligations.
Being able to get a commitment from a regular lender can also help a co-op get better terms from any private underlying loan a sponsor might have been holding. That's what an eight-unit loft co-op on Crosby Street in SoHo did. The sponsor was holding the underlying mortgage of $170,000 and had been unwilling to lower interest rates below 10 percent, figuring the building had no other choice.
But after great difficulty, when it did find someone else, said Anthony Orphanos, the co-op's treasurer, they were able to get the sponsor to provide even more competitive terms, including no prepayment penalties. Mortgage costs have thus fallen from $4,500 a year per unit to $3,000, even though the co-op added $50,000 to the loan amount for capital improvements.
However, since lenders are still uneasy about underlying mortgages in general, co-ops must take extra care to put their financial houses in order.
Many lenders quickly lose interest, Mr. Niland warned, when boards don't have the necessary figures at their fingertips. "Do your homework," he said. "Know exactly how many units are owner-occupied" and how many are being sublet, he added, warning that this number is now being added to the sponsor's total. It also helps if the budget shows a modest annual surplus.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Shopping Centers;
Stores Pick Up the Construction Slack

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN the normal pattern of growth, housing comes first and the stores follow. Normality is prevailing in the western reaches of the North Shore of Staten Island.
On a flat 10 acres off Forest Avenue where the Weissglass family once ran a dairy, the developer Sanford Nalitt has started to build a strip shopping center called Forest Plaza. Its largest store will be a 52,000-square-foot A.&P. In addition there will be 110,000 square feet for other stores, nearly half of it spoken for already, said Mr. Nalitt. Separating the stores from the avenue will be an unlandcaped stretch of 3.7 acres where 660 cars will be able to park. 
 Sanford Nalitt & Associated Companies owns and runs about 3.5 million square feet of shopping centers in New York State, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. About 10 percent of that space is on Staten Island, where Mr. Nalitt was born and has his main office. "I've seen opportunities under my nose," he said.
Recession notwithstanding, the opportunity-sniffers have continued to prowl the broad stretch of Staten Island from Mariners Harbor on the north to New Springville in the dead center of the island. Thirty years ago, with support from the Department of City Planning, developers planted the Staten Island Mall in New Springville, a regional mall anchored by a Macy's and a Sears department store.
A new highway network serving it was under development at the time and the area has since grown as anticipated as a population center. Housing, in that instance, followed commercial development.
Now the Staten Island Mall itself is expanding. The Rouse Company of Columbia, Md., which bought the mall in 1980, is building a 180,000-square-foot J.C. Penney's as a third anchor, and adding an additional 130,000 square feet of gross leasable space in the mall for about 50 more stores. There are already 165 tenants in the mall, the largest in the city.
The Forest Plaza project, in the Mariners Harbor section of Staten Island, is in a location filled with town houses built in the decade of the 80's. Sales of new homes are still under way at two of them, Woodmont West and Chester Place. But it is only at the shopping-center site that construction is in progress. Home sales are slow.
Mr. Nalitt's project itself might not be under way had he not been able to find financing for it from other than his accustomed institutional backers. The $16.5 million construction and permanent loan for Forest Plaza came from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Building Investment Trust, which was launched in 1988 to promote jobs and economic development through union pension fund investments in commercial and industrial real estate.
Mr. Nalitt had been accustomed to financing from lines of credit with Chemical Bank and Marine Midland Bank. "For five years he wouldn't even come to me," said Marilyn Brown of American Asset Advisers, a mortgage banking firm in Staten Island, through whom the developer found the lender. The loan was made in March when the development was 67 percent preleased.
In Chicago, John Tung, senior vice president of Draper & Kramer Realty Advisers, investment advisers to the trust, said that the fund had grown to $200 million of lending capacity in four years and has approved $160 million in loans to 16 projects, including one to a 50,000-square-foot shopping center called Rose City Plaza in Madison, N.J. It was completed two years ago.
Financing problems were not the only impediment to construction at Forest Plaza. It took New York City three and a half years to rezone the land to permit a supermarket. The zoning was industrial because of the presence of the dairy the last time the city adopted a comprehensive new zoning ordinance, in 1961. The lease with A.&P. was actually signed in 1985.
"The attitude in the city was that they were just too busy," Mr. Nalitt said. "Staten Island could not get approvals."
THE mall is now scheduled to open next August. Tenants already committed include Sav-On Drugs, Fashion Bug and Fabco Shoes. Rents are typically $16 and $22 a square foot for larger stores and in the low $30-a-square-foot area for smaller stores.
The tenants at Forest Plaza are for the most part expanding from other Staten Island locations, but not relocating existing stores, said Richard Pesin, who is handling leasing at Forest Plaza for Sanford Nalitt.
The unlandscaped parking area will have the dismal appearance typical of New York City's midsized shopping centers. Architects themselves express dismay over this, but without minimum standards established in a zoning ordinance by the City Planning Commission improvement is unlikely.
The J.C. Penney store coming to the Staten Island Mall is a relocation from an older shoping center in the Westerleigh section of Staten Island. The mall has a 239,500-square-foot Macy's store and a 190,500-square-foot Sears store already, plus 165 mall tenants in 409,000 square feet of space. The property covers 112 acres off Richmond Avenue and has open parking for 5,600 cars. That will be increased by 1,000 spaces.
The expansion creates an extension at the center of the existing structure, into vacant land behind it. The new parking will mainly replace the grassy 400-foot buffer that now attractively separates the parking lot from Richmond Avenue. That landscaped buffer will shrink to about 40 feet.
Leasing of the new mall space began two years ago, said Benjamin Levine, manager of the mall, and about 80 percent of the 130,000 square feet of mall space is committed. Among the tenants to have signed leases so far are Express, Victoria's Secret and Structure, all affiliated stores of The Limited Inc., of Columbus, Ohio; B. Dalton bookstore and Merry-Go-Round, a clothing store. The mall is expected to have 50 stores.
THE project will employ about 500 people over the course of construction, said Charles Bacon, the project executive for Lehrer McGovern Bovis, the construction manager for Rouse. The economic climate for building "could not be better," he said, meaning that the slow economy has produced favorable subcontractor prices. But The Rouse Company refused to disclose what construction would cost.
The two commercial projects have compensated modestly for what has been a sharp turndown in new home construction on Staten Island. The sluggishness of sales is evident directly on the border of the Forest Plaza center, where home builders have sites for new homes.
At Woodmont West, Woodmont Development Corporation, headed by Morty Simon and his son, Neil, set out to build 287 town houses on the site in 1986 and 270 of them have been built, sold and occupied. This year, however, prices are down substantially from the level a few years ago. A three-bedroom house that sold for $155,000 at one time is priced at $130,000 now, Mr. Simon said. A three-story house that sold for $190,000 initially sells for $160,000.
Sales are plugging along at a rate that could keep the Simons on the land for five more years, Mr. Simon said, although he still hopes to be finished in two or three.
"We build in groups," he said. "Four months ago we began a group of seven after four or five sales, and now six are sold. It's a juggling act deciding when to start a group, a lot more difficult than when we had people lining up to buy."

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Low Prices in a High-Rent Location

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
THE former Le Peep's in the center of Greenwich has, with new ownership, been transformed into Ashton's. The setting in the long dining room is restrained, with floral and ship prints on pale orchid walls, burgundy carpet and matching tablecloths, and dining areas separated by lattice dividers.
The place retains elements of the old Le Peep's menu at breakfast and lunch, but dinner is somewhat more interesting, with a few pizzas and pastas, as well as a half dozen other entrees. What is amazing about Ashton's, considering its high-rent location on Greenwich's major shopping street, are its low prices. Entrees for $6 to $12 represent good value anywhere in Fairfield County, but seem especially so in Greenwich. 
 There are a few appetizers, the best being the asparagus constellation: fresh asparagus spears wrapped in thinly sliced prosciutto and blanketed in a tangy, smoky cream sauce made with Connecticut smoked pepperjack cheese. Crab cakes (two lumpy ones that looked as though a small child had modeled them from clay) were well-seasoned, but were, unfortunately, borderline-burned.
We fared better with our entrees. Mexicali ravioli consisted of a generous portion of cheese ravioli in a delicious Parmesan cream sauce, enlivened by fresh corn niblets, jalapeno peppers chopped fine to give well-balanced heat and kick, and red pepper strips latticed on top. A hint of cilantro finished it off.
Broiled red snapper basked in the zing of a tri-citrus white wine-butter sauce and was light, moist and tasty. Unfortunately, also on the plate was a mahogany-brown baked potato that had seen better days.
On one occasion our spirits were revved by a goat cheese pizza piled generously with a fresh sharp goat cheese, chunks of sun-dried tomatoes, green pepper strips and a plum tomato sauce, all tasty enough for us to overlook the canned black olives.
Southwestern pizza -- a combination of Italian sausage (not chorizo, as stated on the menu), green peppers and Connecticut smoked pepperjack cheese -- was zesty, though the addition of jalapenos might have given it more southwest pizazz.
Oddly, though Ashton's sells pizza to take out, on the one occasion when we tried it, it was cut into slices and packed in a plastic foam box. When we tried to remove it from the box to reheat it, the slices, separated by pieces of wax paper, stuck to the paper, creating a real mess that made it impossible to separate, heat or eat. In short, we paid $10 for an inedible six-layer paper-and-pizza whatzit.
Desserts -- chocolate cake and cheesecake -- were commercial and could be skipped.
A three-course dinner for two came to $34. Beverages, tax and gratuity were extra. There is no bar, but wine and beer are available. Service can be erratic and slow. But for an inexpensive meal, Ashton's may be just what a shopper strolling along Greenwich Avenue is looking for.
 
A LA CARTE
 As some of New York City's top restaurants are treading the economic downturn by offering prix fixe menus, L'Abbee, at 62 Main Street in New Canaan, may be starting a similar trend in Connecticut. The small, elegant restaurant now offers a $34 prix fixe dinner Sunday through Thursday evenings. The price includes appetizer, entree, dessert and coffee; in each category there are several choices, making this a very good deal indeed as most entrees alone run from $18 to the mid-$20s. Lunch is now served Friday and Saturday only, with brunch on Sunday. Telephone: 972-6181.
Pompano Grille, at 1460 Post Road East in Westport, has changed its name to Pompano Oyster Bar and Seafood Grill. A recent visit suggests that nothing new has been added except for a raw bar (called an oyster bar), featuring oysters and clams on the half shell and lobster and shrimp in the rough. Decor, price structure and seafood dishes (with a few chicken and beef entrees) seem much as they were. Even the staff has the same "otherwise engaged" air that prevailed during past visits. There is just one oyster dish on the menu (other than at the raw bar), a baked oyster appetizer. Telephone: 259-1160.
 
Ashton's
 Satisfactory
48 Greenwich Avenue (between U.S. 1 and Railroad Avenue), Greenwich; 869-0161.
Atmosphere: A long narrow room with orchid walls, burgundy carpet and tablecloths, and lattice area dividers.
Service: Cheerful, but slow and can be scattered.
Recommended dishes: Asparagus constellation, goat cheese pizza, Mexicali ravioli, red snapper.
Price range: Lunch entrees $5-$7; dinner entrees $8-$12.
Credit cards: All major cards.
Hours: Breakfast 6:30 A.M.-4 P.M. daily; lunch 11 A.M.-4 P.M. daily; dinner 4 P.M.-10 P.M. daily.
Reservations: Accepted but unnecessry.
Wheelchair access: Ground-level access, but restrooms up two flights.

HEADLINE: Youngsters Vote in a Presidential Poll

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: HACKENSACK

 BODY:
At Mike's Barber Shop here, the price of a haircut invariably includes a freewheeling, good-humored debate on politics and national affairs. Regular customers expect it, and some customers are drawn by it.
Now 49-year-old Michael Sutlovich Jr. has transformed his basement shop here into a continuing civics lesson for those customers whose votes don't count -- not yet, at least. 
 He has adorned the shop in red, white and blue bunting and balloons. A large American flag covers one wall. Another wall bears Clinton-Gore and Bush-Quayle posters, along with a hand-printed Perot sign. The centerpiece, though, is a ballot box for his young customers to support their favorite candidates.
"Kids have opinions, pretty strong ones too," Mr. Sutlovich said, "and, hey, we're talking about the future leaders of our country here. People think: 'Kids, what do they know?' But I'll tell you, they're pretty sharp, they're honest, and what they have to say is refreshing."
Over a six-week period ending last Tuesday, 265 customers, age 8 to 17, cast their ballots as follows: 128, or about 48 percent, for President Bush, and 135, or about 51 percent, for Gov. Bill Clinton. Ross Perot received 2 votes.
 
Request to Change Vote
 "I had one kid, a little girl, who voted for the President," said Mr. Sutlovich, a Lake Hiawatha resident who 27 years ago started cutting hair in a basement shop at Packard's, a supermarket housed in a former textile mill. "She comes in the next day, all upset, and asks to change her vote to Clinton. It turns out that her father had just been laid off from his job."
One recent afternoon, Maria Matina, a 12-year-old from Paramus, said she had voted for Mr. Clinton because the President had not kept his promise about reducing taxes. Her mother, Vincenzina, nodded in agreement as her daughter dropped her ballot into the makeshift box.
Dominic Cutri, 11, of Parsippany said his parents did not always vote, despite the sixth grader's efforts to get them to the polls.
"I think that it's important because in other countries people don't have a choice to make," he said. "The choice is made for them."
Nicholas Lapolla, 12, of Hackensack said Ross Perot was "the country's only real choice" on Election Day. "President Bush hasn't gotten anything done, and Clinton just wants to raise taxes," he said. "Perot will raise taxes too, I think, but not as much. Either way, I think he's got more on the ball than the others."
 
'Warm-Up for the Real Thing'
 For Theresa DiStasi, who turns 18 on Friday , the chance to vote in Mr. Sutlovich's unofficial poll while she was still 17 was "a warm-up for the real thing" and a welcome chance to seriously weigh the issues. Many adults, Ms. DiStasi said, feel that teen-agers are "too inexperienced" and that their votes have little meaning. That opinion, she says, does not apply to her.
"I think that the Republicans have done enough damage to our economy and that Bush's version of Reaganomics has taken its toll," she said. "When I step into that voting booth in November, for me it's the real thing, and I've taken the time to study what I'm voting for. I'm exercising my right to make a difference."
Mr. Sutlovich's poll was born from the comment of a lively 10-year-old customer, he said.
"I'm cutting this kid's hair and I asked, 'So, who would you vote for in November?' He looks me right in the eye and says, 'Oh, I'm a Bush man. Four more years and he'll have the country back on its feet,' " Mr. Sutlovich said.
He said he was so impressed by the boy's intensity that the following day he fashioned a ballot box.
"In a lot of these schools, kids don't get taught about issues and the special things that make this country great," Mr. Sutlovich said, "and a lot of them don't know or care who the heck is running. I want to give them a chance to think and make a choice, to know that what they say in time will mean something."
Mr. Sutlovich said that if the three major candidates wanted more debate time, he would gladly offer them a forum at his shop. "Hey, I've got three barber's chairs," he said, "if they don't mind a close shave on the issues."
Because of the ailing economy, Mr. Sutlovich said, many of his customers are in trouble. "It's unbelievable," he said. "People sometimes come in here in tears. I feel like I'm a priest." He mentioned a customer who had helped with his grandson's education.
"Here's this kid with an M.B.A. in his pocket now and no job," Mr. Sutlovich said. "You know what he is doing now? He's got a paper route. True story! Maybe he should have learned Japanese."
Mr. Sutlovich said that he learned at a young age, growing up in the Hell's Kitchen area of Manhattan, that voting counts. His father, he said, was a union organizer in New York City's garment district in the 1940's when sweatshops operated with little interference from the law.
"My father, he died a poor man, but he went to his grave knowing that people deserved a better life," he said. "The right to vote made it happen for them, especially if they voted from their hearts."
