HEADLINE: Women's Progress Stalled? Just Not So

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
You've heard it often: The 1980's were the backlash years, when Ronald Reagan and George Bush trashed affirmative action, feminism went out of fashion and the news media convinced women that they couldn't have it all. The implication is that women's economic progress stalled.
Widely accepted though it may be, that last assumption is mostly wrong. A fresh body of research -- mostly by a new generation of female economists who've mined a mountain of unexplored data -- shows compellingly that women were big economic winners in the 1980's expansion and that their gains are likely to keep coming in the 1990's regardless of who is in the White House. 
 From the top of the pay scale to the bottom, from stock traders earning six-figure bonuses to $5-an-hour sales clerks, women gained on men in the 1980's. While the median annual salary for men slid 8 percent after inflation between 1979 and 1990, to $28,843 from $31,315, the comparable salary for women rose 10 percent, to $20,656 from $18,683.
The most basic measure of women's status in the work force -- the number of cents women earn for each dollar of men's earnings -- rose to a record 72 cents in 1990. Conventional wisdom -- enshrined in the best-selling book "Backlash: The Undeclared War Against American Women," among other places -- has it that women made no progress in the past decade. In fact, women were stuck earning around 60 cents to the men's dollar from 1960 through 1980, but started catching up fast as the economy expanded during the 1980's.
Things look even better for young women, ages 24 to 35. They now earn 80 cents for every dollar earned by men of the same age, up from 69 cents in 1980.
Far from losing ground, women gained more in the 1980's than in the entire postwar era before that -- and almost as much as between 1890 and 1980.
"We're moving toward a more egalitarian society," said Heidi Hartmann, an economist and the director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research, a feminist research organization based in Washington.
Of course, women's pay is still far below men's. Why? The short answer is that, on average, women are still entering lower-paying occupations than men. They still work fewer hours, are less educated and have less job experience and fewer of the skills -- from selling cars to programming computers -- that are most valued.
Remember, too, that the 54 million American women in the work force include several generations. The 35-year-old pharmacist or lawyer with 10 years on the job is lumped together with her mother who graduated from high school, left the work force at 20 and returned to a minimum-wage job at a local store.
 
A Solid, n Enduring Trend
 Apple-to-apple comparisons give a far different impression. Women in economics with Ph.D.'s, for example, earn between 95 percent and 99 percent as much as male peers with the same experience.
That is not to say that all is well. Bosses and co-workers still discriminate, husbands still hold back their wives' careers by not doing their share at home, and there is a new set of anxieties, like guilt about combining work and motherhood. And, just as with men, some women are working less because they want to than because they have to, especially in tough economic times.
But the economists studying women's pay emphasize that the significance of the gains of recent years should not be lost. An understanding of how things have changed in the past decade could improve women's confidence in what lies ahead. And ignoring these facts could discourage younger women from achieving all they can. "If you continue to see yourself as a society that's not doing well by women," said Karlyn Keene, a public opinion expert at the American Enterprise Institute, "the implication is that it could become a self-fulfilling prophecy."
In contrast to the temporary increase in women's pay during World War II that ended abruptly when the boys came home and the women were laid off, today's gains in women's pay reflect solid, enduring trends.
For one thing, women now expect not only to work most of their lives but alo to reap greater rewards. Millions therefore have chosen to stay in school longer, train for higher-paying occupations, have fewer children and just plain work longer and harder. Women are entering male-dominated professions from management and medicine to law enforcement and construction work. Sex segregation by occupation, which hadn't budged for a century, is beginning to break down.
Meanwhile, the explosive growth of services, which still employ the overwhelming majority of women, has sheltered clerks, nurses and salespeople, while the savage restructuring of Smokestack America has clobbered blue-collar men. For the first time since women joined the paid labor force in large numbers, their unemployment rate is consistently lower than men's.
"What made the 1980's distinctive is that everything started to come together for women," said Francine Blau, an economist at the University of Illinois.
That's not how many people see it.
Some feminists stress the politically hostile climate. "All we got was a few little crumbs," said Pat Reuss, a lobbyist at the National Organization for Women's legal defense fund. Conservative Republicans fret that working mothers helped fray the family. And liberal Democrats tend to lump women with men as victims of Reaganomics.
Even President Bush, the free-market president, isn't bragging about this apparent triumph of free-market economics and fairness. To explain why the President isn't trying to win votes from working women by talking up the shrinking pay gap, Labor Secretary Lynn Martin said, "It's difficult to argue that women have come a long way when everybody -- women and men -- is worried about losing jobs."
But the real reason that women's relative success doesn't fit neatly into anyone's political script may be that change happened not so much through powerful institutions in Washington as on a grass-roots level, in the hearts and minds of women.
 
The Researchers
 The new analysis of American women's gains in the workplace emerges from recently published books, including "Understanding the Gender Gap: An Economic History of American Women," by Claudia Goldin, a Harvard economist, and "The Economics of Women, Men and Work," by Ms. Blau with Marianne Ferber of the University of Illinois. The findings also come from studies of women's wages by June O'Neill, an economist at Baruch College in New York City. The economists tapped data -- in censuses, health records and labor reports -- spanning two centuries.
In three periods in the past 200 years, women have made giant strides toward pay equality. One was during the Industrial Revolution, in the mid-19th century, when farm girls streamed into factories. The second was during the rise of the corporation and the white-collar work force in the first few decades of this century, when young, unmarried, middle-class women headed for offices. The third is happening now.
True, women's pay did slip a bit last year, to 70 cents for each dollar earned by men. But the dip was probably due to the recession. Unemployment jumped a lot more for men than women, and because proportionately more low-paid men lost their jobs, the average of men's pay looks a little higher.
As the economy recovers, women are expected to close the pay gap, many economists say. "If women get 1980's-type growth, they'll do better than men," Ms. Hartmann said, noting that women's skills and experience are growing faster than men's.
While figures on annual pay showed a widening pay gap last year, data on weekly pay -- a more inclusive measure than the one that counts those who worked all year -- shows female pay still rising as a percentage of male pay, to 75 cents per dollar.
What made the pay gap shrink and why do economists think it will keep narrowing?
Young women's expectations about work underwent a sea change between the late 1960's and the early 1970's. The first wave of baby boomers, who were high school and college students in the late 1960's, did not expect to spend much of their adult lives on the job. Those women invested less in schooling and career training than they might have had they seen the future.
But by the early 1970's, many more young women were forecasting their futures accurately. Among the reasons for the big shift: the burgeoning women's movement, inspired in large part by Betty Friedan's 1963 book "The Feminine Mystique," and, probably, dissatisfaction with their mothers' experience in returning to work in middle age with little job experience or up-to-date skills.
Landmark civil rights legislation -- including the equal pay act of 1963 and Title 7 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 -- and some well-known court cases against large companies over discrimination in hiring and promotions probably acted as a catalyst by lifting women's aspirations.
By all accounts, women now set their sights even higher. Younger women "have expectations we never had," said Darlene Meskell, 43, a managing associate at Coopers & Lybrand. "If we had these expectations, they were more bravado than realism."
Another indication of women's new determination is that they now join the work force with more impressive credentials. Since the mid-1980's, women have been earning more bachelor of arts degrees than men. They see college as preparation for a lifelong career. A business major is now their first choice. Thirty years ago it was teaching. Today women earn more than a third of all professional degrees, up from 6 percent in 1971.
New educational choices are leading women into careers with greater lifetime earnings potential. The super-segregated pattern of female and male occupations barely changed between 1900 and 1970, Ms. Goldin said. In 1960, some 80 percent of women with college degrees were in teaching, nursing, social services and civil service, the same as in decades past. In the 1980's the figure fell below 30 percent.
Now 30 percent of working women are professionals or managers, the same proportion as men, though just 3 percent of top executives in large corporations are women. The percentage of women in clerical and service jobs is falling. Half of accountants and one sixth of doctors are women.
 
Experience Counts
 Another major reason that women's pay closed in on men's is growing job experience. More women work full time, fewer drop out of the labor force and most are taking off less time to raise children than in earlier generations. Seven percent of working women drop out of the work force in any given year, down from 12 percent in the mid-1970's.
Contrary to a flurry of news reports that women are leaving the work force to raise children, "We're not seeing any dropping out on account of kids," said Howard Hayghe, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
For women in all kinds of work, staying on the job rather than dropping out has been a powerful pay booster. The accumulation of more experience on the job accounts for as much as a quarter of the narrowing of the gender gap in pay.
The gains of the 1980's are even more remarkable than the raw numbers suggest, the economists say. For one thing, as the law of supply and demand has shown, a group that's growing rapidly in the work force -- say, immigrants at the turn of the century -- generally suffers a decline in wages relative to the rest of the working population. Yet wages climbed, absolutely and relatively, even as the pool of working women swelled.
The narrowing of the pay gap under such circumstances "strongly confirms that when the demand for skilled labor increased and women acquired the skills, they were able to succeed in our flexible labor market," said Michael Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
Liberals have been quick to credit women's pay gains to the decline in men's wages. Some of the relative gains of women in the bottom half of the wage scale did indeed reflect the sharp drop in the wages of men with high school educations or less during the 1980's. But what these critics forget, Ms. O'Neill said, is that "at the upper end, where men did very well, women went through the roof." For example, college-educated men in the top 5 percent of wage earners saw their pay rise by 7 percent after inflation; but the pay for the corresponding group of women jumped 19 percent.
 
The Decade to Come
 The economists are optimistic that the gender gap in pay will keep shrinking. In addition to upbeat trends in education and skills, the pay history of women who embarked on their work lives at the start of the 1980's looks far more promising than that of a generation ago.
For example, the group of women who were 25 to 34 in 1955 earned 62 cents for every dollar earned by men in that age group, but just 55 cents per dollar by 1965. By contrast, those 25 to 34 years old in 1980 remained at 69 cents per dollar in 1990.
Nonetheless, all is not cheery for women, who now represent 40 percent of the work force and, if Bureau of Labor Statistics projections are right, will account for half of the work force by 2000. As with men, real wages have been growing far more slowly since 1973 than after World War II.
"Just because they escaped to an incredible degree in the 1980's," Ms. Blau said, "women can't escape the effects of lagging productivity growth forever."
 
 
 
THREE WHO DID THE RESEARCH
 In lots of ways, the three economists whose research has found big gains in the workplace for American women exemplify many of the trends about which they've been writing. They've broken into a formerly all-male profession, two of the three have juggled work and children, and all were inspired by the women's movement.
Claudia Goldin, 46 years old, is a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science who as a girl dreamed of saving the world by peering through a microscope. Her scholarship on slavery, the family and women has catapulted her to the top of the profession: "What better life could I have?" she asked. "I like a sweater with holes and a beat-up car." She lives with Lawrence Katz, also a Harvard labor economist.
Francine Blau, also 46 and also a New Yorker, teaches at the University of Illinois. She's just been elected vice president of the American Economics Association. Her husband, Lawrence Kahn, also a labor economist at Illinois, is a close collaborator, helping with splashy articles. "Having a colleague that you have great rapport with is always wonderful," Ms. Blau said. The couple has two children in junior high school.
June O'Neill, 58, teaches at Baruch College in New York City and is also married to a labor economist, Dave O'Neill. She remembers Richard Nixon as an Equal Rights Amendment proponent who sparked her interest in the gender gap. The President, it seems, was asked by the Ladies Home Journal to write an article on women and the economy. Ms. O'Neill, a young working mother, was the ghost writer.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
At Long Last, Are Consumers Ready to Buy?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The American economy may be on the verge of finally showing some decent growth. Consumers were not quite as hostile to buying this summer as it first appeared, and it looks as if low interest rates have made it possible for them to do so.
One little-noticed effect of the long decline in interest rates of the past couple of years has been the bailing out of consumers, not to mention corporations, that were in trouble with high rates but have now managed to refinance a lot of their debt. 
 The great debt orgy of the 1980's meant that by early 1990 consumers had to devote a record 17.5 percent of their income to making payments on debts, whether the mortgage or the car loan or all the credit cards. And then the recession hit.
That debt burden had barely changed by early 1991, when euphoria arrived following the victory over Iraq in the Persian Gulf War. Then, it will be recalled, the conventional wisdom was that the recession was ending, that recovery would be rapid and that the Democrats had no chance to win the Presidency in 1992.
One reason that wisdom proved so wrong is that consumers decided that no matter how good they felt, they simply couldn't afford to spend.
Now, the facts seem to indicate, they can afford to buy. Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, estimates that by the end of this year the consumer debt burden will be down to 14.75 percent or so, in large part because of all the mortgage refinancings. Traditionally, that number bottoms a little after the economy ignites, and while there is nothing to stop it from continuing to fall -- in early 1983, it dropped almost to 14 percent -- the current level probably allows for higher borrowing and spending.
In other words, Americans are able to buy. But with unemployment so high, and consumer confidence so low, are they willing? Mr. Barbera voices hope that if Bill Clinton wins, that fact itself could help to improve spirits. After all, new Presidents are almost always popular until they do something.
The evidence that consumers are already starting to buy is limited, but it is there. In saying that retail sales rose 0.3 percent in September, the Commerce Department also revised upward its estimates of sales in July and August. Moreover, the strength seems to be in durable goods, which is where one wants it to be. Auto sales are not setting the world on fire, but there are indications that consumer demand is rising, with the weakness in reported sales a reflection of the decision by auto makers to slash the discounts offered to car-rental companies.
To be sure, there have been optimistic indications before, and they have faded time and again. Bad trade figures, and the indication that European economies are slipping, should probably restrain optimism this time as well. But at least it now appears that a consumer-led recovery is possible, something that was not the case even a few months ago.

HEADLINE: Forum;
There's Still a Way for Bush to Win

BYLINE: Robert L. Dilenschneider, author of "A Briefing for Leaders," is head of the Dilenschneider Group, a public relations firm.
By ROBERT L. DILENSCHNEIDER

 BODY:
WHEN it was a two-man race, voters judged the differences between President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton principally by ideology. They wanted to understand the approach each candidate would take to solve the nation's problems. But with Ross Perot's re-emergence -- one-liners and all -- the focus of the race has shifted. Voters now are far more likely to judge each candidate on the issue of leadership. And if leadership is the issue, Mr. Bush can still win.
To understand which candidate is the better leader, the public will be paying special attention to the way each candidate advances his agenda. But agendas -- like elections -- do not take place in a vacuum; each candidate must also define the context for his agenda. 
 Mr. Bush's mistake has been to advance his agenda defensively. That sends the wrong message. Instead, he must reassert the positive approach he took when he first energized the country by talking about the thousand points of light.
Mr. Bush should should use the turbulence in the world to set the context in which he will lead. He must make the electorate understand that against the backdrop of civil war in the former Yugoslavia, chaos in the former Soviet Union, the civil war in Somalia and the struggle for peace in the Middle East, the United States looks strong, healthy and stable. He must also get the message out that compared with those of our trading partners, the American economy -- with all its problems -- still looks good.
In his ads and in tomorrow's debate, Mr. Bush should demonstrate that the countries his opponents have cited as models for the United States have deep-seated problems of their own. Japan, which has been lauded for its economic growth, is mired in a deep recession, coupled with a real estate and stock market collapse. And America's productivity is higher than Japan's. Mr. Bush's opponents point to Germany, where government and business work hand in glove. The President should point out that Germany is also in the midst of a recession with sky-high interest rates and creeping inflation -- problems already encountered here and solved.
Mr. Bush should tell voters that Europe, the continent his opponents warn may surpass the United States in wealth and influence, has seen its currency system unwind, its unification plans put on hold and its economies slow down. For emphasis, he could point to Sweden, with its liberal social-welfare state, and tell Americans that last month, Sweden's short-term interest rates hit 500 percent.
In the final days of the campaign, Mr. Bush must carefully draw a distinction between a strong America with real but solvable problems -- his context -- and an America in chaos, his opponents' vision.
There are four additional tactics President Bush must embrace to present himself as a leader:
* Credentials. Mr. Bush must make the voters feel that neither Mr. Clinton nor Mr. Perot has the credentials to be President. To do that, Mr. Bush must reintroduce himself as the candidate with world-class leadership experience.
* Taxes. This is the breadbasket issue that will persuade most Americans. Rather than making pledges about not raising taxes, Mr. Bush must focus on the cost of Mr. Clinton's plans. He must also convey to the voters the terrible cost of Mr. Perot's deficit-reduction reforms. Unless Mr. Bush takes the offensive on taxes, many of those who voted Republican in 1988 will stray from the fold next month.
* The cold war. Mr. Bush must warn the voters that the cold war is not over. He must tell them that unless there is a new Marshall Plan, the old Communist Party and military establishment could regain power in the former Soviet republics and other Eastern European countries. Rather than taking credit for having won the cold war, Mr. Bush should talk about how to prevent Eastern Europe from returning to totalitarianism.
* Endorsements. Mr. Bush should turn his attention away from photo opportunities showing him eating tacos or kielbasa in favor of addressing at least one public policy group a week between now and the election.
No Doubt, Mr. Clinton will continue to project a vision emphasizing the generational differences between himself and Mr. Bush, invoking the Democrat's Roosevelt-Kennedy legacy and emphasizing his plans to improve competitiveness. But it will be a formidable challenge for him to raise his stature beyond the domestic context.
Tomorrow's debate has set the stage for Mr. Bush's breakthrough. It is now a long shot, but if Mr. Bush succeeds in developing a little fire tomorrow, he could well achieve the biggest comeback since Truman whipped Dewey.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Mapping Offshore Migration of Jobs

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
When he set out to document the emigration of employment from the heartland and shores of the United States, it never occurred to Charles Kernaghan, executive director of a union-sponsored research group, that there wasn't someone out there collecting the information he needed. Surely, he figured, there were professors or think-tank wonks who decorated their offices with push-pin maps of plant closings and tables of jobs lost.
The data weren't available, Mr. Kernaghan says, at least not centrally and systematically. And what was there could not answer the fundamental question: Why do American companies go offshore? So, after spending several months doing more traditional forms of research in archives and libraries, Mr. Kernaghan and his colleagues, Barbara Briggs and Jack McKay, formed a bogus company. Posing as officers of an environmentally correct manufacturing company, they explored the shadowy networks of doing business as a foreigner in Central America and the Caribbean and made the improbable discovery that, advertently or inadvertently, Government programs run through the United States Agency for International Development may be encouraging American companies to go offshore. They estimate the cost to taxpayers at more than $800 million. 
 The project is in the shadows no longer. Earlier this year it piqued the interest of news show producers, and three Sundays ago, the CBS program "60 Minutes" broadcast a report of its own investigation.
A few days later, ABC's "Nightline" ran its version of the story over two nights. Even the unflappable Ted Koppel was unable to modulate exchanges between Senator Al Gore and Labor Secretary Lynn Martin that made the Vice Presidential debate a week later look like a Quaker meeting.
The Bush Administration vehemently denies its policies encourage companies to move south, arguing that programs stimulate development and increase imports from the United States.
The project began in Mr. Kernaghan's office at the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, one of the 21 unions that supports his work, in New York. For nearly a decade, Mr. Kernaghan's organization, the National Labor Committee in Support of Worker and Human Rights in Central America, had monitored political violence. As a delicate peace set in, he turned his attention to the problems of low-paid workers in the region's maquiladoras -- foreign-owned assembly plants.
The researchers, none of whom have business experience, decided their "company," New Age Textiles, would make re-usable canvas bags that could replace the plastic and paper bags supermarkets use. They made up samples, confabulated a company history, established a mailing address and fax and phone lines and had business cards and stationery printed up.
In December, they headed for a high-level trade conference in Miami to see if the idea would take flight. "We were nervous, to put it mildly," Mr. Kernaghan said. "Any questions could have blown us out of the water."
Like many people who have a long-distance relationship with business, Mr. Kernaghan and his colleagues assumed that having no experience, no business plan and no information about markets, distribution or other esoterica might create a problem.
Wrong. New Age Textile's eco-shopping bag was the hit of the conference. "It captivated them," Mr. Kernaghan said.
The conference mutated quickly from a test of verity into a whirlwind of opportunities, as members of the group carommed from meeting to warehouse tour to live radio call-in show. One night they dined with the Mayor of Rotterdam, who wanted them to ship the bags to Europe through his port.
The group spent much of its time visiting booths, pitching its bags to trade organizations from Jamaica, Honduras and El Salvador. At each booth, a representative touted his country's no-tax, low-wage, nonunionized environments and subsidies available for training workers and building factories.
With more confidence, Mr. Kernaghan took the New Age Textiles show to another conference in April -- this time with "60 Minutes" in tow. In July, again accompanied by "60 Minutes," he went to Central America and the Caribbean, where he found evidence of Government money being used on projects that could undermine onshore industries.
Mr. Kernaghan has been using A.I.D.'s own documents, piles and piles of them, to verify his figures. On "Nightline," Secretary Martin acknowledged that A.I.D. may need a review. But she argued that the agency's programs will lead to regional prosperity, which will benefit the United States.
Jack Sheinkman, A.C.T.W.U. president and one of Mr. Kernaghan's principal sponsors, recognizes that argument from debates on the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico. Since 1983, roughly when the A.I.D. programs began, he has watched the number of jobs in his industry drop 42 percent, to 1.02 million. At the same time, the wages of apparel workers in Central America has dropped to 30 cents an hour from 44 cents. The programs, he argues, are not helping anyone's standard of living and they appear to be impairing the ability of workers to organize.
Mr. Kernaghan now has the beginnings of the job-loss/plant-closing data base he assumed would be easy to find. He and his colleagues have already inspired Congress to restrict A.I.D.'s activities. And, as he told an A.I.D. official who came to call last week, he has any number of ideas for new research -- research that will almost certainly make somebody at A.I.D. uncomfortable again.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Muted Optimism for a Battered Japan

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
ANDREW BALLINGAL has some wonderful news. Over the next two years, predicts Mr. Ballingal, the strategist here for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities, the Japanese stock market's Nikkei index will rise at least 50 percent from its recent low. After that fantastic rally, the index would stand at more than 21,000 -- still down 12 percent or so from the beginning of this emphatically miserable year.
Much of the turmoil that hit currency and financial markets last month missed Japan, to the relief of most Japanese. But avoiding that mayhem has done nothing to heal this market's deep, long-term ills. 
 The economy is floundering, banks are swimming in a sea of bad loans, corporate profits are sliding and politics has been thrown into chaos by the resignation last week of Shin Kanemaru, the governing party's kingmaker, because of a money scandal. With its close Friday at 17,369.81, the Nikkei index is still down more than 50 percent from its peak three years ago.
It is a mark of the melancholy mood in Kabutocho, Tokyo's Wall Street, that an analyst who expects that it will take more than two years for the market to regain its level of nine months ago is counted an optimist.
"We are in a new bull market in Japan," said Mr. Ballingal, who bases his forecast on a view that things will get no worse. "There's a floor under this market now. We'll get a normal cycle from here."
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, made some surprisingly somber comments in Tokyo on Wednesday in which he could have been speaking for Japan as well as the United States.
Mr. Greenspan lamented that the problem is not that the American economy is declining, but that it is not really improving. Despite big reductions in official interest rates, the economy was not responding as it would be expected to. That prompted him to conclude that the United States was in a stubbornly sluggish phase in which many of the lessons learned over the past four decades simply do not apply.
The Japanese Government has slashed interest rates and announced a $90 billion public works program to pump cash into the system. It has also issued a steady stream of positive pronouncements.
"The Government says the economy is starting to rebound, but nobody believes it," said Yuichi Matsushita, a senior analyst at Nikko Securities. "At this point we're expecting a recovery in the second half of next year."
As for the stock market, Mr. Matsushita said recovery was still in the future, in part because investors are being caught by surprise at the signs of how badly the slowdown is affecting corporate Japan.
Nikko, in fact, has just made a sharp cut in its forecast for corporate profits in the current fiscal year, which ends March 30. It had been forecasting a 9.9 percent decline from the previous year, Mr. Matsushita said, but now expects a 19.7 percent drop. That means that, on aggregate, the profits of corporate Japan will have plummeted 35 percent over three years.
Some, however, say that even that figure for the year is too optimistic. "That's a joke," said Alan Bell, deputy head of research at Baring Securities here. "They'll be down at least 25 percent."
Mr. Bell's remarks underscored one of the underlying problems with the stock market -- expectations have still not fully adjusted to the depth of the economic malaise in Japan. As a result, when there are surprises, as there have been in the projections of corporate profits, they have always been negative surprises that knocked the market lower.
Most companies have been slow to recognize in their official forecasts how deeply the economic slowdown is cutting into profits, but some analysts have been more hard-nosed.
"The problem is that analysts' forecasts are really not afforded any credibility here," Mr. Bell said. "We can jump up and down and scream and make as much noise as we like, but the market doesn't take any notice. This is still an incredibly inefficient market."
In the long run, few doubt that the Japanese economy will prove itself fit, particularly its manufacturing sector. That is one big difference between Japan and the United States. Japanese industries have not lost their competitiveness, just their profitability, and few doubt that that adjustment is taking place.
"I'm not utterly despondent," said Mr. Bell. "The problems are just going to take a little time to work out."
Mr. Ballingal of Barclays said he based his modestly positive outlook on the assumption that the economy had bottomed, even if it had not yet begun to advance strongly. The deep problems with bad loans in the banking industry are severe, he said, but manageable. In addition, new issues of shares here have all but stopped, which means investors have not had to contend with additional supply, another positive factor.
"The point is that it's going to get better from here, but in a normal way," he commented. "It's not bad that we tread water for a while."
Mr. Matsushita said he, too, had seen some mildly better signs in the form of more optimism among institutional investors.
"The trust banks are a little more positive," he said. "They don't expect the market to collapse and so they're doing some buying. It's not an exceptional or tremendous amount of buying, but it adds some stability to the market."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1683 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 11-16

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Voters Make Their Interest Clear to the Candidates 

When the major Presidential candidates met last Thursday to debate the issues and answer questions from a studio audience, it was clear what was on the country's mind. For the first 65 minutes of the debate, the questions from a group of undecided voters were on the economy or other domestic issues. And though not much new ground was broken, the nation was tuned in, big time. According to the A. C. Nielsen Company, 18 million households were watching. President Bush said he would not raise taxes and would create inner-city enterprise zones to get the economy going again. Gov. Bill Clinton said the deficit should be reduced slowly -- 50 percent in the next four years. To cut it any faster, as Ross Perot advocates, "you'd have to raise taxes too much and cut benefits too much to people who need them," Mr. Clinton said. That did not sway Mr. Perot. "I suggest now that our No. 1 preoccupation is red ink," he said.

The Scoop on Executive Pay
 
When the chief executives of some of America's largest companies joined President Bush on his visit to Japan earlier this year, they got more than they bargained for. While the Americans talked trade, the Japanese talked salaries and pointed out that while the top executives at America's 30 largest companies earn an average of $3.2 million a year, their Japanese counterparts earn only $525,000. That raised a ruckus among militant shareholders who have complained for years about how much top executives earn, and how difficult it is to find out the exact amount of their compensation. No more. Last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved new rules to require publicly traded companies to disclose in full, using simple language and charts, what their top executives earn. "These proposals make sure the information is out in the open and remove the restraints so shareholders can do something," said Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the commission.

Greenspan Is at a Loss
 
Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's descriptions of the economy often resemble smoke rings. The ideas are well shaped, they float out effortlessly, but the substance is often impossible to grasp. He speaks that way so he won't disrupt the markets, it is said. But last week, while in Japan, Mr. Greenspan became a little less vague. The nation's sick economy was not responding to the Fed's low-interest-rate medicine, he said. Not only that, but Mr. Greenspan said he did not know why the old medicine had lost its punch. The methods the Fed had used to steer the economy since World War II were failing to guide it now. "No models can explain the types of patterns we're having," Mr. Greenspan said.

At Least Inflation Isn't . . .
 
Sales may be sluggish, but at least prices are holding firm. Prices at the producer level rose last month by 0.3 percent, the Labor Department said, slightly above the 0.1 percent increase for August. And consumers are getting an even better break. The Labor Department's Index of Consumer Prices rose by just 0.2 percent in September, less than August's 0.3 percent rise. Those numbers translate into an annual inflation rate of about 3 percent -- slightly less than in Germany and Japan. Still, inflation has taken its toll. A basket of consumer goods that sold for $100 in 1982 would cost $141.30 today.

For the nation's pensioners, the slowdown in inflation means the smallest increase -- just 3 percent -- in Social Security benefits in six years. The average monthly Social Security check will increase to $1,128 from $1,088.

The Politics of Arms Sales
 
Selling arms abroad is usually left to the generals and bureaucrats. But this is an election year and arms sales mean jobs -- and jobs mean votes, especially in the big industrial states. First, President Bush authorized the sale of F-15's to Saudi Arabia and F-16's and helicopters to Taiwan -- China's longtime rival. Last week, the White House went further. Mr. Bush personally intervened to get Kuwait to buy 236 advanced M1-A2 tanks and spare parts in a deal worth about $4 billion. The tanks are made by the General Dynamics Corporation in Michigan and Ohio.

Whither the Export Boom?

The "export boom," as economists called it, was responsible for 70 percent of the economy's growth -- such as it was -- over the last three years. The future of that boom is now in doubt. The Commerce Department said last week that exports fell 6 percent in August while imports surged, pushing the trade deficit to a five-year high of $9 billion for the month, a 24 percent increase over July.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Trade Surplus That Won't Die

Economists say each country has comparative advantages: one makes walkmen; the other grows wheat. That's why nations trade. But if that's true, why does Japan's trade surplus only grow? Last month it rose 25 percent to a record $12.1 billion, its Finance Ministry said. Japan's trade surplus is expected to hit $120 billion this year. Its surplus with the United States reached $4.84 billion last month, half of America's world trade deficit.

Lucas's Dark Days
 
Back when sports cars had side curtains and were mostly British, their notoriously unreliable electrical systems were made by Lucas Industries. Car enthusiasts called the company the Inventors of Darkness. But Lucas went on to other things -- like the electronics in the supersonic Concorde. Even so, the company has been taking its hits. Last week it announced it would lay off 4,000 workers and take a charge of $149.5 million. Lucas will also restructure itself by selling off businesses worth $170 million.

The Russian Riviera
 
Moscow isn't exactly the Mediterranean. Still, it has its attractions -- at least that's what the bureaucrats in the Kremlin hope. To lure tourists into the cold, the Russian Government made a deal with the Carlson Companies of Minneapolis to renovate and manage 13 hotels and develop retail travel agencies, car rental agencies and tour operations. The deal is worth about $1 billion, for Carlson.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
G.M.'s Sinking Fortunes
 
The General Motors Corporation has 15 new models out this year, but continues to lose market share in the United States. It now has 34.7 percent of the market, down from 35.3 percent last year and more than 50 percent a decade ago. Analysts expect G.M. to lose $4 billion to $5 billion this year on its North American operations. Among the analysts, there is even talk that those losses could force the nation's No. 1 auto maker into Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law. G.M.'s woes have put enormous pressure on the company's top management and touched off speculation that G.M.'s outside directors and management are feuding over what to do. To quell the speculation -- and rumors of another management shake-up -- Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, issued a statement saying "there is no disagreement between management and outside G.M. directors."

Adding Insult to Injury at I.B.M.
 
It hasn't been the best of years for the International Business Machines Corporation. Not only was it forced to thin its ranks to become more competitive -- Big Blue will eliminate 40,000 jobs this year -- but it also had a $2.78 billion loss in the third quarter. In September in Europe, "People just stopped buying things," said Frank Metz, I.B.M.'s chief financial officer. The losses also resulted from early retirement programs for 20,000 workers. Big Blue's showing stunned Wall Street. Its stock price fell $5.125 on the news to $72.875, its lowest level in a decade. As recently as July, shares in the world's No. 1 computer maker traded at $100 or more. Big Blue closed the week at $70.625.
 
I.B.M. may be down on its luck, but Apple Computer Inc. is flying. It had earnings of $97.6 million in the fourth quarter on revenues of $1.77 billion. And Apple's Powerbook notebook computer is a smashing success. More than $1 billion worth were sold this year, making Powerbook the most successful new computer product since the PC.
 
Time Wants No Part of It
 
First it was the candidates complaining about the media. Now it's the media complaining about the candidates. Last week Time Inc. filed a suit in a Federal District Court against the Bush-Quayle campaign for infringing on its Time magazine copyright and trademark. TV ads for the Bush-Quayle ticket have been showing a Time magazine cover titled "Why Voters Don't Trust Clinton." Time argues that it has done critical articles on all three candidates "and we object to the implication that we are taking sides," said Henry Muller, the managing editor. In a letter to the campaign, Time said the use of the cover was "extremely damaging" to the magazine's reputation. The suit won't deter the Bush-Quayle campaign. "We are not going to pull the ad based on the Time magazine complaint," said Tony Mitchell, the campaign's deputy press secretary. Mr. Mitchell said use of the ad was "standard fare" in political campaigns.

P.& G.'s No-Coupon Policy
 
Last year, when the Procter & Gamble Company introduced its new pricing strategy of eliminating discounts on its consumer products in favor of consistently lower prices, analysts were dubious. After all, coupons do sell soap. But last week, at its shareholders meeting, Edwin L. Artzt, the company's chairman, told shareholders the strategy was paying off in sharply reduced costs. Procter & Gamble expects savings this year of $175 million from eliminating incentives. Without discounts, demand for products is more constant so the company's factories can operate more efficiently, Mr. Artzt said. In the 1990's, he told shareholders, "customers won't pay for a company's inefficiency." The company's stock gained 87.5 cents to $50.50 on the announcement and closed the week at $51.

Hertz's Price Break
 
The Hertz Corporation said last week it would stop charging a fee when cars are rented in one location and returned at another.

HEADLINE: When Mastery of U.S. Media Does Not Come Trippingly

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Maybe it's something in the air, but American media companies have proved especially irksome to foreign buyers. Some newcomers, like Sony, Matsushita and Hachette, snapped up sizable media properties here in the late 1980's and ran into unforeseen snags.
Bertelsmann seemed like a surer bet. The $9 billion German media combine, No. 2 in the world after Time Warner, had all the appropriate stuff when it got into American media in a big way in the 1980's. 
 A stable and conservative outfit, its top managers back home seem firmly in place and its profits worldwide are solid. By contrast, Sony bought Columbia Pictures and Matsushita bought MCA, both at heavy premiums, just as the parent companies were hit by recession.
Bertelsmann A.G.'s American landing, though, has not been smooth. The executive turnover at its outposts here -- RCA Records, the Literary Guild and the book publishers Bantam, Doubleday and Dell -- has been striking compared with the stability in Germany. And though the company cites some bright spots, the money is not rolling in as it had hoped.
There's the economy, of course; nobody is doing too well these recessionary days. But perhaps media companies pose a special challenge to the outsider. Books and records, and those who create them, traffic in a distinct local idiom, presenting added problems for management when cultural barriers loom.
This is true even for a company like Bertelsmann, whose experience elsewhere would have seemed reasonable protection against making bad leadership and strategic decisions in this country. It now insists that it has learned the language and that smoother days lie ahead, but it still faces daunting challenges.
Just watch how the revolving door has turned for Bertelsmann, which entered the United States in 1977, buying 51 percent of Bantam, but greatly expanded its presence in 1986 when it bought Doubleday, Dell, RCA and other properties. RCA, the linchpin of its record group, has had three presidents since 1986, the Literary Guild two. Bertelsmann has replaced the head of its book companies as well as top executives at Bantam and Doubleday in the last four years.
RCA is reportedly just breaking even. And book profits are down slightly because of past problems at Bantam and Dell. The bright spot is the Literary Guild, which after trouble in the late 1980's is now profitable.
At that book club, Bertelsmann's first president tried to use selling tools that work in Germany before a new management team realized Americans have different buying habits. For example, the company printed large, costly catalogues to which Americans did not respond.
At the book companies, it's hard to tell what was more to blame, the strategy or the actors. Executives expanded just as recession hit. "The American market is really tough," conceded Bernhard von Minckwitz, president of Bertelsmann's international publishing division.
To be sure, some media executives say Bertelsmann has fixed many problems. New management has put the Literary Guild on the right track, and recent changes at the book division have been well received.
BUT for Bertelsmann, whose 1992 global profits were up 5.6 percent, to $407 million, the American results must remain disappointing. This is particularly so at RCA Records, since sales of English-language artists represent 60 percent of sales outside Germany.
The book companies have also been roiled by problems. In the latest fiscal year, sales were reportedly flat at about $600 million and profits fell slightly from $35 million, where they had been since 1988.
Bertelsmann's 6.1 percent profit margins on books in the United States are not bad these days, one book executive said. But they fall far short of the 13 percent margins at Putnam Berkeley, Matsushita's book unit.
Bantam, which last year accounted for roughly half the division's sales, is by far the largest. Doubleday and Dell account for the rest.
In the early 1980's, Bantam got off to a roaring start in hardcovers with hits like Lee Iacocca's autobiography. After the acquisition of Doubleday and Dell, Alberto Vitale, then a top Bantam executive, was made president of the Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group Inc. With Linda Grey as publisher, Bantam moved into trade publishing as well.
Meanwhile, at Doubleday, its new president, Nancy Evans, began an expansion program of her own, a strategy that led to losses in the late 1980's. "There were too many books published, " said Stephen Rubin, who took over Doubleday in 1990. "It is impossible to publish that many books well."
By 1989, Mr. Vitale had left to become head of Random House. There is still speculation that Bertelsmann's management had become concerned about Mr. Vitale's leadership, but Mr. von Minckwitz denies it.
Whether or not Bertelsmann was aware that expansion was ill-timed, no Bertelsmann executives -- here or in Germany -- showed any particular foresight about the direction the American market would take.
Mr. von Minckwitz did replace Nancy Evans with Stephen Rubin at Doubleday, which by the late 1980's was losing money. Mr. Rubin is said to be doing an excellent job, having slashed the list of releases and promoted certain writers.
But once Mr. Vitale left, Bertelsmann was neither quick nor savvy in replacing him. The book division floundered for a year until Mr. von Minckwitz hired Paul Neuthaler as president. A personal friend of Mr. von Minckwitz, Mr. Neuthaler is an American who had had no experience in trade book publishing and was shortly removed as president.
The newest president, Jack Hoeft, appointed in 1991, had been second to Mr. Vitale and is considered a good choice because of his experience.
Last summer Mr. Hoeft shifted management at Bantam, giving Ms. Grey her own imprint and replacing her with Irwyn Applebaum.
At Bantam, too, cuts are under way, pushing the company to focus on its core mass-market business.
PHYLLIS GRANN, Putnam Berkeley's chairman, is optimistic about the new direction at Bertelsmann, whose non-United States holdings include book clubs and magazines in Europe and record companies worldwide. "It is not essential that you get it right at the first go-round," she said, "but that you get it right fairly quickly. Bertelsmann seems to have done that."
For all the talk about global synergies, the barriers to building international companies are often mundane, starting with language.
Compared with other foreign owners of media companies, Bertelsmann gets relatively good marks. Both current and former Bertelsmann book executives say the German managers have made efforts to relate to the American executives. Mr. Rubin recalls a 1989 meeting with Mr. von Minckwitz, who is based in Munich but spends about a month each year in the United States, in which language differences led to confusion. "I told him that my hands were really tied," Mr. Rubin recalled. "And he looked down at my hands."
Since then, Mr. von Minckwitz has perfected his English. And though Bertelsmann's president, Mark Wossner, inevitably apologizes for his English, the Bertelsmann team has mastered the language far better than the management of some other foreign companies.
As to work styles, they are a factor cited by both German and American executives. Mr. Wossner recalled, for example, that at the company's home base of Guetersloh, executives tended to work until after 8 P.M. He did not understand why Americans left at 6 P.M. until it was explained that they often have an hour's commute.
Though such cultural differences initially presented problems at the book club, Bertelsmann soon brought in Gerhard Greiner as president and Markus Wilhelm as senior vice president.
Mr. Greiner had turned around various Bertelsmann book clubs in Europe, while Mr. Wilhelm had restructured the Canadian club. The pair succeeded in focusing the clubs on the profitable women's market and introducing special-interest clubs, from children's clubs to an incipient religious book club. One industry expert says the book clubs earned about $25 million last year on sales of about $200 million. "We had to learn," Mr. Wilhelm said. "We were book-club experts in South America and elsewhere, but we had to learn the U.S. market."
Bertelsmann also seems to understand America's "star" system. Clive Davis, president of Arista Records, owned by Bertelsmann, reportedly negotiated a new five-year contract valued at $25 million, a huge amount by American standards, but even larger by German standards.
Still, because the United States is such a crucial part of the world music and publishing market, a number of media executives say Bertelsmann was wise to invest here.
There is more of a debate in books, not only because profits are under pressure, but because the synergies are not as apparent.
Morton Janklow, a literary agent who represents Danielle Steele, a Dell author, among others, says Bertelsmann's worldwide clout is a benefit, allowing it to coordinate release dates and other issues. But Ed Victor, another top agent, sees no particular benefits in size. "Synergy happens when synergy happens," he said.
But the challenge remains of making Bertelsmann's United States operations a successful part of its worldwide business. And, in a recessionary economy, where there is little chance that the economics of media businesses will improve, the challenge is even greater.
 
 
 
DISAPPOINTMENTS AT RCA
 For Bertelsmann, the performance of RCA Records must be especially disappointing. Since the German company bought it in 1986, RCA has not gotten more than a small share of the American market and is now just breaking even. And during that time turnover at the top has been high.
RCA had some success in the year ending in June 1989, when the "Dirty Dancing" album and its sequel reportedly pushed it to about $225 million in sales. (Bertelsmann does not break out results by division.) In fiscal 1992, sales were said to be about $160 million. And Rudi Gassner, president of Bertelsmann International, conceded: "RCA has had a hard time. Our market share in the U.S. is terrible. We were slow starters when we took over. That's why we are behind in our timing."
RCA Records has had a series of presidents. But Bertelsmann has watched its share of the American market hover around 10 percent, though it inched up to 11 when "Dirty Dancing" was hot. Michael Dornemann, chairman of Bertelsmann's Worldwide Music Group, has been in the United States for five years, and began his career at IBM Germany, but his current choice of Joe Galante as president was considered an odd one.
Mr. Galante ran the company's successful Nashville division for 12 years. But after moving to New York nearly two years ago, to head RCA, the question in the minds of several music industry executives remains whether Mr. Galante is handicapped by not having a carefully cultivated network of contacts in New York.
With its market share still weak, the company recently negotiated a $30 million deal with the group ZZ Top to help its sagging roster of artists. It was a deal that met with widespread skepticism because of the price. One industry executive said the deal was made to give it visibility and to attract other top groups.
"BMG is committed to the business, but there is probably nobody more impatient than I am," Mr. Galante said. Mr. Dornemann acknowledged that the company, which has had successes in country music, "has had no success in contemporary." It still has the smallest market share of the six top record companies. He maintains that he is optimistic.
Mr. Dornemann says that one problem smaller companies face is that they are competing against increasingly large rivals, like Polygram and Sony Music. Nevertheless, Bertelsmann's own Arista label, smaller than RCA and run by the veteran Clive Davis, has done well.

HEADLINE: Glamour Boy

BYLINE: By JOAN KRON

 BODY:
"MY God, what's happening to the world!"
Nolan Miller is quite serious.
"The magic!" he adds. "The glamour! The star quality! It doesn't exist anymore!" 
 Until glamour has its moment again, those who need a fix can head for the Museum of Television and Radio at 25 West 52d Street, where Nolan Miller style will be in reruns until the end of March. "Nolan Miller: Costume Designing for Television," which opened Thursday, is the museum's first exhibition dealing with design for television.
On display are 12 extroverted gowns worn on television by Mr. Miller's glamour galaxy -- Joan Collins, Linda Evans, Elizabeth Taylor, Diahann Carroll, Barbara Stanwyck and Ann-Margret -- and 75 costume sketches signed "Nolan Miller" but mostly done by Donna Peterson, his ghost illustrator. (Mr. Miller has his priorities. He believes it's more important to be present at every fitting than to do every sketch himself.)
With a museum show under his Hermes alligator belt, the 57-year-old designer, who lives in Beverly Hills, Calif., will perhaps now be less of a target for those fashion elitists in New York and Paris who love to belittle him.
"Nolan suffers in the same way television does," the museum's president, Dr. Robert M. Batscha, said. "It is still to be recognized how wonderfully significant his work has been. Nolan Miller brought a largeness of concept and the glamour we associate with film to television."
The show is organized in three sections: "The Early Years: 1959-1975" (including "The Addams Family," "Green Acres" and "Honey West"); "The Glamour Begins: 1976-79" (including "Charlie's Angels" and "The Love Boat") and " 'Dynasty' and Beyond: 1980 to the Present" (including "Dynasty," "Hotel," "The Colbys," "Poker Alice" and "Hollywood Wives").
Or in the spirit of Nolan Miller, one can think of the career of the 6-foot-5 designer, usually clad in Savile Row pin stripes, as a mini-series, with the plot turning on a chance meeting with the producer Aaron Spelling.
"Nolan and Aaron were made for each other," Dr. Batscha said. "Aaron gave Nolan the opportunity, and Nolan gave Aaron's shows ambiance."
Their relationship started in the mid-1950's. Hollywood was in the doldrums. Films were being made abroad. Studio wardrobe departments were shutting down. And only the most farsighted film types could see the potential of television.
Aaron Spelling was a writer from Texas who, to make ends meet, played drug addicts on "Dragnet." Nolan Miller, the grandson of a Comanche and the son of a Louisiana oil-field worker (who didn't appreciate his son's insistence on eating by candlelight), was fresh out of Chouinard Design School in Los Angeles. His portfolio of sketches was always under his arm. He wanted to be another Adrian, the designer who dressed Joan Crawford and Norma Shearer at M-G-M in the 1930's and 40's.
To support himself between occasional commissions for custom gowns, Mr. Miller worked in a flower shop where Miss Stanwyck shopped. He admits, with embarrassment, that she befriended him after he inundated her with gifts of gardenias, her favorite flower.
One day, Mr. Spelling came to the shop to buy flowers for a date. Miss Stanwyck was there. "I had just written a 'Zane Grey Theater' script for her first TV appearance," Mr. Spelling recalled. "She introduced me to Nolan. She said, 'He's a terrific designer. You've got to use him.' "
The two men became friends, and Mr. Spelling vowed that when he became a producer, he would hire Mr. Miller to design costumes. It was the beginning of a 33-year relationship that would include some of the most memorable television shows of their time, if not all Mr. Miller's favorites.
"They say the 60's are back," he said in an interview this month. "I hope not. I hated doing 'Mod Squad' and 'Starsky and Hutch.' Nobody got to dress up."
"Charlie's Angels," which ran from 1976 to 1981, was a little better. Mr. Miller dressed its three policewomen in a "very modern, professional-of-the-time look" that had a great deal of influence, said Dr. Batscha, perhaps becoming the first to suggest that Mr. Miller is a feminist.
The most radical thing Mr. Miller remembers about the show is: "We threw away their bras. It was the first show that allowed nipples to show through."
He nonetheless tried to put the Angels into evening gowns and furs at the slightest provocation.
"When Aaron called in 1980 to tell me about his proposed new show 'Dynasty,' " Mr. Miller recalled, "he said, 'At last I have a show that will make you happy.' 'Dynasty' was a designer's dream."
During the show's nine seasons (1981-89), Mr. Miller designed and custom-made, often in 48 hours, some 3,000 outfits that trod a fine line between parody and elegance. "Dynasty" became an adjective -- a synonym for shoulder pads, peplums, veils, gloves and over-the-top glamour -- as in "I want, or don't want, a Dynasty look."
Joan Collins, who played the ruthless Alexis Colby, could handle props better than anyone since Miss Crawford, Mr. Miller said. "She can take her gloves off, smoke her cigarette, bite an hors d'oeuvre, stir her martini and eat the olive all at the same time. I always put Joan in gloves on 'Dynasty.' "
Once he took his wife to Bergdorf's to buy her some gauntlet gloves. He said, "The saleswoman told me, 'These are Alexis gloves.' "
Mr. Miller's clothes enabled Mr. Spelling to lure more and more film stars into television. "We dangled Nolan," Mr. Spelling said. "Instead of offering more money, we said Nolan will do your clothes."
Many a career was rehabilitated in the process. "Hollywood is terrible as it relates to age," Dr. Batscha said, "but through Nolan's work on 'Love Boat' and 'Hotel,' " older stars got a break. "Aaron was exceptional in creating the budget for this."
In the 80's, when Mr. Miller was designing costumes for "Hotel," "The Love Boat," "The Colbys," "Dynasty," "Fantasy Island," "Hart to Hart," "Matt Houston" and several movies of the week all at once, he was spending nearly $2 million a year on costumes, Mr. Miller said. For Elizabeth Taylor's guest spot on "Hotel," the designer spent more than double his $15,000 budget for guest stars to dress her alone. The average costume budget for an episode of "Dynasty" was about $25,000, plus $100,000 at the beginning of each season for staples, including a dozen suits, 50 ties and 6 dozen shirts for John Forsythe, its male star. At the time, such budgets were unheard of.
But only the stars were given made-to-order clothes. Other actors on other shows might wear recycled garments from "Dynasty." A few years ago, Mr. Spelling's company decided there was gold in its costume warehouse and began renting the "Dynasty" clothes.
"My costumes are in residuals now," Mr. Miller said. "Aaron made $800,000 in rentals in the first year. At last he's recouping his expenses."
At the height of "Dynasty's" popularity, when 40 million to 60 million people were watching each episode, Nolan Miller was receiving almost as much mail as the stars -- up to 1,000 letters a week. By then, he was the highest paid costume designer in Hollywood, making, he said, in excess of $10,000 a week -- more than half a million dollars a year. For a bonus one year, Mr. and Mrs. Spelling surprised him with a 1965 Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud, the car of his dreams. The car is still purring along, unlike the television shows that paid for it.
For the first time in his career, Mr. Miller is not under contract to Mr. Spelling. The teen-ager shows that Mr. Spelling is producing -- "Beverly Hills 90210" and "Melrose Place" -- are not Mr. Miller's flute of Dom Perignon. "Have you seen the clothes?" he said with a groan. "It's not the kind of thing you need to design and make to order. Probably if I did '90210,' they'd all look like Sandra Dee."
TODAY, hardly anyone gets to dress up on television, except at Academy Awards ceremonies and on mini-series, which are what Mr. Miller now designs for. He also makes clothes to order for Miss Taylor, Sophia Loren and other stars, who pay $3,000 for a suit and $5,000 to $10,000 for an evening gown.
Mr. Miller has two ready-to-wear lines carrying his name, which have had their ups and downs. He recently tested a line of jewelry he designed with Mr. Spelling's wife, Candy. It is being sold on QVC, a television shopping channel; $350,000 worth was sold in 40 minutes on July 7.
Mr. Miller operates out of two adjacent one-story ateliers on Robertson Boulevard in Beverly Hills. In one building, he makes some of his ready-to-wear. In the main building, which is worthy of a scene in "Scruples," he runs his couture operation. Many of his 40 employees -- cutters, fitters, sewers, shoppers -- have been with him for 15 to 25 years.
Scattered around the bustling workroom are naked dressmaker dummies of his clients. Cotton batting pinned on in strategic places proclaims to one and all who has gained weight recently.
The heart of the couture operation is the spacious pink-silk-walled dressing room where private clients have their fittings among Louis-something settees. Anyone who is not sure she is in the right place can scan the tabletops, a sidewalk of stars, with silver-framed photos each endorsed adoringly to "Nolan dear" or "Nolan darling."
An autographed picture of Miss Taylor occupies a position of honor on Mr. Miller's desk, next to one of his wife, Sandra. Sandra Miller, who is 43, is the daughter one of her husband's earliest private clients, Matilda Stream, a New Orleans socialite. Mr. Miller did Sandra's sweet-16-party dress, her debutante gowns and her first wedding dress. "That marriage lasted 10 minutes," he said. "Ten years later, I married her. It sounds like a mini-series."
The couple live among fine French furniture in a Spanish-style house in Beverly Hills. Mrs. Miller is resigned to sharing her husband with the world's most glamorous women.
"They're all people I adore," she said, adding without specifics: "I've only been jealous twice in 15 years. When Nolan comes home from work and says he's been in every bedroom in town and he's exhausted, I find it hard to work up any sympathy."
Mr. Spelling said: "All the stars became his friend. Nolan is a great confidant for women. The stories he could tell -- but he would never do a kiss-and-tell book."
Mr. Miller said, "I was lucky to cut my teeth on glamorous women."
Bette Davis "knew exactly where her hem should be," he said. "Dietrich told me she would only wear taupe-colored shoes -- to match her hosiery and give the leg a long line.
"Stanwyck taught me to stop worrying about the shoes. 'If they're looking at the shoes,' she said, 'everything else is a mistake.' She thought the top of the dress was the most important, especially in TV where it's all close-ups. She called them 'tabletop dresses.' She wanted her gown simple: in a beautiful fabric with a four-inch hem." Forced to wear let-down hand-me-downs when she was young, "Stanwyck believed a tiny hem said 'poor,' " he explained.
Ginger Rogers, he said, "knows just how full her skirt should be for dancing." Jane Wyman, one of his most loyal clients, "refuses to wear anything in navy trimmed with white because that's what she wore when she was a chorus girl," he continued, adding, "Every night she had to wash and iron those organdy collars and cuffs."
Of Lana Turner, Mr. Miller said: "Lana can put you through your paces. She was raised at M-G-M. There was no such thing as reality there. It was all image. Lana could fit for three hours at a time, fine-tuning every detail, over and over.
"And I put up with it. My aim was to please. There's nothing worse than an actress unhappy in a dress. It destroys her confidence. I knew it was necessary to make them feel secure."
Joan Crawford, who, he said, would play with her jewels on her bed, had "horrible taste."
"She put plastic covers on furniture," he said, "but she knew all about lighting and photography. She taught me how to pack a dress after something I sent her arrived all crumpled up in the box." (She told him to stuff the dress with enough tissue to simulate a body.)
For every outfit in her closet, Miss Crawford had an index card with a photograph and swatches attached and a list of all the right accessories. "With Joan, everything had to match," he explained. "On the back of the card she'd write where she wore it and who was there. Before she went anywhere, she'd ask for the guest list so she could decide what to wear. When she'd get there, she'd say. 'Oh Mr. So-and-so. How nice to see you. I haven't seen you since that night in New York.'
"I can't imagine what she would have done if she'd had a computer."
Elizabeth Taylor was a big catch for Mr. Miller. "I used to have a joke at my workroom," he said. "When I went out to lunch, I'd say, 'If Elizabeth Taylor calls, tell her I'll be back in an hour.' Then one day she called."
That was in the mid-80's. Mr. Miller went on to design clothes for her Passion perfume tour and ads. Valentino, a friend of longer standing, designed her most recent wedding dress, but Mr. Miller did the rest of the family. He said he did not take it personally.
Perhaps that's because he knows the service he provides is irreplaceable. For example, Miss Taylor called him just two weeks ago. She needed several outfits for a trip to New York for the Elton John AIDS concert last weekend.
No problem.
Sketches and swatches were taken back and forth on Tuesday by assistants. The clothes were cut and fitted on Wednesday on Miss Taylor's dummy. ("We make it and pray that it fits," the designer said.) On Thursday, Mr. Miller and a fitter went with the garments to Miss Taylor's house. The clothes were finished on Friday.
Can any French couturier compete with that?
No matter how many women he dresses in real life, Mr. Miller concedes he will always be remembered for the fantasy world of "Dynasty."
Richard Martin, the newly appointed director of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said, "The 'Dynasty' look so codified power that we won't see its likes again for a long time."
Or will we?
"In a depression," Mr. Spelling said, "people need fantasy, they don't need reality." He said he was developing "a glamour show in a beautiful setting -- a Nolan Miller show."
The Presidential election, the economy and the national mood certainly do not worry Mr. Miller. "Honey," he said, "the ladies I know aren't going to look down-home no matter who gets in the White House."
He tells of the forest-green sequined gown he made for the actress Susan Hayward, a close friend, to wear as a presenter at the 1974 Academy Awards. She was terminally ill and died less than a year later. She was buried in the gown, according to her wishes.
"When she got to heaven," he recalled her saying, "she wanted to look like a star."

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
To Keep or to Buy, There's the Rub

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
THE question occurs to a lot of us from time to time: Should I fix up the clunker or should I bite the bullet and lay down a bunch of cash for a new car?
Fortunately for the automobile manufacturers, the answer usually lies in our hearts instead of our heads, and we sigh and set about finding something new. But now the bean-counters at Runzheimer International have sorted out the actual cost of the decision, and their analysis might help some of us to make a wiser choice. 
 To approach the dilemma objectively, accountants at Runzheimer, a Wisconsin consulting firm, put aside the subjective considerations of image, safety, comfort and reliability and focused exclusively on cost.
They also made certain assumptions in order to create an example.
For a start, they decided that the car you own is a 1988 sedan with a six-cylinder engine and that the new one will be the same. The old car cost $12,597 and goes 21 miles on a gallon of gas. Mileage for the new one is the same, but the price has risen to $15,448.
The car you own also is paid for, but the new one will be financed with a four-year loan. By trading your '88 model, you take care of the down payment, and the loan carries an annual interest rate of 10 percent.
And, with all that, the answer is. . . .
According to Lee Czarapata, vice president of Runzheimer's transportation division, the new-car payments are the decisive factor.
"Even though the newer car has a much greater trade-in value after four years," he said, "and even though you save on repairs and maintenance, the monthly payments total more than $14,000 in principal and interest over four years. And that more than counterbalances the other factors."
The bottom line, he said, is a difference of $8,864 in savings by 1996 if you keep your 1988 model instead of buying new.
Still, the subjective factors do enter in, and Czarapata acknowledged that reliability can be particularly important. "A business person can't afford to blow a big deal or miss an appointment because the car broke down," he said.
"Also, image can be crucial. It would be embarrassing -- if not outright inconsiderate -- to pick up an important client when you are wearing your $400 suit but driving an old beater. And safety, which is important to everyone, is a particularly sensitive issue for business fleets because of the combined effects of repair work, replacement vehicles, lost time on the job and workers compensation."
More information on costs can be had by calling Runzheimer at (414) 767-2200 or by writing to the company's transportation division in Runzheimer Park, Rochester, Wis. 53167. But information on safety also is available in a new booklet published by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, an insurance-industry clearinghouse.
The booklet, "Shopping for a Safer Car," notes that some 200 different 1993 models will have driver-side air bags, nearly all of them as standard equipment. Many also will offer bags for front passengers, and about 150 different models will have antilock brakes in the coming year.
Brian O'Neill, the institute's president, said the publication is designed to help consumers make informed choices by listing '93 models and their safety equipment. "Safety is now near the top of the list for car buyers, right up there with quality," he said.
According to the booklet, purchasing decisions in which safety is a consideration should take into account the essential fact that bigger is safer. "Some people claim small cars are more maneuverable than large cars and, therefore, less likely to be involved in crashes," the authors say. "But this simply isn't true."
The best evidence for that, they add, comes from insurance claims, which are far higher for small cars than for larger ones.
"The problem with small cars isn't confined to crashes with larger vehicles," the booklet says. "In both single and multiple crashes, death rates in small cars are higher than in large cars. In single-vehicle rollovers, in fact, the death rate in small cars is more than five times the rate in large cars."
The authors call air bags the single most important safety feature in today's cars, but they devote space to seat belts, too, and they properly note that automatic seat belts are undesirable and a poor substitute for the bags.
"Shopping for a Safer Car" is available free from the institute. Write to Car List, Box 1420, Arlington, Va. 22210.
For those who are really serious about buying a safe car, the institute offers yet another pamphlet, this one with the catchy title "Injury and Collision Loss Experience by Make and Model."
This one lists vehicle-by-vehicle performance based on crashes, and it notes that the most popular cars on the road vary greatly in their likelihood of insurance claims for injuries and damage.
The five 1989-91 cars with substantially better than average performance in that regard are the Buick Park Avenue, Plymouth Voyager, Dodge Caravan, Ford Crown Victoria and Buick Century. Those with the worst record are the Hyundai Scoupe, Geo Storm, Dodge Daytona, Mitsubishi Eclipse and Chevrolet Camaro.
The car with the best injury claims experience is the Lexus LS400, but it also has worse than average damage results. Other cars that are low on the injury-claims scale are the Buick Park Avenue, Volvo station wagon, Ford Aerostar van and the BMW 7-series cars.
The BMW's, however, have the most expensive damage claims among all 170 cars in the report.
The cars with the worst injury claims, according to institute, are the Hyundai Scoupe, Hyundai Excel sedans and the two-door Geo Metro.
"There are general patterns by size and body style in insurance loss experience," O'Neill said. "For example, large cars generally have better results than small cars, and four-door models tend to do better than two-door models. But even within the same group, large differences characterize the results."
Among small four-door sedans, for instance, the one with the best injury claims result is the Volkswagen Golf. The worst car in the group, the Hyundai Excel, has a result that is nearly twice as high as the Golf's.
