HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Budding Scandal, in Brief: A Primer on the 'B.N.L. Affair'

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is called "Iraqgate" and "the B.N.L. affair," and it could have the makings of a major scandal. But what is it?
It began with charges by Congressional Democrats that the Bush Administration was wrong to try to curry favor with President Saddam Hussein before he invaded Kuwait. If the United States had been tougher earlier, some said, the United States and its allies might never have had to go to war. 
 Then it evolved into a myriad of charges and suspicions that the policy was not only flawed but criminal. There were allegations, still not proven, that fraudulent loans from an Atlanta bank to Iraq, backed by an obscure Federal credit guarantee program, ended up paying for some of Iraq's weapons. A Commerce Department list of goods approved for sale to Iraq was altered before Congressional review, disguising the military utility of American high-technology items for Iraq's arms buildup. Democratic lawmakers charged that senior Administration officials misled them about the policy afterward.
More recently, there were accusations that the Administration was less than thorough in its investigation of a huge fraud scheme at the Atlanta bank.
The result: charges that the Bush Administration was engaged in one or more coverups, and the appointment by Attorney General William Barr on Friday of a special investigator to examine the charges.
The pieces do not fit together yet. But an outline is beginning to emerge of what investigators know and what they are trying to find out. Here is a summary:
What was the old United States policy toward Iraq?
In October 1989, President Bush signed a formal directive to use economic and political incentives to try to moderate the actions of President Hussein, described in one 1988 State Department document as a dictator "who believes that power comes from the barrel of a gun." Mr. Bush has said the policy was an attempt to bring Mr. Hussein into "the family of nations."
In the nine months after the Bush Administration settled on its policy -- as Iraq grew steadily more belligerent -- the United States sold Baghdad high-technology equipment that could be used in its military programs, and provided intelligence on Iran's political and military situation. It fought Congress's attempts to impose economic sanctions and to brand Iraq a supporter of terrorism. And it played down the importance of Iraq's human rights record.
Most controversial was the White House decision in November 1989 to provide $500 million in loan guarantees and push for $500 million more under an obscure program run by the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corporation to promote sales of American farm products abroad. The United States did not lend money to Iraq under the program. Rather, it told banks it would make good on their loans if Iraq didn't repay.
How did the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro become involved in dealings with Iraq?
The Rome-based bank, now widely referred to as B.N.L., is one of Italy's largest commercial banks. In the early 1980's, its Atlanta branch, seeking new business opportunities, began lending money to Iraq under the Agriculture Department program. The relationship between the Iraqis and the branch manager, Christopher P. Drogoul, grew, and an elaborate illegal loan scheme began. Prosecutors say Mr. Drogoul concocted the scheme, in which he would use his bank's high credit rating to borrow from other banks, then turn around and lend to Iraq at a slightly higher interest rate. These transactions were recorded in a separate set of books. His negotiations were conducted through phony telexes and faxes. Inside the bank branch, the transactions were known as "Perugina," after the Italian candy maker.
Some of the loans and credits directly funded Iraq's purchase of weapons and weapons technology, according to the indictment. Federal prosecutors in Atlanta and Administration officials scattered throughout the Federal bureaucracy raised suspicions, but never proved, that loan money backed by the United States Government was diverted into weapons purchases. Other critics say that this misses the point because money is fungible and the loans would at least have freed up other Iraqi funds for arms purchases.
Whether the bank's Rome headquarters knew of the scheme is one of the main questions in the current inquiries, because that would bring the scandal to high levels of the Government of a major American ally.
What made these transactions criminal?
On Aug. 4, 1989, Federal agents, acting on a tip from two bank employees, raided the bank's Atlanta branch. More than 18 months later, the Justice Department indicted Mr. Drogoul and other bank employees, a Turkish national, four Iraqi officials and two Iraqi banks, alleging a five-year scheme to extend more than $5 billion in loans and credits to Iraq and other countries and companies. The charge was based on the thesis that the money was lent without the knowledge and approval of the Rome bank, which was therefore defrauded.
In addition, Mr. Drogoul was charged with lying to bank officials and Federal and state bank authorities, a scheme to illegally sell Cuban sugar, and tax evasion.
In return, the indictment charged, Mr. Drogoul was paid $2.5 million in bribes from exporters whose goods were paid for by the loans.
Lending money to Iraq was not in itself a crime. But the indictment asserted that Mr. Drogoul, who pleaded guilty to masterminding the scheme, had defrauded his superiors and lied about it. Throughout the investigation, however, the Atlanta prosecutors and the Justice Department clashed repeatedly on whether Rome was involved.
Is there proof of a coverup?
The most sweeping charge, made by some Democrats in Congress -- that the Administration allowed the bank to make the loans and then covered up that decision -- has not been proven. But in some instances the Administration has been less than candid in explainingits policy decisions and its handling of the case.
On the first day of Mr. Drogoul's sentencing hearing last month, for example, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat, disclosed the existence of C.I.A. documents indicating that Rome had some knowledge of the scheme. A C.I.A. letter was sent to prosecutors three days later omitting the fact that the agency had received classified reports about Rome's involvement. Since then, the C.I.A. and the Justice Department have been locked in a bitter feud over the handling of the case. C.I.A. lawyers accused the Justice Department of urging them to provide prosecutors and the judge in the bank case with incomplete information via the letter. And the the C.I.A. has admitted failing to turn over all its secret documents to the Justice Department.
In addition, lawyers believe they were misled in two other major instances. One involves alterations made on a Commerce Department list of high-technology items approved for sale to Iraq, before the list was sent to Congress. The second involves a charge by Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Agriculture Committee, that Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter misled him when he argued that the decision to extend the loan guarantees had nothing to do with foreign policy considerations.
In all of this, what are the stakes for the Bush Administration?
On the policy level, the release of thousands of pages of classified and recently declassified documents has been deeply embarrassing. It has exposed the workings of secret policy making: the interagency battles, the candid cables, the impulse to fulfill the President's wishes.
On another level, however, the most insistent conspiracy theorists, including Mr. Drogoul's defense attorney, suggest that the United States might have known about the irregular lending from the tiny Atlanta bank and promoted it, perhaps in collusion with Italy, to help Mr. Hussein. Therefore, this line of thought goes, the Administration had no other choice but to cover its tracks afterward. One way of doing that would be to absolve the Rome bank of any wrongdoing, placing the entire blame on Mr. Drogoul.
Has anyone accused Mr. Bush of direct involvement in a coverup?
Both Congressman Gonzalez and Mr. Drogoul's defense lawyer, Bobby Lee Cook, have suggested that Mr. Bush was involved in a coverup. Although there are some examples of highly unusual behavior by the Administration -- White House and State Department phone calls to the Atlanta prosecutors, for example -- there is no proof that Mr. Bush engaged in a coverup.
On the other hand, Mr. Bush has made several public remarks that have been contradicted by internal documents. For example, he denied that the United States enhanced Iraq's nuclear, chemical, biological and ballistic missile capability, but one document showed that one week before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was urgently warning that Iraq was secretly using American technology in its vast arms buildup.
Does the bank fraud case affect the American taxpayer?
When Iraq invaded Kuwait, it defaulted on all of its loans to the Atlanta bank. Some $1.9 billion of those were guaranteed by the agricultural credit program and the Government has already paid back about $1.5 billion in loans that have come due. The Administration says taxpayers will eventually be reimbursed through Iraqi assets now frozen in foreign banks or by forcing Mr. Hussein to give up some profits from oil sales.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Defunct Car, Like Its Homeland, Was the Sum of Its Parts

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: KRAGUJEVAC, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
Remember the Yugo, that cheap car from Yugoslavia? It was made in this sprawling Serbian industrial town, which proudly welcomes visitors to "the home of the Yugo." But the sad fact is that the Yugo no longer has a home.
Its plight may cause only mild surprise in the United States, where the car was offered for a sticker price of $3,999, but developed a reputation for shoddy construction and was withdrawn from the market this year after a splashy introduction in 1986 and sales of about 150,000 cars. But here, the Yugo really stood for something, like technological prowess, industrial accomplishment and social progress. The Yugo was viewed here as the Yugoslav Model T, putting ordinary families on the road and accounting for more than two-thirds of the domestic car market. 
 Now, however, the Yugo factory has been left moribund by a combination of war, the breakup of the country and United Nations economic sanctions.
"It depresses me to even think of all this nonsense," said Kamenko Sretenovic, the deputy general manager of Zastava, the company that makes Yugos.
With its paralyzed production line, on which incomplete auto bodies dangle sadly like gondolas on a ski-lift during the off-season, the plant presents a compelling image of the havoc wreaked by the splintering of the old Yugoslav federation.
The Yugo, if it could be made, would now be a hybrid vehicle from several different countries.
Before the Balkan war, most of the Yugo's electrical parts came to this town 60 miles south of Belgrade from a factory in Nova Gorica, which is now in independent Slovenia. Most of the car's interior fittings were made in Split, now in independent Croatia.
The company in Split was called Jugoplastika, but has since changed its name to Audgelovi-Slim to make it quite clear that it no longer has anything to do with Yugoslavia.
The brakes, too, were a Croatian product, made in Varazdin. Some of the electrical parts for the engine came from Banja Luka, which is now in a Serb-held section of war-ravaged Bosnia and Herzegovina. As for the seat-belts, locks and mirrors, they came from Ohrid in Macedonia, which has also declared independence but unlike the others has not yet been recognized by many nations.
The rest of the car's parts were made in what is left of Yugoslavia -- Serbia and Montenegro.
"A car is a complex product requiring many different kinds of technology," said Mr. Sretenovic. "And the Yugo was the paramount representation of the economic and technological power of Yugoslavia."
He explained that the breakup of the country, which began last year, inevitably crippled the Yugo, because parts could not be obtained from newborn countries with which Serbia was at war. But scrambling to make substitute components for those no longer available and to import others from Poland, Italy and elsewhere, the plant managed to limp along in the first months of this year with production running at less than half its normal level of 220,000 autos a year.
Then, on May 30, United Nations sanctions were imposed, severing Yugoslavia from world trade.
This was the final blow for Zastava, in which the Italian auto company Fiat has a minority stake, and for the Yugo. Of 16,000 workers, 13,000 were immediately laid off. These idle workers have been receiving the equivalent of about $45 dollars a month from Zastava.
Those still working have been cleaning machinery. They have also managed in the last four months to complete 3,000 cars -- equivalent to two and a half days' production in normal cirumstances.
The vast plant has been transformed into what one worker, Jelenko Poledica, called "a terrible desert."
Another worker, Miroljub Provokovic, who is 42 years old and is earning about $100 a month, worried about how he will support his children, ages 7 and 6. He declared that "the sanctions are totally unjust because they are based on very superficial judgments from the West.
"Serbia is not the aggressor," he added. "Serbs in Bosnia and in Croatia are defending their fireplaces."
But the views and anger of the workers reflect widespread feelings in Serbia, where sanctions appear so far to have produced more anger against the outside world than against the hard-line government of the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic. The West had hoped that Mr. Milosevic would bear the brunt of popular discontent.
The workers' fears for their jobs seem justified. Mr. Sretenovic said the plant, which had already lost about $300 million so far this year, would close fully by the end of the year if Serbia's current isolation persisted. Before that, Zastava would run out of funds to pay workers who have been laid off.
Even if sanctions are lifted soon, the Yugo plant -- like nearly all of Serbian industry -- will face enormous problems. The company's relations with foreign banks and suppliers have been broken. An export market that accounted for about 25 percent of production is rapidly being lost. A total of 100,000 jobs in the former Yugoslavia linked to the auto business are threatened. And it will take months -- probably at least six -- to acquire the parts needed to resume full production.
"We are on the brink of complete collapse," Mr. Sretenovic said. "This place is rapidly turning into a museum."

HEADLINE: Strike Zone;
Debating 'Character' to the Bitter End

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It has been said that a man never discloses his own character so clearly as when he describes another's.
Most Americans are so frantic about the economy that they are turning a deaf ear to Republican attacks on Bill Clinton's character. But the President and the Governor are still locked in a tendentious tango on the issue of Presidential character -- one that is highly revealing about their respective strengths and weaknesses as leaders. 
 Mr. Clinton knows that he is vulnerable on the matter of integrity. He has admitted to a history of problems in his marriage and to breaking a written commitment in order to avoid the Vietnam war-era draft. When stung by the past, he has evaded, eluded and edited.
But, buoyed by a public more in the mood for statistics than titillation, he has shifted the debate on Presidential character by slicing the concept in half. His message is this: Never mind about what has happened in my private life. That's not relevant. Judge my character by the way I handled my job in Arkansas.
With the cupboard bare on domestic issues, Mr. Bush is forced to take the opposite tack. His message is this: Never mind about the promises I broke in my first term. Don't be angry that I got so distracted by my love of foreign affairs that I often seemed like an absentee landlord. Judge my character and my opponent's by my personal code of conduct.
Mr. Clinton tries to camouflage criticism about his evasiveness by blanketing the public with plans and programs. Mr. Bush tries to camouflage his governing failures by throwing hand grenades about trust.
There is something poignant about watching Mr. Bush as he strains to make character the campaign's central issue.
In the past, George Bush seemed to view character as something baked into you by your parents and teachers. It was not something that you boasted about and served up on a fancy dish for company.
In the 1988 race, he found it hard to address the character issue, even though it was clear from conversations with him that what he felt had prepared him to be President had been instilled in Greenwich, Andover and Yale: the love of country, the desire to serve, the sense of loyalty and team-play.
He could bash Michael Dukakis on trumped-up patriotism issues like the Pledge of Allegiance with relish. But when his campaign advisers insisted he talk about his own war record, he felt guilty -- even more so when his mother told him it was unseemly. He had to force himself to talk to reporters about the 1953 death of his 3-year-old daughter, Robin, of leukemia, a heartbreaking event that his advisers felt could be portrayed as character-shaping.
He often waved off character and personality questions with a good-natured line about not wanting to "get on the couch" or not liking "psychoanalysis" stories or "Gail Sheehy stuff," referring to the Vanity Fair writer who combined her campaign profiles into a book called "Character."
But now he has no choice. At the debate in Richmond on Thursday night, Mr. Bush looked uncomfortable and slightly depressed as he tried to press his case before the audience and his rivals yanked him back into a policy discussion.
He began by defending himself against Mr. Clinton's barb that his father, a Senator, would not have approved of his innuendos about Mr. Clinton's trip to Moscow as a young man: "He raised the question of my father and said, 'Well, your father, Prescott Bush, was against McCarthy. You should be ashamed of yourself. McCarthyism.' I remember something my dad told me. I was 18 years old, going to Penn Station to go into the Navy, and he said, 'Write your mother' -- which I faithfully did -- he said, 'Serve your country' -- my father was an honor, duty and country man -- and he said, 'Tell the truth.' And I've tried to do that in public life, all through it. And that says something about character."
Mr. Clinton, by contrast, argued that character is substance: "I'm not interested in his character. I want to change the character of the Presidency. And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next four years."
Further evidence of the President's desperation came on Friday, when he began a speech on a new plan on car insurance and ended up abandoning it to launch an emotional attack on Mr. Clinton's honesty.
"Character does matter," Mr. Bush insisted. "A pattern of deception is not right for the Oval Office." And he added: "You cannot separate the character of the President from the character of the Presidency. They go together. You cannot be one kind of man and another kind of President. It's that simple."
The President was so rattled by a group of young pro-Clinton hecklers that he scorned them as "draft-dodgers," a displacement insult meant for the Democratic candidate.
The polls reflect a sense that Mr. Bush's style of leadership, that of a cautious caretaker, is out of date and out of sync. Mr. Bush still seems disbelieving that the country could prefer a man of Mr. Clinton's character and resume. He may be having trouble understanding what has happened to the country he fought for. Mr. Bush came of age in an era of absolutes. Mr. Clinton came of age in an era of moral ambiguity, part of a generation that had more complicated experiences with sex, drugs, war and abortion.
In the past, the Republicans had great success raising the specter of a nasty and volatile Evil Empire to argue that the nation needed a strong, stable figure in the White House. The end of the cold war makes it more difficult to scare Americans into believing in the importance of a muscular "stand-up" character. They are yearning for a nurturing character -- and Mr. Clinton has played to this mood.
Dan Quayle sounded more vague than ominous when he said during the Vice Presidential debate in Atlanta: "At some time during these next four years there is going to be a crisis -- there will be an international crisis. I can't tell you where it's going to be, I can't even tell you the circumstances, but it will happen. We need a President who has been tested, who has the integrity and qualifications to handle the crisis."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle are right that character matters. But Republicans are not getting any traction on the character issue because they are defining it in an outdated way and because the attacks are hollow, only serving to remind voters that Mr. Bush is having trouble running on his record.
Within President Bush's argument about character is buried his fatal flaw: He has always seemed to think he should be President because he had the right breeding, the right resume and the right character to serve as a careful steward of the country, not because he had ideas he wanted to implement.
And what the public is saying is that, in a year of economic crisis, concern and performance may be the most important tests of character.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Many Companies Try to Simplify Pricing

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
To attract harried but value-conscious consumers, more American companies are adopting a marketing strategy that drops the quick sale in favor of low prices year round. To the buyer, it seems to signal an end to haggling and shopping about for the best price; to the seller it may mean steady customers.
So far, and despite the skepticism of some critics, the approach is building a following among companies ranging from computer makers to car dealerships to hotels. In the process, they are creating what many marketing experts and economists say is a noteworthy shift in how goods and services are bought and sold. 
 Simplified pricing aims to eliminate the system of markdowns buyers have confronted for years. With it, retailers seek to re-establish credibility in the wake of a former practice of sales versus regular prices.
 
Converts Growing
 Some experts, however, voice doubts about the staying power of the strategy. They say steady pricing will inevitably seem old hat, and retailers may only promise low pricing without delivering it.
Competitors who slash prices may also cause businesses with everyday low prices to rethink their approach. "It's part of the American psychology to want to get a really good deal," said James Posner, a retailing consultant in Manhattan.
Whatever the logic, the list of converts is growing. Dozens of car dealers have adopted the no-haggle sticker prices popularized by the fledgling Saturn division of General Motors. The Ford Motor Company has expanded a promotion advertising a single price for several different Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer models.
Many computer manufacturers such as NCR and Zenith Data Systems are dropping list prices in favor of prices closer to what consumers are likely to pay at computer stores. In April the Sheraton hotel chain lowered its posted rates -- which few people actually paid -- and halted widespread discounting. The gambit has resulted in a 14 percent year-over-year increase in room reservations and a slight gain in the average rate that customers actually paid.
American Airlines recently failed in its attempt to make the going simpler and cheaper. Its chairman Robert L. Crandall announced in April the airline would eliminate the confusing discounts so familiar to airfares. But a few weeks ago, Mr. Crandall signaled he was scaling back, citing a lack of cooperation on the part of the other airlines.
The popularity of this pricing pitch is driven in part by the slothful economy. Businesses under pressure to jumpstart revenues have found inspiration in the track record of the country's leading retailer, Wal-Mart. Except for a few sale items every month, the chain promises everyday low prices on major brands. "We've been taught some important lessons by the likes of Wal-Mart, which has gained the trust of the American consumer," said Frank E. Blod, a partner at the New England Consulting Group in Westport, Conn.
 
Some Pay More
 While some consumers revel in the negotiating game, many are willing to pay a premium for the peace of mind of knowing that others are not getting a better deal. Magazines such as Consumer Reports have noted that car shoppers may pay less dealer profit if, instead of buying a Saturn, they negotiate at competing dealerships that sell other brands. But that mattered little to Carol Christian, a training consultant in Westchester County, N.Y., who purchased a Saturn last year partly because of its no-haggle policy. With previous car-shopping excursions, the negotiating process "made me feel bad, defective," she said.
Finally, consumers seem to have less patience for time-honored traditions such as watching for supermarket specials and organizing sheaves of coupons. So-called warehouse clubs and supermarket chains like Winn-Dixie and Albertson's have expanded their low-pricing strategy.
The "high-low" strategy of the supermarket evolved in the early 1970's in the wake of rising inflation. Shortly after price controls were set by the Nixon Administration, commodity prices started dropping. But instead of lowering their newly raised prices, food manufacturers started offering deals to retailers on certain products. Those discounts were passed on as sales to consumers, who had more time for comparison shopping. "High-low pricing is really based on an older, although deep-rooted, paradigm of the American consumer," said Gary M. Giblen, a Paine Webber retailing analyst.
Although many retailers operate successfully with high-low pricing, one daunting force pushing everyday pricing is the consumer products giant Procter & Gamble Company. Since the start of the year, the company has lowered wholesale prices on about half its products and eliminated many discounts it had offered grocers. Procter & Gamble said it changed because grocers were abusing the deals and stockpiling products on special, creating costly, uneven production cycles.
With Procter & Gamble pushing at one end, and time-starved consumers pulling at the other, many people believe that other supermarkets and retailers are likely to adopt more predictable pricing in the future. "It will gradually become more prevalent in the 90's," Mr. Giblen said, but added, "Who knows what will happen later in the decade?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: ISSUES -- Health Care;
Bush and Clinton Aren't Saying It, But Health-Care Taxes Are Likely

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton both say they will rein in health costs and provide health insurance for 35 million uninsured Americans without raising taxes for anyone.
But experience suggests that such promises are unrealistic, that health-care costs eventually explode even if they are artificially controlled, and that some new taxes are likely if the Government guarantees health insurance coverage for all. 
 In some ways the two candidates have radically different ideas about how to achieve their goals. Mr. Clinton says he has "the guts to control costs" by regulating health care and health insurance. Mr. Bush prefers free-market solutions and says he does not want to create a new Federal bureaucracy to regulate medical prices.
But both candidates are vague about details. Neither says how he will finance his plan. And both seem to underestimate the difficulty of passing legislation to revamp the system.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton, like Ross Perot, the independent candidate for President, agree that there is an urgent need for action. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that under the current system, national spending on health care will rise from $808 billion this year to $1.7 trillion in the year 2000. As part of that, spending on hospitals, doctors and nursing homes will more than double in the next eight years, the budget agency says.
The rest of the economy is expected to grow more slowly. So health care, which now represents 13.6 percent of the nation's total output, will account for 18 percent in the year 2000, the budget office said in a report made public last Wednesday.
 
Some Areas of Agreement
 While there are profound philosophical differences between the Bush and Clinton proposals, in some areas they agree. Both would build on the current health insurance system, which provides coverage to most Americans through employers, rather than seek to replace it wholesale, as others have suggested.
Both want to encourage the use of health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care. Both want to cut paperwork and increase the use of electronic billing. Both want to curb medical malpractice lawsuits, and Mr. Bush has chosen to make that a campaign issue.
But both candidates are vague about important details, for reasons suggested by Uwe E. Reinhardt, a professor of political economy at Princeton. "Politicians who articulate fully and forthrightly their ideas about reform of the health-care system run the risk of political self-immolation," he said.
Legions of lobbyists, representing doctors, hospitals, drug companies and the elderly, stand ready to challenge any proposal that could hurt them. All proposals, as Professor Reinhardt said, imply "some redistribution of privilege among Americans."
The proposals are drawing more attention than in the past because health care has, for the first time, emerged as a major issue in a Presidential election, and because Congressional leaders are eager to tackle the problem.
Millions of people in middle-income families have either lost health insurance or fear they will lose it in the future; many others find themselves paying large sums for insurance premiums and medical expenses not covered by insurance. With health costs rising twice as fast as other consumer prices, health benefits are a central issue in most labor-management negotiations. Economists say workers eventually bear most of the cost of such benefits as health care consumes a bigger share of their total compensation package.
 
Private Insurance And Managed Care
 Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton say they will make greater use of health maintenance organizations, which provide a wide range of medical services in return for a fixed monthly payment. Both endorse "managed competition" as a strategy to overhaul the health-care market. Under this concept, consumers would join large groups and be represented by a sophisticated buyer, known as a sponsor. The sponsors would encourage insurers, hospitals and doctors to compete for their business. In many cases that sponsor would be a health maintenance organization.
But there is a big difference. Mr. Clinton says such competition should occur within the framework of a comprehensive budget for all health-care spending, public and private. Mr. Bush favors stringent limits on Federal spending for Medicare, Medicaid and other Government benefit programs. But he insists that the Government must not impose limits on private spending for health care.
The President contends that such limits will lead to the rationing of care, will slow medical innovation and reduce access to advanced technology that Americans now take for granted.
Mr. Clinton and many other Democrats contend that managed care, by itself, is not enough to curb the explosive growth of health costs and that the Government should establish some type of limit.
Henry J. Aaron, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, a research center in Washington, said: "Managed care can be very helpful in making sure that resources are well spent and efficiently used. But managed care by itself cannot cap the growth of health-care spending."
Mr. Bush says he will retain more of the current system, particularly the balance between private health insurance and Government health programs. He would provide tax credits of up to $3,750 a year to help poor families offset the cost of buying private health insurance.
Mr. Clinton has modified his proposal to deflect Republican charges that he favors socialized medicine. But the core of his proposal is the same as it was early this year: He would impose annual limits on health-care spending and would require employers to provide health insurance for employees, either directly or through a purchasing group.
The Governor says a new mandate on employers is needed to guarantee coverage for the uninsured. Of the 35.7 million people without health insurance, 20 million are employed, mostly in small businesses, and 10.5 million others are dependents of workers.
Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, says the Clinton plan will require "massive new Government intervention in the medical marketplace, eventually leading to a complete Government takeover of health-care financing and delivery."
While Mr. Bush "emphasizes market mechanisms to protect consumer choice," Dr. Sullivan says, "Governor Clinton's plan would enhance the role of a heavy-handed Government health-care bureaucracy."
In fact, the Government is likely to play a bigger role in the health-care market no matter who wins the Presidential election. Democrats and Republicans agree that the Government should set standards for private health insurance to prevent insurers from discriminating against people who are chronically ill or have a history of medical problems.
 
'Play or Pay' Vs. Tax Credits
 During the New Hampshire primary campaign early this year, Mr. Clinton was seen as a supporter of "play or pay" proposals, under which employers must "play," by providing health insurance, or pay a tax to enroll their workers in a public program.
But after Republicans pummeled him as an advocate of new taxes and socialized medicine, Mr. Clinton unveiled a revised version of his plan in a speech to employees of Merck & Company in Rahway, N.J., on Sept. 24.
In that speech Mr. Clinton said of his proposal: "This is a private system. It is not pay or play. It does not require new taxes." Indeed, the Governor's latest proposal would generate substantial new business for private health insurance companies.
Mr. Clinton would retain Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. But low-income people on Medicaid would get private health insurance, with all or part of their premiums paid by the Government.
For nonworkers under 65 years of age and their families, Mr. Clinton would guarantee private health insurance coverage through purchasing groups organized with the help of Federal and state authorities. "We will fold Medicaid into this program for private coverage," he says, but he does not give details.
This failure to specify how he would arrange private insurance for Medicaid recipients is one of the larger gaps in Mr. Clinton's plan.
By contrast, Mr. Bush would keep Medicaid in its current form. Poor people not covered by Medicaid -- fewer than half of the nation's 35.7 million poor people have Medicaid -- would get tax credits to help buy private insurance. Middle-income people would get tax deductions that would help them buy private insurance.
Under Mr. Bush's plan, the Administration says, a family of four with an income of $60,000 a year but no employer-sponsored health insurance could take a tax deduction of $3,750, providing about $1,050 to help buy insurance. That figure is less than a third of the cost for a typical family policy.
The President says the proposed tax credits and deductions "would benefit more than 90 million Americans." But some experts say that at least 25 million people will still be left without insurance under the Bush plan.
 
How High the Cost, And Who Will Pay?
 The Bush Administration says the President's plan will cost $100 billion over five years, mainly because the tax credits diminish Federal revenue. Mr. Bush has not said how he will cover the cost. He has ruled out an option favored by many economists: a limit on tax-free employer contributions to employees' health insurance.
Mr. Clinton does not say how much his plan will cost. For a transition period of several years, he would offer tax credits to small businesses to help them provide health insurance for employees. But he does not say how he will make up for this loss of revenue.
Mr. Clinton is also vague about his proposal for a comprehensive health-care budget, which calls for state-by-state limits on spending for doctors, hospitals and nursing homes. The limits, he says, would be set by "a national health-care board made up of consumers, providers, business, labor and government."
But the Governor sidesteps an important legal question: whether the board would be an agency in the executive branch of Government, with power to enforce its decisions, or simply an advisory panel that makes recommendations to Congress.
If the board is truly a private entity it cannot compel consumers, businesses and private insurance plans to limit their spending. If the board is a Federal agency it can control Government outlays, but would invite lawsuits if it tried to limit spending by private groups. Previous attempts by Federal agencies to set prices have generated litigation.
How the overall budget would be translated into local rates for doctors, hospitals, X-rays, laboratory tests and other services is unclear.
Mr. Clinton says that "states will establish fee schedules applicable to all payers" -- businesses, labor unions, insurance companies -- "in order to meet the global budget targets." He does not say whether the uniform rates would be negotiated with doctors and hospitals or adopted unilaterally, by the national board or by state officials, acting separately or together.
Mr. Perot almost certainly knows more about some aspects of health insurance than either Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton. After Mr. Perot founded Electronic Data Systems in 1962, as part of the company's business it processed the payment of billions of claims filed with private health insurance companies and with Medicare and Medicaid.
But Mr. Perot's public statements on health-care policy are much vaguer than those of his two rivals. Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of Families U.S.A., a research and advocacy group that focuses on health care, said Mr. Perot had not offered a comprehensive health plan, "but merely a promise to develop a plan."
Mr. Perot, a billionaire, has said several times that the Government should not pay Medicare or Social Security benefits to people who are extremely wealthy. "One of the leading economists in this country, whose name you'd recognize just like that, has told me that if people like me would give up their Medicare and Social Security, we'd save $100 billion a year," Mr. Perot said in April.
Federal officials like that idea, but say it is inconceivable that it would save $100 billion. There are simply not enough wealthy people to allow the Government to save so much, they say.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "CANDIDATES ON THE ISSUES"
 
Two Proposals for Health Care
 
Medical prices are rising about twice as fast as other consumer prices. The United States spends far more on health care than any other country. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that total health spending will rise from $808 billion this year to $1.7 trillion in the year 2000.
 
Medicare and Medicaid eat up a growing share of the Federal budget. But 35 million Americans have no health insurance.
 
Consumers, business executives and government officials agree that the nation's health-care system must be revamped.
 
THE PROPOSALS
 
President Bush would grant tax credits to poor people and tax deductions to middle-income people to help them buy private health insurance. He would allow self-employed people to deduct 100 percent of the cost of their health insurance premiums (up from the current 25 percent). He would encourage small businesses to pool their purchasing power to buy health insurance at a discount. Mr. Bush says one of his goals for the health-care system is to "keep the government as far out of it as possible."
 
Under Gov. Bill Clinton's plan, a new entity, composed of consumers and providers of health care, would establish national limits on health spending, with a separate budget for each state. Employers would have to buy health insurance for their employees. The Government would guarantee insurance coverage for people who are not working; they would pay premiums that rise with their income. The Government would provide tax credits to small employers to help offset the cost of health insurance in the early years of a transition period. Small businesses could band together, form large groups and buy insurance at a discount.
 
THE SCORECARD
 
The Bush Administration has put together a coherent proposal, but Mr. Bush suffers from a public perception that he ignored this issue for nearly three years. Mr. Bush does not say how he would control health costs. Many experts say his plan would not significantly slow the rise in medical prices and would leave many people uninsured.
 
Mr. Clinton has not confronted the true cost of his program; he asserts that his proposal "does not require new taxes." He says, "We will dedicate Federal savings from cost controls to expanding coverage to all." But hardly anyone believes that such savings would finance expanded coverage for all who need it. Mr. Clinton is vague about the future of Medicaid, the Federal-state program for 30 million low-income people. But he benefits from a public perception that Democrats are more concerned and knowledgeable about health care. (pg. 26)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: MOSCOW IS SELLING WEAPONS TO CHINA, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
In a move that is undercutting efforts to stem the spread of arms, Russia is selling missile-guidance technology, rocket engines and other advanced weapons systems to China, its onetime adversary, American officials say.
The exports to Beijing worry Bush Administration officials, who fear that a main reason the Chinese are acquiring the technology is to develop new weapons to sell to the third world. 
 "Re-export is a big problem," a Pentagon official said. "You don't know what the Chinese will do with the stuff once they get the high-tech capabilities."
Russia's arms sales have become a growing worry for Washington even as its military threat has shrunk. Moscow's reduction in military spending, combined with a desperate need for hard currency, has led arms factories and military-related institutes to look abroad for orders to survive. At the same time, conversion of military industries to civilian production has proved difficult.
 
Enriching Uranium
 In addition to weapons, a senior Bush Administration official said, Moscow is selling technology to the Chinese that can be used to enrich uranium. Washington is concerned that Beijing will use the technology to improve the design of its nuclear power plants, making them attractive to third-world buyers and further undermining efforts to stop the spread of nuclear arms.
Despite a cooperative relationship with non-Communist Russia, the United States has so far been unable to stop the Russian sales. Russian officials seem to have decided that the proceeds from arms and technology sales are worth the risk of irritating American policy makers.
The Administration, for its part, seems to have concluded that supporting reform in Russia is more important than drawing a firm line against weapons sales and threatening a reduction in financial assistance.
 
U.S. Formally Complains
 Moscow is proceeding with the sale of diesel submarines to Iran, and a Russian company, Glavkosmos, is selling a rocket booster to India in violation of an agreement restricting technology for ballistic missiles. A senior American official said the Administration had complained to Russia and China about the sale, apparently with no effect.
Undermining its leverage, the protests by Washington have come as Western nations, including the United States, have shown little restraint themselves in selling arms. The Administration, although it has exhorted governments of other industrial nations to control the spread of destabilizing weapons, appears to have placed emphasis on competing with its allies for arms deals as it faces a faltering economy and a difficult election campaign.
Two such deals -- the sales of combat jets to Saudi Arabia and Taiwan totaling $14.8 billion, announced in September -- exceed the value of American arms sales to all nations of the third world last year. Administration officials say that the Russians would be selling weapons to Iran and China regardless of American sales. But Russian officials have cited such deals to justify their exports.
The pattern of Moscow's arms sales has changed considerably since the cold war, when it provided billions of dollars in arms to nations like Cuba, Iraq and Libya, often at concessionary terms, in an effort to extend or maintain its military influence.
What the Russians are after is cash, not influence. That, plus the defeat of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, which effectively removed Baghdad as a potential client, has limited the number of prospective customers. Two of the major customers are Iran and China.
 
Risky Business
 "In absolute figures Russian exports have gone down," an Administration official said, "but the reality is that the customers that still want to buy from them are questionable."
And Richard F. Grimmett, an expert on conventional arms sales at the Congressional Research Service, observed: "The Russian focus is on those countries that are willing to pay cash. There is a tremendous focus on Iran. China has picked up, too. The Chinese cannot get high-technology weapon systems from other suppliers. What you have there is a marriage of convenience."
Russia has sold diesel submarines and SU-24 and MIG-29 aircraft to Iran, and is providing spare parts for some of the Iraqi aircraft that were flown to Iran during the gulf war -- planes that the Iranians have said they will not return. And along with Czechoslovakia, Russia has sold T-72 tanks to Syria.
 
Better Guidance Systems
 American officials say Moscow has sold missile-guidance technology, rocket engines and rocket technology to China. China's air-to-air missiles are not well equipped to seek out enemy planes, and Russian technology is expected to enable Beijing to improve them. China's surface-to-surface missiles are also considered to have inferior guidance systems and could benefit considerably from Russian exports, American officials said.
Moscow has sold S-300 surface-to-air missiles to China, the officials say. The S-300 is a Patriot-like system designed to shoot down planes and missiles.
In addition, Russia has sold 24 SU-27 fighters to China. American officials believe that Beijing is buying the planes in hope of acquiring production technology so that future aircraft can be assembled at home. Adding to the American concern, there are indications of discussions between Russians and Chinese officials about the joint production in China of tactical missiles and other weapons systems, an Administration official said.
Russia is also selling tanks and tank technology to Beijing.
A further worry, a senior Administration official said, is the sale of advanced Russian dual-use technology, which can be employed to enrich uranium for nuclear power plants. The United States is worried that this technology transfer will help China modernize its nuclear power plants and make them more marketable in the third world.
Both Russia and China have recently announced the sale of nuclear power plants to Iran, a transaction that disturbs Washington. The Administration believes that even ostensibly peaceful nuclear programs will enhance Teheran's expertise and help it develop nuclear weapons.
 
Yeltsin Lays It Out
 The Russians have not been secretive about arms sales. In February, President Boris N. Yeltsin said weapons exports would be a cushion for the Russian arms industry as the country tried to make the transition to a civilian economy.
More recently, a Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman justified the sale of three diesel submarines to Iran in blunter terms, saying it was a way of raising cash during a difficult period.
"Russia cannot in principle, taking into account the economic situation in this country, give up the receipts of freely convertible currency through the sales of armaments abroad," the spokesman said.
Whatever the rationale, Moscow has been stepping up sales efforts. In August, it held a major air show and used the occasion to promote arms, displaying surface-to-air missiles and self-propelled artillery. Signs in Russian and English said customers could buy military aircraft out of existing inventories or purchase specially configured planes off production lines. Chinese and North Koreans were among the foreign officials examining the weapons systems.
Norman Friedman, an American military expert, remarked, "They have got one product that is worth buying and they are selling it."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Pulse -- New Hampshire;
Clinton Leads in New Hampshire, a G.O.P. Bastion

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KEENE, N. H., Oct. 17

 BODY:
Four years ago, George Bush scratched out a pivotal victory over Senator Bob Dole of Kansas in the New Hampshire primary and went on to triumph in November, carrying the state with 63 percent of the vote against a regional rival.
"Thank you, New Hampshire!" he exulted on election night. 
 This year, with the local economy haggard, the conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan threw President Bush on the defensive while the slushy snows of February covered the ground, and he is still there eight months later as the trees stage their riotous autumn color show.
"The President didn't get the message," said former Representative Charles G. Douglas 3d, who backed Mr. Buchanan. "He never came to grips with the economy, and now it's too late. New Hampshire gave him his wake-up call, but George Bush hit the snooze button."
 
'Settling Into Clinton'
 Mr. Bush beat Mr. Buchanan in the primary, of course, but he pulled only 53 percent of the vote. And now he trails Gov. Bill Clinton in the polls in this most Republican of New England states, as in every other state in the region, and most leading politicians of both parties here say he seems headed for defeat.
"People have given up on Bush," said Richard Bennett of the American Research Group, a Manchester poll-taking firm. "There was a day of reckoning, sometime in mid-September, when they stopped waiting for him to give them a reason to vote for him. They decided he wasn't going to do anything in this campaign, and now, as the debates unwind, they're settling into Clinton, getting comfortable with the new man."
Mr. Bennett's most recent survey, conducted Oct. 2-8, showed Mr. Clinton ahead, 42 percent to 37, with 11 percent for Ross Perot and 10 percent undecided. Eight hundred people whom Mr. Bennett considered likely to vote were interviewed for the poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
A lead of that size could still be overcome, of course, and Gov. Judd Gregg, who is running for the seat of retiring Senator Warren B. Rudman, insisted in a brief interview that it would be.
But more recent private polls have found a similar trend, and Mr. Bennett's detailed figures show the President in deep trouble not only with independents, many of whom favor Mr. Perot, but also with Republicans. Fewer than 60 percent of Republicans said that they were prepared to back Mr. Bush; he is especially weak among those who describe themselves as moderately conservative rather than very conservative.
 
'Economic Demolition Derby'
 To a great degree, the problem is the economy. In 1988 it was New Hampshire's pride and joy, but in 1992 it is the state's despair. With high-tech jobs vanishing and real estate at a standstill, with five of New Hampshire's biggest banks closed and consolidated into two, with almost half the retail space empty in downtown Concord, the state capital, and with 45,000 liens this year on houses because their owners failed to pay property taxes, Chris Spirou, the Democratic state chairman, speaks of witnessing an "economic demolition derby."
Mr. Gregg, who appears to hold a moderate lead in his own race, said state revenue had exceeded his greatly reduced forecasts in nine of the last 10 months, indicating that New Hampshire was slowly emerging from its economic slump. But the Presidential race is still "a lot closer than it should be," he said, because "people here don't think the Federal Government is doing the job."
Senator Rudman, a Republican who is by far the state's most popular politician, a near-icon whose name is invoked in the television commercials of both Mr. Gregg and his Democratic rival, John Rauh, paints a much gloomier picture of Mr. Bush's prospects in citing the same major problem.
"Most recessions in the past affected mostly blue-collar people," Mr. Rudman said. "I don't mean to be callous, but they cope with layoffs because they're used to them, and after things pick up they go back to their jobs. This time there are people all over the state like a couple of neighbors of mine, computer people, thought the boom would last forever -- both lost their jobs, everything leveraged so they've lost their cars and may end up homeless soon.
"There's been no President -- not F.D.R., not Ronald Reagan -- who could survive the kind of political rage that that produces."
 
No Move to the Center
 Tom Rath, a former State Attorney General whom many here consider a keen political strategist, sees another reason for the Republican Party's problems here this year: a failure to recognize the difference between the primary campaign and the general-election campaign.
"Running against Buchanan in the primary, Bush had to move to the right," Mr. Rath said. "His people felt that was the only way to contain the trouble, here and in the South. Fine. But in the general election you have to appeal to a lot of people who aren't ideologically driven, the moderates, the centrists. That's what conventions are for, moving back to the center, but at Houston we did the opposite."
It is not so much that any individual constituency was offended. Abortion has not figured heavily in the campaigns here in Justice David H. Souter's home state, and polls show no large gap between male and female voters. But the moderate Republicans have felt shut out, and one of their most visible figures, State Senator Susan McLane, has endorsed both Mr. Clinton and Arnie Arneson, the Democratic candidate for governor.
David Moore, a political science professor at the University of New Hampshire, who also takes polls, asserted that Mr. Bush had lost so much credibility that he found it hard to catch voters' ears.
"People in New Hampshire think he has stronger personal characteristics," Professor Moore said. "They certainly think he's better qualified to conduct foreign policy. But it doesn't matter. No matter what he has tried, he hasn't been able to turn people's attention from the present either to the past and his triumph in the gulf war, or to the future and his promises of better days ahead."
 
Defying a Political Maxim
 Mr. Bush has spent $23,000 to show some of his commercials on a Manchester television station, but he has not visited the state this fall; it has only four electoral votes. His campaign's low energy level, especially compared with that of Mr. Clinton, who attended the Democratic state convention on Sept. 26, could hurt other Republican candidates on the ballot.
Ms. Arnesen is trying to disprove New Hampshire's oldest political maxim: that anyone who advocates a broad-based tax loses. The high rate of foreclosures here results from high property taxes, which results in turn from the fact that this state gives less aid to schools than any other state, which results, finally, from the lack of any broad-based state tax.
She has advocated a state income tax, with three-quarters of the proceeds going to local communities for property-tax relief, and there are some signs that she has made headway in her race against Attorney General Stephen Merrill, a protege of the former Governor and White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu.
Mr. Gregg, a champion of small government and low taxes in the New Hampshire mold, appears to be in better shape. His opponent, he says, "marches in the army of Ted Kennedy." He has painted Mr. Rauh, a nephew of the late Joseph L. Rauh Jr., a leading Washington lawyer, as "a cross between Karl Marx and John Gotti," in the words of an editorial in The Keene Sentinel.
"For the first time in 25 years," said Mr. Bruno, the former Democratic chairman, "we have a real two-party fight in this state, and that's thanks mainly to George Bush's weakness as a candidate."

HEADLINE: Lord Franks, Diplomat Who Led Marshall Plan Effort, Dies at 87

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Oliver Shewell Franks, a British diplomat and academic who played a crucial role in putting the Marshall Plan for European recovery into effect after World War II, died on Thursday at his home in Oxford, England. He was 87 years old.
The cause of death was not disclosed. 
 In his varied career, Lord Franks was a leader in government, diplomacy, education and business. He served as a top procurement official in Britain's World War II effort, as Ambassador to the United States in the formative years of the cold war and as chairman of Lloyds Bank P.L.C., one of Britain's largest banks.
He was also a professor of philosophy, provost of Queen's College and head of Worcester College, both at Oxford. And he directed a 1983 commission that held an inquiry into the events leading up to Britain's war with Argentina over the Falkland Islands.
He first came to national prominence while in his 30's, when he left academia to work as a wartime administrator. Impressing officials with his analytical and managerial talents, he steadily advanced in rank until he was promoted to the critical post of Permanent Secretary of the combined Ministries of Supply and Aircraft Production.
 
Mastery of Foreign Policy
 He was known for his intellectual detachment and purposefulness. When a German bomb exploded near a building on the Thames that housed his office and sleeping quarters, the 6 feet4 inch Mr. Franks dashed into the street wearing his pajamas -- and carrying his briefcase.
He gained an international reputation for his mastery of foreign-policy issues and economics during Western Europe's postwar recovery. In 1947 he headed Britain's delegation to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, a 16-nation conference in Paris that drafted recommendations for parceling out American aid under the Marshall Plan.
Elected chairman of the organization's Executive and the Economic Coordinating Committees, he was credited with resolving the conflicting needs and interests of the 16 European countries.
In 1948 Prime Minister Clement Attlee appointed him Ambassador to the United States. At the age of 43, he was the second-youngest ever to hold that post, and he played a significant role in cementing the relationship between the two nations as the cold war began.
 
Falkland War Post
 In a farewell address in 1952, he hailed British-American unity on Korea and the Berlin blockade. He said the Berlin airlift "was the first time perhaps that we both fully recognized the new peril that faced us and straightaway took joint and effective steps to cope with it."
Back in England, he was chairman of Lloyds Bank from 1954 to 1962. He drew attention in 1959 for shifting the focus of his analysis of world affairs from the East-West conflict to the emerging issues between the industrialized North and the underdeveloped South.
Returning to academia, Lord Franks headed Worcester College from 1962 to 1976. Before the war, he had been provost at Queen's College, a professor at the University of Glasgow and a visiting professor at the University of Chicago.
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher named him in 1982 to head an inquiry into the Falklands war, his last high-level appointment. His report exonerated her administration of blame for failing to anticipate the Argentine invasion of the islands.
 
Pondering a Question
 He was made a Commander of the British Empire in 1942, knighted in 1945 and given a life peerage in 1962.
For a time he was considered a possible candidate for Prime Minister. But for all his erudition, Lord Franks was uncomfortable with political glad-handing and social small talk. Asked at a dinner party to name his favorite film star, he thought for some time while puffing on his pipe and finally said he would have to ponder more deeply before answering.
He was born on Feb. 16, 1905, and grew up in Bristol. He graduated from Queen's College, where he studied classics, ancient history and philosophy.
His wife of 56 years, the former Barbara Tanner, died in 1987. They had two daughters, Caroline and Alison.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Debate Between New York's Senate Candidates

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the senatorial debate last night broadcast from WRGB-TV in Schenectady, as transcribed by The New York Times. 
 
Abortion Rights
 MODERATOR While polls say the economy ranks as No. 1 on voters' minds, perhaps the most volatile subject you face is abortion. Senator D'Amato is on the Right to Life line but recently voted against the Bush abortion gag order. Mr. Abrams is a vocal supporter of a woman's right to choose. First, clearly state your stand on abortion and then tell us why you think you're right.
. . . 
 D'AMATO I'm pro-life. Everyone knows that. It's a matter of conscience. I understand people who have a difference of opinion; who are pro choice. My position is that unless the life of the mother, rape or incest, under those conditions, yes, but no, no -- and it's, again, the matter that I understand where people have a difference of opinion. But even pro-choice people, I believe, overwhelmingly understand that a youngster, 12 or 13 or 14, should have parental consent. I think I differ greatly with the Attorney General on that. He does not believe that there should be parental consent.
 
. . .
 It seems to me that a 12 or 13 or 14 who's frightened, etc., should have the advice, should have the counsel of her parents, and they should not be shut out of the process and, indeed, I think most people, again, even those who are pro choice, would agree with me on that.
ABRAMS Senator D'Amato, just a couple of weeks ago, was one of only 14 members of the United States Senate to seek to continue the ban on using fetal tissue for important medical investigations and experimentations in order to try to solve the answer to the diseases of Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease and diabetes. This is a clear difference between the two of us: I want to go to the Senate to vote for the freedom of choice act, in order to get rid of the overriding -- rid of the kinds of decisions that have been coming down from the United States Supreme Court that Al D'Amato sanctions with his confirmation votes for those justices.
 
Sticking to the Issues
 MODERATOR This campaign has seen charges of sleaze leveled by both sides. Just this week Mr. Abrams accused Senator D'Amato of being right wing to the point of fascism. Senator D'Amato has accused Mr. Abrams of being hopelessly liberal. Now I want you to both be specific on what your opponent has done that makes him unworthy of being the next U.S. Senator from New York.
ABRAMS Well, I indicated, again, there was an unfortunate expression used, and I apologize for that, but then I had hoped that Senator D'Amato would pull off his negative commercials, his distorted commercials, which would then allow me not to be able to respond or to force me to respond so that we can come here tonight and be, on all occasions, talking about the issues that separate us: on choice, on the economy, on health care, on the environment, on what people want to have changed in this country and in this society. I have run, I have been an elected official over the course of a lifetime with a strong record of integrity and I resent the kind of character assassination that has taken place in the commercials of Senator D'Amato. The fact of the matter is that Senator D'Amato has been criticized by the Senate Ethics Committee for running his office in an improper and inappropriate manner and that his brother has been able to misuse that office for personal gain. I think that issue looms large in terms of people evaluating whether or not Senator D'Amato deserves another term in the United States Senate.
MODERATOR Senator, your response.
D'AMATO Well, there goes Bob Abrams again. And I think it's unfortunate. Because I think the people of New York are tired. They're tired of this kind of wallowing in the mud; wallowing in the gutter. I think he owes the people of New York -- you know, the people of New York know that Bob doesn't like me. But, you know, they want to hear us talk about the issues and the facts and get out of the gutter.
Thursday night, they had a Presidential debate, and it concentrated on the issues and the people said they wanted that. They don't want to hear a continuation of this same kind of tired charge because he doesn't want to talk about the issues. He doesn't want to talk about the fact that his health care plan is going to raise taxes and government spending 38 percent. He doesn't want to talk about the need for quality education and how he would get quality education. He wants to wrap himself desperately around Mr. Clinton even though on major issues they differ. He calls Clinton's approach to health care a Band-Aid approach.
 
. . .
 I didn't invent that he endorsed and supported the Russo Bill. [That bill would establish a national health-insurance system.] That's what he did. He campaigned on it during the campaign. I didn't invent the fact of what his cuts would mean to the economy, that's what he did.
I didn't say untruthfully he referred to me as a fascist and then three days later sat there and cheered Bella Abzug; he laughed while she and others not only called me a fascist but also Nazi. Now, you know, stereotype me as the same conduct similar to the Nazis. And then he says that this campaign has hit a low; it certainly has, and he should change it.

 
Link to Clinton
 MODERATOR O.K. Mr. Abrams.
ABRAMS Senator D'Amato once again, just now, for the second time on this show, has misstated my position on the funding of health care. He knows full well that my funding is very different from Congressman Russo because I said it here earlier tonight. I've said it many times. It's been printed in the newspapers and he knows that. And, yes, he persists in misrepresenting. It's interesting.
. . . Bill Clinton today issued a statement, because in the last 24 hours Al D'Amato has tried to get closer to Bill Clinton, saying that I'm separate from him or he is closer to him on positions. Here's what Bill Clinton says: "I reject Senator D'Amato's attempt to link himself to me or my campaign. I stand firmly with Bob Abrams, who is New York's best chance for real change and leadership in the U.S. Senate. Bob Abrams understands we must create jobs, improve our schools, train our labor force and provide affordable housing and health care. He also understands the need to heal the wounds of the past 12 years and to bring people together. New Yorkers need his leadership."
So he shouldn't try to misrepresent again as to where he is vis-a-vis Bill Clinton and where Bill Clinton is vis-a-vis Bob Abrams.
MODERATOR Al D'Amato.
D'AMATO All I'm saying, and someone said it much better than me, is let's look at the record. Al Smith said that. Take a look at the record. On defense, Bill Clinton calls for defense cuts over the next five years of $110 billion. Bob Abrams, $280 billion. If you work at General Electric and you're on a defense project, forget about it. If you work at any of the military bases, whether they be at Staten Island or whether they be at Griffiss or whether they be at Fort Drum, forget about it. If you work at Grumman in Long Island, you're out. Four hundred thousand people would lose their jobs in New York under the Abrams's plan.
 
. . .


 
Education
 MODERATOR Education and health care in America are both getting poor grades. Briefly, tell us what you would do to improve each.
D'AMATO Well, let's take a look at education. We're not spending less money today on education, we're spending more money. But the question is, is the money getting into the classrooms? Is the money getting in to do the job for the kids. When you have a situation where two out of three dollars get stuck into the bureaucracy and doesn't get in to the kids; when you don't have merit pay for good teachers, competency testing for teachers; when you don't have freedom of choice -- and I'm delighted to begin to see some movement in that area, where the city system is saying they will involve and give parents an opportunity to send their kids to different systems. There is no competition, there is no initiative, and that's why we've fallen so badly behind.
 
. . .
 ABRAMS Well, dollars are important in education. And the fact of the matter is during the D'Amato years in the United States Senate during the last two administrations of President Reagan and George Bush, this state has lost $300 million. As of 1989 for example, as contrasted with 1980. That's a lot of money that hemorrhages from local school districts. Teachers being fired, curriculums being cut. It's not only money. Of course you just can't throw money at a problem and expect the solution to that problem. You need some fundamental reform. Magnet schools, cluster classes, you need some Head Start. Al D'Amato voted three times during his years in the Senate against guaranteeing a Head Start seat for kids in this state and this country.
 
. . .
Gay Rights
 ABRAMS I've been a strong supporter of civil rights and civil-liberties legislation throughout my life and my career, including equal rights for those who are lesbians and gays, going back many, many years. And I would go to Washington to be a prime sponsor of legislation that would make sure that there would be no discrimination against people based upon their sexual orientation as it relates to their ability to get a job or to live in housing. Too many gay people are being bashed on, beaten upon, and that's why I've supported legislation that would protect anybody -- and the public interest in terms of any bias violence -- based upon religion or race or sexual orientation. So I've got a very strong commitment to civil rights and civil liberties throughout that life and career, and would bring that as a fighter for that kind of legislation in the Senate.
D'AMATO There's nothing more important than government protecting the rights of every citizen, and that right should be protected regardless of a person's sexual predilections, regardless of what they are, what their color is, what their ethnic, race, religion, -- it makes no difference. I agree that we have to do more to see to it that this is the case.
I've encouraged them in a number of cases, and I won't even mention a case. I think the Attorney General's encouraged them in the same case to become more actively involved.
We have an absolute obligation to see to it that no citizen has got to fear for his or her safety because of who they are and what they are, regardless of race, color, religion or sex.
