HEADLINE: Review Finds Inquiry Into Iraqi Loans Was Flawed

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO with DEAN BAQUET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Sometime in late 1989, a team of Federal prosecutors in Atlanta made a decision, one that would guide one of the biggest bank fraud investigations in history and influence President Bush's troubled re-election campaign. The Italian Government, they concluded, did not know that a bank it owned had secretly lent billions of dollars to Iraq, providing crucial funds for President Saddam Hussein's military machine.
Three years later, a reconstruction of the Government's investigation of corruption at the Atlanta branch of the Italian-owned Banca Nazionale del Lavoro shows that the conclusion at the heart of the case -- that Rome was uninvolved -- was based on incomplete information and a flawed investigation. 
 The reconstruction, based on interviews with current and former Government officials and on hundreds of pages of documents, portrays an investigation marred by bitter feuding among Atlanta prosecutors, their superiors in the Justice Department and the Central Intelligence Agency.
One Justice Department memo, from July 1990, shows that prosecutors were concerned early on that the C.I.A. itself might have played a role in the bank's dealings with Iraq and other foreign governments. C.I.A. officials, for their part, despite screaming matches with frustrated prosecutors, never shared potentially explosive leads that might have reshaped the whole case.
 
Who Was the 'Victim'?
 An examination of the decision made in 1989 is crucial. If the Rome headquarters was aware, then it could not have been the victim of the fraud and the prosecution would have a much weaker case. And if the Rome bank -- and therefore the Italian Government -- was somehow involved, the scandal could have damaged Italy's banking system and toppled the Government of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti.
Prosecutors in Atlanta were insistent that the bank had to be a victim for the case to hold up. Gail McKenzie, the lead prosecutor, told her superiors in Washington on February 1990 that without that premise, a multibillion-dollar case would disintegrate into a minor prosecution of technicalities.
An Atlanta grand jury eventually charged that the manager of the Atlanta branch, Christopher P. Drogoul, masterminded the scheme, authorizing $5 billion in loans to Iraq and other countries, and concocted an elaborate subterfuge to conceal it from his superiors. Mr. Drogoul at first pleaded guilty to the charges, then changed his mind and withdrew his plea during the sentencing hearing. The case will now go to trial.
Last week Attorney General William P. Barr named a retired Federal judge from New Jersey to investigate the Bush Administration's handling of the bank-fraud case.
 
Change of Heart
 Some Congressional Democrats say the recent revelations are only a tiny part of a two-pronged Government-wide cover-up: to protect and conceal its dealings with Mr. Hussein, and to accommodate the Italian Government. Even more ominously, these critics, without any real proof, have begun to suggest that the Administration knew about the loans all along.
The unfolding story of the Atlanta prosecutor has become a major issue in the closing weeks of the Presidential campaign, with the Administration vigorously denying accusations that it engaged in a cover-up.
The internal documents -- including correspondence among senior prosecutors, draft indictments and State Department cables -- do not resolve such questions. But they provide the most detailed picture of the decision-making and analysis that drove the inquiry, and offer a portrait of how behind-the-scenes battling influenced the case.
The following are among the findings from the review of the documents:
*The Justice Department believed from the outset that Rome must have been involved, then inexplicably changed its mind just weeks before the 1991 indictment of Mr. Drogoul. In one Nov. 29, 1990, memo, Lawrence A. Urgenson, chief of the department's fraud section, complained to a colleague of a "virtual absence of any hard probing" of Rome's guilt. Atlanta prosecutors contend that the reason for the change was simple: they were able to make a convincing case that Mr. Drogoul was the mastermind. But during 1989 and 1990, the Italian Government extensively lobbied United States officials, including the American Ambassador in Rome and senior Administration officials in Washington, explaining that the case could have severe foreign policy implications.
*Though the Justice Department has insisted that the indictment was based solely on a review of the facts, economic and foreign-policy considerations played a major role. When one department official considered charging the bank as a whole, the lead Atlanta prosecutor argued that it would create a "crisis to the stability of world monetary markets."
*Federal prosecutors repeatedly struggled to elicit information from the C.I.A. about the case, but to little avail. Intelligence reports that were provided in 1989 and 1990 dealt mainly with Iraq's military purchasing network abroad, not the bank's activities in either Rome or Atlanta. David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, now says that during this time the C.I.A. had documents indicating that Rome had at least some knowledge of the scheme. The internal memos suggest that such information might have made prosecutors more skeptical of the Italian Government's position.
 
'Suspicious as Anyone Else'
 The documents describing the internal decision-making in the case were provided by Government officials outside the C.I.A. and the Justice Department. The Justice Department declined to make Mr. Urgenson available to discuss the case, citing the appointment of the special prosecutor. The C.I.A. said on Friday that it would have no further comment.
Gerrilyn Brill, the acting United States Attorney in Atlanta, said in a recent interview that when investigators swooped down on the Atlanta bank in August 1989 and seized boxes of records, the prosecutors went in with an open mind about Rome's involvement. "We were as suspicious as anyone else," Ms. Brill said. "We didn't go into this with a predetermined theory. How could so much money go undetected? But we never came up with evidence higher-ups were involved."
By Ms. Brill's account, about five months after the raid Atlanta prosecutors presented the Justice Department with a first draft of an indictment, one that portrayed the bank's headquarters as unwitting dupes of a sophisticated fraud. The department sent it right back, contending that the Atlanta team had not fully investigated whether the scheme also involved high-level bank and Iraqi Government officials.
In one internal memo dated Nov. 29, 1990, Mr. Urgenson argued that the prosecutors had not been skeptical enough of Rome. He wrote, "I am not yet convinced that the principal prosecutive theory articulated by the U.S. Attorney's office -- that B.N.L. was an unwitting victim, and that there was no involvement by any B.N.L. personnel outside the Atlanta agency -- is sufficiently well founded."
By Mr. Urgenson's account in the memo, one major problem was that prosecutors were dependent on Rome for all of their information. They had never managed to dig into the bank and develop their own more skeptical sources of information. He wrote, "Part of the difficulty we are experiencing in this regard is the virtual absence of any hard probing of B.N.L. New York or Rome personnel -- an unfortunate concomitant of relying so heavily upon B.N.L. for assistance."
 
Crucial 3-Month Period
 But the Government created this problem for itself. For reasons that remain unexplained, the investigative team canceled a planned visit to the bank's Rome headquarters, which is on the Via Veneto across the street from the American Embassy. The executives whom investigators wanted to interview were flown to Atlanta by the bank, as were bank records.
Sometime between the end of November and February 1991, the Justice Department changed its mind and went along with the decision to charge Mr. Drogoul as the main person in the scheme. The documents do not offer a hint at how such a major change in position was made. Lawyers involved in the case acknowledge that no powerful new evidence emerged. Ms. Brill said the Department changed its mind in January 1990, after reviewing the evidence again.
The documents show that at least one prosecutor was concerned that the C.I.A. might have had some relationship with the bank. On July 3, 1990, Rimantas A. Rukstele, then head of the criminal division of the United States Attorney's Office in Atlanta, wrote a letter to the Deputy Assistant Attorney General Mark M. Richard, citing some "potential stumbling blocks to the investigation." Among those he cited was the question of "what knowledge and role, if any, the Central Intelligence Agency had or played in B.N.L. dealings with foreign governments in general and Iraq more specifically."
Mr. Rukstele added, "As you well know, experience has demonstrated that C.I.A. knowledge and participation can seriously impact a decision to prosecute." He did not state the reason for his concern.
Over the last few weeks, the C.I.A. has uncovered several classified reports, primarily from its station in Rome after the August 1989 raid on the Atlanta branch, indicating that the Rome bank, or at least officials within it, knew about the scheme and may have been involved in it. Most of the documents were not turned over to the Justice Department until after Mr. Drogoul's sentencing hearing began in mid-September.
Although the documents are highly classified and much about their content is not known, Senator Boren has read them and says they would have been extremely useful to the prosecution. A team from Mr. Boren's committee began taking sworn depositions from C.I.A. officials at the agency's headquarters on Friday as part of the committee's investigation of the mishandling of intelligence information in the bank fraud case, United States officials said today.
One document, dated October 1989, cites an interview with an official from Danieli, an Italian steelmaker that was providing a factory to Iraq, according to United States officials who have read it. The official said a representative from the Rome bank went to the company in Udine to discuss financing for the project, telling officials there to contact the Atlanta branch of the bank, which they did. The C.I.A. report concluded that the incident was at odds with the theory that the Rome bank did not know of the Atlanta bank scheme.
Another C.I.A. report that same month cited a source considered generally reliable who said that Western bankers believed that the Rome headquarters of the bank was aware from the beginning of the activities of its Atlanta branch.

HEADLINE: European Unity: Reaffirming Respect for Diversity

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, England, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The European Community summit meeting here Friday was more an exercise in public relations than hardball diplomacy, an attempt to sell skeptical parliaments and doubting publics on a more limited vision of European unity, one that will take into account separate national identities.
But by conceding that the building of Europe had often been left to a remote bureaucracy in Brussels that few voters in Britain, France, Italy, Germany or other countries understand, the leaders may well have marked a turning point -- away from the idea of a "United States of Europe" that was in the minds of the community's founders 35 years ago. 
 Even Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany acknowledged Friday that the phrase itself was easily misunderstood. "Now we must be more careful, because it's not New York and Texas and California getting together," he said. "It's separate European traditions with distinct cultural identities."
In their final declaration Friday, the community's leaders pledged themselves to continue to move toward closer political and monetary cooperation, as outlined in the treaty agreed to last year in the Dutch city of Maastricht.
But they also reaffirmed their determination to respect "the interests and diversity of member states," and promised to produce specific ideas for making the community more open, more respectful of national traditions and more democratic, when the leaders meet again in Edinburgh in December.
 
A Thatcher Echo
 Only a few years ago, Britain was alone among its European partners in voicing skepticism about the trend toward European federalism, which Margaret Thatcher, then the Prime Minister, regarded as anathema and a fatal compromise of Britain's national sovereignty.
But the last several months have brought home some hard lessons to advocates of European unity, who have seen their complacent vision of a federal Europe shaken by the economic and political turbulence surrounding the debate over the pending treaty on European union.
In June, Danish voters narrowly rejected the treaty in a national referendum. Two months later, French voters narrowly approved the accord, but only after a bruising campaign that not only revealed deep popular doubts over the treaty, but set off a wave of damaging speculation in currency markets across Europe.
The resulting turmoil, which drove the British pound and Italian lira out of the European monetary system, is still buffeting European parliaments and economies, and forcing Community leaders to rethink exactly what it is they want from European unity.
 
Seeking to Reassure Markets
 Indeed, the summit Friday had been called by Prime Minister John Major of Britain to reassure European markets and people that their leaders were still committed to the goal of greater political and economic unity, despite concern about whether separate national identities would be submerged in the process.
Much of the debate about where Europe goes next revolves around the application of what is called "subsidiarity," an arcane term of theological origin that is enshrined within the Maastricht treaty. Critics of federalism want to define the term to mean that actions should be considered in Brussels only when they cannot be taken by member states.
During discussions in the corridors in Birmingham, and at briefings with various national officials, the notion was often compared to the intent of the 10th Amendment to the United States Constitution, ratified as part of the Bill of Rights in 1791 and reserving to the states and the people those powers "not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States."
But while the idea is reassuring to those European states whose officials say they do not want their national identities swallowed up in a United States of Europe, the debate over the structure of a European union is far from over.
An aide to Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, said on Friday that authority can be reserved to the member nations only after they first join a federal system, and some nations, including Britain and Denmark, don't want to go that far in the first place.
"We are not in a federal system and subsidiarity can only be applied in a federal system," said an aide, quoting Mr. Delors.
 
A Political Problem
 During the meetings here, those kinds of questions -- as well as divisions within community ranks over liberalizing world trade -- were deferred. Instead, the European leaders concentrated on the more immediate political problem of restoring public confidence in the treaty among ordinary European citizens, and helping ease the path for ratification of it by Danish voters and the British Parliament.
Under terms of the treaty, it will not come into effect unless it is ratified by all 12 member states of the Community. So far, France, Ireland, Luxembourg and Greece have approved it.
The Danes say they are willing to put the treaty up for a second vote if they can be assured of not having to join a single European currency, one of the long-term goals of the treaty.
Mr. Major will put the treaty up for a vote in the House of Commons this fall, where he is facing a rebellion among members of his own Conservative Party.
On the one hand, Mr. Major emphasized the importance of the European Community to the British economy, noting that 60 percent of Britain's trade is within the community. He also praised the declaration passed in Birmingham as evidence that the community is moving to become more open and responsive to its citizens.
At the same time, Mr. Major did not hesitate on Friday to act without consulting or even informing his European partners, by cutting the British interest rate a full point, to 8 percent, in the face of mounting anger over his handling of the economy, including a decision earlier in the week to lay off 30,000 coal miners and close more than half of Britain's coal mines.

HEADLINE: U.S.-European Trade Gains Seen as Likely

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Ontario, Oct. 17

 BODY:
As trade representatives of the world's wealthiest economies met here, a European Community official said today that a breakthrough between the United States and Europe was possible in deadlocked world trade talks by November.
The community's External Affairs Commissioner, Frans Andriessen, said he saw signs that Washington and Brussels could soon overcome their impasse on agricultural subsidies. This issue is one of the main stumbling blocks in the six-year-old Uruguay round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 The community has offered to compensate American oilseed producers for their losses from its subsidies, but the United States insists that Europe has not offered enough.
Trade officials of the United States, the European Community, Canada and Japan are meeting here this weekend to discuss the differences between Washington and the community on access to their markets and the lowering of tariffs and import limitations.
At a meeting on Friday in Birmingham, England, community leaders said they had made progress on several key issues in the GATT talks. The four-way talks end on Sunday.

HEADLINE: Dodd Holds Lead in Polls In Connecticut

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 17

 BODY:
In the race for United States Senate, Connecticut voters are encountering a cozy, backyard version of a Bill Clinton-Ross Perot face-off: a quintessential public man, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, against an archetypal businessman, Brook Johnson.
Mr. Dodd, the Democrat, is leading by a large margin in polls as he seeks a third term in the Senate, where one of his predecessors was his father, Senator Thomas J. Dodd. But Mr. Johnson -- who followed his father into textile mills, working his way up to executive and finally owner -- is mounting an expensive attack, financed almost entirely by himself, that focuses on the Federal deficit and blames it on Washington insiders like Mr. Dodd. 
 As the campaign begins to expand from television screens, where both men are advertising heavily, onto the streets, Mr. Dodd, the career Connecticut politician, has several advantages over Mr. Johnson, a newcomer to politics who until May was registered to vote in Florida.
 
An Unabashed Politician
 Mr. Dodd, first of all, is an unabashed politician who, in public appearances, manages to convey both how seriously he takes his job and how much he enjoys the work, from his late-night lobbying for a favorite child-care bill to wading into crowds on the campaign trail.
He accepts the open-book nature of public life and uses self-deprecating humor to keep his work in perspective.
"When they run these polls and say 22 percent of the American public has confidence in Congress, what surprises me is not how low that is, it's how high it is," Mr. Dodd said Friday, discussing the corrosive effects of negative political campaigns as he rode to an Enfield mall, where he was speaking at Senior Day.
"Who are these people?" he asked with a laugh. "Have they been living on some planet and just arrived back on earth? Have they been living in a cave?"
 
A Tough Transition
 Mr. Johnson, in contrast, has found the transition from private business to public scrutiny a trial at times. At a news conference in Hartford, for example, he responded to one reporter's question by snapping, "Where did you go to college?"
Last month in Greenwich, where he lives, Mr. Johnson stopped and confronted a teen-age driver who, seeing a "Goodbye Senator Dodd" sticker on the candidate's BMW, honked his horn and made an obscene gesture.
But Mr. Dodd, in addition to making his personal case that politicians have a legitimate role in society, has used his experience in another way: he raised $3 million for the race, and had $1.4 million left to spend going into the last month.
Mr. Johnson, by comparison, had raised $190,000, while lending his campaign nearly $1.6 million of his own. He entered the last month with little cash, facing a decision on how much more to contribute himself.
Mr. Johnson's campaign, like Mr. Perot's, has been mainly an electronic one, as he has tried to make both his name and his views known in a short time. His television ads, which begin with the line, "Hi, I'm Brook Johnson," and feature him talking, have helped produce 85 percent name recognition across the state, according to his polls. But the ads, which have mainly attacked Mr. Dodd, have conveyed little more.
Addressing a group in Farmington this week, Mr. Johnson, who is 46 years old, sketched his life: "I'm from eastern Connecticut. I grew up in the little town of Willimantic. I worked my way through college. When I finished college with an engineering degree, I enlisted in the Army in 1968. I was a private at Fort Dix, N.J. I went to the London School of Economics on the G.I. Bill and then started with a resume at a Fortune 500 company, Collins & Aikman."
 
A Salesman's Skills
 Given his own forum, Mr. Johnson shines as a salesman. His typical stump speech is presented like a boardroom proposal at which listeners who accept one idea are then shown how it leads logically to others.
The Federal deficit, always his focus, is what moved him to enter politics. It was caused, he tells listeners, by both the culture of Washington, where he believes special interests have too much power, and by the fact that members of Congress are always running for re-election, and so always need those groups' contributions.
Imposing term limits on Congress and spending limits on campaigns, he says, would be a first step, though he concedes a spending cap would rule out his own $1.8 million campaign. He also favors cutting the capital-gains tax to stimulate the economy, and eliminating the deficit by putting caps on the rate of growth in Federal spending.
"He sounds like Ross Perot," said Morris Mirizio, a Bristol resident who heard Mr. Johnson speak at St. Joseph's Church in Bristol this week.
But as an unknown with no public record to measure his words against, Mr. Johnson is discovering how fragile his electronically built image may be.
While he has accused Mr. Dodd of standing by while Connecticut lost 190,000 jobs to the recession, he was put on the defensive this week when Mr. Dodd challenged his own record of creating jobs, pointing out in an ad that the Republican's vaunted manufacturing base was all in Canada.
One questioner at St. Joseph's thought the Dodd ad was, in fact, Mr. Johnson's. "You moved a plant to Canada?" he asked.
"No," Mr. Johnson tried to answer.
"Your father moved the plant?" the man pressed.
"No, my father worked at a plant in Willimantic," he responded.
Mr. Johnson, who rose from salesman to group president at Collins & Aikman before buying his own company, finally said he never moved any factories. What he had done, he said, was sell a United States operation and buy an existing Canadian company.
The Dodd ad, he told an audience in Farmington, is "not true." But, he added, "it's not untrue."
"What they do," he said, "is distort the truth."
 
No Apologies
 Mr. Dodd, 48, makes no apologies for his counterattack, as he makes few apologies for his 18 years in Congress: three terms in the House representing eastern Connecticut and two terms in the Senate.
Mr. Dodd also notes that most of his commercials have stressed his own accomplishments, especially in saving a Seawolf submarine contract for the endangered Electric Boat shipyard, enacting a child-care subsidy program, and helping to broaden eligibility for Federal aid for middle-income college students.
Only months ago, hopeful Republicans were hungrily circling Mr. Dodd, saying Connecticut voters were starting to decide that he had not been much help as the state sank into recession. They also hoped that anger over the state's new income tax would wash over the incumbent.
But then Mr. Dodd played a significant role in saving the Seawolf contract. Audiences now listen closely as he warns that the Seawolf will not save Electric Boat, only give it and government time to find some other use for the sub yard and its sophisticated technology.
As he details the efforts he has made to help Connecticut industries become less dependent on military contracts, and handicaps the impending assault on military spending in the next Federal budget, a clear message emerges: this is a Senator who already knows his way around.
Mr. Dodd is also keenly aware of the deep gloom of many Connecticut residents, who have seen their state's quality of life chipped away by recession, layoffs and a sharp drop in housing values.
That feeling, however, may be more likely to hurt the White House than Democratic incumbents like Mr. Dodd. At his appearance in Enfield, one group of shoppers was divided over the Senator, but nearly unanimous in rejecting President Bush. The economy was their chief concern.
"It's scary," said Donna Blanchette of Suffield. "People are living thinking they are going to lose their jobs. There's no security anymore."
So as Mr. Dodd travels the state, emerging crisply at each stop from a Ford Explorer, he displays his experience while delivering a mix of economic realism, pep talk and social idealism. Connecticut has a proud history, he says. These are challenging times. We have to be smart. We have to work together, rich and poor, young and old, city and suburb.
Three debates have been scheduled between Mr. Dodd and Mr. Johnson, the first at 7 P.M. Tuesday, to be broadcast on Connecticut television stations.

HEADLINE: False Charges By Woman Culminate In Her Arrest

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
A homeless woman who had accused 13 men of rape, robbery and larceny over the last six years was arrested yesterday and charged with making up the crimes, the transit police said.
One of the accused men received a 90-day jail term, the transit police said. 
 The woman, Deborah Ford, 36 years old, was charged with 21 counts of falsely filing criminal complaints in incidents, including three in the subway, that date back to Sept. 25, 1986, said a transit police spokesman, Albert W. O'Leary. It was the second case of false allegations of subway crimes in two weeks, he said.
The transit police determined that Ms. Ford was lying Friday afternoon after she told an officer, who was standing outside the subway station at Christopher Street in lower Manhattan, that a man had raped her, Mr. O'Leary said. The man was promptly taken into custody.
"But during questioning, it became apparent that something was not right and she admitted that the crime report was in fact bogus," Mr. O'Leary said. "She even admitted that she had made many of these types of claims in the past."
The suspect was released. Ms. Ford was in custody Saturday night pending her arraignment on the charge. Mr. O'Leary said a man arrested Oct. 4 on a complaint from Ms. Ford remained in jail, although the transit police were moving to get him released.
 
Move Towards Release
 "One good thing about our criminal justice system is that as soon as information is received that a person does not belong in jail, we get them out," Mr. O'Leary said. Another man was in jail until yesterday on a robbery charge, when he was released.
In the worst case, one man with a lengthy criminal history received a 90-day jail term after pleading guilty to a bogus robbery charge, Mr. O'Leary said.
"This guy's a career criminal and has become very savvy about what helps him," Mr. O'Leary said. "That may be the reason he agreed to plead guilty. It's unclear."
It was not known yesterday whether the man was still in jail.
In a similar case, the transit police two weeks ago arrested a man for filing false complaints against 26 men who, the police said, accused young men of robbing him when they did not return his sexual advances.
The transit police said 10 young men were wrongly jailed based on the complaints of James Cooley, 25, an unemployed freight handler. Mr. O'Leary said a system of checking past complaints started after the Cooley case and led officers to look into whether Ms. Ford had a history of making complaints.
"Bringing false arrest accusations against someone is a crime," Mr. O'Leary said. "It's got to be; otherwise we'd have people running all over the place pointing out people and having them arrested."

HEADLINE: Unemployment Before Employment;
Frustrated, New York Teen-Agers Look for Their First Jobs

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
On Columbus Day, Dolayna DeArmond wistfully thought of the fun things she might do with a day off from school: going to the movies, shopping, hanging out with her girlfriends in Crown Heights. Instead, the 15-year-old did what she has done for the last two years without much success: looked for a job to help her single mother put food on the table and money in the bank for college.
Ms. DeArmond, a sophomore at Harry Van Arsdale High School, is one of thousands of New York City teen-agers whose hopes of joining the working world are running up against Depression-era employment rates. 
 Although the Los Angeles riots inspired additional Federal aid to cities that translated into 22,000 more summer jobs in New York City -- 52,000 compared to 30,000 last year -- the current employment landscape is as barren as autumnal trees.
Teen-age employment in the city has fallen almost in half over the last two years, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, and youths between 16 and 19 years old here work at one-third the rate of their peers nationwide: about 12 percent have full-time or part-time jobs, compared with 39 percent nationally.
 
Frustration Mounts
 Employment of teen-agers in the city has been decreasing. The rate last year was 16.9 percent; it was 20.5 percent in 1990.
People who work with youth say the overwhelming majority would like at least some work. Many of the frustrated young job seekers are still in school but need part-time work to help support their families. And the issue is even more pressing for those who have graduated or dropped out of high school and try to support themselves.
The dismal employment picture means more violence among young people with time on their hands, dozens of young people and youth workers said in recent interviews; it means fewer teen-agers who develop work mores like dressing appropriately and being punctual; it means children who turn to crime to make money and develop a general feeling of isolation from the mainstream world.
"These young people being idle out here is manifested in the youth violence," said Richard Green, head of the Crown Heights Youth Collective, which offers a range of services to youth in that Brooklyn neighborhood. "You know the story ---- if he's out there on the corner and can't get a j-o-b, someone says 'come spot me for $50 a day' and they do," he said, referring to young people who work as lookouts for drug dealers.
"I had a young man come in today -- new car, more gold in his mouth than any six of us on our fingers," Mr. Green said. "He said he wants to get out of it," meaning the drug trade. " 'I want one of them j-bobscq, slang for job,' he said. The path they're on right now is not the path they want to be on."
The lack of job prospects fuels a palpable anger and bitterness among teen-agers in struggling, minority neighborhoods like East Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant and the South Bronx. In interviews, many said they felt disconnected from the traditional societal paths to success: school and work. They also said they felt they were blamed for their failures even though they received little guidance. And many believe they are victims of racism.
Last year, only 10.6 percent of black and 14.6 percent of Hispanic New Yorkers between the ages of 16 and 19 had jobs. Almost 19.7 percent of white youths did.
 
'An Education for Nothing'
 "We go to school and get an education for nothing, for nothing," said Wilhemenia Johnson, 16, a 10tenth grader who lives in East Harlem. "They don't want us to be educated, they don't want us to compete with them for jobs," she said, referring to white people.
James Bellamy Jr., 19, a history major at City College who said he has been looking for work at messenger services and fast-food franchises, said, "You have to talk proper and be proper to find a job, but I want to be who I am."
Mr. Bellamy, 19, said he must change his mode of dress and the way he carries himself when he approaches potential white employers, who, he said, view most young black men as threatening.
"It's almost as if they want me to be white," Mr. Bellamy said. "Maybe a person can't carry themselves in a proper way, but it doesn't mean they don't have the skills."
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said low employment rates in the teen-age years were correlated with low employment rates later in life. He said New York had historically offered its teen-agers fewer chances at jobs than other big cities like Chicago and Washington, even during relative prosperity.
"They need jobs more than anybody else," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "There are many youngsters in the city who don't see school as relating to their lives, which affects the school retention rate. Many are in families where they don't see anybody working or it's not a job that has anything to do with school experience."
 
Competition for Beginners
 The structural reasons for low teenage employment in New York have been well-documented. The economic downturn engulfing the nation hit the Northeast earlier and harder, drying up retail and entry-level computer and telecommunications jobs, in addition to the loss of 65 percent of manufacturing jobs since 1966.
New York has more immigrants -- legal and illegal -- willing to work in low-paying jobs. More jobs have moved to suburban communities and away from the inner-city youth who need them. And teen-agers here must also compete with a large arts community that relies on part-time employment to get them through the dry spells between employment.
"A lot of people are looking for work," said Ms. DeArmond, whose only job experience has been working with her mother, a building superintendent, and a two-week stint at a day-care center in Minnesota. She has concentrated her search in Crown Heights, relying on word-of-mouth, classified advertising and signs in windows.
"The places I go, they said they'd get back to me or sometimes they'd say the job was filled. It's hard, pretty much. People need to give you a chance."
Despite lingering stereotypes that poor, minority youngsters do not wish to work or that their money goes to gold jewelry and designer clothes, people who work with them said the reality was grimmer. Many of the youngsters are indeed naive about how to look for work -- some come from families where no one has ever had a job -- but they desire employment and in some cases turn down offers to join the drug economy, youth workers say.
Some are high school dropouts who are the sole support for families that may include their own children, and they have few prospects beyond entry-level jobs.
 
'Real Survival Money'
 "You take the high drop-out rate and combine it with unemployment and the situation is disastrous," said Josephine Nieves, Commissioner of the New York City Department of Employment. "We are not in any way taking responsibility for our youth. They are being lost."
The Commissioner said her office was working on a youth-employment plan that would include partnerships between labor unions, city schools, the private sector and various industries. She said she could not give a cost for the program, because it involved making better use of resources rather than an infusion of new money.
People like Geoffrey Canada, the executive director of the Rheedlen Foundation, which serves 500 children in Manhattan each day in education, recreation and social- services programs, said the cost of doing nothing would be much higher.
"Part of the solution is we have to give young people jobs at 14 or 15," he said. "It's not that expensive, especially when you see the other costs society end up paying in juvenile courts and probation officers. This is real survival money for these kids ---- it's frightening. You begin to see a certain hunger in these children's eyes over the years. "
Mr. Canada said that a significant number of poor young people lagged in employable skills, a problem worsened by their lack of social skills. They may dress inappropriately for a business environment and fail to make eye contact during an interview, he said. Because so many have fragile self-esteem, he said, they may perceive curt directives from a boss as a challenge to their dignity or evidence of racism.
Indeed, a survey last year of 300 businesses in the city by Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, found that 37 percent of the employers said that the performance of entry-level employee in New York, of all ages, was worse than elsewhere.
 
'Any Job Is a Good Job'
 Bobyecq List, the executive director of the New York City Partnership, a business group that sponsors the city's largest program to match teenagers with summer jobs, said that in other cities, the business community and the schools work together more closely.
There are exceptions, of course. Companies like New York Telephone, Con Edison and Brookyn Union Gas have successfully hired large numbers of teenagers in entry-level jobs. About 30 percent of the Partnership's summer jobs continue as part-time jobs the rest of the year. The Philip Morris Company has underwritten 100 young people in jobs in nonprofit organizations.
"Three or four years ago you had young people with unrealistic expectations, but not anymore," Mrs. List said. "In this economy, any job is a good job. What happens is that a number of young people never get in the mainstream of referral to get connected. A number of young people have never been out of their borough. A number have never been out of their little neighborhood."
Still, away from the office towers and the community centers where their lives are being discussed, young people said that they felt that city and national leaders have abandoned them or they would have long ago instituted the kind of job programs that Ms. Nieves envisions.
"Me and my friends drive around to Wall Street and we go into places where there are signs up saying 'Help Wanted' and we go in and they say 'It's already been filled," said Kevin Frye, who is 15 and lives in Harlem. "They ask, 'Why do you want to work?' I tell them there isn't anything else to do in the streets except get in trouble."

HEADLINE: Sharp Clashes as D'Amato And Abrams Debate Issues

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In the second debate of their Senate campaign, State Attorney General Robert Abrams and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato collided forcefully last night, stressing their sharp differences on nearly a dozen issues from abortion to the economy, health care, education and the tone and tactics of their own campaigns.
Locked in a tight race, both candidates made strong appeals to the political middle ground, each painting the other as an extremist out of step with the concerns of New Yorkers, and each striving repeatedly to wrap himself in the mantle of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who holds a big lead over President Bush in the state, according to all the polls. 
 In the hourlong debate, broadcast from the studios of WRGB-TV in Schenectady and carried live around the state on C-Span, Mr. D'Amato, the two-term Republican incumbent, mentioned the President only in the final moments, and only to remind listeners that he had criticized Mr. Bush's economic policies and advisers "before it became popular."
In an especially pointed dig, Mr. D'Amato noted that Mr. Abrams -- during his own Democratic primary campaign -- had criticized as inadequate the plans for cutting military spending and creating a national health insurance system that Mr. Clinton supports. "Bob Abrams is way outside the mainstream of the Democratic Party," he said.
 
Clinton Statement Cited
 For his part, Mr. Abrams said over and over, "I'm proud to be on the same ticket with Bill Clinton and Al Gore." And he sought to link Mr. D'Amato to the 12 years of Republican economic policies in Washington that he said had cost New York jobs and billions of dollars in vital aid. He read from a statement that Mr. Clinton issued yesterday, condemning Mr. D'Amato's attempts "to link himself to me or my campaign."
Responding to the first question, about jobs and taxes, Mr. D'Amato wasted no time in bringing up Mr. Abrams's description of him last weekend as a "fascist" -- a comment for which Mr. Abrams later apologized. Several times during the debate, he responded to criticism from Mr. Abrams by saying "Well, there goes Bob Abrams again."
But most of the time was spent in a sober discussion of the issues, in which Mr. Abrams, typically earnest, and Mr. D'Amato, unusually low-key and almost mournful at times, made it clear just how much they differ on topics from the death penalty (Mr. Abrams opposes it in all cases) to tuition tax credits for private schools (Mr. D'Amato said it would prompt competition and improve education, while Mr. Abrams said it would "destroy one of the bulwarks" of the nation, its public schools).
Though the candidates differed markedly, they often looked startlingly alike as the camera shifted between the two, balding and bespectacled, in dark suits and red ties, standing behind lecterns as they answered questions posed by Alan Chartock, a public radio commentator.
 
Softer Tone on Gay Rights
 On some of the sharper-edged issues, Mr. D'Amato took a distinctly conciliatory tone. For example, in answering a question about gay rights and how to stem violence and discrimination against homosexuals, Mr. Abrams stressed his own longtime support for extending civil rights laws to gay people. Mr. D'Amato said the Federal Government needed to "do more" to protect people whatever their "predilections," but without specifying how.
Throughout the debate, Mr. Abrams repeatedly sought, as he has since the morning after his primary victory on Sept. 15, to portray the election in terms of sharp policy differences between himself and Mr. D'Amato. "This campaign is very stark in terms of the choices," he said, "on choice, on the economy, on health care, on the environment."
At another point, he suggested that Senator D'Amato was stuck in the past with a cold-war view of military spending while his own vision would provide for a major conversion of military industries to other purposes.
But Senator D'Amato appeared less inclined to paint such clear differences on some other issues: in fact, he continued a theme he established last week. On several issues, he contended his views were closer to Mr. Clinton's than were Mr. Abrams's.
 
Death-Penalty Debate
 He noted that he and Mr. Clinton favor the death penalty for certain drug dealers, while Mr. Abrams opposes it under any circumstances.
On abortion, the two men offered clear differences. "I'm pro-life," Senator D'Amato said. "Everybody knows that. It's a matter of conscience."
But he sought to soften the differences between himself and abortion-rights advocates. For instance, he said he now believed in allowing abortion in cases of rape or incest -- contrary to stands he took in the past -- and said he had opposed the gag rule that prevents clinics that offered counseling on abortion from receiving Federal funds.
And he said that he believed that most people would would agree with his position in favor of parental consent laws that require minors to get their parents' permission before an abortion.
 
Favorings Choice, No Buts
 Mr. Abrams, though, was unequivocal, saying that abortion was a choice that should be made "by a woman and a woman alone."
"Senator D'Amato is the candidate of the extremist Right to Life Party" Mr. Abrams said. "This is a clear difference between the two of us."
Asked about the mud-slinging that has marked the campaign in recent weeks -- some national political consultants have described the race as the nastiest Senate contest in the nation -- each candidate seemed to denounce negative campaigning while simultaneously getting in a few licks at his rival.
Mr. Abrams repeated his apology for calling Mr. D'Amato a fascist, and called it "an unfortunate expression," but also added that he had hoped that his apology would cause his opponent to pull his "distorted commercials," and focus on issues like abortion and the economy. "I resent the kind of character assassination that has taken place," he said.
 
A List of Allegations
 And then Mr. Abrams rattled off a list of allegations against the Senator: the Senate Ethics Committee report saying he had run his office in an inappropriate manner that allowed his brother, Armand, to use it to lobby for a military contractor, and a new investigation into charges that Mr. D'Amato had coached a witness in a grand jury proceeding. "These are serious issues that I think have to be evaluated by the people of this state."
Mr. D'Amato responded that his opponent was "wallowing in the mud, wallowing in the gutter."
And in his closing statement, Senator D'Amato once more asserted that his opponent was running a vicious campaign against him and had done "the same thing to Geraldine," referring to Geraldine A. Ferraro, a candidate in the Democratic Senate primary. He also clearly sought, again, to disassociate himself from the Republican Administration in Washington.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Democrats' Hopes Rise, Republicans' Grow Heavy

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Three-fourths of the way through the debates that were supposed to begin President Bush's final rally, Democrats can barely contain their euphoria. And Republicans, ever more anxious, remain clinging to the hope of a major break in the final two weeks, and the hope that their President can seize it.
Gov. Bill Clinton has begun warning against complacency, the ritualistic closing appeal of a front-runner. But his travel schedule indicates the extent of his campaign's aspirations these days. Among the states the Democratic nominee is expected to visit after the next debate on Monday night are historically Republican strongholds like Nevada and Wyoming, which his aides present as part of a game plan to keep the Republicans pinned down and on the defensive to the very end.
 
Favorable Signs
 "These are states that we think we have a legitimate shot of winning," said David Wilhelm, manager for the Clinton campaign. "At this point in the campaign you're not trying to fake somebody out." 
 The electoral map, in fact, looks remarkably favorable to the Democrats in this final stage of the campaign, with Mr. Clinton dominating California and the Northeast, holding clear leads across most of the industrial Midwest and being in a competitive position across much of the South, a variety of polls have indicated.
"Look at the map, and you see that Republicans are scratching and clawing to stay even in those states where they should be up by 10 or 20 points," said Stuart Rothenberg, a Washington analyst who publishes a political newsletter. "This is a national trend. It's showing up in New Hampshire and California and Ohio."
 
Polls Add to Fears
 Bush campaign officials contend that the Democrats are overreaching, that two weeks is still sufficient time to close this race and that their attacks on Mr. Clinton's trustworthiness are beginning to pay off. Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, asserts that the campaign's own polling shows Mr. Clinton's negative ratings are rising and that the race is tightening.
Mary Matalin, deputy manager of the Bush campaign, asserted that Mr. Bush was also gaining ground in individual states and added: "The Clintonistas are a little full of themselves right now. It ain't over till it's over."
Still, a national Newsweek poll released today, conducted after the second Presidential debate on Thursday night, showed Mr. Clinton retaining the lead with the support of 46 percent, Mr. Bush with 31 percent, and independent candidate Ross Perot at 14 percent. The margin of error for the poll was four percentage points. All that makes Republicans' hopes and fears for Monday night's final debate all the more acute.
An Administration official, who would speak only if not named, said on Friday that the campaign continued to believe that the trust issue was Mr. Clinton's fatal flaw. "The only thing we can do and will do for the next 18 days is continue to say here's what you need to know about this guy, here's what you need to know about his policies, and do you really want him to lead you for the next four years," the official said.
But many Republicans closed out this week in a grim mood. They had hoped for a turning point in the first two Presidential debates, but so far the polls do not reflect one. "Right now I'd say the race is basically a flat line on the screen," said Linda DiVall, a Republican poll taker, who hastened to add that there was still time to turn it around.
 
Gloom and Jitters
 Adding to the gloominess of some Republicans is the view, widely held by pundits and political professionals, that the President was not meeting the needs of the moment in the debates, occasionally seemed off his game and was not behaving with the aggressiveness his supporters yearned for. His aides assert that the format of the Thursday night debate, which began with voters urging the candidates to stick to the issues, simply did not lend itself to drawing a stark contrast with Mr. Clinton.
Underscoring the stakes of these final days, Ms. Matalin today assailed the unnamed people complaining to newspaper reporters that the President did not seem committed to be running flat out. "The people who are anonymously appearing in these stories are the lowest form of life," Ms. Matalin said. "He has never, never in my presence shown any signs of backing down or resignation. He remains confident and serene."
But the anxiety is high among Republicans who are focused on races below the Presidential level and includes the fear that Mr. Bush will be written off in the final days of the campaign. "If there is a sense out there on or around Nov. 3 that George Bush can't win, I really worry about what can happen to us on turnout," said Eddie Mahe, a veteran Republican political consultant. "We all lived through '74. Republicans didn't vote in '74. Republicans don't switch, they stay home."
The Democrats are an emotional mirror image of the Republicans this weekend, reveling in the polls in delight that the debates seem to have left Mr. Clinton's status as the front-runner intact, but almost superstitiously fearing to look ahead two weeks. "It certainly looks very good right now," said Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "But anyone who knows Bill Clinton, knows he does not have a complacent bone in his body."
 
Confidence and Caution
 Phil Angelides, the chairman of the California Democratic Party, said, "We're ahead, but having lost so many times, with 18 days to go, what's the sense of imbuing ourselves with temporary euphoria and risk another dismal four years?"
Still, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, was one of several Democrats who voiced the belief that Mr. Clinton may have begun to "close the sale" with the voters this week. "I think he really broke through with a lot of people who were leaning in his direction but weren't quite there yet."
Mr. Clinton himself, who is expected in these final days to try to elevate his message and present a Democratic vote as a mandate for a set of economic policies, warned today that talk of a landslide is premature. "There is no need for overconfidence," he said as he left Little Rock today. "This is not a race just to beat my opponent. This is a race to shape the future of the country. It's not about landslides. It's about what's going to happen to the American people."
Adding to the remaining uncertainty is Ross Perot, the independent candidate who enjoyed a bump in public esteem after his performance in the debates this week. Some Republican strategists say that if Mr. Perot's supporters defect in the final days, as many supporters of third party candidates often do, it could be a boost for Mr. Bush.
Republicans also comfort themselves with the notion this has been an unpredictable year and this Presidential campaign has transformed itself very quickly before.
